column2: Kim Clijsters continued her remarkable return from a two-year layoff on Sunday when she defeated Venus Williams, 6-0, 0-6, 6-4, to reach the quarterfinals of the United States Open.

Andrea Carla Michaels is mostly known for her witty early-week crosswords. Ashish Vengsarkar is famous for his later-week brain twisters. We have their first collaboration today and it combines the best of both. The impressive grid manages to fit seven theme answers in a standard 15-by-15 size while still maintaining an amusing, breezy style.
Serena Williams routed Daniela Hantuchova and Rafael Nadal won in straight sets against Nicolas Almagro, despite a strained abdominal muscle.

As one part of a renewed effort to search for Americans who went missing in World War II, a United States military team searched a cow pasture in Bauler, Germany, where an American bomber was shot down in 1944.

Back in 2003, which is akin to half a lifetime ago in tennis years, Juan Carlos Ferrero won French Open and was runner-up at the United States Open. He claimed the No. 1 and won Spain's "National Sportsman of the Year" award.
Five years after a near-death experience, Lego has emerged as an unlikely winner.
A microcosm of the borough, a highly international mall gears up for back-to-school shopping.

The New England Patriots' trade of defensive lineman Richard Seymour to the Oakland Raiders on Sunday in exchange for a first-round draft pick in 2011 indicates several things about how the Patriots view the N.F.L.

The match of the day between Venus Williams and Kim Clijsters begins shortly. Williams won the Open in 2000 and 2001, while Clijsters prevailed in 2005. A round of 16 matchup like this is rare indeed.

STILLWATER, Okla. - The post-Matthew Stafford era at Georgia got off to a rough start Saturday. The fifth-year senior quarterback Joe Cox, the successor to Stafford, the first pick of April's N.F.L. draft, struggled mightily in the Bulldogs' 24-10 loss here to Oklahoma State. Battling what was described as flu-like symptoms and making just his second career start, Cox was 15 of 30 passing for 162 yards with a touchdown and an interception.

An American teenager, Tennys Sandgren of Gallatin, Tenn., defeated Daniel Berta of Sweden, the French Open junior champion, 4-6, 6-3, 7-6 (5) in the first round of the United States Open junior championships.
KANSAS CITY, Mo. - Booze and pornography are already off limits. Smoking is being actively discouraged. What might be next on the military's list of forbidden vices for deployed troops?

On the subject of the Women's Tennis Association world rankings, Serena Williams and Dinara Safina could not disagree more. Safina, who is the world No. 1 despite never having won a Grand Slam title, is fine with consistency and constancy being rewarded. Williams, ranked No. 2 despite winning this year's Australian Open and Wimbledon titles, is of the opinion that one's record in the majors should weigh heavily in the rankings.
Sloane Stephens advanced to the second round in the United States Open juniors competition, but her 6-4, 6-2 win Sunday against Polina Leykina of Russia was hardly routine.

ATLANTA -- It must have been a little unsettling to Alabama fans to see their new quarterback, Greg McElroy, try an awkward-looking jump pass and have the ball batted down by a Virginia Tech defender.

PITTSBURGH - Ross Ohlendorf has had a breakthrough season for the Pittsburgh Pirates, going 11-9 with a 3.97 E.R.A. for a last-place team. But he is also Princeton graduate with an off-season ranching business and a relentlessly curious mind. So when Tom Vilsack, the United States Secretary of Agriculture, threw out the first pitch at PNC Park this season, Ohlendorf offered to catch for him.

As many wait to see what Joseph P. Kennedy II may decide about running for the Senate seat long held by his uncle, Edward M. Kennedy, The Boston Globe examines the political implications of Joe Kennedy's work with Citgo and its ties to Hugo Chávez, the Venezuelan president.

With President Obama planning to address Congress on Wednesday about his plans for overhauling the health care system, his commitment to a new government program for the nation's uninsured still seems unclear.

Alliteration is inevitable. This was not a Super Saturday, a term reserved for those years when the women's singles championship was sandwiched between the men's semifinals, and that day session often crept into night.

Great white sharks, one of the ocean's greatly depleted predatory species, tend to cause a stir any time they show up near populated places, and that was certainly the case on eastern Cape Cod this weekend. Marine biologists for the state of Massachusetts, working with a commercial fisherman who is a talented swordfish harpooner, tagged two of several 8- to 10-foot great white sharks spotted in waters off the eastern shore of the Cape. Previously, only one great white shark had been successfully tagged in the Atlantic Ocean. The photo above was taken by Gregory Skomal of the state Division of Marine Fisheries, who has become the go-to shark specialist in the region.

Monologue | Aired Friday night on NBC: Next Tuesday -- a lot of people talking about this -- President Obama plans to make a televised speech to the nation's students during school hours. Many Republicans are planning to keep their kids home from school in protest. As a result, those kids have voted Obama "Best President Ever."
Monologue | Aired Friday night on CBS: Hey, you know who's coming to town next month? Have any idea? Dictator of Libya, Muammar Qaddafi. Thank you, travelocity.com.

Monologue | Aired Friday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: It's a great day for President Barack Obama. He's getting ready for a speech he's giving to schoolchildren tomorrow. And he said he wants the speech to be at third grade level, so he tested it on Joe Biden.
Monologue | Aired Friday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Labor Day is Monday. Labor Day, of course, is the day that we set aside to remember when people used to have jobs.
Monologue | Aired Friday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: I want to say happy Labor Day weekend. I hope you have a job to be off from on Monday.

In documents filed with U.S. Bankruptcy Court judge Redfield T. Baum, the N.H.L. finally sets a fee for the relocation of franchises: $101 million to $195 million. Those are the figures two N.H.L.-hired consulting firms recommend, as the league at last puts a hard dollar number on the relocation fees called for in its bylaws.

Stephanie Liss and Marc Otten tell about how they met in August of 2005 after Ms. Liss decided to not to make it an early early night, and attended a birthday party with her brother at an East Village bar.

On the eve of Labor Day, an Obama administration official is out of a job. Van Jones, the president's green jobs "czar," resigned on Saturday amid a furor over various associations and comments he made in the past.

Can the magic continue for Taylor Dent? A tall order given his opponent, Andy Murray, the world No. 2 and last year's runner up. At 22, Murray has improved every year since turning pro in 2005. Many believe this is the year he breaks through and wins his first Major. Murray's game is built around solid ground strokes and speed. Murray, a guest blogger for T Magazine's The Moment, covers more court than just about any player on tour, and his backhand is the best in the game.

The United States Open Junior Championships begin Sunday, and if you're interested in glimpsing the next Melanie Oudin, who reached the girls singles semifinals at last year's United States Open, head to the outer courts.

LONDON | The name of the art venue called SPACE has a literal meaning: this converted technological college in the depths of Hackney, East London -- reminiscent of PS1 in New York -- houses two exhibition rooms, an extra outdoor space and 600 studios.
Mike Tanier of FootballOutsiders.com is a co-author of "Football Outsiders Almanac 2009" and a contributor to The Fifth Down.
A brief review of the novel “Lime Tree Can’t Bear Orange” on Page 15 this weekend misspells the author’s surname at one point. She is Amanda Smyth, not Smith.

Because of an editing error, an article on Page 36 this weekend about the failure of economists to anticipate the latest recession misquotes the economist John Maynard Keynes, who compared the financial markets of the 1930s to newspaper beauty contests in which readers tried to correctly pick all six eventual winners. Keynes noted that a competitor did not have to pick “those faces which he himself finds prettiest, but those that he thinks likeliest to catch the fancy of the other competitors.” He did not say, “nor even those that he thinks likeliest to catch the fancy of other competitors.”.

Now that injuries to Michael Young and Josh Hamilton have thrown cold water on the Rangers' pursuit of the Angels in the A.L. West and Boston for the wild card, the only race in baseball with any excitement is the Colorado-San Francisco battle for the National League wild card. That leaves plenty of time to check out the September call-ups around the majors.
Suzann Pettersen of Norway shot a five-under-par 66 to extend her lead to five strokes after three rounds of the Canadian Women’s Open.
Gigi Marvin set up all three of Meghan Duggan’s goals to lead the United States into the championship game of the Hockey Canada Cup with a 4-0 victory over Finland.
Nino Schurter of Switzerland defeated the Olympic champion Julien Absalon of France by three seconds in a sprint finish at the cross-country race in the world mountain bike championships.
Fabian Cancellara of Switzerland won a rainy individual time trial Saturday to retake the overall lead at the Vuelta a España.
Peyton Manning and his wife, Ashley, will give $1 million to Tennessee for a new athletic training facility.
Martin Truex Jr. won his first pole at Atlanta Motor Speedway, qualifying first for Sunday night’s Pep Boys Auto 500 with a lap of 184.149 miles per hour.
The Red Sox might have their own 2009 version of the Nasty Boys. Now if they can just keep that nastiness pointed at the opponents.
The Pirates have got to be sick of Milwaukee.
What is Kansas City's Zack Greinke going to have to do to win the American League Cy Young Award?

The hand-wringing over the future of American tennis has eased somewhat, mainly because of the tenacity and heart of Melanie Oudin. Playing Maria Sharapova in Arthur Ashe Stadium, the 17-year-old Oudin of Marietta, Ga., gave no quarter to the heavily favored Sharapova, the 6-foot-2 media darling whose outfits are discussed as much as her serve.

In a victory for Republicans and the Obama administration's conservative critics, Van Jones resigned as the White House's environmental jobs "czar" on Saturday. Controversy over Mr. Jones's past comments and affiliations had slowly escalated over several weeks, erupting on Friday with calls for his resignation. Read more...

Though its approach to overhauling health care is different than that of its predecessors, the Obama administration hasn't been able to avoid all of the political and public relations problems that earlier health care efforts confronted.
The United States kept moving methodically toward the World Cup in South Africa, but Argentina's path took a turn for the worse with a 3-1 loss to Brazil in Rosario on Saturday night.
Roger Federer didn't get his wish. He had said he was hoping to play James Blake in the fourth round because of how much excitement he brings with him when he plays at the Open.

Tommy Robredo defeated James Blake in straight sets in Arthur Ashe Stadium, a match that ended at 1 a.m. Eastern and brought an anticlimactic end to a dramatic Saturday on the U.S. Open's show court. The match took only 2 hours 19 minutes, which on this day (and night) was a blink of an eye.
In a match that will further stoke criticism of the WTA ranking system, No.1-ranked Darina Safina lost to the 72nd-ranked woman in the world, Petra Kvitova.
Van Jones, the White House’s environmental jobs “czar,” had come under scrutiny from Republicans and conservative critics for his past comments and affiliations.
This is just a quick Labor Day weekend look back at a story I wrote in 2005 assessing Bhutan's effort to adopt gross national happiness as its main
It's likely that the state of Oklahoma is in full meltdown mode right now, as Saturday's surprising results could portend a shift in the balance of power in the state.
No. 5 Alabama outgained No. 7 Virginia Tech in total yards, 498 to 155, and finally slammed the door in the fourth quarter to win the Chick-fil-A Kickoff Game.
STILLWATER, Okla.- Oklahoma State Coach Mike Gundy was concerned Saturday about the coaching technique of his first-year defensive coordinator, Bill Young.

The Walt Disney Family Museum, which opens on Oct. 1, proves to be something of a high-tech wonderland.

The manufacturer plans to sell 1,200 pairs this season at $1,295 a pair — the most expensive boot on the market.
Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
On a day of World Cup qualifying matches around the world, Portugal and France hurt their chances with disappointing ties.
For all its struggles to reach the elite ranks of international competition, the United States soccer team has been able to rely on success against El Salvador.
A committee on the island is looking at options including trimming brush in backyards and installing feeders that coat deer with insecticide. Most controversial is whether to allow more deer hunting.
The 36 Hours column on Aug. 23, about Oslo, misspelled the given name of the artist who painted “The Scream,” at the National Gallery. He is Edvard Munch, not Edward.
Zach Frazer threw for 127 yards and 2 touchdowns to help Connecticut improve to 15-1 against teams from the Mid-American Conference.
With the Heisman Trophy winner Sam Bradford helplessly watching on the sideline, his right arm in a sling, No. 20 Brigham Young upset No. 3 Oklahoma, 14-13.
Two others were wounded in the shooting that killed Shante Graham, who had been shot and wounded at the same location in the spring, a family member said.
The 36 Hours column on Aug. 23, about Oslo, misspelled the given name of the artist who painted “The Scream,” at the National Gallery. He is Edvard Munch, not Edward.
On a perfect day for golf, a Nascar race broke out in the playoffs for the FedEx Cup on Saturday.
A leader of the Juárez Cartel is accused in the shooting deaths of 17 patients at a clinic in northern Mexico.
Firefighters’ efforts are being helped by cooler temperatures and higher humidity in the Angeles National Forest.
Read the authors who are difficult and demand rereading because that effort doubles their value.
Don’t settle for anything less than falling in love with your intellectual vision of the future.
To be a successful college student, cut through the clutter of jargon, methods and ideological differences and locate the common practices of argument and analysis hidden behind it all.
Have passion for what you are learning.
Think about the whole of your life, not just your job.
Dr. Rosen was one of two young physicists at Los Alamos, N.M., who devised a way to confirm that thermonuclear fusion had occurred in a hydrogen bomb test.
Make sure you are in the right class, for starters.
College is never what one expects.
Read a good newspaper, it will be your path to the world at large.
Long Island arts listings.
Two radio station towers near Seattle that have generated intense local opposition were toppled in an act of sabotage that appeared to be linked to the radical Earth Liberation Front.
The most severe drought in the nation is drying up the spring-fed Barton Creek Pool, where more than 400,000 visitors from around the world flock each year.
Rachel Alexandra showed a new dimension in the Woodward Stakes, proving she was not just the best horse in the field but also the toughest.
A residential treatment center in Fall City, Wash., offers a 45-day program intended to help people wean themselves from pathological computer use.
A former Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent who had been stationed in Mexico was arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to smuggle cocaine into the United States.
A former Alabama state trooper was indicted in May 2007 in the death of Jimmie Lee Jackson 44 years ago, but a trial date has been delayed by feuding between the prosecutor and the judge.
So far, the cases at the university have been mild, stemming from a late-August outbreak.

A review on the cover of the Book Review on Aug. 23, about “Hos, Hookers, Call Girls, and Rent Boys,” a collection of essays and other writings about the sex industry, misstated the connection of R. J. Martin Jr., one of the book’s editors, to the SAGE Project (Standing Against Global Exploitation) in San Francisco. While he was indeed once its director of development, he is no longer associated with the group, which had nothing to do with the book. The review also referred imprecisely to the SAGE Project. While it offers a wide variety of support services for the sexually abused, its ultimate goal is to bring about the end of commercial sexual exploitation.

The Keeping Score column last Sunday, about the challenge of being a championship contender in men’s tennis during the Roger Federer era, misidentified a publication edited by James Martin, who commented on the difficulty of competing against a motivated Federer. It is Tennis magazine, not Tennis Week.
Despite being just 17 years old and standing 5 feet 6 inches, Melanie Oudin, not the stars she grew up watching, is the focus of her country’s most important tennis tournament.

A picture caption on Aug. 16 with an article about “Cafe Society: The Wrong Place for the Right People,” a memoir about the interracial Manhattan nightclubs owned by Barney Josephson, misstated the number of clubs he owned, and a correction in this space last Sunday misidentified the decade in which one of them opened. Mr. Josephson owned three clubs, not two. (In addition to Cafe Society Uptown and Cafe Society Downtown, open in the late 1930s and 1940s, he also owned the Cookery, which began as a restaurant in the 1960s — not the 1970s.).
Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic grinded out victories on Saturday night, but Andy Roddick became the first top-10 seed to fall on the men’s side.
The newly released C.I.A. memos confirm that harsh interrogation was pointless at best.
How the effects of a weakened economy are reflected in a maximum security prison.
After eight years of work in Afghanistan, we still do not have a reliable Afghan partner to hand off to. It’s time to discuss if nation building is still worth doing and at what cost.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
David Pogue is a man with many masters.
Tom Ridge’s backpedaling from his assertions in his book makes one wonder if any hard truths about the Bush administration are actually at hand.
Russian prosecutors should now focus on finding the real killers of the journalist Anna Politkovskaya, no matter where the trail may lead.
The Federal Communications Commission should develop a fundamentally new approach to cable regulation that ensures customers have real choices.
Mr. Obama must stand tough for a comprehensive plan that would benefit both the uninsured and most other Americans as well.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the new or higher fees being levied by governments and public authorities in the New York region as the economy falters rendered the name of Connecticut’s governor incorrectly. She is M. Jodi Rell, not Jodi M. (The M stands for Mary.).

An article last Sunday about secret documents obtained by the American Civil Liberties Union on the abuse of prisoners in American custody misstated, in some editions, the name of a New Jersey law firm that had worked with the A.C.L.U. and other advocacy groups on the case. It is Gibbons P.C., not Gibson P.C.
INTERNATIONAL.
Contrasting images suggest contradictory sides to Nancy Garrido, the woman charged in Jaycee Dugard’s kidnapping.

A review on Aug. 16 about “Zeitoun,” Dave Eggers’s account of the experiences of a New Orleans contractor, Abdulrahman Zeitoun, during and after Hurricane Katrina in 2005, referred imprecisely to some aspects of the storm. While there were strong winds and heavy rain at Zeitoun’s house on the evening of Aug. 28, the hurricane didn’t “hit” on that date; it made landfall in Louisiana in the early hours of Aug. 29. And while Katrina was at one point a Category 5 storm, by the time of landfall, it was Category 3.

To the Editor: Your Practical Traveler column “Labor Day’s Last-Minute Lure” (Aug. 23) highlighted the difficulties the travel industry is having during these challenging economic times.

To the Editor: Matt Gross’s Frugal Traveler column “Expert Tips on Hitchhiking the Planet” (Aug. 9) brought back fond memories of my hitchhiking days in the late ’60s to mid-’70s. I started while in uniform, and despite the negative attitude toward the military, the hitching was excellent. Upon discharge, I headed off to what became a four-year journey hitchhiking through parts of Europe, Asia, Australia, New Zealand and 9,000 miles in Africa. The rewards far outstripped the risks. Hitching seems riskier now. Perhaps it’s just aging, but I don’t think so. David Vollenweider.

The Rookie Detective Andrew Baum, 26, served in a countersurveillance unit in the Israeli Army, where he learned useful skills like finding and removing electronic bugs. He had decided to go to Israel, where he is a citizen and his mother lives, after graduating from college and discovering he was not cut out for a desk job. Now Mr. Baum, who lives in Astoria, Queens, freelances for several private detective firms, and is nearly finished with the three-year apprentice period required before he can become licensed and open his own firm.

In the small trailer her family rented over the summer, 9-year-old Charity Crowell picked out the green and purple outfit she would wear on the first day of school. She vowed to try harder and bring her grades back up from the C's she got last spring -- a dismal semester when her parents lost their jobs and car and the family was evicted and migrated through friends' houses and a motel. Charity is one child in a national surge of homeless schoolchildren that is driven by relentless unemployment and foreclosures. The rise, to more than one million students without stable housing by last spring, has tested budget-battered school districts as they try to carry out their responsibilities -- and the federal mandate -- to salvage education for children whose lives are filled with insecurity and turmoil.

IN ''La Bohème,'' the lovers Mimi and Rodolfo are pried apart by disease, poverty, failure of nerve and, ultimately, death. When Sarah Joy Kabanuck and David Miller played the roles on Broadway in 2003, some strange magnetism seemed to be forcing them together. ''There was a moment of connection, but it was so intense that we couldn't be friends,'' Ms. Kabanuck, now 30, said of their initial encounters. ''Our time together was nothing but awkward.''

SINCE 2005 Jim O'Rourke, the once perennially busy American musician and producer, has lived in a small apartment in Japan, keeping to himself. He had flown there for work at least 50 times in earlier years; every time he returned to the United States, he said, his mood sank. At first his relocation was on and off, during the long process of acquiring an artist's work visa. Now it seems pretty permanent. ''It's the only place I'm happy,'' he said during a recent telephone interview, with a perfectionist's mordant cackle. Mr. O'Rourke, 40, is about equally known for his own music -- albums like ''Eureka,'' ''Insignificance'' and his remarkable new one, ''The Visitor'' -- as for his work for other people. For about 10 years, starting in the mid-1990s, Mr. O'Rourke, based in Chicago and then New York, saw his craft, knowledge and legendarily selfless work ethic connect some far-apart poles in music: pop, improvised music, contemporary classical and noise.

SEID--Florence, 97, "Flo" died peacefully on September 3rd at her home in Florida. She lived a long and very happy life as the devoted wife of 71 years to her late husband Clarence "W2KW." Mother of Jane Chaves and the late Carol Seid. Sister of Evelyn Gerstenblith. Grandmother of the late Mark Chaves. She is survived by her grandchildren Susan and Scott Zucker, and Mark's wife Kim, also by her great-grandchildren Jeri, Brian, Evan and Allison. Her family will miss this gentle, loving and kind lady of extraordinary strength, whose wisdom and keen intelligence we will never forget. Services will be privately held.

The Minnesota Vikings might have been more of a favorite to win the division before they got Brett Favre. They have the best running back in football in Adrian Peterson and a good defense, especially against the run, and the unimpressive Sage Rosenfels and Tarvaris Jackson would have merely been asked to play conservatively and not make mistakes. With Favre, the Vikings' coaches may be tempted to open up the passing game and that could be a mistake. Favre can still throw the ball a mile -- the question is, who will catch it? He has a partially torn rotator cuff and is coming off surgery. These hardly seem the ingredients for an improvement in the 40-year-old Favre's play over last year, when he led the Jets into a late-season collapse with an avalanche of interceptions? If Favre can limit his interceptions -- the late-season five-year trend is not promising -- the Vikings will be one of the N.F.C. teams to beat for a Super Bowl spot. But if he is closer to the Jets' version of Favre, the Vikings, and Coach Brad Childress, will be in trouble. As it is, they will have a tough time holding off the Bears for the division title. The Chicago Bears finally have a franchise quarterback -- cue the Sid Luckman retrospectives. Jay Cutler is one of the best young quarterbacks in the league, and running back Matt Forte should have another strong year, particularly because the Bears also upgraded their offensive line. Still, the thought of Cutler's teaming with Devin Hester on the deep pass has the Bears salivating, because playing with the lead helps a defense that in the last few years has had to do much more than its share to keep the Bears in games. We'll find out how good the Bears are early: they open at Green Bay and then play the Steelers, but it could come down to the regular-season finale between the Vikings and the Bears to determine the division champion. The top of this division is a tossup, but there is not much question the Bears got the better upgrade at quarterback.

Robin Soderling seems to be one of those players you see in the first week of a Grand Slam tournament, pushing a top opponent to four or five sets before losing. Such is the career of a second-tier player. At the Australian Open, Soderling has not advanced past the second round. At Wimbledon, his best finish is the fourth round. And until this year, he had not played in a Grand Slam final; that came at Roland Garros, where he fell to Roger Federer.

No need to spend much time on the New Orleans Saints' offense. In short, it is a powerhouse, even if Reggie Bush remains something of an enigma. Drew Brees led the league in passing yards last year, but the breakthrough player this season could be running back Pierre Thomas, who in limited playing time averaged nearly 5 yards a carry. That leaves the defense, which has undermined the Saints the last few seasons. It should be better heading into the season because every player on the line is healthy, which should finally allow an adequate pass rush. That will help the secondary, too. The Saints have seemed like a team on the brink for a few seasons, but injuries undermined them last season. If they are healthy, they could be among the N.F.C.'s elite, especially because it is hard to imagine any other team in this division improving their records from last year. The Carolina Panthers are coming off a season in which everything went well for a long time -- no significant injuries, a relatively easy schedule. But things went sour in the playoffs, where they imploded against Arizona. Quarterback Jake Delhomme had one of his worst games ever, committing six turnovers. That overshadowed what had been a good offensive season for the Panthers, who had the benefit of the rushing tandem of DeAngelo Williams and Jonathan Stewart. That opened up the passing game for Delhomme and receiver Steve Smith. The defense excels at pressuring the passer, but it has not been able to stop the run since Kris Jenkins went to the Jets. Still, the Panthers could repeat as division champs if they are lucky enough to avoid injuries again. They will not get as much help from their schedule, which is much tougher. The last month includes trips to the Patriots and the Giants and home games against the Vikings and the Saints.

AS a founder of the design studio Surface to Air, Gordon Hull has worked in film, fashion and art. Now, in his first solo show, at Partners & Spade, he is trying his hand at magic. ''Lo-fi magic,'' he stressed. Entitled ''Narratives From the Collection,'' the exhibition is a grab bag of paintings, performance, collage, sculpture, video and photography inspired by the beguiling and benevolent trickster figure of African oral narrative. Here, things are not exactly what they seem. The wonderfully grainy photos from Mr. Hull's recent trip to India have been manipulated to look like old Kodachrome images. The imperial African masks, gold-leafed by his own hand, are simply cheap tourist souvenirs. But most enchanting is a short film in which he plays the Great Belghazi, a trickless magician who, through sleight of editing, turns his friend, the artist Kon Trubkovich, into a ladder.

Girls Girls, the San Francisco duo of Christopher Owens and J R White, arrives with shoulders shrugged, head slightly down. Its debut album, titled ''Album'' (True Panther Sounds/Matador), is a lean ramble, in no way ostentatious. Knowingly or not, Mr. Owens has the tender brooding of Buddy Holly down cold, with a touch of Elvis Costello's shakiness in his voice. But ''Album'' isn't clean: it's flayed and ragged and hazy. Like so much of the noise and psychedelia lately infesting the indie-rock underground, underneath the slop lies terrific instincts for clean, artful melody. In that vein ''Album'' is one of the year's most bracing pop releases, and one of the best, a devastatingly fresh reframing of the pop songbook. Mr. White lends versatile support on these numbers, which pilfer elementary punk, country-rock and 1950s-vintage shuffles. (A beautiful instrumental with stirring gospel organs is called ''Curls.'') But Mr. Owens is the revelation, with deliciously malleable voice and attitude: desperate on ''Ghostmouth,'' snide on ''Lust for Life,'' pleading on ''Lauren Marie'' and on ''Hellhole Ratrace, '' just plain old winded. The feelings are complicated but the songs are raw -- like templates for others to copy.

Navy's strong performance against Ohio State on Saturday raises a question that has been percolating around college football: why don't more teams run the option offense? Elements of the option have returned in force the past five years as spread offenses have proliferated. But pure option teams, once a staple, are still a rarity. ''Sometimes, we get afraid of doing something we don't know much about,'' Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel said in a phone interview last week. Because so few people run it, he theorized, it's difficult to find a coach comfortable enough with the offense to implement it. He also pointed to recruiting.
Film Stephen Holden

MELNIK--Ronald Peter, Spring Lake, NJ. With dignity and grace in the presence of his loving family, taken into the hands of our Father on Saturday, August 29th in his 75th year. Born June 27, 1934 in Brooklyn, NY. A devoted husband to Peggy and a cherished and loving father to Diane, Patrick and Ronald Jr. and spouses and proud grandfather to Meredith, Natalie, Luke and Connor. A friend to all those who were fortunate to make his acquaintance, Ron had a wonderful gift to make newcomers into friends and to touch all those who shared time with him. Ron was loyal to the schools he attended: Blair Academy, United State Military Academy at West Point and the University of Virginia. He served his country honorably as a Captain in the U.S. Army. In 1956 he was drafted by the New York Giants but selected instead to attend the University of Virginia Graduate School of Business where upon graduation he joined the faculty. Ron enjoyed a long and accomplished career spanning four decades on Wall Street. He was a solid and good man who always placed family and friends before himself and who did it with a smile. Ron leaves a legacy of a full life well lived. His heart and love will be missed by all. A memorial Mass will be held in his honor on Saturday, September 12th at 11am at St. Catharine Church, 215 Essex Avenue, Spring Lake, NJ. Neary-Quinn Funeral Home, 39 South Street in Manasquan, NJ in charge of the services.

What is Kansas City's Zack Greinke going to have to do to win the American League Cy Young Award? Unfortunately for Greinke, right, the win column is often the first place people look when handicapping the race for the award, and that is the one statistical area where he is lacking. Greinke's 13 victories are tied for eighth most in the league.

Coach Bill Belichick should probably send bouquets to Michael Vick and Brett Favre with notes saying, ''Thanks for pushing us off the radar.'' While those two consumed preseason attention, Belichick's New England Patriots have the most important comeback story of the regular season and, if all goes as expected, the postseason. For those living under a rock -- or in Philadelphia or Minnesota -- Tom Brady is back from his knee injury. While the contributions of Vick and Favre remain the subject of much speculation, the expectations for Brady are simple: get the Patriots back to the Super Bowl. They came within a whisper of making the playoffs without him -- kudos to Belichick for adaptability -- and during the off-season engineered a considerable roster makeover, upgrading the secondary with Shawn Springs and Leigh Bodden. Then they added Fred Taylor, one of those aging running backs Belichick works wonders with, and receivers Joey Galloway and Greg Lewis. As a result, the Patriots could pick up where they left off in 2007, blowing out opponents for much of the season. Their offense will get two good tests in October -- against the Baltimore Ravens and the Tennessee Titans, with a game against the Denver Broncos in the middle -- before they play in London against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. (This is the N.F.L.'s idea of a marquee game?) If Brady holds up, anything short of an appearance in the A.F.C. championship game will be a letdown. The Patriots thump you over the head with greatness. The Miami Dolphins delight you with shock value. But repeating their division title will be tough, and not just because of Brady. The Dolphins have a brutal schedule -- the toughest in the league, if you go by how opponents finished last season -- and they could easily start 0-3. It is also hard to imagine linebacker Joey Porter's matching the season he had last year. Miami drafted quarterback Pat White and will unveil new iterations of the Wildcat with him, and the secondary should be better. The Dolphins may be a better team this season than last but could finish with nine or fewer victories.

DAPHNE GUINNESS, at right, the heiress, aesthete and awe-inspiring clotheshorse, is no subtle thing. Neither is her new fragrance. Created in collaboration with Comme des Garçons, this opulent floral takes its inspiration from her own heady memories: the armloads of tuberose she would gather at her childhood home in Cadaqués, Spain; the incense burned at church; the earthy oud of her exotic travels. Packaged in a sleek pebblelike bottle, decadent red velvet pouch and black-and-white box, it is, as she described it, very her. ''It has a mysterious feeling,'' she said. ''It's not everyone's cup of tea, but I love it. It's personal. I would hate to make something I wouldn't wear.''

With all due respect to Tony Dungy, the Indianapolis Colts may be in the midst of the most seamless transition in N.F.L. history. That is thanks, of course, to the presence of Peyton Manning and the fact that Dungy's replacement as head coach, Jim Caldwell, was around all along. Manning is fully recovered from the secret knee surgery that hampered him early last season, and even though Marvin Harrison is gone, Manning still has plenty of receiving weapons. The Colts hope for a more consistent running game (it averaged only 3.4 yards per carry last season), and the presence of the rookie back Donald Brown of Connecticut should help. The Colts upgraded the defensive line in the off-season, which should bolster their desperate run defense immensely. The division has also helped the Colts -- Albert Haynesworth left the Titans, the Jacksonville Jaguars are struggling and while the Texans are on the upswing, they probably will not keep the Colts from winning the division again. The nondivision schedule is manageable, outside of the Colts' annual slugfest with the New England Patriots. They may not win the division, but the ultimate under-the-radar team, the Houston Texans, could make it to the playoffs for the first time. It's hard to make much noise on offense when you are in the same division as Manning, but the Texans, with receiver Andre Johnson, are good. It is their defense that may push them into the postseason, though. It's time for everyone to admit that the former general manager Charley Casserly made the right call when he drafted defensive end Mario Williams over Reggie Bush and Vince Young. Williams is one of the best defensive linemen in the N.F.L. Combine him with an elite group of linebackers, and the Texans finally have what Casserly said they needed: a way to stop the Colts. With an incredibly easy schedule to start the season, including the Jets, the Jaguars, the Oakland Raiders and the San Francisco 49ers, the Texans may finally be ready to push the Colts.

THE revamped Ford Mustang was released within months of the rebirth of the Chevy Camaro and the Dodge Challenger, and the puddle of drool at the feet of muscle-car owners was probably matched only by the puddle beneath the editors of car magazines, for which the throwback ''pony cars'' provided no-brainer cover stories. Motor Trend's tag line for its story was: ''The Comparo We've Waited 35 Years to Write. And The Feud We've Waited 35 Years to Watch.''

The Fair Game column last Sunday, about access to financial information in the municipal bond market, overstated the amount of West Penn Allegheny Health System bonds bought by individual investors in the first quarter of 2009. It was $1.3 million, not $1.3 billion.

ON Sept. 12 Trey Anastasio, the lead guitarist of the jam band Phish, will give the New York premiere of his concerto ''Time Turns Elastic'' with the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall. If earlier versions available online are any indication, Mr. Anastasio will be bringing New Yorkers not some gaseous reimagining of Carl Orff's ''Carmina Burana'' or Gustav Holst's ''Planets'' -- the route pop classicists usually take -- but a recognizably Anastasian composition rooted in the style that made Phish so successful. As such, it is bound to be an improvement on what these escapades in cultural alchemy usually turn into. Classical ensembles have been slumming with rock stars since the days of Frank Zappa. This year alone the Decemberists have performed with the Los Angeles Philharmonic and with a pickup orchestra in Chicago; the classical pianist Christopher O'Riley is offering tarted-up versions of songs by Radiohead and Nick Drake; and, most ominously, Sting is giving onstage readings of the letters Schumann wrote to his wife, Clara; meanwhile a pianist in the background plays Schumann.

BMW was slow to get into hybrids and plug-in vehicles, but it is making up for lost time with the hybrid X6 set for the United States by the end of the year. The company also put the Mini E electric car in the hands of hundreds of American lease customers and introduced the related Megacity vehicle. And now there's a sleek new plug-in hybrid saddled with an ungainly name, BMW Vision EfficientDynamics Concept. The car, which we'll just call the BMW Vision, will be shown at the Frankfurt Motor Show in September (and possibly at the Los Angeles show in December).

WHILE the fashion press loudly proclaims leopard as the animal print to own this season, snakeskin has surreptitiously emerged as a fresher, more interesting alternative, both on the street (in Zara python-print leggings, far left) and down the runway. Dries Van Noten and Derek Lam worked it quite fantastically into their fall collections, sending out some of the smartest looking accessories around, while Isabel Marant used a cool reptilian print for a range of pieces from slouchy trousers (a similar style is available at Topshop) to a ruched cocktail dress, which Sienna Miller (left) recently took a red-carpet turn in. But it is the French Vogue editor Carine Roitfeld who has given the look its best endorsement yet. ''You know,'' she told a reporter from The Guardian who had admired her snakeskin Martin Margiela boots, ''I think as you get older, the snake is more chic than the leopard.''

Lonely Planet has reintroduced its cycling guidebook series, after noticing that out-of-print editions were selling on the Web for many times their face value. The first three guides -- for Britain, France and Italy -- are available now, with Australia and New Zealand on the way this month. The original cycling guide series was published from 2000 to 2003 but soon fell out of print. Lonely Planet decided to resurrect the series when copies began selling on places like eBay and Amazon. (A recent eBay search yielded a 2003 ''Cycling Italy'' guide being offered for $139 and a 2002 ''Cycling Cuba'' for $64 -- though most are available for much less.)

The biggest tennis matches at the United States Open happen on the blue hardcourt of Arthur Ashe Stadium. But the center of the tournament is an obscure, windowless room in the stadium's bowels, behind a door marked Private. That is where the plot-twisting logistical calisthenics of producing the daily match schedule, or official order of play, take place.

There are two reasons the Seattle Seahawks could reassume their place atop the division a year after the Cardinals shocked the N.F.L. and nearly won the Super Bowl: Matt Hasselbeck and the Kansas City Chiefs. Hasselbeck had back trouble last season and played in only seven games, and his receiving corps needed a MASH unit. Hasselbeck is back, and he can throw the ball to T. J. Houshmandzadeh, the most talented receiver he has ever had. Other than injuries, the problem last year -- and potentially this year -- is the defense. It was terrible in 2008, particularly against the pass, not a good thing when you are in the same division as Kurt Warner and Larry Fitzgerald. End Patrick Kerney is returning from an elbow injury, which should help the pass rush. The Seahawks owned this division until half the team went on injured reserve last season. If their health holds up, they should overtake the Cardinals. One thing working against the Arizona Cardinals: for a Super Bowl runner-up, they had an unusual amount of off-season tumult. Both coordinators are gone to the Kansas City Chiefs. Anquan Boldin spent the off-season upset about his contract. And Warner got a few months older. Todd Haley left to become the Chiefs' head coach, but the offense he left behind is incredible, particularly the other-worldly Fitzgerald. If Fitzgerald plays during the regular season anything like the way he did when he took over the playoffs, the Cardinals' offense cannot be stopped. Unless Warner gets hurt. The good news is the Cardinals filled a gaping need when they drafted Chris Wells, a hulking running back who can provide the ground game that was absent last season. The pass rush is still not great, so the superb secondary will have its work cut out for it the two times the Cardinals play the Seahawks.

SILBERSTEIN--Roselle S.,on August 29. Wife of 52 years of the late Dr. Alexander G. Silberstein. Mother of David Silberstein and Jane Herzog and mother-in-law of Veronica Silveira and Eric Herzog. Grandmother of Emilia, Kim and Andrew. Born in New York City, Roselle graduated Dalton School in 1931, lived in White Plains for 30 years and retired in La Jolla, CA. A lifelong volunteer in many organizations, her family and all who knew her were enriched by her positive spirit, intellect, wit, and love of people and life.

330 The number of gray wolves that can be killed in the first legal hunts in decades in the United States outside of Alaska. In March, wolves in parts of the northern Rockies were removed from the endangered list, losing their legal protection. The Interior Department said the population of roughly 1,640 animals had recovered. Hunting began last Tuesday in Idaho; Montana's season starts Sept. 15. As of late Friday afternoon, hunters had killed three wolves.

JOHNSON--Barbara. Friends, colleagues, and students mourn the loss of Barbara Johnson, a world-renowned literary critic and professor of English and Comparative Literature at Harvard University, who died August 27. A pioneering practitioner of deconstruction and a distinguished translator, Johnson wrote groundbreaking essays that profoundly influenced the field of literary and cultural studies. She was revered by students for her insight and generosity, admired by colleagues for her brilliance and integrity, and beloved by friends for her wisdom, keen wit, good cheer, and open heart.

THE WILD SIDE Just because we don't yet understand all the information that genomes contain doesn't mean they aren't useful. Consider, for example, the single-celled being Cryptosporidium parvum. This is an intestinal parasite of humans and other animals; it belongs to a group known as the apicomplexans, which includes a number of nasties such as Plasmodium, the bugs that cause malaria. The complete genome sequence of Cryptosporidium revealed that it is missing several of the genes that had been identified as potential drug targets in some of its apicomplexan relatives. Attacking Cryptosporidium will thus require a different strategy.

As children of all ages dread the impending return to early morning wake-up calls and homework overload, a short-term antidote is the annual ritual of foraging for school supplies, clothes and shoes. The Queens Center mall in Elmhurst, a short walk from the Woodhaven Boulevard stop on the R, V or G train, has 70 stores, including most major chains, and is anchored by Macy's and J. C. Penney. But it is also a microcosm of its surrounding borough, one of the most diverse places in the country: Colombian teenagers bump up against elderly Chinese, Indian women in saris shuffle past Filipino toddlers. The mall offers translation in close to 50 languages. And what other mall allows for a nosh on empanadas, Italian ices or halal food just outside the air-conditioning? LIZETTE ALVAREZ

This division can be summed up neatly as three bad teams and an underachiever. For years, the SAN DIEGO CHARGERS have had one of the most talented rosters in the league, only to struggle to make a dent. That does not apply to Philip Rivers, who has emerged as one of the N.F.L.'s best quarterbacks, even as the cornerstone of the Chargers' offense, running back LaDainian Tomlinson, has begun to fade. If Tomlinson and tight end Antonio Gates return to full health, the offense, second in scoring in the league last year, should lead the Chargers to an easy division title (San Diego finished 8-8 and still won the West last season). How much further they go may depend on the defense, which should return to form with the return of the pass rusher Shawne Merriman, in whose absence the secondary was exposed. But with Merriman back and more depth on the defense, the Chargers could be poised to make a deep run in the playoffs. They had better hurry, because the window is closing fast on this group. Whither the Denver Broncos? They were cruising to a division title last season but since then have stumbled into the N.F.L.'s alternate universe. They collapsed, losing the title and sending Mike Shanahan into temporary coaching exile. The new coach, Josh McDaniels, decided Matt Cassel was preferable to Jay Cutler, which annoyed Cutler, who threw a fit and forced a trade -- not for Cassel but for the Bears' Kyle Orton, who threw three interceptions in the first preseason game and is uncertain for the Broncos' opener with an index finger injury. And don't forget Brandon Marshall's getting upset about his contract and being suspended for part of the preseason. The Broncos also cannot count on much from an abysmal defense that was not upgraded. The middle of the schedule is brutal, and McDaniels will learn that all these distractions -- and shipping out Cutler, one of the N.F.L.'s best young quarterbacks -- do not build a winner, even in a weak division.

JAFFE--Bernard. The Board of Directors and Officers of Montefiore Cemetery Corporation and Springfield L.I. Cemetery Society mourn the passing of President Bernard Jaffe, our cherished leader, mentor and friend for decades. We extend our condolences to his beloved wife Fern and to his entire family.

THERE is a certain car in my neighborhood, a sporty silver Mazda with Thule bike racks. I would have no interest in it if not for its owner's insistence on taking up two spaces every time he parks. Day after day, it's the same thing. He nudges his car into a parallel space, nestling it about four feet from the bumper in front of him, as if this is going to protect his precious vehicle from errant dings, or make quick escapes easier. The effect for the rest of us is one less space that could have gone to a parent juggling children and groceries.

N.F.L. strategy evolves through punctuated equilibrium. After years of gradual, imperceptible changes, new rules or coaching innovations can bring sudden jolts to the way football is played. This is one of those periods of rapid change. Spread and Wildcat offenses are forcing defenses to adjust, and safety-oriented rule changes are making coaches rethink age-old strategies. Here are five tactical trends to watch for this season. Some are brand new, others have been evolving into their current form for years. The Wildcat and Beyond

For all its struggles to reach the elite ranks of international competition, the United States soccer team has been able to rely on success against El Salvador. The games have been trusted vehicles in taking the Americans toward World Cup qualification. So the United States' 2-1 victory on Saturday night will be not be remembered for how the Americans came back from a deficit against the Salvadorans, but for how the Americans emerged unscathed and a step closer to South Africa in 2010.

''The goal there is very much to take risks that nobody else will take.'' Vinod Khosla, whose firm said it had raised $1.1 billion in two funds that will invest in green technology and information technology start-ups -- the largest amount raised by a venture capital firm since 2007.

THE NEWS The Securities and Exchange Commission failed repeatedly to uncover the huge investment fraud run by Bernard Madoff, a government report concluded. BEHIND THE NEWS As early as 1992, the S.E.C. received the first of six ''substantive complaints'' that over the years ''raised significant red flags'' about Mr. Madoff, the agency's inspector general found. But S.E.C. investigators failed to take even the most basic steps to determine if a Ponzi scheme was in play. Perversely, the fact that investigators found nothing awry actually enhanced Mr. Madoff's credibility. Thousands of investors were ruined; Mr. Madoff is serving 150 years in prison.

Seeking to become one of Europe's top airports, Barcelona Airport officially opened Terminal T1 in late August -- a $1.7 billion structure shaped like an aluminum sword. It is expected to welcome 30 million passengers a year, doubling the airport's capacity. The curved and sleek terminal, which was designed by Ricardo Bofill, a native of Barcelona, reflects the latest in airport trends. Its environmentally friendly features include solar-powered water heaters and glass walls that let in plenty of daylight and views of the city. And its resortlike amenities -- spa, fitness center, hair salon, multifaith church, beds and, of course, some 80 stores and restaurants -- suggest a world of long layovers and delayed flights.

COHEN--Edward Baron, 91, on September 4, 2009. Devoted son of the late Elias and Rachel (nee Baron) Cohen. Loving brother of Sherman and the late Mortimer. Beloved husband of Suzanne (nee Mendelson). Loving father of Andrew and Richard. Affectionate grandfather and uncle. Together with his brothers, Edward helped shape the skyline of Manhattan to what it is today. To paraphrase Christopher Wren, "If you want to see his monument, look around you." Funeral Service Sunday, September 6, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., NYC.

Give the N.F.C. East credit: it's never boring. The Giants remain the favorite because at the nitty-gritty of football -- line play and the running game -- they are among the best. The defensive line has been bolstered by the additions of Chris Canty and Rocky Bernard (although the line has also been hit by injuries in the preseason). The most important addition is the return of end Osi Umenyiora, who missed 2008 with a knee injury. The defense was still fifth in points allowed and had 42 sacks. The offensive line is superb and the running game with Brandon Jacobs can be devastating. The Giants were headed for another deep run in the playoffs, and perhaps a chance to defend their Super Bowl title, before Plaxico Burress accidentally shot himself in the leg last November, and the offense screeched to a halt. Burress is gone and so is Amani Toomer, but the Giants drafted receiver Hakeem Nicks. Still, Eli Manning, who signed a huge contract extension, may not have to make many clutch passes to win. With this running game and defense, the Giants can play conservatively and still be a Super Bowl favorite. The Giants' defense will have to worry about a new wrinkle when they play the Philadelphia Eagles, their closest competition. Michael Vick is almost certain to be used in Wildcat-type plays, where, Coach Andy Reid has hinted, he and Donovan McNabb could be on the field at the same time, with one of them lined up at receiver. But the Eagles' Super Bowl chances hinge much more on McNabb than on Vick. If the McNabb of late last season is the one who shows up this year, the Eagles are in good shape. If he is the one who was so bad against the Ravens that Reid benched him, you can expect a quarterback controversy. Otherwise, the Eagles are loaded. The defense lost the coordinator Jim Johnson, who died in the off-season after fighting cancer. Still, this is another superb defensive line and a great defense, and unless Brian Westbrook gets hurt and McNabb falls apart, this is another Super Bowl-caliber team.

STANTON--Joan Alexander. A Memorial Service for Joan Alexander Stanton will be held on Tuesday, September 22nd at 10am at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, New York City.

Now that injuries to Michael Young and Josh Hamilton have thrown cold water on the Rangers' pursuit of the Angels in the A.L. West and Boston for the wild card, the only race in baseball with any excitement is the Colorado-San Francisco battle for the National League wild card. That leaves plenty of time to check out the September call-ups around the majors. The most accomplished of the rookies to be promoted this month is Giants catcher Buster Posey. With Bengie Molina dealing with a quad injury, Posey will be tested in the heat of the wild-card race. The fifth overall draft pick in 2008, Posey hit .326 with 15 homers and 58 runs batted in in 50 games for Class AAA Fresno.

The Pirates have got to be sick of Milwaukee. Last Sunday, the Brewers beat Pittsburgh for the 21st straight time at Miller Park, 4-1. The last time the Pirates won on the road against the Brewers was in May 2007. It is the longest such streak in the major leagues since Cleveland beat the St. Louis Browns/Baltimore Orioles 27 times in a row at Cleveland Municipal Stadium from 1952-54.

LATSON--Edwin Millard (Jim), of Greenport, NY, died September 3, 2009, in Eastern Long Island Hospital following a short illness. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Constance Thayer Latson; three children, Anne L. Vogelsberg, Amy M. Latson, Peter H. Latson; and two grandsons, Benjamin and William Latson. Another son, Edwin, Jr. (Ned) died in 2008. He was predeceased by three siblings, Almet R. Latson, 3rd, Susanne L. Blankley, and Mary L. Connolly. A graduate of Poly Prep Country Day School and Yale College, 1941, he served as a captain in the US Army during WWII. A resident of Brooklyn Heights during his working years, he retired in 1985 from the New York Heart Association, where he was Controller. He was heavily involved as a volunteer in community organizations such as the Brooklyn SPCC, Long Island College Hospital, Packer Collegiate Institute and Grace Church. A memorial service will be held Friday, September 11, at 11:00am at Southold Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Southold Presbyterian Church, PO Box 787, Southold, NY 11971 or Eastern Long Island Hospital, 201 Manor Place, Greenport, NY 11944.

The Pittsburgh Steelers got the scare of the preseason when Ben Roethlisberger was stepped on during a practice, injuring his Achilles' tendon. Now that it looks as if Roethlisberger is O.K., he can go back to being one of the best, and the most underrated, quarterbacks in the league. The Steelers did not change much in the off-season, but why change when almost everything works so well? The line has to protect Roethlisberger better and the running game has to improve -- can Willie Parker finally stay healthy? -- to take some heat off the quarterback. But the defense has to do nothing but be as great as it was last season, which seems a given because of its coordinator, Dick LeBeau, who is starting his 51st year in the N.F.L. The Steelers made their way through the toughest schedule in the league last year. This season, they will get a huge break because they play the A.F.C. West, and the Detroit Lions. Don't be surprised if they go back to the Super Bowl. Only the Steelers could make Baltimore Ravens quarterback Joe Flacco self-destruct in the playoffs last season, which is why the Ravens will again push the Steelers in the regular season and perhaps again in the playoffs. The Ravens have all the elements in place that helped Flacco become one of the rookie surprises last year. The defense lost the coordinator Rex Ryan and linebacker Bart Scott to the Jets, but it remains loaded. The running game is strong, and Flacco has a successful season under his belt. The Ravens may not win the division, but another run deep in the playoffs would not be a shock.

THE French director Loïc Prigent admits it was laziness that prompted him to film Karl Lagerfeld, Jean Paul Gaultier, Sonia Rykiel (above) and Proenza Schouler during the 36 hours leading up to their fall 2009 fashion shows. (In Mr. Gaultier's case, it is his couture show.) ''In the past, I've followed designers around for six months,'' Mr. Prigent explained. ''This time, I wanted something easy to edit.'' Which is not to say that ''The Day Before,'' his four-part series that will have its premiere on Sept. 9, isn't rich in material: there is the panic at Proenza Schouler at having to re-sew a velvet dress just as it's about to appear on the runway; the look on everyone's face as Ms. Rykiel stumbles upon the ''secret room'' housing preparations for her surprise 40th-anniversary tribute show; the 1 a.m. collective nervous breakdown at Fendi, as loopy design assistants stage a comical fashion show of their own, an amused Mr. Lagerfeld snapping photos from the sideline. ''Most people don't know the truth about the fashion world,'' Mr. Prigent said. ''I'm trying to show it, and it's hysterical.''

FRANKEL--Larry. The ACLU deeply mourns the loss of a beloved colleague, Larry Frankel. Frankel worked at the ACLU Washington Legislative Office as the State Legislative Counsel and had previously led the work of the ACLU of Pennsylvania. Frankel was a tireless advocate for civil liberties and civil rights, and his warmth and winning sense of humor will be greatly missed by his colleagues. Our sympathy goes out to his family and loved ones.
Art Ken Johnson

RINEHART--Dr. John McLain, Composer, concert pianist and professor, died peacefully at age 72 surrounded by family and loved ones on Tuesday, August 4th in Atlanta, GA. He will be remembered by family and those close to him for his dry wit, huge smile and enormous appetite for living life to its fullest, but most importantly to him he will be forever remembered for his legacy as a truly gifted composer of modern classical music ranging from the piano to symphony orchestra, and as a gloriously talented and electric classical concert pianist. Born on March 17, 1937 in Pittsburgh, PA he began piano studies at age 5, composing and performing in concert his first work (a waltz for piano) at age 8 and by age 12 performing Chopin on television. He studied composition and piano performance at Kent State University for his BA, studied for his MM at Yale and the Cleveland Institute of Music and attained his Ph.D. at Ohio State Univ. Following his studies he taught at such universities and conservatories as Heidelberg, CIM and Oberlin before arriving at Antioch as the chair of the music department where he remained until his retirement in late 2004. All the while he composed works which earned performances in the U.S., Europe and Asia. He never stopped performing classical standards and modern contemporary music for solo piano, chamber ensembles and concerto across the nation, winning the highest of acclaim from his contemporaries and audiences alike. A concert played by John Rinehart was truly an exhilarating experience! During the last 13 years of his life he battled Parkinson's Disease but never gave up hope for a brighter future. He miraculously retained his skill and depth as a pianist during this time and composed his largest and broadest works to date including two new symphonies, two concertos and a full Mass. He always felt he would live on in his compositions. His dream was to have his new works performed live, a dream he and his son pursued in the final years of his life and that his son will continue to pursue in his honor and for the benefit of lovers of music around the world. Dr. Rinehart was survived by his only son, John Miles Rinehart III, his son's fiancee Nancy Myers, his sister Doris Abrams and nieces. A private memorial service was held on August 16th in Atlanta, GA. Many of his compositions and performances can be found at www.myspace.com/john mrinehart01. For more information regarding Dr. Rinehart and his compositions please write to his son at john.rinehart@gmail.com

DAVIS--Edward Shippen, of New York City died on August 28, at his home in The Springs, East Hampton. Born at New York Hospital January 23, 1932 of Wendell Davis and Lavinia Riker Davis, he was a graduate of Pomfret School, Harvard College, and the Harvard Law School. His professional life centered around his partnership as a corporate lawyer with Hughes Hubbard & Reed. He served for a number of years as a Director of Hillenbrand Industries and Cognitronics Corporation. Ned had a lifelong commitment to educational issues, serving as a member and later president of the Board of Trustees of Collegiate School, a life Trustee of Pomfret School, and most recently a Director of the Bronx Charter School for Children in Mott Haven. To the end of his life he was actively involved as a member of the Executive Committee of Doctors of the World-USA as it achieved its transition to the independent entity HealthRight International. Ned is survived by his wife of 29 years, Barbara Thompson Davis, and his daughter Martha Knapp Davis. He was predeceased by his son Edward Shippen Davis, Jr. He was the attentive stepfather of Tamur and Daniyal Mueenuddin, their wives Lauren Ingram and Cecilie Brenden. He also left three young grandsons. With the support of East End Hospice, his family was able to be with him to the end. The funeral service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street on Thursday, September 10 at 4pm. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to East End Hospice, Westhampton Beach, NY.

DAVIS--Edward. The Collegiate community mourns the passing of Edward "Ned" Davis, Class of 1949, former trustee (1972-1984; 1992-1998), past parent, and president of the Board (1977-1984). A loyal friend of the School, Ned worked tirelessly to forward the School's mission and improve its physical plant. A Life Member of the Alumni Council, Ned was honored with the Collegiate School Alumni Association Distinguished Alumnus Award in 1985. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Lee M. Levison Headmaster George R. Bason, Jr. '72 President, Board of Trustees

TAKING IN THE VIEW AT TORRES DEL PAINE NATIONAL PARK, PATAGONIA, CHILE, APRIL 24, 2009 Francisca Piola, a 37-year-old design manager for LAN Airlines in Santiago, Chile. ''I've traveled a lot, not because I work for an airline, but because I grew up in different places. I was born in Santiago but moved to Venezuela from when I was 2 until when I was 18; I traveled with my family around Latin America, the U.S. and the Caribbean. When I got back to Chile I also traveled a lot, pretty much to every country in Latin America. But it was really weird -- I always went outside Chile. Then I went to the States and lived there for two years and flew to Europe two times. So when a photographer friend of mine came to Chile to take pictures of Patagonia, I took four days off my job because I had never been. Torres del Paine is a very special place, for the shapes of the mountains, the openness, the views, the lakes, the icebergs floating in the lakes. The vegetation is really different from anything I had seen before. It was like a discovery. And I was wondering why I hadn't come sooner.'' As told to Seth Kugel

As legacies go, David Tyree has an extraordinary one. But even his one-handed, against-the-helmet catch to continue the winning drive in Super Bowl XLII -- perhaps the greatest play in Giants history -- was not enough to save Tyree on Saturday, when he was among the players the Giants released as N.F.L. teams got down to the 53-man roster limit for the start of the regular season. Tyree could draw interest from other teams, particularly because he was a special-teams standout, but his jaw-dropping third-down catch in the Super Bowl nearly two years ago, with New England Patriots safety Rodney Harrison draped around him, turned out to be his last for the Giants. Leg injuries kept him out for the 2008 season, and he struggled with inconsistency and more injuries during training camp this summer.

SCHULTZ--Robert J.,M.D., born in Brooklyn, New York on June 29, 1930, passed away on August 8, 2009. He was an extraordinary man who lived life to the fullest and gave much of himself to make this world a better place. A graduate of Brooklyn College and Chicago Medical School (where he was awarded the Distinguished Alumnus Award in 1984), Dr. Schultz had a distinguished career in both public service and in his practice as an orthopedic surgeon. He served during Vietnam, attaining the rank of Captain, M.C. United States Navy, and spent close to two years at the Naval hospital in Millington, TN, caring for wounded Vietnam veterans. While serving with the 1st Marine Brigade, he was a member of the Black Sheep Squadron and earned expert rifle and pistol awards, as well as a National Defense Service Medal. Dr. Schultz piloted fixed wing aircraft as well as helicopters. Throughout his life he voluntarily offered to serve this country in whatever capacity he could. During his professional career, Dr. Schultz became Director of Orthopedics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in 1967, then both Chairman of Orthopedics at Westchester County Medical Center and Professor of Orthopedics at NY Medical College in 1977 and Chairman of Orthopedics at USF Tampa, FL in 1990. Dr. Schultz was the inventor of artificial finger joints, the Schultz Angle Guide and surgical K-Caps. He authored The Language of Fractures (1972) and was close to publishing a new book on exercising safely to avoid injuries, which will be published posthumously. He lectured worldwide on orthopedics as a visiting professor in Israel, England, France, and the People's Republic of China, held three professorships and was a 32nd degree Mason. He served as the doctor for the New York Rangers Hockey Team in 1979, was Chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, and was the police surgeon of Westchester County, NY. He also served on the Surgeon General's Advisory Panel in Washington, DC. Dr. Schultz was an accomplished flamenco guitarist and active athlete. He played football for Tilden High School and Brooklyn College, won medals in skiing and trap shooting, had entered rodeos with his wife Marcie in Louisiana in the 1960s, and was an avid tennis player. He is survived by his wife Marcie, daughter Judith, son Andrew, daughter-in-law Erica, and three grandchildren, Jacob, Alexander, and Samuel.

AUG. 20 TO 23 Newport, the Rhode Island summer colony, prizes old money, old houses, old cars and old customs, all punctiliously maintained. Every three years, the Preservation Society of Newport County invites the Coaching Club to hold a weekend of drives at the celebrated estates and gardens, some of which are newly restored. It is a tradition that began with Alfred Vanderbilt, who turned coaching into a sport after the arrival of the railroads ended coach mail delivery. The code of dress for guests on the coaches: hats for everyone. The weekend includes stops for Champagne, lunches and dinner-dances at the mansions and a public display of the vehicles on the lawns of the Elms. On Sunday, while the 19th-century coaches were rolling through a main gate at the Breakers, one of the Vanderbilt mansions, 21st-century surfers were passing through the waterside gates on the Cliff Walk, hoping to catch the 20-foot waves generated by Hurricane Bill. The weekend ended with lunch at another mansion, Marble House, where the Chinese teahouse is now open to the public.

But Wednesday morning is a window for mere mortals to sit and relax and plan the day-- or maybe just start getting to know one another. YOUNG--Dr. Elizabeth, Professor of Psychiatry, Senior Research Professor at the Molecular and Behavioral Neuroscience Institute and member of the Depression Center at the University of Michigan passed away on September 1, 2009 after a yearlong battle with leukemia. She was 59 years old. Dr. Young was an internationally renowned biological psychiatrist and neuroendocrinologist who conducted seminal work on stress biology and its role in depression and other mood disorders. She was raised in the Detroit and Chicago areas and completed her medical degree from The Ohio State University in 1976. She completed her residency in Psychiatry at the same institution in 1979. She received postdoctoral training at the University of Michigan Medical School in the Department of Psychiatry and the Molecular and Behavioral Neuroscience Institute. She was then recruited to the faculty of the Institute and the Department where she remained until her death. Dr. Young was the quintessential "translational" physician-scientist, who understood the biology of stress and used that knowledge to enhance our understanding of the causes of mood disorders. A particular focus of her research was to uncover the biological and psychosocial reasons for the increased vulnerability of women to depression and anxiety. Dr. Young was also a loving wife and stepmother, a caring physician, a wonderful collaborator and mentor, an ardent gardener and appreciator of the best that life has to offer, and a devoted friend. She is survived by her husband Dr. Peter Hinman, her stepdaughter Dr. Mira Hinman and two step-granddaughters Annika and Celia McDermott-Hinman. A ceremony to honor her memory is planned for early October. A Memorial Fund has been created to establish The Elizabeth A. Young Lectureship on Stress and Mood Disorders at the University of Michigan. Donations to the Fund can be sent to MBNI, 205 Zina Pitcher Place, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-5720. Attn: R. Freedman.

BILL T. JONES is fond of saying that when he was growing up, Abraham Lincoln was the one white man he was allowed to love unconditionally. Sometimes he includes John F. Kennedy and his brother Robert as well. It's a catchy sound bite, the sort that comes in handy for people who often find themselves in the spotlight. And it has served Mr. Jones well over the last two years, as he has undertaken one of the most ambitious and challenging projects of an ambitious and challenging career: a commission by the Ravinia Festival in Illinois to create a dance-theater work celebrating the bicentennial of Lincoln's birth.

I GREW up with four siblings who were 12 to 17 years older, so I was exposed early to the fields they were interested in -- science, art and business -- and the diversity influenced me. When I was a preteen, I programmed an Apple II computer to manage the inventory for my parents' paint store. I was 16 when my mother died, and I realized that life is short. It motivated me to take risks and have fun.

Americans are deeply torn about the prospect of a health care overhaul, according to an analysis of 22 recent nationwide public opinion polls by two professors at the Harvard School of Public Health. The majority of Americans favor the abstract concept of remaking the medical system, according to the analysis, published recently in The New England Journal of Medicine. But at the same time, the study found, the majority believes that if Congress were to enact health care legislation, neither the overall quality of medical care nor their own personal care would improve.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Tickets Are a Tough Sell for the New Giants Stadium,'' Aug. 31: The recession is a significant factor, but I believe sticker shock is the primary reason for the difficulty the Jets and the Giants are experiencing in selling season tickets for 2010 in their new stadium.

HOXIE--John William, 74, of Frederick, Maryland, died peacefully August 25, 2009. Born November 30, 1934 in New York City to John A. and Marion R. Hoxie, he was a graduate of Choate Rosemary Hall and Harvard University. Mr. Hoxie served as an editor for numerous newspapers, most recently at the Washington Times. He loved to play the violin and was an accomplished artist, art restorer and portrait painter. He is survived by his devoted wife of 53 years, Diana Depping Hoxie of St. Louis, two sons, Thomas and William Henry Hoxie, a daughter, Alice Hoxie and seven grandchildren. Also surviving is his sister, Joan Hoxie Bristol, of Washington, DC. Services will be private.

JAMIE BOCHERT, model and musician. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW The dress is Camilla Staerk. The belt came off a kimono-style robe from the Park Hyatt hotel in Tokyo, and the jacket and shoes are Ann Demeulemeester. I don't wear a lot of designer clothes, but when I do, it's mostly Ann's stuff.
NEUFELD--Ben, 97, died August 31 in Savannah. He was formerly from Hewlett and Ft. Lauderdale. Ben was an exceptional husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle.

SCHUR--Sylvia Zipser, born Brooklyn, NY, June 27, 1917, long-time resident of New Rochelle, NY, died Chicago, IL, September 2, 2009. Widow of Saul Schur (d. 1988) and Kaneji Domoto (d. 2002), loving mother, doting grandmother, endlessly creative writer and developer of new products for the food industry, and mentor to many young women starting in business and journalism. Sylvia graduated Hunter College, served as a food editor at PM, Seventeen, Look, Flair, Woman's Home Companion, and Parade, founder and president of Creative Food Services, author of over a dozen cookbooks, consultant to General Foods, Duffy-Mott, Campbell's, Seagram's, and to restaurants including The Four Seasons. She was the second president of Les Dames d'Escoffier New York. She is mourned and missed by sons Stephen Schur of San Francisco, Jonathan (Annie) Schur of Paris, France, and daughter Jane (Carl) Smith of Chicago, grandchildren Aaron, Ethan, Jeremy, Lucia, Solon, Matthew, and Julia, and brother, Philip Zipser. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street), Sunday, September 6, 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Self Help Home in Chicago, IL, or Les Dames d'Escoffier New York.

THERE may be no better way to bait a baby boomer than to be anything less than totally reverential about the Beatles. So the news that the lads from Liverpool were taking fresh form in a video game (a video game!) called The Beatles: Rock Band struck some of the band's acolytes as nothing less than heresy. Luckily, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr, along with the widows of George Harrison and John Lennon, seem to understand that the Beatles are not a museum piece, that the band and its message ought never be encased in amber. The Beatles: Rock Band is nothing less than a cultural watershed, one that may prove only slightly less influential than the band's famous appearance on ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' in 1964. By reinterpreting an essential symbol of one generation in the medium and technology of another, The Beatles: Rock Band provides a transformative entertainment experience.

J. Novak as the members of his staff.
