Anthony Minghella (''The English Patient,'' ''Cold Mountain'') directed the pilot episode, his final completed work before he died in 2008. (HBO, $59.99, not rated)

KRAKOFF--Arthur. September 2, 2009. Beloved husband of Helene R., devoted father of Laura and Joan, adored grandfather of Valerie and Daniel, loving great-grandfather of Matthew and Morgan. He will be deeply missed by all who had the privilege to know this wonderful member of the "greatest generation."

CHERTOFF--Carolyn. Born February 17, 1915, died September 3, 2009. Widow of M. Leonard Chertoff, former supervisor of the New York City Home Instruction Program. She was adored by her husband and treasured by her children and grandchildren. Her wise counsel, strong sense of ethics and wonderful cooking made her special to us all. Her recipes will be handed down through her family as will memories of holidays spent together. She is survived by her brother, Bernard Berkowitz; her children Andrew Chertoff, M.D. and Susan Steinhart; and her three grandsons Jason Chertoff, M.D., Shawn and Joshua Steinhart. She was the heart of our family and will be greatly missed.
SCHNEIDER--Melanie (nee Milstein). One in a million and loved by so many. Services Sunday, September 6, at 12:30 pm, Park Avenue Synagogue.

FRADRICH--James, award-winning concert pianist, composer, orchestrator and musical director, passed away August 27 at UMDNJ in Newark, NJ due to complications from liver illness while waiting for a second transplant. He resided in Union City, NJ. Jim was a child prodigy and state-level award-winning pianist who performed both as soloist and with several symphony orchestras. He gained prominence as a composer, orchestrator and musical director off-Broadway and regionally. He was archivist for the Rodgers and Hammerstein Library from 1979-1981 and was a frequent assistant to the Broadway composer, William D. Brohn. Born January 22, 1951 and raised in Menasha, Wisconsin, he graduated from Lawrence University (B.M.) in Appleton, Wisconsin in 1971. There is a void in our hearts and he is very deeply missed by many people. He will be remembered for his gentle elegance and dapper style, his sharp wit and his uncompromising love for the arts. Jim is survived by his life partner of 27 years, Kevin McMullan, and several cousins. Memorials will be held at Leber Funeral Home, 2000 Kennedy Blvd., Union City, NJ on Thursday, September 3, 6-8pm. A memorial in celebration of his music, date and time to be announced, is being planned for late October. Donations may be made to The James Fradrich Memorial Scholarship (for classical pianists and composers) at Lawrence University or to the Actors' Fund of America. Jim, thanks for the music. Kevin McMullan William D. Brohn Valerie Gebert

JAFFE--Bernard. The Law Firm of Pryor Cashman LLP mourns the passing of Bernard Jaffe, our dear friend and client for many years. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Fern and to his entire family.

A federal judge in Texas on Aug. 28 dismissed the remainder of a defamation lawsuit Roger Clemens filed against his former trainer Brian McNamee. The dismissal, however, is only a technicality. Clemens's lawyers asked for the complete dismissal as a way for them to appeal the lawsuit, much of which was thrown out by United States Judge Keith P. Ellison in February. The Daily News first reported Saturday that the case had been fully dismissed.

WHILE the number of cylinders used in motorcycle engines has ranged from zero to at least eight, the ideal number for many types of bikes seems to be two. The V-twin engine design, a hallmark of modern Harley-Davidsons, has dominated the cruiser market for so long that it's easy to forget the earlier popularity of other shapes and sizes. The V-twin is also a staple of today's sport bikes, especially those wearing the Ducati logo.

SHAKIN--Seymour, died August 28. Devoted husband to Charlotte for 63 years; loving father to Steven (Pamela) and David (deceased); adored grandfather to Matthew and Rebecca Shakin. Seymour was admired and respected in the automotive industry with friends all over the world. Services were held.

Your loving brother Sherman and family, Gloria, Charles, Clo, Robin and Kenneth.

Dr. David Himmelstein is an associate professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School and a primary care doctor at the Cambridge Hospital in Massachusetts. In 2005 and 2009, he helped write major studies finding that medical bills were a leading contributor to personal bankruptcies in the United States. He spoke to the freelance writer Anne Underwood.

During a 23-stroke rally on Friday night, Nicolas Kiefer pushed Rafael Nadal along the baseline - pummeling potential winners to opposite corners that Nadal barely flicked back at full stretch - then drew him forward with a deft drop shot, only to volley a perfect lob to send the muscular Spaniard galloping toward the back fence for an unbelievable, though ultimately futile, get. It was the sort of athleticism that was only hinted at two decades ago, and that would have been unimaginable a generation earlier.

When the Sudanese authorities picked up a dozen women in a cafe in July and charged them with breaking the law by wearing trousers, they didn't realize what they started. Most of the women (some of them actually just girls) accepted what they saw as inevitable and received a flogging. The penalty is up to 40 lashes with a whip that can leave scars, and one teenage girl was so scared she wet her pants.

I was in Prague last month and went to visit Prague Castle. There, just inside the gate near the tram stop, I happened upon an exhibition I heard had recently opened. Continuing through Nov. 8, it is devoted to Judah Loew, called Maharal, the rabbi of Prague at the turn of the 17th century, whom I was already familiar with from the often-retold story of his golem. According to various tellings of the legend, Loew created the golem, a giant he made out of clay, to do hard work and to protect the Jews of Prague from persecution.

With Kim Clijsters taking a turn at being the latest cannonball in the United States Open -- No. 3 Venus Williams the latest to be washed aside in Clijsters's fourth-round upset -- the race for the women's title is one player from being turned entirely upside down. Serena Williams, the No. 2 seed who makes an argument for being the No. 1 player in the world, stepped into the mayhem Sunday and restored her own world order. She crushed No. 22 Daniela Hantuchova, 6-2, 6-0, with an overpowering game she had left idling in the earlier rounds. That raises questions of just who can beat her when she is fired up and tuned in. She has a 22-1 record in Grand Slam matches this season, a remarkable stretch, even by Williams's lofty standards.
Tatjana Jovanovic-Grove Moving From Serbia,

PHISH ''Joy'' (Jemp) ''Happy happy'' are the first words Trey Anastasio sings on ''Joy,'' the first studio album from Phish since its rescinded final breakup in 2004; ''second time around'' are the last ones. That's no accident. Five years apart apparently left the band members missing Phish as much as its fans did, and their pleasure at collaborating again comes through every song. Where Phish's last studio album before the breakup, ''Undermind,'' was filled with dissonances and misgivings, ''Joy'' celebrates friendships, continuity and shared memories with quick-fingered glee.
Rick Alexander A Builder by Trade

It was late in the third phase of the deeply compartmentalized match between Venus Williams and Kim Clijsters, and the largely American crowd in Arthur Ashe Stadium had unmistakably chosen its favorite. In a reflection of the power of new motherhood and the lure of an excellent comeback tale, the choice would not be Williams, the dignified seven-time Grand Slam singles champion from the United States. Instead the biggest roars of approval down the stretch would be reserved for the powerfully built Belgian on the other side of the net.

MAYER HAWTHORNE ''A Strange Arrangement'' (Stones Throw) Mayer Hawthorne's debut album, ''A Strange Arrangement,'' breezes by in a torrent of reference points: doo-wop and quiet-storm R&B, a Philly-soul horn section, Funk Brothers bass lines and drumming, the dignified and elegantly rendered heartbreak that was the text of soul music's late 1960s and early '70s glory period.

During ninth-ranked Oklahoma State's 24-10 victory at home against No. 13 Georgia, Oklahoma State Coach Mike Gundy said he noticed that Bill Young, his first-year defensive coordinator, was telling the defensive ends on the sideline what the defensive ends in the game were doing wrong as the action unfolded. ''It's hard to call a defensive game and turn around and talk to people behind you and coach,'' Gundy said. ''I guess if you've done it for 40 years, you can do that.''

By his death at 78 in 2002 Larry Rivers had had a long and prolific career in art. Yet far from being the admired figure that his work of the 1950s seemed to promise he would be, he was regarded in the art world, to the extent he was noticed at all, as a has-been, a self-repeater working in an insubstantial, out-of-date mode. People had forgotten how audacious his 1950s work once felt. At a time when heroic abstraction had a lock on the market, he was painting the figure, specifically the nude figures of his 60-something mother-in-law, Berdie Berger, and of his close friend and occasional collaborator and lover, the poet Frank O'Hara. And he was painting them with a fleet, Bonnardish realism that felt invigoratingly fresh and upbeat when set beside the turbidities of action painting.

Back in 2003, which is akin to half a lifetime ago in tennis years, Juan Carlos Ferrero won the French Open and was the runner-up at the United States Open. He claimed the No. 1 spot and won Spain's National Sportsman of the Year award. His game slipped in subsequent years, and a promising 2008 season was riddled with injuries. His ranking fell to its lowest point in a decade -- to 115th as recently as May -- and he found himself having to play qualification matches for tournaments leading up to the Open.

The revolving door of talent continues at ''Saturday Night Live'' as that NBC comedy series approaches the start of its 35th season. Variety.com reported that Casey Wilson, top row left, a performer and screenwriter (''Bride Wars'') who joined the ''SNL'' cast in 2008, did not have her contract with the show renewed and will not be returning in the fall. Michaela Watkins, top row right, a featured performer who appeared on the 2008-9 season of ''SNL,'' was also let go as the show added two new cast members, Nasim Pedrad, above left, and Jenny Slate, above right. The Variety report also said that Darrell Hammond, a cast member since 1995, was still negotiating his return. The Sept. 26 season premiere of ''Saturday Night Live'' is expected to be hosted by Megan Fox (''Transformers'') and feature U2 as its musical guest.

KLEIER--Jonathan Ian, age 26. Beloved son, brother, uncle - who passed away peacefully in his sleep - you were taken from us before you had the chance to ever grow up - you were the sweetest child with your blond curls and cherubic face, you were the sweetest young adult, so full of life, star of the Horace Mann football team, you excelled at whatever you put your mind to, loved by all you friends and teachers. You were the most wonderful light in our family - we loved you more than anything in the world, and we know how much you loved us. We feel so fortunate that you worked with us, and that we saw you so often, and that you got to know your little nephews, both whom look like you and adore their "han." Your kindness, your sweetness, your innocence, your joy for life and the family and the girls, your passion and talent for writing, your intelligence, your light will be with us every day forever. Our hearts are broken, we will miss you so very much and remember you every day. We love you forever and ever - good night sweet boy - love, "The Family" - Mom, Dad, Samantha, JP and Chase, Sabrina, Rob and Cooper, and of course the little girl angels who adored you Roxy, Lola, Dolly and Dixie. Service Tuesday September 8, 12pm at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St. In lieu of flowers, donations in Jonathan's name can be made to the Horace Mann School c/o Thomas Kelly.

KLEIER--Jonathan. We are so saddened to learn about the passing of Jonathan. We are beyond words. Jonathan's warmth and energy will be missed forever. Our deepest condolences to the entire Kleier family. Love, Randi, Sam and Brett.

Any lingering illusion that Canada is a milder, blander version of the United States is dispelled by ''Durham County,'' a Canadian-made crime series that begins on Monday on the Ion network. It takes a while to realize that this scary, well-made thriller was not made in America. ''Durham County'' has all the signposts of a Hollywood production: lush theme music and stark cinematography, a brooding homicide detective, barbaric rapes and murders, philanderers, sociopaths, yoga moms and alienated teenagers.

Are online user reviews better when they are written in the heat of the moment or after the writer has returned to the home computer and had some time to cool off? That is the question facing review sites like Yelp and Citysearch as they build mobile applications. ''There's a trade-off here, and I think the trade-off favors giving users the opportunity to share the experience when they're feeling it,'' said Dinesh Moorjani, head of mobile for Citysearch, which lets users write reviews from its iPhone application.
Jenny Salinas From a Nonstop Career

They were left out of the latest unemployment rate, as they are every month: millions of hidden casualties of the Great Recession who are not counted in the rate because they have stopped looking for work. But that does not mean these discouraged Americans do not want to be employed. As interviews with several of them demonstrate, many desperately long for a job, but their inability to find one has made them perhaps the ultimate embodiment of pessimism as this recession wears on.

On the subject of the WTA world rankings, Serena Williams and Dinara Safina could not disagree more. Safina, who is the world No. 1 despite never having won a Grand Slam title, is fine with consistency and constancy being rewarded. Williams, ranked No. 2 despite winning this year's Australian Open and Wimbledon titles, is of the opinion that one's record in the majors should weigh heavily in the rankings. But the two are united in their belief that the United States Tennis Association showed disrespect to the women Saturday by moving Safina's night match against Petra Kvitova from Arthur Ashe Stadium to Louis Armstrong Stadium after the day session ended well past the scheduled 7 p.m. start of the night session. Safina's match was scheduled to be the first played at Ashe but was bumped for James Blake's match against Tommy Robredo.

There's bleak, and then there's pull-the-covers-over-your-head, tremble-and-hope-it-stops bleak, which is the state in which server manufacturers find themselves. The research outfit IDC has just issued its second-quarter data on the server market, and it shows server sales falling off by 30 percent year over year, to $9.8 billion. As it turns out, that number stands as the lowest three-month total since IDC began keeping track of such things on a quarterly basis in 1996.
Ray Rucker Feeling Counted Out

It had been nearly 30 years since the Rev. Carl Kabat and a group of peace activists, including his fellow Catholic priests Daniel and Philip Berrigan, barged into a General Electric weapons plant outside Philadelphia. Known as the Plowshares Eight, they battered missile nose cones with hammers in an effort to disable some of the world's most fearsome weapons, and sprinkled blood on classified documents to protest the cold war, before they were arrested. The cold war ended with the fall of the Berlin Wall 20 years ago this November and the splintering of the Soviet Union in the early 1990s. Three of the Plowshares Eight, including Philip Berrigan, have died, and scores of other activists have turned their attention to the Arab-Israeli conflict, the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and the terrorism suspects held at Guantánamo.

The iPhone has proved lucrative for some developers. Now, advertising networks are cashing in on the platform. Greystripe, a mobile advertising start-up, takes a different approach to advertising on the iPhone. Rather than simply layer a banner ad across the bottom or top of an application, the company creates advertisements that look like games. For example, one ad for the car company Kia pits players against a ram in a boxing ring. Another ad lets users pop heart-shaped bubbles floating out of a tub in which the Burger King character, the King, is soaking.

9 P.M. (History) MANSON A little after midnight on Aug. 9, 1969, Linda Kasabian stood guard outside the Benedict Canyon home of the actress Sharon Tate as three members of what she called her family, led by Charles Manson, committed mass murder. After fleeing the group's compound several days later, she became a witness for Vincent Bugliosi, the chief prosecutor in the case, and was granted immunity. She tells the story of the nine months leading up to the murders in this two-hour documentary, which also includes interviews with Mr. Bugliosi, above with Ms. Kasabian in 1971; Tate's sister Debra; and Catherine Share, also known as Gypsy, who was then a Manson follower. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY A preview of fall movies; Sean Kingston performs.

OS MUTANTES ''Haih or Amortecedor'' (Anti-) There is something brash, quixotic and wistful in a 57-year-old songwriter determined to return to the kind of music he made as a teenager, especially when the songwriter is Sérgio Dias, the guitarist from the Brazilian band Os Mutantes, which released their first album in 1968.

AMY MILLAN ''Masters of the Burial'' (Arts & Crafts) The bittersweet-molasses voice of Amy Millan communicates strength as well as vulnerability, and she often finds a way to put forth a little of both. Best known for her steadfast work with Stars and Broken Social Scene, a pair of interrelated Canadian indie-rock bands, Ms. Millan has a fondness for the rustic side of country music, with its lonesome confidences and modest avowals. A few years ago she brought a hint of twang to her respectable solo debut, ''Honey From the Tombs.'' She pursues much the same sound on ''Masters of the Burial'' but with even more reserve.

When Jeff Cox, a 15-year-old candidate for the rank of Eagle Scout in Windermere, Fla., approached the small town's mayor with park improvement ideas to help earn a badge, the mayor informed him that those projects were already covered. ''He came back and said, 'Would the town like a memorial if I can get World Trade Center steel?' '' Mayor Gary Bruhn said. ''I was stunned. I said, 'Son, the town would be elated to have something like that.' He said, 'I think I need the town's support. I don't think they're going to just give it to me.'''

She hit the net with her racket, she angrily tore at a loose bandage on her knee, and she even hit her own leg with her hand. But the one thing Vera Zvonareva could not hit was a winner when it mattered most. Zvonareva, the volatile seventh seed from Russia, lost her composure after failing to put away any one of six match points in a 3-6, 7-6 (6), 6-0 loss to the 10th seed, Flavia Pennetta.

The man known on some of Harlem's toughest streets as the ''P.O.D.,'' shorthand for ''pastor on deck,'' brought his black Jeep Compass to a screeching halt on Lenox Avenue, near 128th Street, on a recent Saturday night, and jumped out. Two teenage girls -- members of the rival street gangs Girls G.F. and Barbie Dolls -- were rolling across the sidewalk in a tangle of elbows, kicks, fists and screams. Blood smeared the concrete as a roaring circle of at least 20 people urged them on.

''Love Story'' by Taylor Swift, above, has had the most spins, or single radio plays, so far this year. Ms. Swift has a second hit in the top 25 songs on the radio, ''You Belong With Me,'' with 213,132 spins. Three other artists have two songs among the top 25: Beyoncé, T.I. and Lady Gaga, whose ''Poker Face'' and ''Just Dance'' are in the top 10. In terms of single-song sales, ''Love Story'' has been downloaded 2.1 million times, placing it in 12th place, about half as many as the most downloaded song, ''Boom Boom Pow'' by the Black Eyed Peas. The natural gas industry has enjoyed something of a winning streak in recent years. It found gigantic new reserves, low prices are encouraging utilities to substitute gas for coal, and cities are switching to buses fueled by natural gas. But its luck has run out in Washington, where the industry is having trouble making its case to Congress as it writes an energy bill to tackle global warming.

ROSENBERG--Gerald A. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member and former Governor, Gerald A. Rosenberg. We extend our sincerest sympathy to Rosalind, Clifford, Nicholas and the entire family. Calvin W. Roberts, President Richard J. Bronstein, Secretary

PHISH ''Joy'' (Jemp) ''Happy happy'' are the first words Trey Anastasio sings on ''Joy,'' the first studio album from Phish since its rescinded final breakup in 2004; ''second time around'' are the last ones. That's no accident. Five years apart apparently left the band members missing Phish as much as its fans did, and their pleasure at collaborating again comes through every song. Where Phish's last studio album before the breakup, ''Undermind,'' was filled with dissonances and misgivings, ''Joy'' celebrates friendships, continuity and shared memories with quick-fingered glee.
POWELL--Maxwell M. Daddy, not a day goes by that I don't miss you and think of you with love.

AMY MILLAN ''Masters of the Burial'' (Arts & Crafts) The bittersweet-molasses voice of Amy Millan communicates strength as well as vulnerability, and she often finds a way to put forth a little of both. Best known for her steadfast work with Stars and Broken Social Scene, a pair of interrelated Canadian indie-rock bands, Ms. Millan has a fondness for the rustic side of country music, with its lonesome confidences and modest avowals. A few years ago she brought a hint of twang to her respectable solo debut, ''Honey From the Tombs.'' She pursues much the same sound on ''Masters of the Burial'' but with even more reserve.

Before he wrote “Love Letters,” “The Dining Room” and many other plays chronicling the sunset of the American WASP, A.R. Gurney was a theater-loving boarding school student who in 1948 traveled to New York to see “Antony and Cleopatra,” and meet its star, Katharine Cornell. Mr. Gurney’s remembrance of this event provides the basis of his new play, “The Grand Manner,” which Lincoln Center Theater said on Tuesday it would present as part of its spring season. In a news release, Lincoln Center Theater said that the new play, described as a “a heartfelt look back at the glorious heyday of the Broadway theater,” would be directed by Mark Lamos, the recently appointed artistic director at the Westport Country Playhouse. It is to begin previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater on May 27 and open on June 24. No casting has yet been announced.

The last time Michael Feinstein appeared on Broadway, “Cats” was halfway through its nine lives, “The Phantom of the Opera” was barely out of diapers and the original run of “A Chorus Line” had just recently kicked the bucket. Now for the first time since his 1990 show “Michael Feinstein in Concert: Piano and Voice,” Mr. Feinstein, the vocalist and pianist, plans to return to the Great White Way with a new production planned for February. In a news release, publicists for the new show said that it is tentatively titled “All About Me,” and that Mr. Feinstein was collaborating on the production with the writer Peter Ackerman (of the “Ice Age” movies and “The Pajama Game”) on Broadway, and that it would feature a small orchestra accompanying Mr. Feinstein on standards and other songs. A theater and an official opening date for “All About Me,” which is produced by Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel, have not yet been announced.

Ever since Thomas P. Campbell took over as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Jan. 1, there has been speculation about when he would put together his own senior management team, especially with some crucial positions left vacant after the museum’s recent downsizing.

Over the years, Snoop Dogg has been a reality television star, a master of ceremonies at WrestleMania, a guest on television series like “One Life to Live” and “The L Word,” and occasionally even a hip-hop performer. Now he can add a new credit to his resume: On Tuesday, EMI Music announced that it had named Snoop Dogg the creative chairman of its Priority Records division, the gangsta rap label that has distributed albums by Snoop Dogg, N.W.A., Ice Cube and many others. In a news release, EMI said that Snoop Dogg would be responsible for “the legacy of Priority and will drive efforts to maximize untapped digital and branding opportunities at the label”; he will also release a new studio album, “Malice N Wonderland,” on Priority in December, and serve as an executive producer for a new line of albums planned for next year in honor of the label’s 25th anniversary. Additionally, Snoop Dogg’s manager and creative partner, Ted Chung, will become a brand strategist at Priority Records. In a statement, Snoop Dogg said, “The business model we’ve developed will bring the musical heritage of groups like N.W.A. to the forefront,” adding that his new album would be “the most potent dose of Snoop Dogg yet.”
What we’re reading on Tuesday morning.

J. M. Coetzee drew one step closer to becoming the first author to win the Man Booker Prize for Fiction three times as the short list of nominees for that British literary award was announced on Tuesday. Mr. Coetzee’s novel “Summertime,” about a writer working on a biography of a deceased author named John Coetzee, is one of six books to make the final cut for the prize, its organizers said in a news release. The real Mr. Coetzee won the prize for his novels “Life & Times of Michael K” in 1983 and “Disgrace” in 1999. The five remaining finalists are “The Children’s Book” by A. S. Byatt (a Man Booker winner in 1990 for her novel “Possession”); “The Little Stranger” by Sarah Waters, who is on the short list for the third time; “The Quickening Maze” by Adam Foulds; “Wolf Hall” by Hilary Mantel; and “The Glass Room” by Simon Mawer. The winner of the prize, which comes with about $82,500, will be announced on Oct. 6.

A roster of 13 musical acts including Mary J. Blige, Chris Brown, Akon, Natalie Cole and Sister Sledge will be among the performers at a tribute to Michael Jackson that will be held at the Schönbrunn Palace in Austria, Billboard reported. This first portion of the lineup for the event, which is called simply The Tribute and is being held on Sept. 26, was announced Tuesday by Jermaine Jackson and the event’s producer, Georg Kindel, at a press conference in Vienna. The concert is to include performances of many of Michael Jackson’s best known songs, including “Man in the Mirror,” “Billie Jean,” “Smooth Criminal” and “Thriller,” and will feature the band that Mr. Jackson planned to use in the shows he was rehearsing before his death on June 25. Billboard said that the Vienna tribute, for which about half the tickets have been sold, would conclude with ensemble performances of “We Are the World” and “Heal the World,” and that additional artists would be announced in the coming days.

How deep is your love for the falsetto sounds of an ethereal pop act of the disco age? Your affection for the Bee Gees may be put to the test by a planned reunion of the two surviving members of that group. Reuters reported that Robin Gibb, one of three founding members of the band, which dominated the “Saturday Night Fever” soundtrack with songs like “Night Fever” and “Stayin’ Alive,” told BBC Radio that he was preparing to play a series of performances with his older brother, Barry. The third Gibb brother, Maurice, died in 2003 after he experienced cardiac arrest before emergency surgery for an intestinal blockage. At that time, the surviving brothers said that they would no longer perform as the Bee Gees. But Robin Gibb told the sports radio program “Test Match Special” that he and Barry had since “got through the breakwater of emotions,” according to Reuters. No dates or locations for the concerts were announced.
Update | 6:45 p.m. The photographer Annie Leibovitz’s $24 million loan was due Tuesday, but by the end of the work day, it appeared that little had happened between her and her lender.

The release date of a new CD has long been record companies’ marketing focal point, but in the age of the leak that date is seldom set in stone. The latest high-profile new album to be rushed into stores early in the wake of its unauthorized appearance online is Jay-Z’s “The Blueprint 3,” which is being released by Jay-Z’s new label, Roc Nation, and distributed by Atlantic. It had been scheduled to go on sale this Friday, but after it leaked late last month the CD was put on sale at record stores Tuesday. When asked by MTV News last week about the leak, Jay-Z said, “That’s pretty much how it happens with all my albums.”

When a panel convened by the Writers Guild of America ruled in August that it would not discipline Jay Leno for continuing to perform his “Tonight Show” monologues while the guild was on strike, it also said that the guild owed Mr. Leno an apology, Variety reported. In a report prepared by a trial committee of the WGA West, the committee recommended unanimously that the guild apologize publicly to Mr. Leno, a longtime guild member, who has “been done a disservice” and had “his reputation harmed by these proceedings,” according to Variety. The writers’ strike began on Nov. 5, 2007, and concluded on Feb. 12, 2008; “Tonight” was in reruns until Jan. 2, 2008, at which point Mr. Leno, who supported the strike, resumed performing monologues that he composed without his writers. According to the committee report, Mr. Leno told the writers’ guild that as a member of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, a union that represents television actors and broadcasters, he was allowed to write material for his own performances. The guild’s leadership disagreed with Mr. Leno but the trial committee supported the comedian on this point. A spokesman for Mr. Leno told Variety that he was happy with the committee’s ruling and that no apology was needed.

HarperCollins and heirs to the author J.R.R. Tolkien reached a settlement with Warner Bros.’ New Line Cinema unit in their suit against the studio over payments from films based on “The Lord of the Rings” trilogy, according to statement from Warner, the publisher, and the heirs on Tuesday.

For those of you with eyes bigger than your wallets, several performing arts organizations are offering free or discounted tickets. Below is a selected list. If over the next few months you see smoke coming from the direction of James Patterson‘s house, it might be the result of the author burning off his fingertips as he types: On Tuesday, the Hachette Book Group announced that it had signed a deal with Mr. Patterson that would cover 17 books. In a news release, Hachette said that 11 of the books would be for adult readers and released by Little, Brown and Company (in hardcover) and Grand Central Publishing (in paperback); the remaining six would be handled by Little, Brown Books for Young Readers. The books will be divided among Mr. Patterson’s various best-selling series, and feature his detective characters Alex Cross and Michael Bennett as well as the Women’s Murder Club. The young adult titles will include books in the “Maximum Ride” and “Daniel X” franchises as well as a new “Witch & Wizard” series whose first book will be released in December. Terms of the deal, which was negotiated by Robert Barnett and Deneen Howell of Williams & Connolly LLP, were not disclosed, but Hachette said the contract would cover books through 2012. That’s just under six books a year, so getting cracking, Mr. Patterson.
Filled with glancing light and happy faces, “Marina of the Zabbaleen,” fights hard to sweeten the misery of its surroundings.

“Crude,” a thorough and impassioned documentary of environmentalist advocacy, focuses its gaze on production rather than consumption.

In case you missed it, 2009 is the 200th anniversary of Charles Darwin's birth and the 150th anniversary of the publication of his masterpiece, "On the Origin of Species." Already, there have been exhibitions and lectures, television documentaries and radio shows, postage stamps and playing cards. Books have been published on every aspect of the man, his work and his life. You can sample his wife's recipes (orange posset, anyone?), read about his garden, experience Patagonia through his eyes and employ an "evolutionary hermeneutic" to see how he influenced writers like William Faulkner. If that's not your thing, you can recite Darwin-inspired poetry and peruse any number of tracts with titles like "Why Evolution is True." What fun.

The N.H.L.'s worst fears were realized on Tuesday when Commissioner Gary Bettman informed United States Bankruptcy Court that Ice Edge Holdings had dropped out of Thursday's auction for the Phoenix Coyotes.

The Mets dedicated the Plum Room in honor of Jim Plummer, a longtime employee of the club, on Tuesday at Citi Field. Plum, who died last year at age 57, worked for the Mets for 31 years. Instead of having a Green Room for visitors to use, the Mets decided to have a Plum Room that would honor Plummer.

Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, is expected to remain as chairman of the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, Senate officials said Tuesday night, rather than succeed the late Edward M. Kennedy as head of the health panel.

This week's Minimalist column -- mussels with pasta and beans -- derives much on the taste-o-meter from the mussels; the better the mussels, the better the dish. This doesn't mean you shouldn't make it with farm-raised mussels, but that if you can find really good wild mussels, you'll eat more happily. (Of course you'll spend more time washing the mussels, but hey, everything has a price.)

Debit cards fees have become a major source of revenue for banks as their profits from other business shrink. For consumers, the quickly mounting fees -- as much as $35 for each overdraft -- can become a financial disaster. Some in Congress have noted that this practice is particularly harmful for low-income and elderly consumers who often don't know that they are being charged. But bankers say that overdraft service and fees can be easily avoided if consumers simply don't spend more than what's in their checking accounts.

The thrill of upsetting the French Open juniors champion lasted only one round for the American teenager Tennys Sandgren of Gallatin, Tenn. He lost to New Zealand's Sebastian Lavie, 7-6 (4), 7-6 (5), in the second round of the United States Open junior championships.

In an announcement to developers last week, Google said it would improve the mobile-apps market for its Android smartphone OS to make shopping on it easier.
The team with the best record in the American League decides which division series schedule it wants. One series includes a day off between Games 1 and 2, the other does not.

On Monday afternoon, the easterly wave I referenced on Friday (was inland over western Africa then) was upgraded to Tropical Depression 7, and was further upgraded to Tropical Storm Fred just 6 hours later. Since then, Fred has continued to get better organized and the latest intensity is 60kts and 990mb. It is located about 350 miles southwest of the Cape Verde islands and tracking west at 12kts.

HP wants you to print more, which is not exactly surprising given the company's profitable ink and toner business. The future of Senator Max Baucus's compromise health care proposal is far from certain, but one industry group was quick to fire back on Tuesday. The protest came from makers of medical devices like heart pacemakers and artificial hips - companies that would have to pay hefty new fees under the Baucus plan.

President Obama met privately in the Oval Office on Tuesday afternoon with the top two Congressional leaders and renewed his pledge to achieve an overhaul of the nation's health care system this year, a goal that will require Democrats to bridge a considerable gulf inside their party over the scope and shape of the legislation.

Most arguments against the public option are based either on deliberate misrepresentation of what that option would mean, or on remarkably thorough misunderstanding of the concept, which persists to a frustrating degree: I was really surprised to see Joe Klein worrying about the creation of a system in which doctors work directly for the government, British-style, when that has nothing whatsoever to do with the public option as proposed. The Belgian designer Dries Van Noten is famously allergic to the spotlight. Ironic, then, that the more he eschews the attention, the more he is celebrated. Van Noten, who last year received the C.F.D.A. award for International Designer of the Year, is being honored tomorrow in New York by the Couture Council of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology (F.I.T.) with its 2009 Award for Artistry of Fashion. (The award was chosen by the Couture Council Advisory Committee, whose members include Dr. Valerie Steele, director and chief curator of the Museum at F.I.T.; Pamela Golbin, curator of the Musée de la Mode; and Julie Gilhart of Barneys New York, among others.) The Moment caught up with Van Noten on the eve of his latest accolade.

William (Boots) Del Biaggio III is sentenced to more than 8 years in prison by a U.S. district court judge in San Francisco for bilking money from investors and using it to support a lavish lifestyle, including some $20 million to buy a 24 percent share of the Nashville Predators in 2007. The 41-year-old Silicon Valley investment banker who once owned a stake in the San Jose Sharks tearfully told the court that he promised to pay back the millions he stole from investors in fraudulent deals. Del Biaggio, who was ordered to begin his prison term in January, pleaded guilty to one count of securities fraud earlier this year.

Juan Martin del Potro does not move as if he bears the burden of being so tall. He arrives so quickly to the ball and prepares his racket so early that it might as well have been sitting there waiting for a bus.

A drinks tray breathes life into a room. It is so easy to put together, and it immediately gives a living room the sense that living indeed goes on there. Much like bookcases, a drinks tray adds depth, is welcoming to the visitor and gives a few clues to the tastes of the inhabitants. A table with a lamp is a good start, and from there add bottles and acouterments. A few dusty, rarely used bottles are never appealing, but a sense of abundance (e.g., plenty of mixers) is. For me the point is hospitality, socializing and having a martini - the way you like it - in the comfort of your own home, where you can really sink back and have a good conversation. This is just so much more comfortable than being jostled in a bar with a second-rate beverage, thinning ice and the mandatory lime garnish stuffed on the side of the glass.

John Lydon, the former frontman for the Sex Pistols, who is better known as Johnny Rotten, told The Guardian newspaper that his band Public Image Limited, or PiL, is back after a 17-year break. Though fans will have to do without two original band members, Jah Wobble and Keith Levene, the guitarist Lu Edmonds returns in the reincarnation, along with the drummer Bruce Smith. A five-date tour is to begin in December with a new member, Scott Firth, and a couple of other changes, it seems. “It feels clean,” Mr. Lydon, above, said of the band’s revised sound. “It’s refreshing. The Sex Pistols were too rigid. PiL allowed me to express proper emotions.” The tour coincides with the 30th anniversary of the release of PiL’s album “Metal Box.” Tour dates and locations can be found at pilofficial.com.

The PEN American Center has announced the winners of the 2009 Beyond Margins Award, which honors outstanding books by minority writers. Uwem Akpan (“Say You’re One of Them”), Juan Felipe Herrera (“Half of the World in Light: New and Selected Poems”) and Lily Hoang (“Changing”) are each to receive a $1,000 award at a celebration hosted by the National Book Critics Circle president, Jane Ciabattari, on Dec. 2 at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in SoHo.

New York City Opera is to announce plans on Tuesday to extend its Opera for All program into the 2009-10 season. The program offers 25 percent of tickets, about 600 per performance, at lower prices, ranging from $12 to $145. The offer includes 50 to 75 orchestra seats to be sold for $25 in the week of the performance. Tickets for the new season, the first under the new general manager and artistic director, George Steel, will be available beginning on Tuesday (nycopera.com).

The singer and actress Deborah Cox, last seen on Broadway in “Aida” in 2004, has been cast in the title role of “Josephine,” the Broadway-bound musical based on the life of the exotic legend of the Paris music halls, Josephine Baker, the show’s producers announced. Joey McKneely, fresh from reviving Jerome Robbins’s original choreography for this year’s “West Side Story,” is set to direct and choreograph. Steve Dorff is to supply a score, with lyrics by John Bettis and a book by Ellen Weston and Mark Hampton. The theater, dates and additional casting for the production are to be announced later. ... Tom Cavanagh, best known for his role as Ed in the television show of the same name, is to join Elaine Stritch in a reading of the Ben Andron play “White’s Lies,” about Joe White, a handsome and charming ladies’ man whose life changes when his dying mother requests a grandchild, the show’s publicists announced. The reading will take place on Sept. 24 at 3 p.m. at the Jerry Orbach Theater at the Snapple Theater Center on Broadway, with direction by Bob Cline.

He leaves his wife, Libby (Johnson); his daughter, Betsey Taft McCarthy and her husband, Billy; his son Ben and his fiancee, Lisa Spinelli; his granddaughter, Fiona Taft McCarthy; and his sister, Betsey Taft Colby and her husband, Bill. He is also survived by brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law, nieces, a nephew and several great-nieces and great-nephews. For further information visit www.milesfuneralhome.com

DAVIS--Edward Shippen, of New York City died on August 28, at his home in The Springs, East Hampton. Born at New York Hospital January 23, 1932 of Wendell Davis and Lavinia Riker Davis, he was a graduate of Pomfret School, Harvard College, and the Harvard Law School. His professional life centered around his partnership as a corporate lawyer with Hughes Hubbard & Reed. He served for a number of years as a Director of Hillenbrand Industries and Cognitronics Corporation. Ned had a lifelong commitment to educational issues, serving as a member and later president of the Board of Trustees of Collegiate School, a life Trustee of Pomfret School, and most recently a Director of the Bronx Charter School for Children in Mott Haven. To the end of his life he was actively involved as a member of the Executive Committee of Doctors of the World-USA as it achieved its transition to the independent entity HealthRight International. Ned is survived by his wife of 29 years, Barbara Thompson Davis, and his daughter Martha Knapp Davis. He was predeceased by his son Edward Shippen Davis, Jr. He was the attentive stepfather of Tamur and Daniyal Mueenuddin, their wives Lauren Ingram and Cecilie Brenden. He also left three young grandsons. With the support of East End Hospice, his family was able to be with him to the end. The funeral service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street on Thursday, September 10 at 4pm. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to East End Hospice, Westhampton Beach, NY.

The breath of people with lung cancer is different from that of healthy people -- it contains higher concentrations of alkanes and other volatile organic compounds. Researchers have known this for years and have tried to develop breath-sensing systems that could diagnose the disease, as an alternative to CT scans and other current diagnostic methods. The systems have tended to be costly, requiring complicated equipment and techniques to concentrate the compounds so they reach detectable levels.

Responding to South Korean demands for an explanation of a dam release that created a flash flood in which at least three South Koreans died, North Korea said Monday that it had been forced to act ''urgently'' after water levels at the dam became dangerously high. South Korea said the explanation ''does not satisfy us'' and failed to mention the casualties. North Korea unleashed columns of water from its Hwanggang Dam, 26 miles north of the border, without warning on Sunday morning, sweeping away six South Koreans who were camping or fishing downstream. Three bodies were found on Monday.

FURMAN--Rosemary Frankel, 72, passed away on Monday after an 11-year battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Tall, elegant, and beautiful to the end, Rosemary exhibited a remarkable zest for life and humanitarian pursuits. After earning a Bachelor's Degree from Barnard College and a Master's degree in English Literature from the University of Miami and a career as an accomplished journalist, she went on to get a law degree in her 40s. She used that degree to help those most in need, specializing in victims' rights and first amendment cases. Rosemary won a landmark case against the city of Miami in defense of day laborers. A driven philanthropist, Rosemary served on the Boards of Barnard College, the Aspen Music Festival, and several social service organizations in Miami. In 2001, she created the Rosemary F. Furman Counseling Center at Barnard College, which employs 14 full-time counselors and tends to more than 35 percent of the student population each year. Rosemary loved the outdoors, an avid hiker and sports enthusiast. She leaves behind a husband of 51 years, Richard, two daughters, Katherine Pasik and Lizabeth Sandler, their husbands Timothy Pasik and Randal Sandler, and five wonderful grandchildren- William, Aerin, and Jessica Pasik and Margaret and Theodore Sandler. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation, www.alzdiscovery.org.

Our heartfelt condolences go out to his wife Rosalind, his sons Clifford and Nicholas, his daughters-in-law Kim and Regina, and his grandson Henry.

The group headed by the Canadian billionaire James L. Balsillie, which is seeking to buy the Phoenix Coyotes and move them to Hamilton, Ontario, increased its bid by $30 million on Monday, bringing the total value of its offer to $242.5 million. In documents filed with United States Bankruptcy Court, PSE Sports and Entertainment's revised offer includes a $50 million payment to the city of Glendale that would allow the Coyotes to break their 30-year lease at Jobing.com Arena. The city had asserted in previous documents that the departure of the Coyotes would cost it more than $500 million in damages.

The killing of a state legislative candidate, his wife and their two children in their home in Tabasco State on Saturday appears not to have been drug related, as authorities originally suspected. Three young suspects arrested Sunday, and a fourth who was being sought, intended to burglarize the home of the candidate, José Francisco Fuentes Esperón, 43, and steal his Hummer, authorities said. ''Our intention was never to kill them, but everything got out of control,'' one of the suspects, Ricardo Hernández Rodríguez, 18, said in a videotaped confession.

ROSENBERG--Gerald A.,65, a lawyer who split his time between his private practice and public service to the city where he was raised, died at home in New York on September 5, 2009. He is survived by his wife, Rosalind, his sons Clifford and Nicholas, his daughters-in-law Kim Mack Rosenberg and Regina Park, and his grandson Henry. For nearly three decades he was a partner at Rosenman and Colin (now Katten Muchin Rosenman), a firm he joined in 1975. From 2004 through 2007, he served as Chief of the Charities Bureau of the New York State Department of Law. In 2007, he became of counsel to the firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb and Tyler. An enthusiastic golfer, hiker and rollerblader, Gerry was a witty raconteur and writer who loved a good political debate, never missed a worthwhile play and was equally at home discussing Russian Constructivism or the finer points of estate law. He also traveled widely, enjoying especially his farmhouse in France. Gerry's civic roles reflected his commitment to legal justice and his deep affection for New York and its parks. He was a Life Member of the American Law Institute, and a director of New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, the Parks Council (now New Yorkers for Parks) and the Central Park Conservancy. He was a founding director of the Non-Profit Coordinating Committee of New York and a director of the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law. Memorial Service, Thursday, September 10, 6pm. Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City.

COHEN--Joel. We mourn the passing of Joel Emmet Cohen A"H, age 57, beloved son of Norman (A"H) and Floreva Cohen, wonderful husband of Jennifer Briggs Cohen, loving father of Alexandra Cohen, Nora Cohen, Nina Cohen and Jessica Cohen, brother of Ruvan Cohen, Jeremy Cohen and Saradee Cohen Fortgang. A prolific songwriter and guitarist, Joel found expression of his deep Jewish soul in music, both liturgical and folk, and in being the senior member of the Cohen Family choir on the High Holidays at the Homowack Hotel and more recently at the Rye Town Hilton. His voice and humor will be missed this year as he joins his father Norman, his brother Leser, his nephew Nathaniel and his uncles in the heavenly choir. May his memory be for a blessing. Joel was a towering figure in the field of labor law, bringing a keen sense of ethics and rectitude to the law practices of Mudge Rose, Kelley, Drye & Warren, McDermott, Will & Emery, and that he was to lead at Jones Day. He was a valued member of the Boards of CNR as its Chairman, Beth Abraham Health Services as Vice Chairman and member of The Music Institute for Neurological Impairment. Funeral will be held Tuesday, September 8th at 1pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Three days after Deputy Prime Minister Zhang Dejiang proclaimed coal mine safety to be a top priority, a gas explosion Tuesday at an unlicensed mine in Henan Province killed at least 35 workers and trapped 44 more, officials said. The explosion rocked a coal pit in the city of Pingdingshan around 1 a.m., a city spokesman told the official news agency, Xinhua, saying that 93 miners were working in the pit when the blast occurred and that 14 escaped right away. The spokesman also said the mine had been under repair and had not been cleared to resume operations. On Saturday, in remarks reported by Xinhua, Mr. Zhang called for improvements in mine safety to prevent, in particular, gas explosions. An estimated 80 percent of the 16,000 mines operating in China are illegal. Government figures show that about 3,200 people died in mining accidents last year, a 15 percent decrease from 2007.

Women can cut their risk of breast cancer by almost half if they watch their weight, exercise daily, breast-feed their babies and limit alcoholic beverages, according to a new report by the American Institute for Cancer Research. The report updates a 2007 review of more than 800 studies, adding information from 81 new studies, said Susan Higginbotham, director of research for the institute.

KABBANI--Raifah M.,PhD, 57, of Larchmont, NY, died August 27, 2009 from metastatic cancer. She will be remembered as a devoted daughter, loyal friend, supportive teacher -- a gentle, calm presence who offered her wisdom in the most delicate way. Dr. Kabbani, a faculty member of Pace University, taught general and advanced chemistry, and served as Assistant Chair of the Department of Chemistry and Physical Sciences. Born in Beirut, Lebanon in 1951, she attended the American University, where she obtained her BS and MS degrees. Dr. Kabbani arrived in NYC in 1976 to attend Fordham University, which awarded her a PhD in Chemistry in 1981. She is survived by her mother Rasha, her five brothers, Badr, Mohamad, Emad, Omar, Fouad and their families, and many close friends and colleagues. In lieu of flowers, send donations to The Raifah M. Kabbani Scholarship Fund, supporting women pursuing careers in chemistry, c/o Dr. G. Majdalany, 525 W. 120 St., Teachers College, Box 7, NYC, NY, 10027.

Here's what I wonder about Derek Jeter's pursuit: will this be the greatest record he ever sets? He will come upon round numbers -- 3,000 hits, perhaps 2,000 runs, and so on -- but what other record could the 35-year-old Jeter break? He used to talk about breaking Yogi Berra's record of 10 World Series rings, but that seems impossible now. Joe DiMaggio's 56-game hitting streak is probably unassailable for anyone, and with a career-high streak of 25 (in 2006), Jeter will probably never chase it.

LET us begin the school year by stating the obvious: American handwriting is in a woeful state. Schools' insistence on teaching looped cursive handwriting has left a generation of Americans with script they dislike or is often illegible. The Palmer method and subsequent 20th-century methods were based on an ornate style that was difficult to learn and broke down under pressure. The loops and curlicues of Palmer and other similar methods obscure legibility. For good reason, one rarely finds looped cursive in print media or computer fonts. We have become a ''Please Print'' nation. Even worse, we have failed to find a replacement.

GONZALEZ--Eduardo M.,M.D., passed away at St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan on August 26th, 2009. He is survived by his sister Maria, his niece Maria and nephews Manuel and Eduardo, and his cousins. He devoted his professional lifetime to St. Vincent's as a surgeon, and was the long-time chairman of emergency medicine and a past president of the medical staff. As a young man he served as a lieutenant in the US Navy. There will be a Mass of Christian Burial at St. Vincent's Hospital on Wednesday, September 9th at 10am. Interment will be in Puerto Rico.

KAPNER--Stanley H.,died on September 6, 2009 at age 90. He retired as Director of Public Affairs at Time Inc. in 1979. Previously, he was the company's chief public affairs officer in the United Kingdom. A Magna cum Laude graduate of Harvard College (1940), Kapner immediately began writing film documentaries in Los Angeles. He enlisted in the U.S. Navy during World War II, held the rank of Ensign after completing Japanese Language School, and saw action in the Pacific Theater. He was a freelance writer in Paris prior to joining Time in 1955. He is survived by Catherine Segal Kapner, his wife of 57 years; a daughter-in-law, Paola; two granddaughters, Julia and Sveva, of Milan; and a niece, Karen K. Hyman, of Illinois. His son Frederic, a journalist, predeceased him in 2005. An excellent speechwriter, as well as author of plays and short fiction, Kapner was a mentor to many who benefited from his precise editorial eye. A memorial service is being planned.

JOHNSON--Dr. Warren David, 56, died suddenly at his home on September 5th in New York City. After completing his Ph.D. at Columbia University, Warren joined the Dalton School where he taught for the past 19 years and where he served several consecutive terms as Department Chair of High School English. Warren was also President of the Faculty Association. Proud parishioner of Saint Thomas Church, Warren was actively involved in many aspects of church life, most recently as Head Acolyte. Predeceased by his father Mervin Johnson; survived by his mother Winnifred Johnson; his sisters Mary Jackson and Ellen Johnson; Mary's husband Jim and Ellen's partner, Leslie Strickler; his niece Laura and his nephews Phil and Sean. Warren will be deeply missed by his many students, colleagues and wonderful friends whose lives he touched during the 30 years that he lived in New York City. Funeral service will be held on Friday, September 11, 2009 at 1:30pm at Saint Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd St., New York. Reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions should be made in Warren's memory to The Dalton School, 108 E. 89th St., New York, NY 10128. A Memorial service will be held at the school on a future date.

Earlier this year, researchers at Cincinnati Children’s Hospital published the most detailed and revealing case study to date of an anterior cruciate ligament rupture waiting to happen in a young girl. The study grew out of the researchers’ ongoing, large-scale examination of ACL-tear risk factors, which had enrolled hundreds of young, female athletes, measured and monitored them, and assigned some to prevention training programs. The girl in the case report hadn’t received training. She was 11 when she joined the study, a small, skinny, prepubescent basketball player. Each year, the researchers noted her height, weight, joint looseness, muscle strength, and biomechanics, using sophisticated motion-capture technology to study how she leaped and landed. At each session, as might have been expected, she’d lengthened, developing coltish legs and a slight but noticeable tendency to wobble and land knock-kneed when she hopped off of a box.
What we’re reading on Wednesday morning.

In a year of independent and obscure nominees for the Barclaycard Mercury Prize, the hip-hop artist Speech Debelle was named the winner of that prestigious British music award on Tuesday for her album “Speech Therapy,” The Associated Press reported. Ms. Debelle, 26, who said the album was inspired by a period in her life when she was homeless, won about $33,000 with the prize, which is awarded annually to the best British or Irish album of the year. The singer-songwriter Bat for Lashes and the rock band Kasabian were among the more recognizable acts to be nominated this year for the Mercury Prize, which in the past has gone to emerging British artists like PJ Harvey and Franz Ferdinand, though performers as mainstream as Radiohead (for its album “In Rainbows”) and Robert Plant and Alison Krauss (for their collaboration “Raising Sand”) have also been nominated. The A.P. said that Ms. Debelle had sold about 3,000 copies of “Speech Therapy,” half of them since the album was named as a nominee for the prize, adding that winners often see a boost in record sales.

Through its original seven-season run on Fox, starting way back in 1992, “Melrose Place” had a unique ability to pit men against women, on screen and at home: female viewers were called to account for the behavior of characters like the conniving Sydney (Laura Leighton), the insidious Amanda (Heather Locklear) and the flat-out crazy Kimberley (Marcia Cross), while male audiences were left to defend the blankfaced Billy (Andrew Shue), the stoic Jake (Grant Show) and the inscrutable Michael (Thomas Calabro).

After drawing the ire of religious conservatives with his young-adult book series “His Dark Materials,” the author Philip Pullman is again taking on potentially controversial subject matter. His next novel is to be a fictionalized account of the life of Jesus that will differ from the version presented in the New Testament, The Guardian reported. The novel, to be called “The Good Man Jesus and the Scoundrel Christ,” will address the idea that the account of Jesus’ life depicted in the gospels was largely shaped by the apostle Paul. “Paul was a literary and imaginative genius of the first order who has probably had more influence on the history of the world than any other human being,” Mr. Pullman told The Guardian. He added that the book is “among other things, a story about how stories become stories.” The book is scheduled for an Eastertime release in Britain by the Scottish publishing house Canongate; an American release was not announced.
“The Boss” and an actor who found early acclaim playing a mob boss are two of the five 2009 Kennedy Center honorees.

One day after announcing some of the performers who are to headline a tribute concert for Michael Jackson in Austria later this month, the singer’s brother Jermaine Jackson denied that Mary J. Blige and Chris Brown would be unable to attend and that the concert had lost the support of some members of the Jackson family, Reuters reported. At a press conference in London on Wednesday, Jermaine Jackson said that though Ms. Blige would be at a fashion event in Italy on Sept. 26, she would fly to Vienna to perform at the Schönbrunn Palace that night. Mr. Jackson also said that Chris Brown, who in August was sentenced to probation for assaulting the pop star Rihanna, would perform at the tribute if he is given permission to leave the United States. “It’s just up to what he’s going through with his court case right now,” Mr. Jackson said, according to Reuters. “He’s definitely going to be here.” He also said that the Jackson family matriarch, Katherine, was in favor of the concert “from the very start.”

Aside from being the last palindromic day we’ll see on the calendar until Oct. 10, 2010, Wednesday is also potentially the most momentous occasion in Beatles history since the time you learned what “Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds” really stood for: it’s the day when the band’s entire catalog is being released in newly remastered stereo and monaural versions (which The New York Times critic Allan Kozinn writes about here), along with a new video game, The Beatles: Rock Band, that’s built around the music of the Fab Four.

With help from an extensive marketing campaign, Whitney Houston has returned to the top of the Billboard album chart. “I Look to You” (Arista), her first album of new songs in seven years, sold 305,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Not everything in that marketing campaign has gone completely smoothly, however. Last week Ms. Houston apologized to fans when her voice cracked while performing in Central Park for the ABC show “Good Morning America.” But her record sales are likely to get another big boost next week when she is interviewed on “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” on Monday and Tuesday.

An appeals court has ruled that Claude Cassirer, an 88-year-old retired photographer, can continue his legal battle against a Spanish museum to reclaim an Impressionist painting that he says was stolen from his grandmother by the Nazis, The Associated Press reported. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in a ruling issued in Pasadena, Calif., said on Tuesday that Mr. Cassirer can pursue his case against the Spanish government and the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum in Madrid, where the disputed painting, “Rue St.-Honoré, Après-Midi, Effet de Pluie,” a Parisian street scene painted by Camille Pissarro in 1897, has been on display since 1993. Mr. Cassirer, who first filed suit in California district court in 2005, has said that his grandmother was forced to surrender the painting to the Nazis before she fled Munich in 1939. The Spanish government bought the painting as part of the Baron Hans-Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza’s collection, which it purchased for $338 million in 1993. The Thyssen-Bornemisza Foundation called Mr. Cassirer’s claim “totally baseless,” according to The A.P.

A trio of Broadway veterans has been tapped to direct the three musical revivals that will be presented in the coming season of New York City Center’s Encores! series. On Wednesday, the press representatives for Encores! said in a news release that Jerry Zaks, a four-time Tony Award winner (“Six Degrees of Separation,” “Lend Me a Tenor”), would direct the production of “Girl Crazy,” the George and Ira Gershwin musical, that will open the series on Nov. 19. Marc Bruni, an associate director of Broadway musicals like “Grease” and “Legally Blonde” will direct “Fanny,” which opens on Feb. 4. And Casey Nicholaw (“Monty Python’s Spamalot,” “The Drowsy Chaperone”) will direct and choreograph “Anyone Can Whistle,” the Stephen Sondheim–Arthur Laurents musical, which opens on April 8. Rob Berman will be the musical director for “Fanny” and “Anyone Can Whistle,” and Rob Fisher will serve that role for “Girl Crazy.” No casting for the shows has been announced.

With six nominations, Brad Paisley leads the finalists for the 43rd annual Country Music Association Awards, the association announced on Wednesday. Mr. Paisley is nominated for entertainer of the year and best male vocalist, as well as best album, single, song and music video. The other nominees for entertainer of the year, the top award, are Kenny Chesney, George Strait and Taylor Swift and Keith Urban.

Garrison Keillor, the folksy-voiced humorist and longtime radio host, has suffered a minor stroke, but plans to begin his new season of “A Prairie Home Companion” as scheduled, The Associated Press reported. Many readers (including Nos. 6, 28, 40 and 92) seem not to have noticed that I conceded the practical reasons for wolf hunting and argued against it only when undertaken merely as a form of entertainment, as surely many hunters do. These respondents went ahead anyway and championed hunting as a form of animal management. (I blame the schools: maybe it was that flirtation with phonics.) Incidentally, "managing" is now my favorite euphemism for "killing." I'm afraid your uncle was managed by a drunken driver. "Deranged Sociopath Goes on Cross-Country Managing Spree."I was a bit disconcerted to see several comments (Nos. 30, 34, 37) propose human-on-human hunting, which might be appealing to producers of TV reality shows but probably not to law-enforcement officials who have enough to handle without some sort of neo-dueling fad.

PERPIGNAN, France - At the beginning of the nightly screening of photographs in a cloistered graveyard here, hundreds of photographers, photo editors and others stood, as one, for a moment of silence. The day before, Wednesday, Sept. 2, the photojournalist and filmmaker Christian Poveda had been found shot in the head in El Salvador, where he was working on a project about violent gangs. After the silence, Mr. Poveda's own voice was heard at the end of a slide show of his photographs from El Salvador. "There's really nothing to fear," he said, in a recording. "I never had any problem in any of the four years that I worked there." He added, "I did not feel in danger."

Very few cars, if any, have been as eagerly anticipated as the McLaren MP4-12C, the successor to the McLaren F1, released in 1993.

It's safe to say that very few cars, if any, have been as eagerly anticipated as the McLaren MP4-12C. For all intents and purposes, it is the successor to the McLaren F1, the car that raised the bar of performance road cars -- way up -- when it was released in 1993. In fact, the F1 spawned a new supercar culture. Suddenly, exotics not only had to look good, but also perform like racecars. Without the F1 there might not be any Koenigseggs or Pagoni Zondas. And it is that culture the new McLaren will enter when it is unveiled at the Frankfurt auto show next week.

Commentary, Norman Podhoretz's work home for almost 60 years, describes its former editor (he held the position from 1960 to 1995) as a "venerable lion of disputation." The disputatious lion is famous for, among other things, his political migration from left to right in the late 1960s, and his subsequent championing of the neoconservative cause, along with his wife, Midge Decter, son John, son-in-law Elliott Abrams, fellow travelers such as Jeane Kirkpatrick, and organizations like the Committee for the Present Danger and Project for a New American Century, in addition, of course, to the pages of Commentary.

The installation of Sol LeWitt's posthumous legacy to New York City -- a major public artwork, 53 feet wide by 11 feet high and made up of 250 porcelain tiles in six colors -- has been completed inside the 59th Street-Columbus Circle subway station, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced on Wednesday.

"Versailles meets Disneyland" is how Andree Cooke, the director of Spring Projects, describes the exhibition on view Sept. 11 through Oct. 22 at her London gallery. "American Chateau: Room One" is the first public collaboration between the designer Jaime Hayon and his girlfriend, Nienke Klunder, and its campy take on excess and opulence represents a near perfect union of the couple's individual aesthetics. Hayon, the Spanish-born, London-based designer, is notorious for his exaggerated Baroque sensibility, his furniture and interiors all lacquer and candy gloss. Klunder, an American-born and Dutch-raised photographer, often meditates on distortions of female beauty - say, a series of images depicting wigged Playboy types burdened by their enormous breasts.

Slide 6 shows relatives and friends grieving over the body of Sultan Munadi, the Afghan interpreter for Stephen Farrell, a Times reporter. Mr. Farrell and Mr. Munadi were seized on Saturday by militants in northern Afghanistan. Mr. Munadi, 34, was killed in a firefight on Wednesday as commandos sought to free him and Mr. Farrell, who escaped captivity alive. Mr. Farrell said of Mr. Munadi: "He was trying to protect me up to the last minute."

Sultan Munadi is dead, and a British paratrooper whose name we may never know. There may also have been other Afghan casualties, perhaps Taliban, perhaps not; that we also don't know yet, for sure. But from where I am writing this, on a sunny autumn afternoon in rural England, the deaths of Sultan and the British commando seem like a grim black cloud darkening the landscape -- a harbinger, perhaps, for the increasingly grim news that seems to await us all from a war that seems to be worsening by the day, and heading for worse yet unless our political and military leaders can find a way to turn the situation around.

As the world's oldest, biggest oil fields slowly tap out, companies are spending ever more to drill farther afield and in deeper water to keep the world's cars and furnaces going. This has led to environmental disruption from the Amazon to the Arctic. Now, it has caused a spreading stain over hundreds of square miles of the Timor Sea between Australia and Indonesia, where oil is spilling unabated from a well drilled by PTTEP, based in Thailand. Still, for the most part, damage from oil spills happens far from the gas stations and parking lots frequented by consumers of this enduring commodity. That's one reason Peter Maass, no friend of big oil, said here last year that it was more ethical to drill in United States waters than to continue to outsource our environmental problems.

There's a phenomenal moment in "When We Were Kings," the documentary Gael Monfils has been watching throughout the Open about his hero Muhammad Ali's fight with George Foreman. It occurs after the first round, when Ali realizes that he is outmatched. The moment is noted by George Plimpton and Norman Mailer, who were covering the fight as journalists. Ali looks dazed, even momentarily afraid, but then he nods to himself and turns inward. It is the look of a champion who knows that he must suffer to have any chance of winning. And he is prepared to do so.

The consumer credit numbers that came out Tuesday are impressive. It is not that the numbers fell for one month; these figures can be volatile. But it is that the numbers are coming down repeatedly. The Saturday Profile article on Aug. 29, about Marina Silva, a prominent environmentalist in Brazil who is likely to become the Green Party candidate in presidential elections next year, misidentified the cancer for which her probable opponent, Dilma Rousseff, President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva’s chief of staff, had undergone chemotherapy in recent months. It was lymphoma, not melanoma.

An article on Aug. 22 about growing confidence among central bankers that a global economic recovery was taking shape misstated the name of the area where the bankers were gathered at the Federal Reserve’s annual retreat. It is Grand Teton National Park, not “the Grand Tetons.” (The Teton range gets its name from a single mountain known as Grand Teton.).

An article on Sunday about the American military’s search for the remains of 74,000 World War II veterans unaccounted for in Europe and the Pacific misstated the magnitude of the Battle of the Bulge in December 1944, Nazi Germany’s last major offensive against the Allies. While it was the bloodiest fighting for the United States in the war, as measured by an estimated 19,000 Americans killed, it was not the bloodiest fighting of the war. (The battle of Stalingrad, for example, which by Russian accounts claimed the lives of more than 1 million Soviet soldiers fighting the Germans, was far bigger.).

This summer, medical students from the University of Washington took a long look under the hood of the health care system they are about to inherit, and many returned to campus last week with their eyes wide open and their idealism tempered. Jacob R. Opfer shadowed a pediatrician in Gillette, Wyo., who sometimes saw 45 patients a day, allowing little more than five minutes a visit. Amanda I. Messinger worked with a family practitioner in Kodiak, Alaska, who eschewed electronic medical records, leaving staff members to decipher histories from illegible script. Jens N. Olsgaard manned a community health center in Butte, Mont., where four of five patients had no insurance, and treatment was often structured around ability to pay.

As Derek Jeter approaches Lou Gehrig's record for hits in a Yankees uniform, one question looms large in these memorabilia-obsessed times: What will happen to the ball? The short answer is that Jeter is not saying. By custom, he would have first dibs on the ball he hits to surpass Gehrig's team record of 2,721 hits. And that assumes it does not land in the stands, where the fan who retrieves it would have the right to keep it.

BIGEL--Barbara K.,age 62 of Naples, FL died September 7, 2009. Barbara had been employed by Reich and Tang. She was adored and cherished by her husband Jonathan and her stepchildren Jordan Bigel; Daniel Bigel and Deborah Hodys; her daughter-in-law Katherine Bigel; her son-in-law Al Hodys and her grandchildren Jonah, Cole and Julia. She was a gracious, kind woman, full of charity and will be sorely missed forever. www.fullerfuneralhome.com

LAWRENCE--Stephen, former president and CEO of Lawrence Metal Products, age 79, on September 6, 2009, of Huntington, New York. Beloved husband of Kathleen. Devoted father of Lisa, Shaun, Karen, David and Susanne. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Sophie, Ilana, Julia, Abby, Rachel, Benjamin, Jade and Lily. Relatives and friends are invited to a memorial service celebrating his life on Friday, 3pm, Gutterman's Funeral Home, 800 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to either the Visiting Nurse Service and Hospice of Suffolk, Inc. or The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

In Floral City, Fla., Diana Dupont was riveted by Kim Clijsters's play at the United States Open. The match on television had the haunting quality of a home movie for Dupont, especially when a shot of Clijsters's 18-month-old daughter, Jada, filled the screen. In 1945, two and a half years after Dupont was born, her mother, Sarah Palfrey Cooke, then 32, won her second United States singles championship. Cooke took great pride in having delivered her first child and second major, in that order, her daughter said. ''That was a badge of honor for her,'' Dupont said in a telephone interview.
MEYERHOFF--Inge (nee Zuber). 3/11/1932 - 9/9/2002. Loved and remembered by all who knew her. -Erich

DeFINE--Robert, 97, died September 7, 2009. A lifetime New Yorker and Fire Island resident was a WWII Naval veteran; Bob shared his life and love of dogs for over 69 years with his wife Ruth (nee Sonnenshein), deceased. Past president of the Board of Carnegie Hill 87th Corp. He was and able and effective administrator and a charming friend to all. We are grateful to Ethel McKoy for the caring devotion and friendship she extended to Bob during his last years. Kathy and Kenny.
MASON--Eli. A Memorial Service will be held on September 13, 2009 at 12 Noon at Mason Hall, Baruch College, 17 Lexington Avenue, New York City.

Kim Clijsters's two-year sabbatical from professional tennis not only gives her a fabulous comeback story to follow through this United States Open -- which now includes a trip to the semifinals after her quarterfinal victory over Li Na of China on Tuesday -- but also a good perspective on the women's game she has dropped back into with a splash. One match after sweeping Venus Williams out of the tournament in front of an electrified crowd on the Arthur Ashe Stadium court, Clijsters faced a much different opponent in a much different atmosphere Tuesday. She proceeded to storm through the match, grabbing an unlikely semifinal berth with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Li, the 18th seed.

The ''Monday's Matches'' summary on Monday with coverage of the United States Open tennis tournament referred incorrectly to the recent Grand Slam accomplishments of Caroline Wozniacki, a rising star in the sport. Over the course of 10 months in eastern Afghanistan, an Army specialist nicknamed Mud Puppy maintained a blog irreverently chronicling life at the front, from the terror of roadside bombs to the tyrannies of master sergeants. Often funny and always profane, the blog, Embrace the Suck (military slang for making the best of a bad situation), flies under the Army's radar. Not officially approved, it is hidden behind a password-protected wall because the reservist does not want his superiors censoring it.
Following are excerpts from Embrace The Suck, a password-protected blog written by an Army reservist who served nearly a year in eastern Afghanistan:

After eight months on the job as the ATP Tour's chief executive, Adam Helfant said he believed that men's tennis does not need an overhaul or even serious tinkering. It is riding a wave of success created by a dynamic set of top players, Helfant said, and that the best thing the tour could do was market that success better. That's why the first big initiative of Helfant's tenure will be an all-star event in the days leading to the tournament in Indian Wells, Calif., in March. It will most likely include skills competitions, celebrity doubles matches and an awards show, a made-for-TV extravaganza reminiscent of an N.B.A. or N.H.L. All-Star weekend.
