Deutsche Telekom and France Télécom said Tuesday that they planned to merge their struggling mobile operations in Britain, creating the largest mobile operator there. The 50-50 joint venture between the companies, the third- and fourth-largest operators in Britain, would have 28.4 million customers and a 37 percent market share, according to the technology research firm Gartner. It would overtake the market leader, O2, which has 27 percent of the market, and Vodafone, with 25 percent. Deutsche Telekom and France Télécom said they expected to sign an agreement by the end of next month.

When Peter Means returned to graduate school after a career as a civil servant, he turned to a debit card to help him spend his money more carefully. So he was stunned when his bank charged him seven $34 fees to cover seven purchases when there was not enough cash in his account, notifying him only afterward. He paid $4.14 for a coffee at Starbucks -- and a $34 fee. He got the $6.50 student discount at the movie theater -- but no discount on the $34 fee. He paid $6.76 at Lowe's for screws -- and yet another $34 fee. All told, he owed $238 in extra charges for just a day's worth of activity.

On sun-soaked tennis courts Tuesday afternoon, tweens and young teens thwacked balls as their coaches sporadically name-dropped to emphasize an instructional point. Melanie, they would say, as in Oudin -- no surname necessary. Melanie Oudin, the 17-year-old who has taken United States Open hearts hostage, is one of them, a student of her coach Brian de Villiers's tennis institute at the Racquet Club of the South, and any lesson that references her is most likely absorbed.

OLFF--Joseph Vincent. Born at home in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, NY, July 15, 1926, died at the VA Hospital in Castle Point, NY of lung cancer on September 4, 2009. He was 83 years old. In his youth he was a Golden Gloves Boxer for P.A.L. He graduated from Brooklyn Technical High School and served in WWII in the U.S. Army infantry during campaigns in France, Belgium and Germany. His father emigrated from Suriname and his mother, an American Indian, is the central figure in the Norman Rockwell painting: The Golden Rule. Mr. Olff worked for the New York Times as a Compositor for over 35 years and was a member of The Typographical Union. An accomplished tennis and squash player, member of AKC, who bred, trained and raised German Shepherds, he was also a horseman, whose horse Sparky, won a ribbon at Saratoga. He leaves his ex-wife of 27 years Regina Rosa Olff, the mother of his children; Nina Lydia Olff, Anton Carl Olff and Julia Adriane Olff, two granddaughters; Maxine Natasha Paul and Jessie Rose Luterbach as well as younger brothers, two sisters, nieces and nephews. He leaves his wife Sarah of Lexington, Kentucky.

FURMAN--Rosemary Frankel, 72, passed away on Monday after an 11-year battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Tall, elegant, and beautiful to the end, Rosemary exhibited a remarkable zest for life and humanitarian pursuits. After earning a Bachelor's Degree from Barnard College and a Master's degree in English Literature from the University of Miami and a career as an accomplished journalist, she went on to get a law degree in her 40s. She used that degree to help those most in need, specializing in victims' rights and first amendment cases. Rosemary won a landmark case against the city of Miami in defense of day laborers. A driven philanthropist, Rosemary served on the Boards of Barnard College, the Aspen Music Festival, and several social service organizations in Miami. In 2001, she created the Rosemary F. Furman Counseling Center at Barnard College, which employs 14 full-time counselors and tends to more than 35 percent of the student population each year. Rosemary loved the outdoors, an avid hiker and sports enthusiast. She leaves behind a husband of 51 years, Richard, two daughters, Katherine Pasik and Lizabeth Sandler, their husbands Timothy Pasik and Randal Sandler, and five wonderful grandchildren- William, Aerin, and Jessica Pasik and Margaret and Theodore Sandler. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation, www.alzdiscovery.org.

ROSENBERG--Gerald A.,65, a lawyer who split his time between his private practice and public service to the city where he was raised, died at home in New York on September 5, 2009. He is survived by his wife, Rosalind, his sons Clifford and Nicholas, his daughters-in-law Kim Mack Rosenberg and Regina Park, and his grandson Henry. For nearly three decades he was a partner at Rosenman and Colin (now Katten Muchin Rosenman), a firm he joined in 1975. From 2004 through 2007, he served as Chief of the Charities Bureau of the New York State Department of Law. In 2007, he became of counsel to the firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb and Tyler. An enthusiastic golfer, hiker and rollerblader, Gerry was a witty raconteur and writer who loved a good political debate, never missed a worthwhile play and was equally at home discussing Russian Constructivism or the finer points of estate law. He also traveled widely, enjoying especially his farmhouse in France. Gerry's civic roles reflected his commitment to legal justice and his deep affection for New York and its parks. He was a Life Member of the American Law Institute, and a director of New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, the Parks Council (now New Yorkers for Parks) and the Central Park Conservancy. He was a founding director of the Non-Profit Coordinating Committee of New York and a director of the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law. Memorial Service, Thursday, September 10, 6pm. Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City.

In Floral City, Fla., Diana Dupont was riveted by Kim Clijsters's play at the United States Open. The match on television had the haunting quality of a home movie for Dupont, especially when a shot of Clijsters's 18-month-old daughter, Jada, filled the screen. In 1945, two and a half years after Dupont was born, her mother, Sarah Palfrey Cooke, then 32, won her second United States singles championship. Cooke took great pride in having delivered her first child and second major, in that order, her daughter said. ''That was a badge of honor for her,'' Dupont said in a telephone interview.

PIKE--Constance Alliott, of Old Lyme, died on September 5, 2009, in Boston. She was born on March 10, 1926, in New York City, the daughter of Laurence G. and Eleanor Parker Payson. She was the widow of William M. Pike, predeceased her in 1984. Mrs. Pike was a graduate of the Westover School and Bennington College. Throughout her life Connie was committed to her family, to her friends, to education and the love of learning, to community and the responsibilities of citizenship, to social justice and to the preservation of open space and the environment. In Old Lyme, the community she called her home, she found expression of these values through her work and leadership of the School Volunteer Program, the Phoebe Griffin Noyes Library, the Old Lyme Children's Learning Center and the Old Lyme Conservation Trust. She used her ever-quick mind, her sense of humor, her resilience and her perseverance to create new possibilities for those around her. She was thrilled by the election of President Obama last fall and found comfort in the hope he represents. Connie faced illness as she faced life, with courage and without complaint and died with grace and dignity. Her family thanks her legions of friends for their love and support and the staffs of the Visiting Nurse Association of Boston and of Sherrill House in Boston for their expert care giving. Connie is survived by her son William H. Pike of Reston, VA; her daughter Adele W. Pike and her husband John F. Hodgman of Brookline, MA; her brother Phillips H. Payson of Washington, CT; her step-grandson John K. Hodgman and his wife Katherine Fletcher of Brooklyn, NY and she was "ConniePike" to her step- great-grandchildren Lucy E. and James F. K. Hodgman. Survivors also include a first cousin, Nancy Payson O'Brien and her husband, William, of Newton, MA, 12 nieces and nephews and 17 great-nieces and great-nephews. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 12th at 4:30pm in The First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, Lyme St., Old Lyme, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in Connie's memory may be made to the Phoebe Griffin Noyes Library, 2 Library Ln., Old Lyme, CT 06371 or to Old Lyme Children's Learning Center, 57 Lyme St., Old Lyme, CT 06371.

Having been absent from his band for five days, James Allan, the lead singer of the Scottish rock group Glasvegas, told his band mates that he would rejoin them in time for an American tour, The Times of London reported. Though the group was nominated for the Mercury Prize for its debut album, “Glasvegas,” Mr. Allan was not present at the award ceremony held Tuesday evening in London. At that time, the band’s bass guitarist, Paul Donaghue, told The Daily Record newspaper that Mr. Allan was “missing in action” and had not been seen since Glasvegas returned from a trip to Italy. “The rest of us got in one taxi and that was the last we saw of him,” Mr. Donaghue told The Daily Record. The Times of London said that James Allan spoke with the other members of Glasvegas on Tuesday to say that he had traveled to New York, and would appear with the band on Friday, when it is scheduled to perform in Mansfield, Mass.

At 6 p.m. On a Saturday. In Toronto’s cavernous Ryerson Theater.

Outside of the catalog of 2 Live Crew, it’s hard to imagine a song more inappropriate for a high school glee club than Kanye West’s “Gold Digger” — but the young misfits of the Fox comedy “Glee” somehow made it work on Wednesday’s episode. Yes, the lyrics are ridiculously bowdlerized, and yes, it’s a little bizarre to hear an ensemble of teenagers chanting “We want prenup!” But it’s kind of infectious — at least as much as the glee-club cover of Salt-N-Pepa’s “Push It” that came later in the show.

It’s not all gloom and doom in the classical music world: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra announced that it had extended the contract of its music director, Manfred Honeck, through the 2015-2016 season. In a news release, the orchestra said that Mr. Honeck’s current contract, which began in September 2008, was originally set to expire after three years. Mr. Honeck, who became the orchestra’s full-time music director in January 2007, holds that same title with the Staatsoper Stuttgart and is the principal guest conductor of the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra in Prague. Also, The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported that the chairman of the orchestra’s board, Richard P. Simmons, gave the group a check for $1 million at the end of a board meeting on Tuesday. The donation, part of a larger gift made by the Simmons family in 2006, gives $1 million to the orchestra’s endowment for every $5 million it raises in its current capital campaign, up to a maximum of $5 million. The orchestra will receive a further $17.5 million if it balances its budget for three consecutive seasons.

The National Portrait Gallery in London on Thursday unveiled the latest addition to its collection by the artist Marc Quinn: a cast of the artist’s head, made from his frozen blood. Agence France-Presse reported that Mr. Quinn created the work, called “Self,” in 2006 using about nine or ten pints of his blood. It is the fourth in a larger series that Mr. Quinn has been working on since 1991, in which he creates a new cast of his head every five years to document his aging process. The artist told Agence France-Presse that his desire to create the casts “came from wanting to push portraiture to an extreme, a representation which not only has the form of the sitter, but is actually made from the sitter’s flesh.” The National Portrait Gallery paid about $500,000 for the 2006 sculpture. A display at the gallery describes the work as being comprised of “blood (artist’s), stainless steel, glass, perspex and refrigeration equipment.”

The school year has begun, and earlier this week President Obama talked to students across the nation about the importance of persisting and succeeding in school. He challenged them to work hard, set educational goals and take responsibility for their learning. "We need every single one of you to develop your talents, skills and intellect so you can help solve our most difficult problems," the president said to a group of students at Virginia's Wakefield High School. "If you don't do that - if you quit on school - you're not just quitting on yourself, you're quitting on your country."

I am back, once again this week, to mortality, aging, time's passage, loss. These preoccupations have, perhaps, always been with me in one form or another - the curse of a personality that always links happiness inextricably to loss - but they were given a new, particularly painful and acute edge earlier this summer when my friend Valérie, age 44, mother of two, suddenly died. And they became inescapable over the course of the past three weeks as we went on vacation to France, saw Valerie's husband, Claude - suddenly gray and bearded, suddenly smoking - and reconnected to the part of ourselves that is rooted in that country, and that resolutely refuses to budge and come settle, with any sort of commitment, in our "real" life in Washington.

The enterprising Arctic voyage of two German cargo carriers, the Beluga Foresight and Beluga Fraternity, is nearing its end. The ships, departing Siberia, are poised to complete the last leg of a journey that began in Ulsan, South Korea, in late July as they take 3,500 tons of cargo to Rotterdam later this month. In doing so they will complete the first known commercial shipment from Asia to Europe via the Arctic -- a centuries-old dream of mariners, after nearly 500 years of dreaming about such a trade route.

For all the inroads made by hipsters in Greenpoint, Brooklyn's northernmost neighborhood, it has retained much of its Old World Polish character and working-class grit (probably because its subway is the much-loathed G train). It's a great place to fill up on tasty, shockingly cheap Polish food - kielbasa, pirogi and bigos, the cabbage and meat stew widely considered Poland's national dish - and to poke about the arty boutiques and bars that have sprouted on the side streets off Manhattan Avenue, the main commercial vein. To eat and explore, take the G train to Nassau Avenue or Greenpoint Avenue, and if you are really keen, print out a Polish primer from greenpunkt.com, a local blog.

The elegant, whimsical and sometimes haunting bronze sculptures by the French artists Claude and François-Xavier Lalanne are the latest addition to the ongoing outdoor sculpture program on Park Avenue. Beginning Sept. 13, eight Lalanne sculptures will grace the avenue's median until Nov. 20, in an exhibition sponsored by the New York City Parks Public Art Program in conjunction with the Paul Kasmin Gallery and in cooperation with the Park Avenue Sculpture Committee. This is the first major outdoor show of the Lalannes' work (François-Xavier died last year), which is collected by design-world luminaries like Jacques Grange and Reed Krakoff. The sculptures, which will be installed between 52nd and 57th Streets, include some of the artists' best-known pieces, including a flock of François-Xavier's famous sheep and Claude's "Choupatte," a anthropomorphized bronze cabbage standing on bird legs, as well as her "Pomme de New York," a really big apple.

Gone are the days when college students called home once a week for a stilted conversation where lots of questions were asked but few were answered. In fact many colleges don't even offer the option of phones in dorm rooms, now that students all carry their own. Today communication is done by scattershot cell phone calls and text messages, or by e-mail, iChat, IM, and (when your kids don't block you) Facebook. All that leads to a slew of tactical parenting questions that earlier generations never faced.

An obituary by The Associated Press on Aug. 6 about Nikolaos Makarezos, one of three ringleaders of the military coup that overthrew the democratic government of Greece in 1967, misstated the reason for his 1975 death sentence, which was later commuted to life imprisonment. He was sentenced on grounds of mutiny, not treason. (He was already serving a sentence of life imprisonment for treason.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message when the obituary appeared; this correction was delayed while The A.P. researched Greek court documents.

An article on Wednesday about Palm’s release of the Pixi, a version of its Pre smartphone aimed at younger users, misspelled the surname of the company’s chief executive. He is Jonathan J. Rubinstein, not Rubenstein.

The Rooms article last Thursday, about the Merce Cunningham rehearsal dance studio on Bethune Street in the West Village, referred incorrectly to plans for the studio, the dance school and the company itself to shut down. The closing is expected to take place after the company completes a final tour, which would likely take at least two years; the closing will not be “sometime in the next two years.” (Mr. Cunningham, a revolutionary American choreographer, died at his home in Manhattan, at age 90, on July 26.).
The listing of lottery results on Wednesday misstated Tuesday’s winning Mega Millions numbers. They are 4, 10, 18, 28, 50, and mega ball, 35.

An article on Saturday about White House visitor logs misstated the outcome of a court case the Bush administration filed in an effort to shield the names of people who met with an energy task force led by former Vice President Dick Cheney. The Supreme Court ruled for the administration — not against it — in 2004, and a federal appeals court later dismissed a lawsuit seeking the records. (A list of people who met with the task force was eventually made public in 2007 when a former Bush administration official provided it to The Washington Post.).

An article on Friday about analysts who said that China has had difficulty dissuading leaders of neighboring Myanmar from renewing fighting with rebels there misstated the timing and the site of a reported meeting between officials from the two countries. It is the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety, not the AAA Foundation for Highway Safety.

Before a hall filled with his friends, protégés and occasional competitors, the late CBS anchorman Walter Cronkite was remembered at a memorial service on Wednesday for upholding a journalistic standard that is, President Obama said, ''a little bit harder to find today.'' Calling Mr. Cronkite ''the man who chronicled our time,'' Mr. Obama was among more than a dozen speakers at the service, at Lincoln Center, one that felt at times like a class reunion for television news.

ROSENBERG--Gerald A. The firm of Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler LLP marks with great sadness the death of our colleague Gerald A. Rosenberg. Gerry was a valued member of our tax-exempt organizations group, an outstanding lawyer, and a leader in the profession. We honor and will remember Gerry's wise counsel, his wit, and his unwavering commitment to service. We extend our condolences to his wife, Rosalind, his sons, Clifford and Nicholas, his daughters-in-law, Kim and Regina, his grandson, Henry, and the other members of his family.

Watching the Steelers can cause an eight-track flashback. The timeless black uniforms, blitzing linebackers, gunslinger quarterback and ever-present Lombardi Trophy make the decades between Terry Bradshaw and Ben Roethlisberger melt away. The Titans' offense also brings a mellow glow to your mood ring. The Titans run the ball more than half the time, a tactic long forgotten in the Spread Century. The Titans allowed only 234 points last season, but their defense won't be as stout without defensive tackle Albert Haynesworth blasting through double teams.

LERNER--Mauricio, M.D. The medical staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Mauricio Lerner. Dr. Lerner was a pediatrician for over 50 years. He was well-loved by all his colleagues and patients. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his wife, children and grandchildren. W. Wexelman, M.D. President H Wasserman, M.D. Pres-elect E. Fitzpatrick, M.D. Secretary G. Neiderman, M.D. Treasurer

SADOWSKY--George, died peacefully on September 7, 2009. He was 97 years old. A resident of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Manhattan. Devoted husband of 50 years to Ruth; loving father of Carol Krinsky and Jane Platt (Ed) and adoring grandpa to Mitchell and Paul Krinsky, Jennifer Ceisler (David), Julie Marquez (Darin); great-grandpa to Sam, Maggie, Rosie, Madelyn and Bennett. George was president of Carol Jane Creations, manufacturing costume jewelry for 30 years. He was a longtime member of Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, NY, the Town Club in Manhattan and the East Pointe Country Club in Florida. Services were private. Contributions in George's memory can be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

Dr. Roger A. Rosenblatt, 64, is the director of the Rural/Underserved Opportunities Program at the University of Washington School of Medicine. The program sends rising second-year students to practice primary care in needy communities for a month each summer. ''As a family physician and medical educator for the last 35 years, I have waited a long time for our country to provide a medical care system that works for all the members of our society,'' Dr. Rosenblatt wrote. ''President Obama's approach is based on common sense: our nation's health depends as much on an inclusive and effective health care system for everyone as the health of our children depends upon their being able to get medical care when and where they need it. The time has come to realize that we are all in this together, and that health of each individual depends on the well-being of all of us.''

SINCOFF--Milton. The attorneys at Kreindler and Kreindler mourn the loss of our partner and dear friend Milton G. Sincoff, who passed away Monday evening after a brief illness. Milt served in the Army during the Korean war and joined the firm shortly after it was founded by Harry and Lee Kreindler. Milt became involved in the firm's fledgling and novel aviation practice and established himself as one of the most respected and admired aviation trial lawyers in the nation. He tried and won many notable and record setting cases, including the Texasgulf Aviation crash at the Westchester County Airport, which resulted in the then highest wrongful death damages award, and the Korean Airlines 007 shoot down over the Soviet Union where he established that the airline was guilty of willful misconduct which was necessary to recover full damages. Milt was a brilliant trial lawyer, an excellent teacher, and a man of integrity, strength and wisdom. He was a member of our firm for 50 years and was a mentor to us all. We will miss him greatly. Milt is survived by his wife Elaine, his daughter Amy and his son, Brian.

Elaine H. Carl, 72, who lives at the Sunrise Lakes retirement village in Sunrise, Fla., said she liked ''part of his speech'' but did not think that Americans should be required to buy insurance. Ms. Carl said some of her fears about Medicare had been at least temporarily soothed. ''I do believe what he's saying, that nothing will be taken from us,'' she wrote. ''But I don't know; I still have my qualms. It's so easy to say one thing and then turn around and do another. People have been hurt so many times by listening to what has been promised, and they end up in a sinkhole. I'm still very much afraid. I don't know where the money is going to come from to pay for all of these things.''

This is a blog post written last week by Sultan Munadi, an Afghan journalist with The New York Times who was abducted Saturday in Afghanistan with Stephen Farrell, a Times correspondent, and then killed Wednesday during a raid that freed Mr. Farrell. KABUL, Afghanistan -- I grew up in the Panjshir Valley, in a place that is a three-hour walk from the nearest road. We don't have a lot of iron there, we don't have concrete, we don't have these artificial things. It's a completely natural place.

WINDELS--Paul, Jr. The partners and staff of Windels Marx Lane & Mittendorf, LLP, are deeply saddened by the loss of our former partner, Paul Windels, Jr., one of the founders of the firm. Among his many other accomplishments, Paul served as an Assistant United States Attorney, Regional Administrator of the SEC, President of the Federal Bar Council, and President of Brooklyn Law School. As all of us who worked with Paul know so well, he was a fierce and committed advocate, and a wonderful raconteur. Paul had an intellectual curiosity which led him to a broad range of subjects, all of which he was ready to discuss on any given day. His leadership, great intelligence and charisma significantly contributed to the firm's growth and success. His good judgment and skills were admired not only by those at the firm who had the privilege to work with him but also by many of the firm's clients who sought out his wise counsel and impressive advocacy skills. Paul will be greatly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his children, Paul, Mary, James and Patrick, and to the rest of his family and his many friends. Windels Marx Lane & Mittendorf, LLP

Kylie G. Boggess, 24, of Twin Falls, Idaho, is a second-year medical student at the University of Washington who hopes to practice primary care. ''When President Obama came out and said that he wants to be the last president to address the health care issue, he commanded a level of confidence and created a sense of urgency that he has lacked while campaigning for health care this year,'' Ms. Boggess wrote.

FRANKLIN--Arthur Joseph, died Tuesday, September 8, 2009. Loving husband of Paula. Beloved father of Rick, Jill and Richard. Treasured father-in-law of Ellen and Vito. Cherished grandfather of Victoria, Daniel, Matthew and William. Past President of National Silver, international business man, WWII hero. A gentle man of great compassion and integrity, Arthur was a renaissance man. He will be greatly missed by family and friends. Funeral service Friday, September 11th, 12 Noon, Sunset Chapel, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, NY.

WINDELS--Paul Jr. The Brooklyn Law School community records with great sorrow the loss of Paul Windels, Jr., Esq., a steadfast, devoted and beloved member of the Brooklyn Law School Board of Trustees for thirty-nine years. He was appointed to the Board in 1968 and became its Chairman in 1983. He served in that capacity for twenty years. Generations of Brooklyn Law School trustees, deans, faculty members and students have benefited from his thoughtful stewardship and compassion. During his tenure, the Law School added scores of new and innovative courses to the curriculum, attracted world-class scholars to the faculty, and greatly expanded the physical plant, with the purchase of eight residence halls, the construction of a major addition to the main building, and the planning of a new 22-story residence hall. His role in helping the Law School achieve its highest aspirations was indispensable and his mark on Brooklyn Law School is indelible. Although his presence will be missed, his legacy will be long enduring. We extend our deepest sympathy to his children, James, Paul III, Mary, Patrick, and the entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean

President Nicolas Sarkozy of France on Thursday is scheduled to unveil details of a carbon tax that would raise the cost of driving a car or heating a home, with the aim of encouraging conservation and cutting emissions. Mr. Sarkozy also would also burnish his nation's environmental credentials ahead of United Nations summit in Copenhagen in December by making France the largest economy yet to impose such a charge.

LUXEMBURG--Phyllis. National Council of Jewish Women New York Section mourns the passing of Phyllis Luxemburg, longtime member and former member of the Board of Directors. We remember her years of service and dedication. Sincerest condolences to her family. Beatrice Kahn, Co-President Beth Mitchell, Co-President Joan Shapiro Green, Exec. Dir.

SANTISI--Rose M.,died September 8, 2009 at her home in New Brunswick. She was 90. She was born to Joseph and Frances Catanese in Barnesboro, PA in 1919 and was a lifetime resident of the City of New Brunswick. Before her marriage, she was a seamstress for Bond Clothing Factory in New Brunswick. Mrs. Santisi was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt and friend. She had a warmth about her that made others feel welcome by her presence and at ease by her conversation. She was a confidant and friend to many. Her infinite wisdom guided whoever called upon her for advice, installing confidence and comfort. Mrs. Santisi not only had the knack of feeding the spirit, but also she was known for her notorious meatballs and gravy every Sunday night. Mrs. Santisi was also an avid traveler spending time in Cape Cod, Florida, and the NJ Shore. She was a devoted Catholic being a longtime communicant of Saint Mary of Mount Virgin RC Church in New Brunswick. She was predeceased by her husband Phil Santisi in 1993 and her siblings Grace Catanese, Peter Catanese and Frances Venute. Mrs. Santisi is survived by her daughters and their husbands: Terri Santisi- Alvator and John Alvator of both Bethlehem and Mantoloking, Felicia and David Rinehimer of Warren, and her sons: Joseph Santisi of New Brunswick and Louis Santisi and his wife Mary Lou of North Brunswick, her brothers Joseph Catanese of New Brunswick and Rocco Catan- ese and his wife Josephine of Monroe Township, and four grandchildren, Sarah Rinehimer of NYC, Amanda Rinehimer of Warren, Jared Santisi of New Brunswick and David Rinehimer of Warren. Services will be Saturday, 10:00am from the Gleason Funeral Home, 1360 Hamilton Street, Somerset followed by a 10:30am Funeral Mass at Saint Mary of Mount Virgin RC Church in New Brunswick. Entombment will follow at Franklin Memorial Park, North Brunswick. Visitation will be Friday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the funeral home. Memorial contributions may be made to ECLC Childhood Learning Center, 21 Lum Ave., Chatham, NJ 07928

Gregory H. Williams, the president of City College of New York since 2001, announced on Wednesday that he was resigning to become president of the University of Cincinnati. Dr. Williams, 65, oversaw a decade of growth and increased academic rigor at City College, one of the 11 senior colleges of the City University of New York and long considered its flagship.
KLEIER--Jonathan. We mourn the untimely loss of Jonathan, dear son of our neighbors Michele and Ian Kleier. 1125 Park Avenue Board of Directors

From the Ground Up is about the progress of the writer's construction of a cabin in the Maine woods and offers advice for those thinking of building their own cabin. An excerpt: THE big maple at the farm where I make my turn into the cabin is showing the first crimson blush of autumn. The nights now are regularly dropping into the 30s. Soon, the geese will be arriving at the beaver pond across the road, and the trout will ascend the mountain brooks in their bright colors to spawn in the cold clear water..

It is the dramatic hit that concludes a game, empties Yankee Stadium and results in a player wearing pinstripes being plastered with a pie in the face. As the Yankees have motored to the best record in the major leagues, they have been proficient at ending games in style. In the first year of the Stadium, the Yankees have won in their final at-bat 13 times in the first 69 home games. So, with one animated celebration every five and a half games in the Bronx, the next celebration never seems too far away.

DIACRUSSI--Mary, on September 6th. The youngest among four brothers, known for her philanthropic activities as well as her musical, vocal and writing skills and her genuine sense of humor. Her life- long ambition to come to America and join her brothers Peter and Anthony materialized when, in 1966, she left the Ionian Islands with husband Basil and her third son Stephen, to permanently live in New York City. She surprised her friends when, after being for more than four years in a nursing home, returned to her former Manhattan residence. She will be missed for her benevolence, centenarian wisdom and her timeless beauty. Visiting: Friday, 6:30-9pm, Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. corner E. 81st Street. Services will be held Saturday, September 12th, 9am at Holy Trinity Cathedral, 319 E. 74th Street between 1st and 2nd Aves. To view a photo remembrance of Mary Diacrussi, visit our website at www.mem.com

SHAMPAINE--Judith Marcus. We mourn the far too early passing of the beloved daughter of Herman and Gertrude Marcus and sister of Richard Marcus and Marlene Marcus Schultz; loving mother of Martin, Leslie and Victoria; doting grandmother of Maya and Hannah Barnett, Brahm and Nadav Soltes; inspiring mother-in-law of Michael Barnett, Nicole Shampaine and Ori Z. Soltes. A Dallas-born graduate of Hockaday School who went off to dance at the School of American Ballet, she traveled the world, gathering its many colors and tastes, and settling in New York City--an ever-evolving painter of canvases and a caring sculptor of her children and grandchildren, to which she added, to her dying day, lasting, loving touches. She has returned to rest in Dallas with her former husband, Martin Shampaine, but the unfinished work of her life and of those countless lives she touched will remain as a masterpiece, scattered--like those who loved her--across diverse countries and continents.

JOHNSON--Dr. Warren David, 56, died suddenly at his home on September 5th in New York City. After completing his Ph.D. at Columbia University, Warren joined the Dalton School where he taught for the past 19 years and where he served several consecutive terms as Department Chair of High School English. Warren was also President of the Faculty Association. Proud parishioner of Saint Thomas Church, Warren was actively involved in many aspects of church life, most recently as Head Acolyte. Predeceased by his father Mervin Johnson; survived by his mother Winnifred Johnson; his sisters Mary Jackson and Ellen Johnson; Mary's husband Jim and Ellen's partner, Leslie Strickler; his niece Laura and his nephews Phil and Sean. Warren will be deeply missed by his many students, colleagues and wonderful friends whose lives he touched during the 30 years that he lived in New York City. Funeral service will be held on Friday, September 11, 2009 at 1:30pm at Saint Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd St., New York. Reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions should be made in Warren's memory to The Dalton School, 108 E. 89th St., New York, NY 10128. A Memorial service will be held at the school on a future date.

GRUEN--Ronald. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing in Dallas, Texas, of our beloved friend who with his wife Ethel Gruen is a cherished Benefactor and established the Ronald and Ethel Gruen Endowed Fund for the Advancement of Secondary Jewish Education which provides scholarships and strengthens Mechina (preparatory) Programs that benefit at least ten secondary day schools through the Azrieli Graduate School for Jewish Education and Administration and its Institute for University-School Partnership throughout North America annually. He received a Doctor of Humane Letters degree, honoris causa, at a special YU Convocation in 2005 in Dallas, while his wife received the Ayshet Chayil Award. Heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ethel, and his wonderful children and grandchildren: Ted (and Helen) Gruen and their children: Michelle and Alyssa, and Aaron, of blessed memory, and stepdaughter Kathy Bogaert, Dan (and Grace) Gruen and their children Sara and John Gruen, and Naomi (and Britt) Schlinke of Austin, Texas, and Naomi Gruen, of Albuquerque, New Mexico, and the entire Gruen family. Schnall, Dean Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration

The job of New York City comptroller comes with a big number: about $80 billion. That is the total value of the five pensions the comptroller oversees, constituting the country's largest municipal pension system. With a staff of over 700, the comptroller audits how city agencies spend taxpayer money. Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr.'s decision to run for mayor has created a spirited race heading into Tuesday's primary. Among Democrats, a runoff is likely between the top two finishers since polls suggest that no candidate will capture the 40 percent of the vote needed to win outright. The comptroller's position has been seen as a springboard to higher office, though the last to achieve that was Abraham D. Beame. Questions

Attendance is down across major and minor league baseball this season, so perhaps it is not a complete surprise that the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., has had fewer visitors as well. Jeff Idelson, the Hall's president, said that attendance was down about 6 percent this year, and that annual attendance would probably slip below 300,000 visitors for the first time in 12 years.

BERNSTEIN--Peter L. A Memorial Service for Peter L. Bernstein will be held on: September 15, 2009 at 4pm Merkin Hall, 129 West 67th St. Contributions should be made to: Peter L. Bernstein Memorial Fund, Williams College Development Office, Vogt House, 75 Park St., Williamstown, MA 01267.

Andy Roddick exited early from the United States Open, a third-round loss to his fellow American John Isner that Roddick's coach, Larry Stefanki, termed a ''big disappointment'' in a telephone interview Wednesday. But Stefanki wants Roddick to remember 2009 not for the disappointments -- like the crushing loss to Roger Federer at Wimbledon, or the early departure at the Open -- but for the strides Roddick has made since last December. Roddick has won as consistently as ever this season, marking a resurgence in both popularity and perception, and Stefanki believes that's what Roddick will and should hold on to.

Allan W. Russell, a 78-year-old retiree from Leesburg, Ga., had attended his congressman's town-hall-style meeting in Albany, Ga., last month because of his concerns about health care. He did not take well to Mr. Obama's characterizations of the opposition to his plan. ''He went quickly to blaming those of us who questioned what was taking place, of using scare tactics and not caring what will happen to those without insurance,'' Mr. Russell wrote. ''He was less than subtle in his suggestion that those who raise questions are uncaring, unthinking individuals with malice in their hearts.''

Martina Hingis reached her first Grand Slam quarterfinal at 15. Venus Williams did so at age 17. Steffi Graf was 16. So when comparing Melanie Oudin's meteoric run at the United States Open to the past, it doesn't seem so meteoric; Oudin is 17.

STAND-UP paddle-boarding, once reserved for Hawaiians and Hollywood celebrities, has reached the landlocked masses. Thanks to a new fleet of boards designed for flat-water cruising, just about any body of water -- from Lake Tahoe to the Hudson River -- is suitable for aspiring Laird Hamiltons ready for a powerful, peaceful workout. With wet suits, stand-up paddle-boarding can last long into the fall and would be great way to view foliage on the shore. Some flat-water boards feature long, single fins to keep them gliding straight while paddling with canoe-like J-strokes; others look and act more like kayaks, or can cross over to ocean paddling and have inserts to tie down fishing gear and coolers. Nearly all have special deck pads and very stable construction that allow newbies to pick up the sport (great for the core and upper body) without dumping into the drink too many times.

RENTSCHLER--Sarah Yorke(Rah), of Hudson, NY died suddenly of heart failure on September 6, 2009 in Hudson. She was 59. Born in 1950 in Minneapolis, MN, she grew up in Lake Forest, IL. She attended the Ethel Walker School and Sarah Lawrence College, before setting down roots in New York City. Sarah managed the Vorpal Gallery in Soho, NY, and then in San Francisco. Returning to Manhattan, she opened the Sarah Y. Rentschler Gallery in her legendary penthouse space in Chelsea, where she brought many emerging artists into focus, with later locations in Soho, Bridgehampton, Water Mill, and in Hudson. She was a features writer at The San Francisco Progress, a weekly edited and published by her father Bill, of whom she was a chip off the old block. Sarah later founded The Complicated Goat catering and kids' cooking classes with her longtime love Dan. And if platters could talk! Sarah was an avid reader and writer, leaving behind many works in progress. She was a force of nature, with an incredible eye, an innate sense of style, and an enormous and loyal heart. Sarah was a rebel, and known to say "What trouble can we get into?!?" In the words of her adoring mother Sylvia, she was "uni-Q"! Over her lifetime Sarah mothered a menagerie of animals; among many others there were the goats Hote and Ginnie and Maaa; cats Wilhelmina Scooter Livingston, Olivia, Bandita, Owly, and recent adoptee Daytona from Hamilton, Ohio; dogs Rufus, and Cora Dijon; an indoor-outdoor chicken named Red. Sarah was adored and will be missed by so many. She is survived by Daniel J. Bleckinger; his children Amber Wedin and Mark Wedin; mother Sylvia Angevin Thompson; father William Henry Rentschler, siblings Peter Ferris Rentschler; Mary Angevin Rentschler; Phoebe Rentschler Cole, Alexandra Angevin Thompson-Cole; Hope Rentschler Garbo; stepsiblings: Lydia Thompson Whitehead; and Wallace Underwood Thompson. Sarah was Auntie Mame to nine nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her cherished stepfather George Wallace Thompson. Memorial service on Martha's Vineyard on Saturday, September 12, 11am, Abel's Hill Cemetery, Chilmark, followed by a celebration at 15 Angevin's Lane, Edgartown. Donations in lieu of flowers: "Animalkind" or "Dan Bleckinger's Free Spirits Children's Tennis" of Hudson, NY (111 Ten Broeck Lane, Hudson, NY 12534).

It was just before 1 p.m. Wednesday when Gerald Richards, a burly handwriting expert, got up from the stand in a 15th-floor courtroom where Anthony D. Marshall and Francis X. Morrissey have been on trial since April. Mr. Richards stretched, the jurors filed out of the room, and with that, 18 weeks of testimony -- some parts of it dynamic, others grueling -- came to an end.

RUBIN--Theodore, third generation chief executive officer of family-owned Ruby Wines of Avon, MA, was a pioneer in the state's fine wine business and among the first to promote and distribute fine wine in MA. Mr. Rubin, a beloved family man, colleague, business partner, sportsman and dear friend, died of leukemia Monday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 70. Mr. Rubin's grandfather, Samuel, and father, Irving, established the family business in 1921 during Prohibition, when alcohol sales were barred. During that time, they distributed Ruby Root Beer. Ruby Wines was founded upon the repeal of Prohibition in 1933, and today is a leading distributor of fine wines from around the world, thanks to the strength, integrity and dedication of the Rubin family. Mr. Rubin's brother, Robert, is chief financial officer for Ruby Wines; his son, Brad, represents the fourth generation in this family business as senior vice president and director of sales. Theodore "Ted" Rubin was an inspiration and dear friend to many. "We celebrated our 40th wedding anniversary together and shared family events throughout our lives," said David Taub, Chairman and CEO of wine importer Palm Bay International. An enthusiastic ambassador for fine wine, Mr. Rubin traveled to vineyards around the world to identify outstanding selections for his customers. He was a founding member of the Guild of Oenopholists, which created the Boston Wine Expo, and a member of wine and food appreciation societies Chaine des Rotisseurs and Ordre de Mondial. His numerous charitable endeavors included support of the Spinazolla foundation, Jimmy Fund and Italian Home For Children. He was a past Master of Everett C. Benton Lodge and an avid golfer who won a record 13 club championships and 12 'father & son' titles at Spring Valley Country Club. Mr. Rubin is survived by his wife, Hilary Lynn, sons Doug and Brad, brother Robert and six grandchildren. A memorial service was held today at Temple Emanuel in Newton, MA, followed by burial in Sharon Memorial Cemetery. David and Linda Taub and Ted's many friends at Palm Bay International

WINDELS--Paul, Jr.,died peacefully on September 8. Beloved husband of the late Mary Patricia Ripley Windels; father of Paul Windels III, Mary Hyde Windels, James Hazen Ripley Windels, and Patrick Dillon Windels; and grandfather of Patrick Emmons Windels, Thomas Ripley Windels, George Gunderson Windels, Mary Catherine Yuelan Windels, and Paul Eugene Ruhao Windels. Alumnus of Brooklyn Friends School, Brooks School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. Served in the United States Army in World War II attaining the rank of Major and saw combat in numerous engagements. Chief Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York (1953-57) and Regional Administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission (1957-61), during which time he led the prosecution of the so-called boiler room operators and the investigation of Cady, Roberts & Co., the initial insider trading case, in 1959. Lead Partner Windels, Curry & Rice, Windels, Merritt & Ingraham, Windels & Marx, and Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives and thereafter of counsel to Windels, Marx, Lane & Mittendorf. Chair of the Judicial Nominating Committees for Senators James L. Buckley and Alfonse M. D'Amato. President of the Federal Bar Council. President of the Board, Brooklyn Law School and the Lycee Francais de New York. Trustee of the Lexington School for the Deaf, the Knox School, the French Institute, and the Atlantic Foundation. A funeral service will be held on Monday, September 14, 2009, at 10:00am at St. James Episcopal Church, Route 25A, St. James, New York. A memorial service will be held at Brooklyn Law School during the fall. He was a man of unique qualities and character, deeply committed and loyal to his family and friends, who will be sorely missed.
LUXEMBURG--Phyllis Jones. We mourn the death of our member and extend deepest sympathy to her family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

Bob and Mike Bryan lost a chance to defend their United States Open title on Wednesday, dropping a dramatic match in the semifinals to Leander Paes of India and his partner, Lukas Dlouhy of the Czech Republic, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6 (6), at Arthur Ashe Stadium. The Bryans, who were the top seeds, seemed in control of the match despite losing the first set. They rolled through the second and had an opportunity to grab the third set with four break points on Paes's serve at 3-3. But they were unable to convert and faced a match point on Bob Bryan's serve at 5-6.

Fabergé, jeweler to the last Russian czar and creator of the legendary Imperial Easter eggs, made a comeback of sorts Wednesday when it presented its first jewelry collection in more than 90 years. The collection is the result of a two-year effort by Fabergé's owners, a group of investors led by the British private equity firm Pallinghurst Resources, to revive the brand by reuniting it with two heirs of the Fabergé family.

5:45 A.M. (TCM) OLD YELLER (1957) Turner Classic Movies goes to animals with a day of programming devoted to two famous movie dogs and a certain marine mammal. The tribute begins with this Walt Disney adaptation of Fred Gipson's book about a frontier boy (Tommy Kirk) who develops a close bond with a yellow mongrel. (Above, Kevin Corcoran in a scene from the film.) At 6:55 a short film looks at dogs' contributions to the silver screen. Everyone's favorite courageous collie is the subject of five films, beginning with ''Son of Lassie'' (1945) at 7:30 and followed by ''Courage of Lassie'' (1946) at 9:15, ''Hills of Home'' (1948) at 11, ''The Sun Comes Up'' (1949) at 12:45 a.m. and ''Challenge to Lassie'' (1949) at 2:30. The tide changes at 4 with ''Flipper'' (1963), in which a Florida Keys fisherman (Chuck Connors) opposes the friendship between his son (Luke Halpin) and a dolphin, who goes on to help capture a group of escaped convicts in ''Flipper's New Adventure'' (1963) at 5:45. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW The ladies chat with Juliette Binoche and Russell Brand.

Update | 9:46 a.m. TORONTO — Movie stars. Can’t live with them. Can’t have a film festival without them.

The big industry news this week was at DC Comics: Its parent company, Warner Brothers Entertainment, has turned the comic-book home of Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman into a new company, DC Entertainment, and the metamorphosis brought the company a new president, Diane Nelson.

The memorializing of Michael Jackson will continue for at least another year. On Friday, organizers of a tribute concert that was being planned in the singer’s honor at the Schönbrunn Palace in Vienna said that the concert was canceled and would be rescheduled for June in London, the Reuters news agency reported. On Tuesday, Mr. Jackson’s brother Jermaine and the promoter Georg Kindel said at a news conference in Vienna that they had lined up a formidable roster of talent for a Sept. 26 concert to pay tribute to the King of Pop, including Mary J. Blige, Chris Brown, Akon and Natalie Cole. But by Wednesday, they were defending themselves amid reports that Ms. Blige would be attending a fashion event in Italy that day, and that Mr. Brown, who is serving probation for assaulting the pop star Rihanna, would need a judge’s permission to leave the United States. On Friday, Mr. Kindel said that the tribute would be held in June at Wembley Stadium in London to mark the first anniversary of Michael Jackson’s death, and that tickets for the Vienna concert would be refunded.

The actress Lauren Bacall, the producer-executive John Calley, the independent film entrepreneur Roger Corman and the cinematographer Gordon Willis are set to receive honors from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences at its first special Governor Awards dinner, scheduled for Nov. 14.

TORONTO — The City-to-City program got underway without incident at the Toronto film festival on Friday morning, as a small crowd of movie-goers filed into the Varsity theater’s auditorium No. 7 for “A History of Israeli Cinema Part 1.”

Maura Tierney will not appear in the coming NBC series “Parenthood” as she undergoes treatment for breast cancer, Variety reported. Ms. Tierney, who has appeared in television shows like “NewsRadio” and “ER,” had been set to star alongside Peter Krause and Craig T. Nelson in “Parenthood,” a comedy-drama adapted from the 1989 Ron Howard film that was expected to have its premiere on NBC in the fall. But in July, NBC announced that it was delaying the debut of the show until next year after Ms. Tierney said she was diagnosed with breast cancer. At that time, NBC said that it would delay production on the show for eight weeks while Ms. Tierney received a medical evaluation. But the Variety report said that Ms. Tierney’s treatment was conflicting with the show’s production schedule and that her role would be recast. In a statement cited by Variety, NBC said, “While we are saddened that Maura Tierney won’t be able to continue in her current role in ‘Parenthood,’ our main concern is for her quick and full recovery. Our thoughts and best wishes are with her.”

One day she’s a judge, the next a defendant: a consortium of major record labels has filed suit against Ellen DeGeneres’s syndicated daytime talk show, saying that their copyrights to more than 1,000 songs were violated when they were played on the show without their permission, The Associated Press reported.

We didn’t think there was much more that Tyler Perry could do to surprise us following his cameo appearance in “Star Trek” this summer. But in an appearance Thursday on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” Mr. Perry (who was promoting his new movie, “I Can Do Bad All By Myself”) proved us wrong: It turns out he’s also an enthusiast of remote-control planes, a hobby he picked up while conquering his fear of flying, and which he demonstrates by gracefully flying a toy plane around Mr. Fallon’s set. The aerial spectacular begins about halfway into this video clip; the pressure is now on Jay Leno to top this in his Monday night prime-time debut.

A planned e-book release of “True Compass,” the memoir by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, has been indefinitely postponed by its publisher, The Associated Press reported. The release of the hardcover book, which was moved up to Sept. 14 from Oct. 6 days before Mr. Kennedy’s death on Aug. 25, was to be accompanied by the release of an electronic edition of the memoir. But Jonathan Karp, the publisher and editor in chief of Twelve, the imprint of Hachette Books that is releasing “True Compass,” told The A.P. that the delay of the e-book was a “business decision,” adding that the pictures and illustrations in the book could not be duplicated in an electronic edition. “We felt that this particular hardcover edition of ‘True Compass’ deserves to be the first and pre-eminent format for the book,” Mr. Karp said, according to The A.P. Mr. Kennedy reportedly received an $8 million advance for the memoir, which he wrote with Ron Powers. Twelve is planning an initial print run of 1.5 million copies, with a retail list price of $35.

When I was making phone calls for my column this week, two people mentioned Barbara Tuchman's great book "The Guns of August." The book is about the chaotic, almost haphazard series of events that led to the outbreak of World War I. One point she makes is that although the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914 was the event that precipitated the war, it was hardly the reason that war broke out. Tension had been building for months -- all that was needed was a spark.

The question of whether or not Joyce Reynolds will operate her Heavenly Scent coffee stand in the Maplewood train station without competition was postponed to another day, after a meeting with a chancery division judge in New Jersey Superior Court today. Ms. Reynolds had asked the judge to prevent Art Christensen, vice chairman of the Maplewood Concierge Company, from having any other subcontractors supply coffee and snacks in the morning. "There was no conclusion," said Diane O'Connell, Ms. Reynolds' lawyer. "The judge will draft a decision in the next couple weeks." A message left with Mr. Christensen was not immediately returned this afternoon. He had wanted to find one contractor to operate all aspects of the concierge services throughout the day, while Ms. Reynolds was interested in operating her business only in the morning. Mr. Christensen had arranged with Mintze Shay to run Maplewood Concierge Company's coffee counter. He has also said he intends to appeal the decision of July 29 that prevented him from evicting Ms. Reynolds. -- Tina Kelley

Nearly seven years in the making, the IEEE's 802.11n standard for high-speed Wi-Fi was finally ratified today at a meeting in New Jersey. But not to worry if you're among the millions who have invested in so-called draft-802.11n gear, equipment based on a draft version of the standard released a few years ago: Routers and adapters based on the final version of the standard will be completely compatible with the older stuff.

Jonathan Benno, who has been the chef de cuisine at Per Se since it opened in 2004, said he will leave in January to become executive chef of a new restaurant now under construction in the plaza of Lincoln Center, near the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Padma Lakshmi - hostess of "Top Chef," former Mrs. Rushdie, model, actress, author and now jewelry designer - is the closest thing foodies have to Eva Peron. So when she appeared last night on the seventh floor of Bergdorf Goodman to judge a "Top Chef"-like competition between designers as part of the citywide Fashion's Night Out, chaos reigned. That the Olsen twins were tending bar only packed more people into the suddenly tiny-seeming BG restaurant. By 7:15 p.m., when Linda Fargo, Bergdorf's platinum-bobbed artistic director, introduced Lakshmi, the place resembled a Who concert - albeit a very stylishly dressed one - with iPhones deployed and bodies pressed against the marble bar behind which Lakshmi would soon hold court. And then there she was, in a Giles Deacon leather minidress with tall leather boots and lots of her own jewelry (also available downstairs). "Hello," she said, whipping the crowd into a froth.

David LaChapelle is using the language he developed as a commercial photography superstar to tell new stories as a fine artist. His latest work, a single large-format image titled "The Rape of Africa," is an allegorical mash-up that makes references to Botticelli and continues his longtime collaboration with the model Naomi Campbell. Days before his new show at the David DeSanctis Gallery in Los Angeles, where LaChapelle will attend the Sept. 12 opening, he spoke with The Moment about his latest project.

Q.

As you've gathered from my earlier posts, I am a schoolteacher. My 8th grade students must present four oral reports and write four research papers a year -- one of each every quarter. It is always apparent to me when a student has done a half-cocked job; when they are stingy with their work, I am stingy with the grade. Although I stress the importance of being thorough, it is hard for a teenager to understand why that is important. Perhaps the following story about my lack of thoroughness with my hives can serve as an example of real-life consequences of sloppy work.

Jaguars at ColtsSunday, 1 p.m.Line: Colts by 7The Colts thrive on predictable excellence, which made their off-season coaching shake-up so unsettling. Coach Tony Dungy, the offensive coordinator Tom Moore, and the quarterbacks coach Howard Mudd never seemed to be doing much - after all, how much coaching and coordinating does Peyton Manning really need? This Sunday marks the 32nd annual steak fry held by Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, and none other than Senator Al Franken, one of the newest members of the Senate and a former (possibly still current) comedian, will be the keynote speaker.

Visit Europe this fall and you'll find agreeable weather, less tourists, and cheaper car rentals. Avis is offering a Fall Getaway promotion, which offers up to 20 percent off rentals of three days or longer in countries like France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Portugal, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. For example, a three-day rental of a compact car with a manual transmission, like a Volkswagon Golf, picked up from and returned to Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris, will cost about $100 with the discount.

Much of the conversation between tennis fans on Thursday was centered on how quickly the match between Roger Federer and Robin Soderling changed on Wednesday. What looked like a straight-sets clinic of brilliant play by Federer turned into a tense battle that the top seed was fortunate to escape. Up, two sets to none, and cruising in the third-set tie-breaker, Federer momentarily took his foot off the gas and Soderling won the third set and nearly won the fourth.

The new men's issue of T is now online and will be on stands this Sunday - just in time for fashion week. Appropriately, we track down fall's most enigmatic trend: Sherlock Holmes-inspired Victoriana. The photographer Matthew Brookes shot "The Brothers Grim" in Paris, while Cathy Horyn met with the designer Alexander McQueen in London to discuss his "hard-core view of sexuality presented in a romantic envelope of Victorian darkness." Our cover star, the actor Michael Fassbender, who was photographed by Jean-Baptiste Mondino, also knows a thing or two about darkness - he literally starved himself for the role of a lifetime. To lighten things up, the photographer Jacob Sutton collaborated with the choreographer Jonah Bokaer on a dance-inspired story; and in "The Randy Dandy," Grazia D'Annunzio reminisces about the wildly eccentric Italian decadent poet Gabriele D'Annunzio, who was her grandfather's cousin. D'Annunzio's famous motto, "I have what I have given," is one we can definitely relate to here at T.
- Franca Sozzani on the buzz in Milan last night for Fashion's Night Out.

The Broadway cast of "Billy Elliot the Musical" will soon lose another performer who portrays its title character -- not to puberty but to a touring production of the show. In a news release, publicists for the musical said that 14-year-old Tommy Batchelor, one of four actors who currently play Billy in the Broadway production, would portray the character in a tour that will start at the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, Oriental Theater in Chicago on March 18. On the tour, he will be joined by Giuseppe Bausilio, 12, who has performed with the State Theater of Bern in "Coppelia," and Cesar Corrales, 13, who has studied at the National Ballet School in Toronto, who will play the role in rotation.
Kraft Foods' run at Cadbury may just be the appetizer in what some expect to be a feast of unsolicited and hostile bids.

The Star Ledger reports that three Millburn High School students have sued the Newark Bears and the baseball team's co-owner after they were kicked out of a game for refusing to stand during the seventh-inning song, "God Bless America." The suit was filed last Friday in U.S. District Court in Newark.

The government of Catalonia, a semiautonomous region of northeast Spain with its capital in Barcelona, approved a decree last month calling for the construction of solar panels on the roofs of 108 public schools.

A New York judge has thrown out the copyright infringement lawsuit filed by the cookbook author Missy Chase Lapine against Jessica Seinfeld over their similar books about how to fool children into eating healthier food. The judge decided that there were some similarities between the two books, but not enough to amount to copyright infringement.

Saturday's Notre Dame-Michigan game pits two of this season's most closely watched coaches in Charlie Weis and Rich Rodriguez, but the challenges in the two football programs run deeper than the guys at the top. Success at the highest level begins with getting blue-chip athletes who can survive academically. That challenge has long been recognized at Notre Dame, but it faces Michigan, too, and increasingly all top football programs. Most people think of Michigan, Ohio State, Texas, Oklahoma, Alabama, Florida, Louisiana State and so on as football powers. They also happen to be the premier public universities in their states. To be both at the same time poses increasing challenges.

This day will always bring more questions than answers. How to explain to your child what happened on a crystalline morning eight years ago? And if your child is Muslim, those questions have added layers, and more complicated answers. In a guest blog today, Moina Noor (a freelance journalist who blogs about public education at NorwalkNet.com) describes trying to make sense of it for her young son, while still trying to understand it all herself.

Haji Muslim Khan, a leader of the Pakistani Taliban whose capture by the Pakistani Army was announced on Friday, was the group's spokesman when its fighters appeared to be drawing ever closer to the country's capital in April of this year. In an interview broadcast on British television at that time, Mr. Khan listed the presence of female soldiers from NATO countries in the region as one of the Taliban's grievances that the Pakistani government had not addressed.

At New York fashion week, there will be an easier-to-pronounce name on the runways. A rarity among the countless Brazilians and Russians who are using the runway for takeoff is Heidi Mount, from Centerville, Utah, a new favorite of Karl Lagerfeld, for whom she opened the Chanel spring 2009 ready-to-wear show and has appeared in consecutive Chanel ads (sorry, Ms. Schiffer). A new Dolce & Gabbana campaign, photographed by Steven Klein, confirms that the 22-year-old - who has also modeled in T - is clearly on the rise. Anticipating a fashion week as busy as the last, when she worked 60 shows between New York, Paris and Milan, I seized the moment before the rush of fashion week to catch up with Heidi in Tompkins Square Park.

Every now and again, a revolutionary kitchen tool is invented. Just think of the impact that the Robot Coupe food processor had on cooks in the '60s, enabling them to make dough or pesto with the push of a button. I know that the Microplane and the Swiss peeler, for example, have changed the way I cook.

Of all of his creative output - films, books, his long-running column in Vanity Fair - Dominick Dunne's crowning work has always been his own life. His story had the kind of arc that few writers can conjure. After a huge rise and fall in Hollywood as a producer that was accompanied by far too many substances, Mr. Dunne eventually sobered up, only to be confronted by the most unfathomable tragedy anyone can face: the murder of his daughter. After chronicling the trial for Vanity Fair, his second act was unstoppable, yielding books, magazines and an endless list of famous and infamous friends that he doted on and traded gossip with. All of it was lovingly recorded by Mr. Dunne, a serial namedropper who was quick to embrace his own fame before anybody ever heard of Facebook. Friends would talk of his penchant for scrapbooking his own life, of putting photos and invitations between pages as if he himself did not believe his good fortune.
The patient showed symptoms of severe depression. She hallucinated, seeing her dead father across her room. Her family was having trouble taking care of her.

Times reporter Joe Drape's new book, "Our Boys: A Perfect Season on the Plains with the Smith Center Redmen," is a portrait of the extraordinary high school football team in Smith Center, Kan., whose quest for perfection sustains its hometown in the heartland. Drape first reported on the Redmen back in 2007, but he knew there was more to the story. He decided to move to Smith Center with his wife and their young son. "Our Boys" is the result. He recently answered some questions about the book and the Redmen.

So the time is condensed, but the emotions, and mom's tears, are certainly not.

Free trade is supposed to be about a principle: nondiscrimination between domestic and foreign goods. Sometimes following that principle requires taxes and subsidies at the border! Oops: After releasing the list of nominees for the 43rd annual Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday, the association appended its announcement on Thursday, saying that Brad Paisley and Keith Urban had been “inadvertently omitted” from one category, best musical event, which recognizes collaborations. “The omission occurred when transferring information from the online ballot to the list of final nominees,” the association said in a statement. Mr. Paisley and Mr. Urban were recognized for their duet “Start a Band,” and the addition gives each man a lift in the total number of nominations: Mr. Paisley now has seven and Mr. Urban five, putting him in second place over all. While the prospect of student performances of the gritty musical “Rent” has provoked objections at some high schools around the country, in Orange County, Calif., it prompted a handful of varsity athletes to threaten to rape and kill the lead actress in their school’s production. Now, to settle a suit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union, that county’s Newport-Mesa Unified School District has agreed to give anti-harassment and discrimination training to students and staff members at the high school, Corona del Mar, and in the district. Hail Ketchum, the student actress who was threatened, said that while the attacks — made in a video and posted on Facebook — “were disgusting and very disturbing to me personally,” what was “really disheartening is that when I complained about them, the administrators did little to deal with them.” The district has agreed to issue her an apology. She is now a freshman at Loyola Marymount University. “We’re very pleased with the length and the scope of the training that was required,” Hector Villagra, director of the A.C.L.U.’s Orange County office, said. Corona del Mar officials initially canceled the production of “Rent: School Edition,” which was chosen by the school theater instructor, Ron Martin. That decision was later rescinded, and a production was staged in May.

WINDELS--Paul, Jr.,died peacefully on September 8. Beloved husband of the late Mary Patricia Ripley Windels; father of Paul Windels III, Mary Hyde Windels, James Hazen Ripley Windels, and Patrick Dillon Windels; and grandfather of Patrick Emmons Windels, Thomas Ripley Windels, George Gunderson Windels, Mary Catherine Yuelan Windels, and Paul Eugene Ruhao Windels. Alumnus of Brooklyn Friends School, Brooks School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. Served in the United States Army in World War II attaining the rank of Major and saw combat in numerous engagements. Chief Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York (1953-57) and Regional Administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission (1957-61), during which time he led the prosecution of the so-called boiler room operators and the investigation of Cady, Roberts & Co., the initial insider trading case, in 1959. Lead Partner Windels, Curry & Rice, Windels, Merritt & Ingraham, Windels & Marx, and Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives and thereafter of counsel to Windels, Marx, Lane & Mittendorf. Chair of the Judicial Nominating Committees for Senators James L. Buckley and Alfonse M. D'Amato. President of the Federal Bar Council. President of the Board, Brooklyn Law School and the Lycee Francais de New York. Trustee of the Lexington School for the Deaf, the Knox School, the French Institute, and the Atlantic Foundation. A funeral service will be held on Monday, September 14, 2009, at 10:00am at St. James Episcopal Church, Route 25A, St. James, New York. A memorial service will be held at Brooklyn Law School during the fall. He was a man of unique qualities and character, deeply committed and loyal to his family and friends, who will be sorely missed.

With ferocious flames and smoke in the barren Utah hills north of Salt Lake City, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration on Thursday successfully test fired the first stage of a new rocket that might soon be canceled. The firing, performed at Alliant Techsystems, Inc., the manufacturer of the motor, was the first full-scale demonstration of a major component of the Ares I rocket that NASA has been developing for the past four years to replace the space shuttles, which are scheduled to be retired next year.

Half a century ago the classical music world ranked Franz Joseph Haydn more or less on a par with Mozart. Then the Mostly Mozart and ''Amadeus'' industries uncovered a sex appeal in Mozart that Papa Haydn could never rival. Still, his achievement remains stunning in its vastness, inspiration and artistry, and he has continued to be well served by recordings. To commemorate the bicentennial of Haydn's death, the classical music critics of The New York Times look back over those recordings and suggest their favorites on Page 4. JAMES R. OESTREICH

Elbow Re-examined The Yankees right-hander Dave Robertson had a second magnetic resonance imaging exam for his stiff right elbow in Pensacola, Fla. Dr. James Andrews, who examined Robertson, recommended that he rest for 10 days to two weeks before starting a throwing program, a timetable that does not rule out Robertson for a chance to make the postseason roster. Robertson has a 3.29 E.R.A. in 42 games, averaging more than 13 strikeouts per nine innings.

Through my own experiences playing junior tennis, I learned the importance of keeping a level head. The message young girls should remember: Attitude is everything.

LYND--Susan Crosby Thompson, 66, died August 16, 2009 in hospice at Scarborough, ME. She and her husband Richard B. Lynd had lived in Brooklyn Heights for 36 years before retiring to Susan's childhood home near Albany in 2003. She was the daughter of the late William Leland Thompson Jr. of East Greenbush, NY and the late Maris Wistar (Townsend) Thompson of Bryn Mawr, PA. She studied at Chatham Hall, Colby and Firenze. Susan worked for thirty-three years for TIME and LIFE, the last twenty-six at TIME, rising to News Desk Manager. She loved her home, her garden, her "Bear", her "Wiglet", cooking, swimming, and especially her Westies, "Gus" and "Agnes." For 55 years she enjoyed her summer times in Kennebunkport. With enormous courage Susan for three years maintained the life she wanted despite a struggle with cancer. She is survived by her husband, Richard, (email: windward22@ verizon.net), her sister Maris Wistar Thompson, many cousins, godchildren, loved ones and friends. A graveside memorial service will be held in late October at the Church of the Redeemer, Bryn Mawr, PA. Contributions in Susan's memory to Gosnell Memorial Hospice, 11 Hunnewell Rd., Scarborough, ME 04074 would be appreciated. HALCYON 10TH ANNIVERSARY When halcyon first opened its doors as a lowercased record shop-cafe-thrift store-gallery-lounge on Smith Street a decade ago, the very idea of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, as a stylish destination was still new. Most of the locavore restaurants, designer-driven boutiques and low-key bars were still a gleam in some well-meaning gentrifier's eye. How far we've come! All the way to ... Dumbo. That's where halcyon moved in 2004, driven away in part by its own success.

WINDELS--Paul, Jr. The partners and staff of Windels Marx Lane & Mittendorf, LLP, are deeply saddened by the loss of our former partner, Paul Windels, Jr., one of the founders of the firm. Among his many other accomplishments, Paul served as an Assistant United States Attorney, Regional Administrator of the SEC, President of the Federal Bar Council, and President of Brooklyn Law School. As all of us who worked with Paul know so well, he was a fierce and committed advocate, and a wonderful raconteur. Paul had an intellectual curiosity which led him to a broad range of subjects, all of which he was ready to discuss on any given day. His leadership, great intelligence and charisma significantly contributed to the firm's growth and success. His good judgment and skills were admired not only by those at the firm who had the privilege to work with him but also by many of the firm's clients who sought out his wise counsel and impressive advocacy skills. Paul will be greatly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his children, Paul, Mary, James and Patrick, and to the rest of his family and his many friends. Windels Marx Lane & Mittendorf, LLP

My Sunday column looks at health care reform through the prism of Nikki White, a young woman from Tennessee. She became too sick with Lupus to work -- and then lost her health insurance, and then died because of lack of medical care. We may know intellectually that 18,000 Americans die each year because they don't have insurance, but to confront one such person is still heartbreaking. And I just can't believe that we will let this opportunity for health reform slip through our fingers, so that Americans like Nikki continue to die needlessly every 30 minutes.

PEN American Center has joined the controversy over a decision by Yale University Press to excise images of Muhammad from one of its new books and urged Yale to reconsider. PEN, the literary and human rights organization, sent a letter to Yale’s president and board calling the decision “out of character with Yale, its reputation and its leadership position.” The book, “The Cartoons That Shook the World” by Jytte Klausen, details the violent protests that erupted after a dozen provocative drawings by Danish cartoonists featuring the prophet were published in 2005 and 2006 in European newspapers. The cartoons, as well as other images of Muhammad, including a Doré illustration for “Dante’s Inferno,” were initially to be included. After Yale consulted with security and Islamic experts, it decided to pull all images of the prophet. The letter said that after debates among members from around the world, including countries where mob protests resulted in deaths, PEN reached “one clear, consensus position: The introduction of violence or threats of violence into debates over art and ideas is to be rejected and condemned.” The letter concluded that PEN was troubled by the “assessment that publishing the images could provoke a violent response — which we believe discredits both Professor Klausen’s work and its readership — and by the decision to pull the images based on speculative threats.”.

GOLDSTEIN--Elliott Goldstein, a leader of the American corporate bar, died on September 10, at Piedmont Hospital in Atlanta, GA. An Atlanta native, he was a partner in the law firm of Bryan Cave Powell Goldstein (formerly Powell, Goldstein, Frazer & Murphy), which he joined in 1939. He was a nationally prominent corporate and securities lawyer and founded the firm's Washington, DC office in 1977. In addition, Mr. Goldstein was a decorated World War II veteran and active in Atlanta community and cultural affairs. Mr. Goldstein was born in Atlanta, Georgia on October 23, 1915, to Max F. and Ray London Goldstein. He was married to Harriet (Weinberg) Goldstein until her death in December, 2004. He is survived by his daughters, Lily Friedlander and Ellen Goldstein; his grandson Jesse Friedlander, his wife Shelly, and great-grandson Adin Zachry. His grandson Emil Friedlander died in 2003. Funeral services will be held at The Temple, 1589 Peachtree Road, NE, Atlanta, GA 30309, at 3:00pm on Sunday, September 13, with visitation at The Temple at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to The Atlanta History Center, The Temple or the High Museum of Art.
