TRUETT--Charles "Charley," age 65. Cherished husband of Eleanor (nee Miller); devoted father of Charles Badgett Truett III, and Lesley Elizabeth Weiss, both of New York; caring son of Gordon and the late Dorothy Marquis; generous and loving big brother of Carl Truett, Elizabeth Marquis de Gomez, Dorothy MarquisOmer and Grace Marquis; beloved uncle and great-uncle. Fatally injured in an accident; died Monday, September 7, 2009 in Cleveland, Ohio. US Navy veteran. Charles was an employee of Bank of America for over 30 years and an employee of Primus International until his retirement in Cleveland, Ohio. Private services will be held. mcgorray-hanna.com 216-226-5356

SELTZER--Harold Isaac, died Wednesday, September 10, 2009. Loving husband of Adele. Beloved father of Amy and Steven and father-in-law of Harry and Sharon. Devoted grandfather of Emily, Jessica, Elisabeth, Samantha, Jacob and Joshua. His humor, kindness and inner strength were matched only by his love for and devotion to his family. Services Sunday, at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. For information call 212-362-6600.

WINDELS--Paul, Jr.,died peacefully on September 8. Beloved husband of the late Mary Patricia Ripley Windels; father of Paul Windels III, Mary Hyde Windels, James Hazen Ripley Windels, and Patrick Dillon Windels; and grandfather of Patrick Emmons Windels, Thomas Ripley Windels, George Gunderson Windels, Mary Catherine Yuelan Windels, and Paul Eugene Ruhao Windels. Alumnus of Brooklyn Friends School, Brooks School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. Served in the United States Army in World War II attaining the rank of Major and saw combat in numerous engagements. Chief Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York (1953-57) and Regional Administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission (1957-61), during which time he led the prosecution of the so-called boiler room operators and the investigation of Cady, Roberts & Co., the initial insider trading case, in 1959. Lead Partner Windels, Curry & Rice, Windels, Merritt & Ingraham, Windels & Marx, and Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives and thereafter of counsel to Windels, Marx, Lane & Mittendorf. Chair of the Judicial Nominating Committees for Senators James L. Buckley and Alfonse M. D'Amato. President of the Federal Bar Council. President of the Board, Brooklyn Law School and the Lycee Francais de New York. Trustee of the Lexington School for the Deaf, the Knox School, the French Institute, and the Atlantic Foundation. A funeral service will be held on Monday, September 14, 2009, at 10:00am at St. James Episcopal Church, Route 25A, St. James, New York. A memorial service will be held at Brooklyn Law School during the fall. SHTOB--Evelyn Dorothy, passed away Wednesday, September 9 at home, surrounded by family. A lifelong political activist, she was the former Executive Director of the NYC National Lawyers Guild. Born in 1915 in Baltimore, she moved to New York, the city she loved, at 17, where she spent the rest of her life. She was devoted to progressive causes and was a mentor and friend to a generation of Guild members. She was predeceased by her husband Abe, her brother Art and sister Ruth. She is survived by her children Terry and Eric (Sonia), grandchildren Nick (Florence) and Dan (Brittany), and grandchildren Hugo, Leo and Molly, and a large circle of devoted friends. A memorial service will be held in coming weeks.

SHTOB--Dorothy. The New York City chapter of the National Lawyers Guild with great sadness recognizes the death of Dorothy (Dotty) Shtob, our long-term Executive Director (ret.) on September 9 at the age of 93. She was predeceased by her husband and friend Abe. Dotty was one of a kind and fought the good fight until the end. A better role model for political activists we could not ask for. Our thoughts go out to her children Eric Shtob and Terry Shtob; daughter-in-law Sonia Collins Shtob; her grandchildren Dan Shtob (Brittany McFall) and Nicholas Chaikin (Florence Denat) and Amy and Callie Setasak; her great-grandchildren Hugo, Leo and Molly and the hundreds of political/legal activists that she nurtured.

NEUMAN--Henry B. Neuman (Hank), 80, of Sarasota, FL, formerly of Ithaca, NY, died September 5th, 2009. Born in Manhattan, he attended Ithaca College (1956) and Cornell University (1958), becoming an actor, teacher and theatre director. Survivors include son, Josh Neuman of Brooklyn, NY, brother, Monroe Neuman of Chevy Chase, MD and his beloved life partner, Rita Compain of Sarasota, FL.

As President Obama prepared to seek support for his health care overhaul in Minnesota this weekend, the state's governor, Tim Pawlenty, raised a states' rights argument to counter his proposal. ''Depending on what the federal government comes out with here, asserting the 10th Amendment may be a viable option, but we don't know the details,'' Mr. Pawlenty said Thursday evening in a conference call organized by the Republican Governors Association, according to Minnesota Public Radio. ''As one of the other callers said, we can't get the president to outline what he does or doesn't support in any detail. So we'll have to see. I would have to say that it's a possibility.''

MANDEL--Stephen Frank, of Darien, CT, of pneumonia, on September 11th at Stamford Hospital. Born in New York at Doctors' Hospital on April 27, 1931, of Dorothy Buchman Mandel and Richard Henry Mandel. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Dartmouth College and the Stanford Graduate School of Business. He is survived by his wife, Ann Safford Mandel, and his sons, Stephen F. Mandel, Jr., and his wife, Susan, of Greenwich, CT, and Edward Safford Mandel and his wife, Betsy, of Chevy Chase, MD, five grandchildren: Kate, Ben, Tom, Ned and Mollie Mandel, and his brother, Richard H. Mandel, Jr., of Denver, CO. In his professional career he was President of Allstate Welding Products in Elmsford, NY, and International Welding Products in Greenwich, CT. As a longtime community leader, he was devoted to the Darien Library, where he was Board President and an Honorary Trustee; Explorer Post 53 Emergency Medical Service; Gallivant; as president of the Darien Community Fund (United Way); and Dartmouth College, among many others. A private service in his memory will be held for his family. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Darien Library, 1441 Post Road, Darien, CT 06820, or Explorer Post 53, Ledge Road, Darien, CT 06820.

FREEDMAN--Jack, 79, passed away peacefully in New York City after a five month long illness. Founder of women's boutiques including The Village Set, August Max, Sam Brown, and a senior executive for the past 14 years at Paul Stuart. His passions included his family, boating, and the retail clothing industry. He is survived by his loving wife Peggy, children Mark, Perry and Lisa; daughters-in-law and son-in-law Renay, Diane and Paul; stepchildren Kristen and Kate; and grandchildren Jamie, Elan, Ari, Nikki, Sam, Rebecca, Jonathan, Harrison and Julia. His wife of 43 years, Joy, and granddaughter Anna predeceased him. Jack successfully passed on his dry wit and humor to his children... but not his delivery. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, September 13, 2009 at 10:30am at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

TILLES--Rose. The Long Island University community extends its deepest condolences to the Tilles family on the death of their beloved Rose Tilles. Mrs. Tilles, a generous benefactress of the University and of its Rose and Gilbert Tilles Center for the Performing Arts, played a pioneering role, along with her family, in changing the cultural landscape of Long Island and in supporting arts education. Her husband, the late Gilbert Tilles, and her son Roger Tilles both served on the University's Board of Trustees, the latter becoming its chair. She will be sorely missed by the many people whose lives she touched. Her legacy lives on through the Tilles Center and through the Gilbert and Rose Tilles Endowment for Arts Education, which was established to honor her and her husband by their children, Ellen, Peter and Roger. Edward Travaglianti, Chairman of the Board Long Island University David J. Steinberg, President Long Island University John R. Bransfield, Jr., Chairman Council of Overseers Tilles Center for the Performing Arts Elliott Sroka, Executive Director Tilles Center for the Performing Arts

8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: JOANNE WOODWARDAnd, as a bonus, a couple of shots of her husband, Paul Newman, who died last year. The must-see viewing begins with ''The Long, Hot Summer'' (1958), Martin Ritt's adaptation of the Faulkner novel ''The Hamlet,'' about the unmarried daughter of a wealthy Mississippi merchant and the drifter who brings the family's problems to a head. (Above, Ms. Woodward and Newman in those roles.) It continues at 10 with ''The Three Faces of Eve'' (1957), starring Ms. Woodward in her Oscar-winning role as a woman with multiple personality disorder; ''Summer Wishes, Winter Dreams'' (1973), at midnight, in which she plays a New York City housewife in a midlife crisis; and at 2 a.m. ''Count Three and Play'' (1955), with Van Heflin as a former Union soldier who becomes a preacher in a small Southern town to overcome his shady past, and Ms. Woodward as the young woman who helps him rebuild a church. The evening concludes at 4 with ''Paris Blues'' (1961), starring Newman and Sidney Poitier as expatriate jazz musicians living in France, and Ms. Woodward and Diahann Carroll as the American tourists with whom they fall in love. 10:30 A.M. BERNSTEIN--William, 82, died September 10, 2009 after a long illness. Survived by wife Doris, daughters Willa and Carolyn, son-in-law Nick Grad, grandchildren Anna, Lucas and Georgia, brother Marvin and extended family. A lifelong New Yorker, alumnus of Stuyvesant, CCNY (Varsity Basketball), and NYU Law (Law Review). Served U.S. Army- Special Agent, Counter Intelligence Corps (Korea). Counselor-at-law for 57 years, Bill was a skilled and zealous advocate, highly esteemed by clients and colleagues. He was a good man who loved life, took great pleasure in simple things and never said no to someone in need. His generosity, undying optimism and genuine interest brightened the lives he touched. He will be missed every day. Memorial services will be held on Monday, September 14th, at 12 noon, at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Tourists who bought some of the $5 commemorative booklets being sold at ground zero this week clutched them closely, almost reverently, as they gazed at the lingering hole in Lower Manhattan. But a look inside many of the slim volumes reveals them to be error-riddled efforts. A typical photo caption notes that the attacks condemned those trapped inside the World Trade Center ''to a horrifice death.''

TILLES--Rose. Rose Tilles lived her life with dignity, courage, beauty and a caring which was an inspiration to all of us who knew and loved her. Rose and Gilbert Tilles were leaders in the community, in philanthropy and in matters which touched people's lives. They were role models for those of us who were younger and inspired us to live as they did: a life committed to faith, community, and the welfare of others. We will always be grateful for the many ways in which Rose, with her love of art and music enriched our lives. We will remember the expression of pride when she looked at her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren who added a new dimension to her life and became her life. Our heartfelt condolence to the Tilles family on their loss. Sol and Joan Wachtler

When it comes to casual clothing, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has never exactly blended in. Incorrigibly preppy, he favors brightly colored V-neck sweaters, pinstriped dress shirts and tan boat shoes. The country-club look presents natural challenges on the campaign trail.

CASPERSEN--Finn M.W. The Peddie School community mourns the death of Finn M.W. Caspersen '59, esteemed chair of Peddie School's Board of Trustees since 1976. Through his wise leadership, incomparable vision and thoughtful generosity, he helped transform Peddie into one of the nation's preeminent independent schools. No one was more devoted to his alma mater or our students. As Finn often reminded us, a good school is about much more than just bricks and mortar; it's about doing better things for children and our society. He will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Barbara, and the entire Caspersen family. John Green, Head of School Peddie School Board of Trustees The Students, Faculty and Staff of Peddie School

Melinda R. Katz, a candidate for comptroller, reminds voters that she is the only woman running for citywide office. And more than once this season, she has had to contend with everything that goes along with that. About 8 a.m. on one recent morning -- four hours after Ms. Katz woke up to feed her infant son -- she greeted commuters at 125th Street and Broadway. One woman cheered her on, saying, ''We all need to stick together.'' A middle-aged woman, who said she worked at Columbia University, talked with Ms. Katz about city issues for several minutes. When Ms. Katz asked her for an assessment, the woman delivered a less-than-welcome endorsement: ''I give you an A+ for personality and a B- for makeup,'' she said.

Mark Green was considered a thorn. Betsy Gotbaum could have been more of one. Those are general some reviews of the only two people who have ever been the public advocate of New York City, a position created in 1989 (came out of charter revision in 89, but seems to have been created in 1993. will fudge) to replace the post of City Council president. The first public advocate, Mr. Green, the first public advocate, from 1994 to 2001, is among the Democrats competing in Tuesday's primary. Officially, the public advocate is the city's ombudsman, solving problems, overseeing city agencies and presiding over Council meetings, all with a few dozen staff members, a modest budget and limited authority. But unofficially, the public advocate can be an outspoken check on the mayor's power -- like Mr. Green -- or a quiet, behind-the-scenes negotiator -- like Ms. Gotbaum. TORONTO — Bright white shirts. Maybe it’s a Tom Ford thing, as Mr. Ford is known for them and is scheduled to show up to begin screening his movie “A Single Man” on Monday night. But the classic shirts have been showing up all over the place at the Toronto International Film Festival. On Harvey Weinstein at lunch on the Four Seasons on Saturday. On both Coen brothers, Joel and Ethan, as they took the stage to present their new film “A Serious Man” at the Elgin Theater on Saturday night. Most unlikely of all, on the shaggy-faced Jeff Bridges. Mr. Bridges, the Dude, made his Friday appearances for “The Men Who Stared at Goats” dressed in a most unfestival-like blue suit, with a steel-blue tie, over a bright white shirt. Maybe the black T-shirt and jeans, a uniform for the last few years among filmmakers and those who wished to look like them, has finally passed.

TORONTO — It’s fascinating to watch the power of myth in action. The process was on full display at a Sunday morning press conference for “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” at the Four Seasons hotel here at the Toronto International Film Festival. One of the first questions came from a television reporter who asked Tyler Perry, an executive producer, how difficult it was to get the movie made. “Did you bankroll it yourself?” the reporter wanted to know.
Jim Carroll, the poet and punk rocker in the outlaw tradition of Rimbaud and Burroughs who chronicled his wild youth in “The Basketball Diaries,” died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60.

TORONTO — Questions about the value placed on art and the motives of those who attribute that value are among the many presented in “The Art of the Steal.” The documentary looks at the Barnes Foundation, a Post-Impressionist and early Modern collection of art that has been revered worldwide. With a structure that plays much like a mystery, the film details the twists and turns in the struggle for control of the collection after the death of its founder, Albert C. Barnes, in 1951. The film’s director, Don Argott, spoke at the Toronto film festival about the Barnes collection and the battle over whether to move the collection from the foundation’s headquarters in the Philadelphia suburbs to the city’s downtown area.

But it does seem that the American Medical Association’s rush to judgment on their behalf, Dr. Pou’s P.R. campaign and portrayal of herself as a victim and the air-brushing of her own role in administering the injections suggest a startling lack of candor. Her ongoing efforts to redefine the meaning of Do Not Resuscitate orders and change public policy and medical standards, perhaps to justify what went on at Memorial hospital, demands close scrutiny if not outright condemnation. The Takeaway Glen plaid has a checkered history that bridges social and cultural divides. The sturdy fabric was originally worn in the 1800s by Scottish gamekeepers but got a big leg up the social ladder when Edward VII embraced it during his time as Prince of Wales.

The literature of women writing about motherhood is by now so extensive that no pebble has been left unturned. Women who have found their life’s purpose in raising a child, women who have not found their life’s purpose in raising a child, women who parse every playground conversation, women who strive to outdo other mothers, women who feel guilty that they bought the cupcakes instead of baking them, women who take to drinking after the little darlings fall asleep — you name it, it’s been duly recorded. Let us now turn our attention to what the men have been going through.

TOM HINGSTON AND UNITED VISUAL ARTISTS.
When plain old yellow just won’t do.

When Ellis Kreuger, a designer who has worked for Daryl K, Tocca and Liz Claiborne, moved to Hong Kong, the city’s famed tailors weren’t all he expected. “Left to their own devices, they tend toward a Gordon Gekko look,” he says. Together with his partner, John Alexander Daye (who has become the label’s de facto model, above), Kreuger created J. A. Daye, an online made-to-measure line. The idea is to use Hong Kong’s relatively inexpensive tailors while making sure that the clothes retain their edge. Visitors log on to the J. A. Daye Web site and browse through a collection designed by Kreuger and Daye; after making their selections, they follow a body measuring guide and input their personal data. Kreuger and Daye pass on the information to their tailoring team, and a week or so later a package arrives in the mail with the bespoke clothing carefully wrapped in tissue paper. In case you’re visiting Hong Kong, the pair just opened a store called Moustache, which carries their more casual, ready-to-wear line of the same name. [?][?][?] ARMAND LIMNANDER.

Back in 1955, when denim was the height of rebelliousness, Sloan Wilson’s novel “The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit” turned a men’s classic into a synonym for drab, middle-class conformity. More than 50 years later, with everyone in jeans and T-shirts, this reliable warhorse has become oddly hip.
Sherlock Holmes . . . Gray Flannel . . . Video Art . . . Hasidic Tailoring . . . Hugh Hefner.
1. Gareth Pugh’s first men’s collection is cutting-edge cool for cyborgs.

There were plenty of highlights during Kim Jones’s debut for Dunhill: trousers with floating waistbands, coats with exaggerated toggles and great leather bags. But a couple of gimlet-eyed editors spotted an odd accessory dangling from Jones’s neck when he came out after the show. It was the key to his house — though, of course, not just any ordinary key. His had a small, beautiful silver watch in its bow. The interest Jones received was such that he decided to make the item available by special order at select Dunhill stores. The only drawback: you’ll never again have a valid excuse for coming home late. Go to dunhill.com or call 011-44-845-458-0779 for more information. [?][?][?] ARMAND LIMNANDER.

He was a patriot and a poet, a dandy and a war hero. In turn-of-the-century Italy, no one embodied the cult of beauty and the love of action like Gabriele d’Annunzio. He was the incarnation of the Nietzschean Übermensch: narcissistic, powerful and seemingly invincible. Soldiers applauded his epic adventures; literati exalted his vast output; women couldn’t resist his voracious sexual appetite.
ARTWORK BY UNITED VISUAL ARTISTS AND TOM HINGSTON STUDIO.

The first time Luc Tuymans exhibited in the United States, in 1994, he showed a painting called “Tracing,” depicting an embroidered bouquet of flowers. Simple, pleasant enough — until you learned that the pattern was taken from a chair in which someone was brutally murdered. Typical Tuymans: his most famous piece is an empty, otherwise-anonymous room with the chilling title “Gas Chamber.” The Belgian artist skyrocketed to the top of Europe’s contemporary art scene in the ’90s by using such banal, decontextualized images as stand-ins for some of history’s most troubled moments. When his first United States retrospective opens this week at the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, the subject matter will consist of 9/11, the Holocaust and the atrocities committed in the Belgian Congo, among others. But “it’s not all horror all the time,” insists Helen Molesworth, the co-curator of the exhibition, which will travel to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art next year. “When you stand in front of his paintings, you can’t believe how beautiful they are. They have an eerie quality of developing before your eyes, like a photograph in a darkroom tray, and an uncanny sense of light and fluidity. They make you think about how just about anything in our culture can be turned into a pretty picture, and how used to it we are.” [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV.
INTELLECTUAL PROVOCATEUR.

Though rules are meant to be broken, sometimes it’s more fun to give them just a little tweak. That’s the thinking behind Homme Deux, the new suit collection by Comme des Garçons. Previously available only in Japan, it has been discreetly reworked for its international debut: suits rock subtly mismatched pinstripes, jackets are accented with tropical wool lapels, and linings boast a riot of polka dots. The softly tailored line, says Adrian Joffe, the C.E.O. of Comme des Garçons and husband to the designer Rei Kawakubo, will appeal to someone who “wants something slightly different, slightly more comfortable. . . . These are suits for the handsome mind.” [?][?][?] GLENN WALDRON.

He was a patriot and a poet, a dandy and a war hero. In turn-of-the-century Italy, no one embodied the cult of beauty and the love of action like Gabriele d’Annunzio. In fashion, the things that appear the simplest never are: fortunes have been made and lost on jeans or the perfect white T-shirt. Enter Barnabé Hardy (barnabehardy.com), who left his job as the director of Balenciaga’s men’s-wear line to cook up the ultimate leather jacket. His first collection consists mostly of variations on the bomber: nine versions in colors that include black, chocolate and dark khaki and come in lambskin or baby calf hair with laser-cut vents or parkalike stitching. Balenciaga fans will recognize Hardy’s fit: narrow in the front but with armholes wide enough to allow for freedom of movement. “Leather is alive,” says the slim 34-year-old. “Besides, nowadays even fashion victims like to be comfortable.” [?][?][?] ALEXANDRA MARSHALL.

1. The Korean designer Juun J. cites early Grace Jones — circa flat-top cuts and Keith Haring-applied body paint — as his inspiration. The resulting big shoulders, hoods, trenches and rider jackets recall the icon’s fearsome, androgynous presence in “A View to a Kill.” At Seven New York, 110 Mercer Street.

Two years ago, when Paul Smith’s creative directors displayed Paul Loebach’s first collection in the window of their SoHo store, they jokingly called it the “anti-Moss,” referring to the superslick Manhattan design temple around the corner. It turns out they were onto something: design is back to a more understated aesthetic, and Loebach’s craft-meets-technology vibe is making him the most talked-about young American designer since Jason Miller. For the design store Matter, to cite an example, Loebach contributed exposed-frame sofas and turned-wood ladders to the shop’s first in-house furniture line; the Milanese gallery owner Rossana Orlandi recently snapped up his digitally distorted wood vases informed by ancient Korean pottery. “I’m more interested in things I can’t make on my own,” says Loebach, who was born and raised in Ohio, graduated from Rhode Island School of Design in 2002 and spent the first five years of his career assisting various Brooklyn woodworkers. Accordingly, his next pieces for Matter will focus on dragging into modernity what may be his least glitzy source material yet: Adirondack furniture. [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV.

Ian Barry is on a quest to make the best custom bikes anywhere. He and his fiancée, Amaryllis Knight, founded Falcon Motorcycles in Los Angeles earlier this year; together they unearth special parts on eBay and on research trips (one find: a 1920 Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost headlight) and transform them into one-of-a-kind rides. The bikes take four to nine months to complete and, like a finely tailored suit, are fitted to the owner. “If a client sits on the bike and looks like a goof,” Barry says, “something’s got to be changed.” Besides special orders, Barry and Knight are working on their Concept Ten collection, 10 bikes created from derelict frames and engines of historic British marques from the pre- and postwar era: “Those bikes were built from an artist perspective, and the shapes and forms are simply amazing.” Only one, the Bullet, has been completed and was purchased by the actor Jason Lee. Buyer beware: Barry likes to joke that whenever Lee leaves town, he gets to borrow the bike.

STYLE MAP NASHVILLE If all that Nashville conjures up is cowboy boots and Robert Altman, it’s time for a visit. Now that the likes of Jack White of the White Stripes and Nicole Kidman have embraced the country-western capital, the style factor is way up. You can spend a Friday night gallery hopping downtown or listening to some of the best bluegrass and indie rock ever. Boots and a Stetson still fly, but so do handmade buffalo wingtips from Billy Reid. CHRISTINE MUHLKE.
Before the mansion, the clubs and the circular bed Hugh Hefner was like every other teenage boy: looking for an identity and finding it in fantasy.

Mendy Sacho is a young Lubavitcher tailor determined to give a contemporary twist to the kapote, the black knee-length coat worn by married Hasidic men. Sacho, who owns Sartoria Sacho in Toronto, trims the kapote in bright hues and lines it in everything from wild paisleys to dark purples. “The younger guys come to me for color on the buttonholes,” says Sacho, who plans to open an outpost of Sartoria Sacho in Brooklyn this fall. “Or they want the inside purple to match the purple in their tie. The older guys come to me because I will make them something that fits perfectly.” Amazingly, Sacho says his clientele is just 70 percent Jewish — and he’d like the ratio to be 50-50. If Jean Paul Gaultier could parade Hasidic-looking raiments on the runway, why can’t Sacho? “We are not all black hat, white shirt,” he says. “You can be religious and still be with the times.” Go to kapotas.com. [?][?][?] SARAH KLEINBERG.

Having an M.B.A. from Oxford and a background in telecommunications may take you places, but London’s Savile Row isn’t usually one of them. Enter Patrick Grant, the debonair 37-year-old boss of Norton & Sons, and currently the youngest “guv’nor” on the Row. Five years ago, Grant spotted an ad in the Financial Times for the sale of Norton — a 19th-century tailoring house loved by Emperor Wilhelm I of Prussia and a young Winston Churchill. With no experience “but an enormous love of old British brands,” Grant sold his house, car “and everything else” and set about transforming the fortunes of the ailing suitmaker. Since then, the entrepreneurial Scotsman has brokered impressive collaborations with some of London’s hottest young designers (Kim Jones, Giles Deacon, Richard Nicoll and Christopher Kane) while ensuring that the company’s client list of European royalty is as nattily attired as ever. This year Grant is also developing a new fragrance with Penhaligon’s and reviving E. Tautz, a long-forgotten English label famed for its hunting breeches. Still, the old timers on Savile Row regard him with caution. “In 20 years I’ll probably still be seen as the ‘new boy’ around here,” he says, laughing. “But it hasn’t done me any harm so far.” [?][?][?] GLENN WALDRON.
MEN’S FASHION FALL 2009.

IN-STORE THE WEBSTER In Miami, a city where bodies matter more than clothes, a 20,000-square-foot shrine to high fashion seems daring. But if anyone can pull it off, it’s Laure Hériard Dubreuil and Frederic Dechnik (below) together with Milan Vukmirovic, the creative director for Trussardi 1911.
It’s a toggle to the end.

For the Japanese designer Jun Takahashi, fashion is never just about clothes. After his Undercover presentation of futuristic nylon outfits (set to a live performance by Kan Takagi and Atsuhiro Ito) in Florence, Italy, he moved on to a stage where he made witchy dolls from cut-up teddy bears, robotic structures and pieces of lace. “They are like my daughters — they are all women, and they are all named Grace,” says Takahashi, who describes himself as a “polite destroyer”; things that are “just beautiful,” he adds, don’t interest him. “By showing these two types of creations, which are almost contrary to each other, I can give more depth to the Undercover world.” [?][?][?] ARMAND LIMNANDER.

An article on Aug. 30 about backpacking in Colorado with llamas misstated the name for the language of the Incas. The official language of the Inca empire was Quechua; there is no such language as “Incan.” The article also misspelled the Quechua word for herder. It is michiy — not michi, which means cat.

In the coming days, a Homeland Security task force is to recommend whether to keep, revise or scrap the color-coded terrorism-alert system that has for years alternately panicked and befuddled Americans. The Op-Ed editors asked four graphic designers for their own ideas for an improved warning system. The threat of terrorism will forever be with us. We will always need to be cautious in airports, train stations and other public spaces. Therefore, our everyday condition is one of ''caution,'' symbolized by the letter C.

CASPERSEN--Finn M.W. The Peddie School community mourns the death of Finn M.W. Caspersen '59, esteemed chair of Peddie School's Board of Trustees since 1976. Through his wise leadership, incomparable vision and thoughtful generosity, he helped transform Peddie into one of the nation's preeminent independent schools. No one was more devoted to his alma mater or our students. As Finn often reminded us, a good school is about much more than just bricks and mortar; it's about doing better things for children and our society. He will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Barbara, and the entire Caspersen family. John Green, Head of School Peddie School Board of Trustees The Students, Faculty and Staff of Peddie School

TILLES--Rose. Rose Tilles lived her life with dignity, courage, beauty and a caring which was an inspiration to all of us who knew and loved her. Rose and Gilbert Tilles were leaders in the community, in philanthropy and in matters which touched people's lives. They were role models for those of us who were younger and inspired us to live as they did: a life committed to faith, community, and the welfare of others. We will always be grateful for the many ways in which Rose, with her love of art and music enriched our lives. We will remember the expression of pride when she looked at her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren who added a new dimension to her life and became her life. Our heartfelt condolence to the Tilles family on their loss. Sol and Joan Wachtler

BEIJING A TASTE OF PYONGYANG Pyongyang Haedanghua Raeng Myon (12 Chaowai Dajie, Wangshi Bailijiaju Shopping Center; 86-10-8561-2925) is the most popular of a series of North Korean-themed diners sponsored by the embassy in Beijing -- and it perfectly captures the tone of that notoriously secretive country. Inside, cellphone calls are cut off, documents and notebooks are checked, and hostesses dressed in traditional gowns will ask for your place of origin in several different languages.

SCHINDLER--Joan, a gifted interior designer, died on September 1st, 2009. Prior to launching her own firm in 1982, she studied at the New York School of Interior Design and went on to partner with her mother Cele Pollock, an established designer. Over the course of her career, she took part in the opening of the Polo Ralph Lauren flagship store in Beverly Hills, designed specialized interiors for a school for children with learning disabilities, created the prototype for a chain of croissant shops, and worked on countless residential projects on both coasts as well as in Europe. Her work has appeared in House & Garden, Elle Decor, Food & Wine, and a recent project was the House Beautiful selection for Kitchen of the Year in 2007, a cover story for the magazine. She is survived by daughter Jo Wood-Brown, son Les Goldberg, three grandsons Christopher Goldberg, Charles Goldberg, Charles Henry Wood, and great-grandson Charles Goldberg Jr. There will be a memorial service on October 11th.

THE Frankfurt Motor Show will begin on Sept. 15 with two days of previews for a media corps eager to gauge what has changed since the automobile industry's last gathering there two years ago. Among European automakers, there seems to be a change in their visions of a greener, more sustainable future. Diesel technologies played on center stage two years ago, as Mercedes-Benz, BMW, Audi and Volkswagen all promoted high-mileage clean diesels as the Next Big Thing.

In the coming days, a Homeland Security task force is to recommend whether to keep, revise or scrap the color-coded terrorism-alert system that has for years alternately panicked and befuddled Americans. The Op-Ed editors asked four graphic designers for their own ideas for an improved warning system. A flaw of the current alert system is that the public gets used to a given threat level and then ignores it. But this system allows citizens to track daily, weekly, monthly or yearly changes in the terrorist threat level as easily as they follow the stock market. Just as investors grow concerned whenever the Dow drops, citizens would know to increase their vigilance only when the threat level goes up and stays up.

SHTOB--Dorothy. The New York City chapter of the National Lawyers Guild with great sadness recognizes the death of Dorothy (Dotty) Shtob, our long-term Executive Director (ret.) on September 9 at the age of 93. She was predeceased by her husband and friend Abe. Dotty was one of a kind and fought the good fight until the end. A better role model for political activists we could not ask for. Our thoughts go out to her children Eric Shtob and Terry Shtob; daughter-in-law Sonia Collins Shtob; her grandchildren Dan Shtob (Brittany McFall) and Nicholas Chaikin (Florence Denat) and Amy and Callie Setasak; her great-grandchildren Hugo, Leo and Molly and the hundreds of political/legal activists that she nurtured.

TALK SHOW It was a bright winter Saturday morning and I'd gone into the small town to get the paper. Not having done this before, I realized in returning that I hadn't paid attention and was not sure how to get back. I was lost. All streets looked equally likely, so I picked one of many for no reason. I picked wrong, but that led to what followed. In front of a schoolhouse there were a lot of parked cars and people milling around among tables, apparently shopping for whatever was on display. Seeing the words ''Village Book Fair'' made me want to stop, but for some forgotten reason, I was in a hurry. It was clearly a popular event but, sadly, there were no vacant parking spaces for even a quick inspection, so I chose, reluctantly, to move on. But suddenly a car obligingly pulled out right in front of me, and I pulled in.

''I'm a resident physician, and for the most part, I am in agreement with the president's address. However, I wish he had touched on something I believe to be essential to reducing costs: the importance of changing our current incentive structure. ... Until the incentives are changed, physicians will continue to drive up costs in order to pad their bottom line.'' Will Knight, in a comment on the Prescriptions blog.

IT takes a lot of confidence to put your designs on shuffle. Applause, then, to Momo, the graffiti artist whose vivid geometric explosions can be found around Manhattan. In a collaboration on a limited-edition sneaker with Y-3, Momo painted three designs, which were cut and formed into a pattern. The sneaker's final look was a complete surprise to the artist, he says, but in a good way. The kicks are about $380 at Y-3 stores. JASON RIDER

'He carries himself in a manner that's worthy of passing Gehrig. One thing that I especially love about him is that if he hits a ground ball to short, it's always a bang-bang play at first, no matter what. He is always hustling.' JOE MADDON, the manager of the Rays, after Derek Jeter tied Lou Gehrig for the Yankees' franchise record for hits, 2,721.
Classical Vivien Schweitzer

SIMON--Debbie. The faculty, staff, and board of directors of the NYU Child Study Center express with great sadness the passing of Debbie Simon. She was a beautiful woman in every way and a strong advocate of children's mental health. We send our sympathy to her children, Lauren, David, and Scott and her entire family.

The number of New Yorkers commuting by bicycle has increased 45 percent since 2006, according to a City Transportation Department survey. As part of a campaign begun three years ago, the city has built new bike lanes, installed more than 750 new bike racks and more than 600 street signs designating bicycle routes, and distributed 23,000 free helmets and 680,000 free maps of bike routes. After a recent visit, Andy Clarke, the president of the League of American Bicyclists, said, ''New York City compares well and is improving faster than almost any other city in the U.S.''

9 P.M. (MTV) 2009 MTV VIDEO MUSIC AWARDS The comedian Russell Brand returns as host of this ceremony, which will be broadcast live from Radio City Music Hall and feature a tribute to Michael Jackson by his sister Janet. Jay-Z, Alicia Keys, Lady Gaga, Beyoncé (right), Green Day, Pink, Taylor Swift and Muse are scheduled to perform; the rapper Wale and the go-go band UCB will join forces as the show's house band. Beyoncé and Lady Gaga lead the nominations with nine each; Britney Spears has seven; and Kanye West, Eminem and Coldplay each received four. Nominees for best new artist are 3OH!3, Asher Roth, Drake, Kid Cudi and Lady Gaga; voting will continue throughout the show until shortly before the award's announcement. Katy Perry, Jennifer Lopez, Ne-Yo, Chace Crawford, Megan Fox and 50 Cent are among the presenters. At 8, Ashley Green and Tim Kash will report from the red carpet. The post-show festivities begin at 11:15. 10 A.M. Cruise ships on their way to Alaska often stop in Vancouver, British Columbia, engines idling, wasting diesel fuel and polluting the crisp Pacific air. Now, Port Metro Vancouver, Canada's largest port and host to more than 250 cruise ship visits in 2009, is offering a greener alternative: ships can now plug into the city's electrical grid while docked. The shore power system, which cost 9 million Canadian dollars (almost $8 million at 1.13 Canadian dollars to the U.S. dollar), allows ships to shut down their engines and connect to BC Hydro's electrical grid through what is essentially a giant plug. The venture is the third of its kind in the world (the first two were Seattle and Juneau).

IT'S no secret that cars pollute the environment, but not all of that pollution comes out of the tailpipe. The Environmental Protection Agency says 2,000 tons of lead tire weights -- used to balance wheels -- are ''lost from vehicles and ultimately end up in the environment each year.'' Exposure to lead has a variety of health effects, the agency says, including disorders of the brain and nervous system and high blood pressure. Recently, the agency reversed previous decisions, agreeing to follow Europe's lead and seek to ban the manufacture and distribution of lead tire weights.

The drug industry's trade group plans to roll out a series of television advertisements in coming weeks specifically to support Senator Max Baucus's health care overhaul proposal, according to an industry official involved in the planning. The move would be a follow-up to the deal that drug makers struck in June with Mr. Baucus, right, and the White House. Under that pact, the industry agreed to various givebacks and discounts meant to reduce the nation's pharmaceutical spending by $80 billion over 10 years.

How can we get digital cable and Internet in our homes, but not clean water? JENNIFER HALL-MASSEY, on the detection of chemicals like arsenic and lead in the water of her community near Charleston, W.Va. [1]

TYSON--David Otto. August 5th, 1925 to August 17th, 2009. Basking Ridge, New Jersey. David Otto Tyson, journalist, husband of the late Yvonne Lorgnie Tyson, passed away quietly the afternoon of August 17th after a long illness. David Tyson was born in New York City to Reba and Levering Tyson, an educator, who, in addition to a long career associated with Columbia University, served as President of Muhlenberg College. David attended the Horace Mann School in New York and, subsequently, the Kent School, in Kent, Connecticut. He graduated from Muhlenberg College in Allentown, Pennsylvania and obtained a master's degree in history from Columbia University. Entering the Navy Officer Training Program while at Muhlenberg College, David was called to active duty during the Korean War. Prior to his service in the Korean War, he worked as a journalist in Washington, DC where he met and married his beloved wife, Yvonne Lorgnie, of Paris, France. Their first two years of married life were spent in Hawaii where he was stationed at Pearl Harbor. He retired from the Navy as a Lieutenant. The Tysons returned to New York City and, after the birth of their first son, moved to Morris County, New Jersey, soon settling in Mendham, where the family remained for many years. David was a lifelong Democrat and was active in the Democratic Party of Morris County. David spent most of his career in journalism. After working as a wire service reporter for the Associated Press in Newark, he subsequently specialized in writing for and editing financial publications. He worked briefly in the marketing department of Lehman Brothers in the 1970s but returned to "pure journalism" after a short period of time. In 1989, after 25 years of service, he retired from his position as the American Banker's Associate Editor. He was a staunch defender of the rights of free speech and a free press in America, and was proud of his journalistic ethics. Throughout his life David remained an active member of the alumni organizations of Muhlenberg College and Columbia University. He was a devoted Columbia University football fan, which is a testimony to his generally optimistic nature. He rarely missed a home game. A member of the Coffee House, the Mendham Golf and Tennis Club, David joined the Essex Hunt Club, to offer his sons the opportunity to play ice hockey. He and Yvonne shared a lifelong passion for travel and learning and kept fit with frequent friendly rounds of tennis. David's well-documented sense of humor was coupled with a strong sense of humility. Throughout their youths, David and his siblings James Levering Tyson and Jane Tyson Clement passed summers in Bay Head, New Jersey, in a home their parents built the year David was born. Subsequently, David and Yvonne took great delight in the fact that the Bay Head house continued to provide a family retreat for the Tyson children, grandchildren and cousins. It is primarily this legacy which provides the framework for interweaving the lives and stories of the new generation of Tysons into those who have preceded them. David Tyson is survived by his two sons, Geoffrey L. Tyson, M.D. of Vancouver, Washington and Alan L. Tyson of Morristown, New Jersey, as well as Donna B. Tyson, his daughter-in-law, and five grandchildren, Melissa, Grant, Reed, Reba, and Jean Yvonne Tyson. In addition to his many nieces and nephews, sisters-in-law Elizabeth Tyson of Meadow Lakes, New Jersey, Marie-Therese Vercken and Jaqueline Lorgnie of Neuilly, France and Magdeline Touchot of Paris, France remember him fondly. He will be missed greatly. The family requests that any remembrances be made to Muhlenberg College in David's name. A celebration of David's life will be held at 10am on October 3 at the First Presbyterian Church, 2 Lee's Hill Road, New Vernon, NJ www.baileyfuneral.com

AT New York Fashion Week, there is an easier-to-pronounce name on the runways. Heidi Mount, at right, from Centerville, Utah, is a new favorite of Karl Lagerfeld. Last year, she opened the Chanel spring ready-to-wear show and has appeared in consecutive Chanel ads (sorry, Claudia Schiffer). A new Dolce & Gabbana campaign, photographed by Steven Klein, confirms that the 22-year-old is on the rise. A rare American among the countless Brazilians and Russians who are using the runway for takeoff, Ms. Mount said that most American models don't fit the industry's stick-figure standards: ''It might have something to do with diet and nutrition at an early age.'' But the requirements for success (''a thick skin, the drive to keep going and a good personality'') are universal, she said. ''The people you work with have to like spending time with you.''
Theater Charles Isherwood
Comedy FAIRFIELD Fairfield Theater Company Margaret Cho. Sept. 22 at 7 and 9 p.m. $27 to $37. Fairfield Theater Company, 70 Sanford Street. fairfieldtheatre.org; (203) 259-1036.

Lake Tahoe (2008) In the art house, in the multiplex, on television: the shaky camera is everywhere. Supposedly hand-held camerawork adds energy, a you-are-there immediacy, to an image. Nearly everyone has forgotten the elegance of stillness -- but not the young Mexican filmmaker Fernando Eimbcke.

If he has second thoughts about the project, he might consider these alternative plotlines: GREED IS STILL GOOD

MARC JACOBS is celebrating more than his impending nuptials with Lorenzo Martone. The publication of ''Juergen Teller: Marc Jacobs Advertising 1998-2009'' ($120, Steidl) marks one of the longest-standing creative unions in fashion. For 11 years, Mr. Teller and Mr. Jacobs have collaborated on advertising for the designer's namesake collections, usually to dazzlingly subversive effect -- Mr. Teller naked in bed with Charlotte Rampling, the tween-age Dakota Fanning striking disturbingly adult poses, Winona Ryder with a shopping bag. But the Teller photos that met with the most opprobrium featured the makeup maestro Dick Page and his lover, James Gibbs. ''Men's Vogue even refused to publish it,'' Mr. Teller recalls. ''I wanted the ads to be like they are: very romantic, tender and sweet. I certainly didn't want to have anything provocative, not at all. The only other controversy that comes to mind was over an ad of a clothed Cindy Sherman and me in which I am grabbing her breasts. That caused a stir. Go figure.'' HORACIO SILVA At right: Kristen McMenamy photographed for a 2005 Marc Jacobs ad campaign.

WHAT really upsets and infuriates me is how cluttered the streets, avenues and sidewalks have become. I live on the Upper East Side, west of Third and four blocks from Mayor Bloomberg's residence. At the intersection of Third and 79th, three corners host 18 ''honor boxes.'' Between 77th and 79th on Third are an additional 13 boxes. Only one of these boxes requires money. All the rest contain either free publications or dried leaves; some serve as storage containers for the homeless. A pedestrian has to navigate around them, but their existence is protected by the right to freedom of speech.

Andre Johnson vs. Darrelle Revis This is a meeting between two Pro Bowl players, both perhaps in the top five at their respective position. Johnson, left, has a rare combination of size and speed, and he caught 115 passes for 1,575 yards last season. Revis grabbed five interceptions last year, rising from a solid N.F.L. cornerback to a shutdown one. The Jets will give Revis help on Johnson. They have to. But most weeks, Revis sees little action, a sign of respect. Not against Johnson on Sunday.

The height (estimated) of President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, whose sensitivity over his stature has been a source of amusement to the French. The latest to-do took flight last weekend following a visit to a factory where workers selected to stand behind him say they were chosen because they were no taller than Mr. Sarkozy. The Élysée Palace called those assertions ''completely absurd and grotesque.''
STEEN--Lois Sonne. Mommy, 15 years and five grandchildren (and one on the way) later, we hope we've made you proud. Thinking of you today and always with love beyond compare. xoxo

Gay travel can seem like a circuit party that resolves around stops in Palm Springs, Provincetown and Key West. Will Atlantic City soon be part of that rotation? The folks who run Harrah's Entertainment seem to hope so. They are planning an ''Out'' weekend for the gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgendered community at their casinos, which include Harrah's Resort, above, Caesars, Showboat and Bally's. The trip begins on Sept. 25, in a private car on the Atlantic City Express Train from New York. Along for the ride will be the transsexual performance artist Amanda Lepore. There is a Friday party at Showboat's Club Worship with Ms. Lepore and the rapper Cazwell. Saturday includes a meet-and-greet with cast members of ''The L Word,'' and a ''Decadence at Caesars'' party with Jai Rodriguez (''Queer Eye for the Straight Guy'') and Lance Bass ('N Sync) as hosts. All good things come to an end Sunday, but not before the ''Rehab Brunch and Gay Bingo,'' with Mr. Rodriguez, at Harrah's ballroom. As the New Jersey gay couple of ''Saturday Night Live'' would say, ''Ooooh!''

THE MORMON MISSIONARY Naisi Zhao, 21, grew up in Shanghai and went to college at Brigham Young University in Utah. It was there, three years ago, that she converted to Mormonism after meeting two missionaries. ''The memories of my own baptism are still very fresh, and the joy that it's brought into my life makes me excited to share it with others,'' she said.

COOL AND COLLECTED WAS ONCE A TENNIS BRAT The composed on-court demeanor that has come to define Roger Federer stands in stark contrast to his early years as a junior player and a young professional. (Published Sept. 10)

After an off-season of drawing somewhat limited interest despite an impressive résumé, Adam Dunn has rewarded the Washington Nationals for their faith in him by hitting 37 home runs while reaching base more times than Ichiro Suzuki. Dunn's .281 batting average and .409 on-base percentage are career highs. He has reached base 244 times, or 18 more than Suzuki, who is hitting a robust .355 for the Mariners. The change has not taken away any of Dunn's famed power, though; his .565 slugging percentage is the highest he has had since he slugged .569 in 2004.

As if two division championships, a World Series ring and the current standings were not enough, the Phillies added another achievement last week that further emphasizes the disparities with the Mets. On Tuesday, when Raul Ibanez hit two home runs to give him 30 and Chase Utley slugged his 30th of the season, the Phillies became the 12th team in major league history to have four players with 30 or more homers in a season. They joined Ryan Howard with 38 and Jayson Werth with 33.

Gelato, normally a business taken very seriously in this city, has developed a sense of humor. Here are a few highlights of a more creative breed of gelati appearing around the city. Let's start with a flavor that's both relatively straightforward and very Italian. The delicately flavored basil gelato at Ara Coeli (Piazza Ara Coeli, 9-10; 39-06-67-950-85) is light enough to have for breakfast and simply, unexpectedly delicious. Flouting common decency, Fatamorgana (Via G. Bettolo, 7; 39-06-8639-1589; www.gelateriafatamorgana.it) combines chocolate with both wasabi and tobacco flavors (the latter in a ''Kentucky'' blend) and marries pecorino with honey and orange.

IT'S small consolation to Ford, which parted ways with Jaguar after 18 largely tear-filled, money-losing years of ownership. But Tata Motors of India, which bought the British automaker in a reverse-colonization, is surely thanking Ford for handing over a Jaguar that is finally purring. Aside from one spectacular debacle -- the widely panned X-Type entry luxury sedan, based on the Ford Mondeo -- history may credit Ford with transforming Jaguar's frozen-in-amber styling and notoriously shoddy reliability. No longer living in and off its glorious past, Jaguar suddenly has a lineup on its hands. These are still the pretty, pedigreed cats you expect, but they are also modern, competitive and -- according to owner surveys -- more mechanically sound than before.

UFLAND--Louise, formerly of New York, died in Westerly, RI, on September 10. Mrs. Ufland was born in New York City on February 13, 1911. She was preceded in death by her two husbands, Emanuel Wartels, who founded Crown Publishers with his brother Nat Wartels, and Arthur William Ufland. Her only son, David E. Wartels, survives her, along with his wife Penelope, and their sons Wyatt and his fiancee Nicole Wanzer, Edward and his wife Kate, and her cherished great-granddaughter Winnie. A lifelong devotee of the arts, she loved music and the ballet, but her passion was for collecting fine arts, which she began in the 1930s, taking pride in the fact that she was able to help impecunious artists with her purchases. She also loved to travel with Arthur, and they covered as much ground as they could. There will be no service, but donations in Louise's honor will be welcome at Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street, New York, NY 10128.

POWERS--S.J. Rev. Richard J.,on September 9, 2009. Beloved uncle of Jane Aleci, John Bohne and Kathy Fufaro. Rev. Powers served in the U.S. Army from 1943-1946. He served both in the European Front (infantry) and the Pacific Front (Army of Occupation). Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Road, Bronx, NY on Friday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel Saturday 11:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Martyrs' Shrine Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors (718)654-0500.

FOR the sisters Phoebe and Annette Stephens, designing their own jewelry must have seemed like a birthright. Their grandmother Annette Nancarrow was a painter, sculptor and jewelry designer married to the avant-garde composer Conlon Nancarrow. From Mexico City, Nancarrow adorned the likes of Frida Kahlo, Peggy Guggenheim, Helena Rubinstein and Elizabeth Arden. Her granddaughters pay homage to her work under the label Anndra Neen, but also nod to other far-flung influences: Dario Argento films, Alexander Calder jewelry, Japanese art, Egyptian motifs, French medieval armor. Hand made of copper, brass and nickel-silver in their Mexico City workshop, each piece is architectural and unique. Or as Phoebe says, ''We like to think of our jewels as sculptures.'' Prices range from $145 to $925. For information, info@anndraneen.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE

In the coming days, a Homeland Security task force is to recommend whether to keep, revise or scrap the color-coded terrorism-alert system that has for years alternately panicked and befuddled Americans. The Op-Ed editors asked four graphic designers for their own ideas for an improved warning system. An effective alert system should take advantage of readily available distribution methods as well as commonly used symbols and language. Via e-mail and text messages sent from an official protocol (to avoid hoaxes), these simple alerts could be easily and urgently sent out to hundreds of millions of Americans; just as effortlessly and quickly, these messages would be blogged about on the Internet, shared on social networks and forwarded from one person to another.

WINDELS--Paul, Jr.,died peacefully on September 8. Beloved husband of the late Mary Patricia Ripley Windels; father of Paul Windels III, Mary Hyde Windels, James Hazen Ripley Windels, and Patrick Dillon Windels; and grandfather of Patrick Emmons Windels, Thomas Ripley Windels, George Gunderson Windels, Mary Catherine Yuelan Windels, and Paul Eugene Ruhao Windels. Alumnus of Brooklyn Friends School, Brooks School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. Served in the United States Army in World War II attaining the rank of Major and saw combat in numerous engagements. Chief Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York (1953-57) and Regional Administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission (1957-61), during which time he led the prosecution of the so-called boiler room operators and the investigation of Cady, Roberts & Co., the initial insider trading case, in 1959. Lead Partner Windels, Curry & Rice, Windels, Merritt & Ingraham, Windels & Marx, and Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives and thereafter of counsel to Windels, Marx, Lane & Mittendorf. Chair of the Judicial Nominating Committees for Senators James L. Buckley and Alfonse M. D'Amato. President of the Federal Bar Council. President of the Board, Brooklyn Law School and the Lycee Francais de New York. Trustee of the Lexington School for the Deaf, the Knox School, the French Institute, and the Atlantic Foundation. A funeral service will be held on Monday, September 14, 2009, at 10:00am at St. James Episcopal Church, Route 25A, St. James, New York. A memorial service will be held at Brooklyn Law School during the fall. He was a man of unique qualities and character, deeply committed and loyal to his family and friends, who will be sorely missed.

IN Edgemont, a high-performing Westchester school district, children as young as 7 could recite colors and days of the week in Spanish, but few if any learned to really converse, read or write. So this fall, the district canceled the Spanish lessons offered twice weekly at its two elementary schools since 2003, deciding the time and resources -- an estimated $175,000 a year -- could be better spent on other subjects. Class consolidation in Yonkers resulted in the loss of four foreign-language teaching positions, and budget cuts have cost Arlington, N.Y., its seventh-grade German program, and Danbury, Conn., several sections of middle school French and Spanish.
Film A. O. Scott

WALL STREET'S landscape has been permanently altered. Lehman Brothers, gone. Bear Stearns, gone. Merrill Lynch, gone. Main Street's landscape has also been permanently altered. Wachovia, gone. National City, Washington Mutual and Countrywide, all gone. These venerable financial giants all crumbled under the weight of the financial crisis. Those that are left shrank down to a fraction of their former market capitalizations, but have all grown since then. Most are nowhere near their former size, but two, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, are slightly larger than they were at the market's peak in October 2007. Many of the survivors were propped up by the government with billions of dollars in loans. And of the seven that are gone, some were bought by others in government-brokered deals.

THE NEWS The typical American household made less money last year than it made a decade ago, according to new figures from the Census Bureau. BEHIND THE NEWS In the four decades that the bureau has been tracking household income, median income has never failed to rise until now. Adjusted for inflation, it slipped to $50,303 last year from $51,295 in 1998. One reason: economic growth in the current decade has been slower than in any decade since before World War II. Income inequality also expanded, to the benefit of a small slice of the wealthy. ''We've seen a lost decade for the typical American family,'' said the economist Lawrence Katz.

I FIRST met Losi (a hairdresser so famous only one name is required) on a men's fashion shoot in the early '90s and have been a customer ever since. I had lapsed for a while, but when I ran into her recently on another shoot, her scissors and clippers came out before I knew it, and it was like old times. And I must say, there is nothing like a Losi cut, a favorite among art directors and high-placed creative types. For the last year, she's made her home at the discreet Martial Vivot Salon Pour Hommes, above, adjacent to the Museum of Modern Art. It's a kind of safe house for men. No loud hair dryers or chemical smells. Just three chairs, and one from a vintage barbershop in the garden. You can sip wine, get a cut and see the Ron Arad show next door. Best of all, your hair will thank you. Prices from $125 to $215. BRUCE PASK

RAWSON--Kenneth J.,a loving husband, brother, father and grandfather who lived in Roslyn, NY passed away Friday afternoon with his family at his side. He was 91 years old. Married to Toby Rawson (nee Treger) for 58 years, she predeceased him in 2008. He was born and raised in Cleveland, attended Ohio State University, and settled in New York City after WWII going on to a storied career in the paper industry. He worked for Gilman Paper Company before becoming a manufactures' representative specializing in paper and plastic packaging materials. Active in community affairs, he served on the Roslyn School Board for six years, the last year as president. He was an avid tennis player, serious cook, ferocious reader and champion of liberal causes everywhere. He is survived by his sister Babette Hughes; two sons, Doug (wife Carole), Andrew (wife Christine), and seven grandchildren: Bobby, Danny, Haley, Sarah, Liz, Natalie and Rebecca. The Memorial Service will be held today at 11am at his home. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Eli & Dorothy Rabin Volunteer of the Year Fund, University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.

The loudest cheer in the early moments of the Notre Dame-Michigan game came when the stadium's public-address announcer said, ''A final score from East Lansing: Central Michigan 29, Michigan State 27.'' The crowd roared at the news. The Spartans are a bitter rival of the Wolverines and play at Notre Dame next week. Central Michigan initially missed a potential game-winning 47-yard field goal, but was able to try the kick again after an offsides penalty. That prompted clapping from news media members and an announcement in the press box.

KAPNER--Stanley H.,died on September 6, 2009 at age 90. He retired as Director of Public Affairs at Time Inc. in 1979. Previously, he was the company's chief public affairs officer in the United Kingdom. A Magna cum Laude graduate of Harvard College (1940), Kapner immediately began writing film documentaries in Los Angeles. He enlisted in the U.S. Navy during World War II, held the rank of Ensign after completing Japanese Language School, and saw action in the Pacific Theater. He was a freelance writer in Paris prior to joining Time in 1955. He is survived by Catherine Segal Kapner, his wife of 57 years; a daughter-in-law, Paola; two granddaughters, Julia and Sveva, of Milan; and a niece, Karen K. Hyman, of Illinois. His son Frederic, a journalist, predeceased him in 2005. An excellent speechwriter, as well as author of plays and short fiction, Kapner was a mentor to many who benefited from his precise editorial eye. A memorial service is being planned.

In the coming days, a Homeland Security task force is to recommend whether to keep, revise or scrap the color-coded terrorism-alert system that has for years alternately panicked and befuddled Americans. The Op-Ed editors asked four graphic designers for their own ideas for an improved warning system. Instead of relying on scary language and irrelevant colors, our system takes advantage of people's innate ability to read emotions in the eyes of those around us. The eyes introduce an approachable human element to a potentially frightening message, and also remind us that even when there is no imminent danger we should still be aware of our surroundings. Alerts can be animated on mobile phones, Web sites and TV, and printed in the newspaper.

WHEN NEW CADETS ENTER the United States Military Academy at West Point, they are marched into the General Lee barracks, where 20-some barbers employed by the Department of Defense are ready with electric buzzers adjusted to the No. 1 setting for the closest cut. The barbershop, which dates at least to the 1880s, keeps track of each 90-second scalping: its busiest day, with 1,258 haircuts, came in 1993; one barber once did 198 heads in one day. MARK OWENS HAS HAD SHORT haircuts before -- ''Not this short, though,'' he said. ''Most people aren't ready at all,'' said Mr. Owens, right, who is 18 and grew up in Pearl River, N.Y., ''but you can't be ready for everything they throw at you.''

The exuberance of Fashion Week in New York was in full force this past week. Designers' assistants dashed out for last-minute bolts of fabric and models rushed to fittings and bookings for shows, which continue through Sept. 17. Macy's Broadway windows were a parade of mannequins on a graffiti-covered dinner table. There's an old cliché that with a few yards of fabric, designers can upset the whole world. But today, it's the shoe designers who turn things upside down. I saw two women in platform shoes without heels. They were walking on the balls of their feet. One of the women, Daphne Guinness, had to lean against a building so as not to fall over while waiting for her car and chauffeur.

BERMAK--Gordon E.,MD. August 6, 1927 July 26, 2009. Gordon Edward Bermak expired from metastatic prostate cancer on July 26, 2009 in the home he had built, with his family by his side. He was born on August 6, 1927 in Winnipeg, Canada, the second son of Charles James and Rose Fred Bermak. Gordon developed a precocious interest in science and medicine, pursuing a medical education in which he particularly resonated to the writings of Sigmund Freud. He graduated from the University of Manitoba Faculty of Medicine at the age of 22 (1950), and completed a residency in psychiatry at the University of Colorado. In 1954, he arrived in California, working primarily in private practice for over 55 years in Berkeley. He trained as a psychoanalyst at the S.F. Psychoanalytic Institute and taught extensively in the mental health profession, to analysts and non-analysts alike. As a native Canadian, Gordon loved the outdoors and nurtured an affinity for skiing, jogging, swimming, and sailing. He was also a proficient pianist and greatly enjoyed communicating in French. He married Dolores Ryan in 1959. They adopted a daughter in 1965, then a son in 1969. He is survived by this family. Gordon's joie de vivre lay in a deep interest with the individuality of everyone he came to know, and with a commitment to being in touch with the commonality of human suffering among the friends he consoled, the family he loved, and the patients he treated until only one week prior to his death. A public memorial for Dr. Gordon Bermak will be held on September 20, 2009, 12pm, at the Brazilian Room in Tilden Park, Berkeley, California.

BRANDT--Robert Jay, beloved widower of film star Janet Leigh, died peacefully at his home in Beverly Hills, CA on September 5, 2009 after a long battle with Alzheimer's. He was 82 years old. Born July 7, 1927, son of Lillian and Walter Brandt from Burlingame, CA, he served as a US Marine. He was an avid sportsman and adventurer. Bob was an innovator in the securities industry, founding Brandt Zwick and Company with Barry Zwick and then later Robert Brandt and Company. He married Ms. Leigh and raised her two daughters, Kelly Curtis and Jamie Lee Curtis. At the time of Ms. Leigh's death in 2004, the couple had been married 42 years. He leaves many close friends in Los Angeles and Sun Valley, Idaho and is survived by his daughters and grandchildren, Anne and Tom Guest and his son-in-law Christopher Guest. Donations can be made to the Motion Picture and Television Fund (www.mptvfund.org) or the Sun Valley Ski Education Foundation (www.svsef.org).

SINCOFF--Milton. The attorneys at Kreindler and Kreindler mourn the loss of our partner and dear friend Milton G. Sincoff, who passed away Monday evening after a brief illness. Milt served in the Army during the Korean war and joined the firm shortly after it was founded by Harry and Lee Kreindler. Milt became involved in the firm's fledgling and novel aviation practice and established himself as one of the most respected and admired aviation trial lawyers in the nation. He tried and won many notable and record setting cases, including the Texasgulf Aviation crash at the Westchester County Airport, which resulted in the then highest wrongful death damages award, and the Korean Airlines 007 shoot down over the Soviet Union where he established that the airline was guilty of willful misconduct which was necessary to recover full damages. Milt was a brilliant trial lawyer, an excellent teacher, and a man of integrity, strength and wisdom. He was a member of our firm for 50 years and was a mentor to us all. We will miss him greatly. Milt is survived by his wife Elaine, his daughter Amy and his son, Brian.

Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

A detailed obituary, including service announcements, is published in today's edition of the Houston Chronicle. Services in Houston are by Geo. H.
