In the latest Marathon Tech Review on the Gadgetwise blog, Danielle Belopotosky takes a look at DailyMile, a social networking site for runners that offers several new features, including mapping tools, calendars of local running events and challenges where runners motivate each other online. She writes:
Should parents love their children unconditionally? Or should children be required to earn their parents love?
The United States stock market has just completed its best six months since 1933. From March 9 to Sept. 9, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index leaped by 53 percent.

In the aftermath of the great meltdown of 2008, Wall Street’s quants have been cast as the financial engineers of profit-driven innovation run amok. They, after all, invented the exotic securities that proved so troublesome.

For years now, many businesses and individuals in the United States have been relying on the power of government, rather than competition in the marketplace, to increase their wealth. This is politicization of the economy. It made the financial crisis much worse, and the trend is accelerating, Tyler Cowen writes in The New York Times.

There is broad agreement that Alan Greenspan, the former Fed chairman, was wrong to have believed that market forces alone would insulate society from excessive financial risk. But Mr. Greenspan was wrong for reasons very different from those offered by his most vocal critics, Robert H. Frank writes in The New York Times.
The following is an interview with Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, conducted, condensed and edited by Adam Bryant:
What if they’d saved Lehman Brothers?

Tom Ollquist remembers Sept. 9, 2008 — the day Lehman Brothers laid him off — as if it were yesterday, The New York Time’s Louise Story and Landon Thomas Jr. reported. “You’re not going to believe it,” he told his wife. “I was shot.”

Nothing succeeds like failure, as the saying goes. And nowhere is this dismal truth more evident than in our financial regulatory system, one year after the bankruptcy filing of Lehman Brothers, The New York Times’s Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest Fair Game column.
A year after the fall of Lehman Brothers, many money managers believe the financial storm that intensified following Lehman’s spectacular failure is still not over.

It didn’t take long after Lehman Brothers collapsed for the consensus to emerge: Many on Wall Street, in politics and from academia came to agree that the United States government made a grave mistake in not rescuing the firm — a mistake that put the global financial system on the brink of failure.

Joseph Stiglitz, the Nobel Prize-winning economist, told Bloomberg News that the United States has failed to fix the underlying problems of its banking system after the credit crunch and the collapse of Lehman Brothers.

The former deputy governor of the Bank of England said he was “astounded” the United States government let Lehman Brothers go under, and that the bank’s collapse marked a clear moment when people lost confidence in the markets.

When President Obama travels to Wall Street today to speak from Federal Hall, where the founders once argued bitterly over how much the government should control the national economy, he is likely to cast himself as a “reluctant shareholder” in America’s biggest industries and financial institutions.
Wall Street lives on.

A few days ago the country was starkly reminded that there are rules of decorum in the United States Congress. And on Sunday night, it became apparent that even the MTV Video Music Awards has little tolerance for outlandish behavior.

Updated | 3:25 p.m. Wipe that tear from your googly eyes and put down the mothballs: “Avenue Q,” the satirical Broadway puppet musical, won’t be shutting down altogether, and will instead transfer to an Off Broadway theater. In June, it was announced that “Avenue Q,” an adult takeoff on children’s shows like “Sesame Street” that won the 2004 Tony Award for best musical, would close at the Golden Theater after its Sunday performance. But Sunday night, at what was to be the show’s closing performance, Kevin McCollum, the show’s lead producer, announced that “Avenue Q” will move to New World Stages in Manhattan, where it will resume performances on Oct. 9.
Over on Wordplay, The New York Times crossword puzzle editor Will Shortz tells us:

TORONTO — One of the buzzier studio movies at this year’s Toronto International Film Festival is “Up in the Air,”, directed by Jason Reitman (“Juno,” “Thank You for Smoking”), which tackles the mundane world of business travel and the grim prospect of losing a job. The film stars George Clooney as a man who is hired by companies around the country to lay off their employees. Mr. Reitman went for authenticity, specifically by beginning his film with non-professional actors in job-loss scenarios. The director spoke about his efforts to get the tone right in today’s economy.

The set that stood in for a historical Elizabethan theater in the 1998 film “Shakespeare in Love” may itself become a theater in Britain, The Associated Press reported. The movie’s set of the Rose Theater, a playhouse on the River Thames where the works of William Shakespeare and Christopher Marlowe were performed, was donated to the British Shakespeare Company by Judi Dench, who won an Oscar for playing Queen Elizabeth I in “Shakespeare in Love.” The theater company told The A.P. that it was looking at locations in Sheffield, Manchester and York where it could use the set to put on Shakespearean plays and display costumes from the movie. The original Rose Theater was built in 1587 and became home to Lord Strange’s Men and the Admiral’s Men, but it declined after the Globe Theater was built in 1599 and was razed sometime in the early 1600s.

So much for the Beatles: in the week when long-awaited remastered editions of the Fab Four’s catalog were finally released, the No. 1 position on the British album sales chart was claimed by Vera Lynn, the British singer of World War II ballads, Agence France-Presse reported. Last month, Ms. Lynn, 92, known for her performances of songs like “(There’ll Be Bluebirds Over) the White Cliffs of Dover” and “We’ll Meet Again,” became the oldest living artist on the British Top 20 chart when her collection “We’ll Meet Again: The Very Best of Vera Lynn,” reached the No. 20 position. That album was rereleased by Decca Records to coincide with the 70th anniversary of Britain’s declaration of war on Germany at the start of World War II. Ms. Lynn is now the oldest living singer to top that chart. In fairness to the Beatles, their own rereleases did not perform too badly: on the British Top 10 chart, “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” was No. 5, “Abbey Road” was No. 6, “Revolver” was No. 9 and “Rubber Soul” was No. 10.

Russian prosecutors have opened a criminal investigation into the possible embezzlement of funds intended for the restoration of the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, Bloomberg News reported. The 185-year-old theater, home to both the Bolshoi Ballet and Bolshoi Opera, closed in July 2005 to undergo renovations were that were supposed to be completed by 2008. But the project has been delayed many times, and is now not likely to be finished until at least 2011. Bloomberg said that auditors had found violations in an inquiry into the Office for Construction, Redevelopment and Restoration, the federal agency in charge of the Bolshoi project. In 2003, the agency struck a deal with the firm ZAO Kurortproekt to design the second phase of the renovation. But over the next six years, investigators said, the agency paid the firm three times for the same work, for a total of about $31 million. A spokeswoman for the agency declined to comment to Bloomberg.

MONTICELLO, N.Y. — Writing about the Melvins today in my review of All Tomorrow’s Parties, I think I overstated the magnitude of the bass sound. Such things are understood in relative degrees, and I got my real bass tempest on Sunday night from Boris, the Japanese band that uses the Melvins as a template.

New music has received a major boost at the New York Philharmonic. The orchestra said today that the financier Henry R. Kravis had donated $10 million to pay for a composer-in-residence job plus a $250,000 grant every two years to a working composer. The award carries with it the obligation to write a piece for the Philharmonic. Under its new music director, Alan Gilbert, who opens the season on Wednesday, the orchestra has beefed up its contemporary-music activities. Magnus Lindberg, a Finn and a favorite of Mr. Gilbert, has already been appointed as the first in-house music scribbler. He will write pieces for the orchestra and oversee its contemporary-music endeavors. The residency and the prize are both named after Mr. Kravis’s wife, Marie-Josée Kravis.

Updated | 3:36 p.m. Hours after an incident Sunday night at the MTV Video Music Awards in which Kanye West interrupted an acceptance speech by Taylor Swift, Mr. West’s fellow musicians were lining up to criticize him.

TORONTO — The director Terry Gilliam has often wandered down a long, winding, uncompromising road of imagination with his films. His latest, “The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus,” continues in this tradition, with offbeat creative ideas woven into the tapestry of the film’s story. Mr. Gilliam offered his perspective on the film and the nature of his style as it has played out in much of his work.
The government of Ukraine said Monday that Elton John cannot adopt a child from that country because he is too old and is not married, The Associated Press reported.

Over on his blog Dot Earth, Andrew C. Revkin recently proposed a contest “to see who can come up with fresh, captivating, accurate ways” to use various art forms to describe climate trends and their significance. He writes, “It’s clear that the arts, from visual to musical, can have a role in shaping how people perceive the planet and their place on it.” The nonprofit group Artist as Citizen was inspired by his suggestion to hold just such a competition. Now the contest organizers will use the recommendations of Dot Earth readers in choosing winners. Read more and make your pick here.
Two of the writers who cover dance for The New York Times make guest appearances today on Straight Sets, The Times’s Tennis blog:

If you’ve been keeping tabs on Willem Dafoe‘s film “Antichrist,” you know that his costars may be wary of taking some lumps. Nonetheless, the Public Theater has found a few actors to appear alongside him in its production of “Idiot Savant,” a new work of philosophical comedy written and directed by Richard Foreman. In a news release, the Public said that Mr. Dafoe, who is to play the title character, would be joined by Elina Löwensohn (whose films include “Schindler’s List” and “Fay Grim”), Joel Israel (who has previously appeared in Mr. Foreman’s plays “Deep Trance Behavior in Potatoland” and “Wake Up Mr. Sleepy! Your Unconscious Mind Is Dead!”), Eric Magnus (Mr. Foreman’s “Astronome: A Night at the Opera”), Daniel Nelson (Mr. Foreman’s “Spoleum”) and Alenka Kraigher. The play, which is presented in association with Ontological-Hysteric Theater, is to begin previews on Oct. 27 and open on Nov. 4. Its limited run is scheduled to end on Dec. 13.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame has added Sting, Jerry Lee Lewis, Jeff Beck, Van Morrison, Jackson Browne and Bonnie Raitt to the lineups for its 25th anniversary concerts at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 29 and 30. They will join U2, Bruce Springsteen, Simon & Garfunkel, Metallica, Aretha Franklin, Stevie Wonder, Eric Clapton and Crosby, Stills, Nash and Friends, who were announced in July. Tickets, available from Ticketmaster, range from $79.50 to $5,004.50.

Patrick Swayze, the balletically athletic actor who rose to stardom in the films “Dirty Dancing” and “Ghost” and whose 20-month battle with advanced pancreatic cancer drew wide attention, died Monday. He was 57.

But there are always a few people on the red carpet who make you say… who? Leading up to the Emmy telecast on Sunday night, we’ll be talking to some first-timers and other nominated actors who might not be as familiar to viewers as the Alec Baldwins, Sally Fields and William Shatners of the world.

Marc Jacobs, who divides his time between New York and Paris, where he also designs for Louis Vuitton, manages to stay one step ahead of the fashion pack. People wonder why that is. Celebrities like to attend his shows; tonight, Madonna was in the front row for his women's spring 2010 collection. But pleasing celebrities hardly explains his ability to satisfy magazine art directors, editors, photographers, retailers and journalists, who, as a collective agency, can be fairly picky and jaded. And not every Marc Jacobs show engages people.

Pedro Martinez threw 130 pitches Sunday night. Yes, 130 pitches. Yes, that Pedro Martinez. A year ago, the Mets were lucky to get 100 pitches and/or six innings from him. A month ago, the Phillies were wondering how much Martinez, who labored through five innings (99 pitches) in his season debut against the Cubs, could give them.
Evangelical churches in Brazil blend religious fervor and popular culture, drawing young people to their fast-growing movement.

The years-long tug of of war between publishers and Google has become familiar. Publishers complain that Google makes money off their backs and want to be paid for their content. Google replies that what it does -- indexing the Web, offering search tools that allow people to find content -- is not only perfectly legal, but also benefits publishers.

Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who is leading bipartisan negotiations on health care legislation, on Monday said he would include in his bill a proposal by the Obama White House to bar illegal immigrants from buying health coverage through a new insurance marketplace, or exchange, even if the illegal immigrants were willing and able to pay the full cost.

Juan Martín del Potro of Argentina did what seemed to be the unthinkable on Monday night, beating Roger Federer in a dramatic five-set match to win the United States Open for his first major championship, 3-6, 7-6 (5), 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-2.

Today was sunny, after a period of rain that had dampened the New York area. I anticipated pulling a number of frames of honey from my hive. There are two high nectar seasons in the Northeast: the spring flow and the leaner fall flow. A major source of nectar in the fall is ragweed. I have seen it blooming on the edge of a few fields and roads in the area. My expectations were high.

One of the unintended consequences of near-universal coverage in Massachusetts, with profound lessons for Washington, has been a deepening shortage of primary care doctors for the newly insured.

Every New York fashion week, before things get too crazy at the tents, the editors at T make a pile of fashion invitations and pick our favorite designs. This season, we gave Ports 1961 points for sending out a hand fan (though it wasn't as zany, or as usable, as Betsey Johnson's fall 2009 oven mitt). We also loved the color and texture of Juan Carlos Obando's rustic woven satchel-cum-invite. Alexander Wang made the cut with his slick peekaboo design that used a cardboard backing. (Though if you ask us, it was basically a Prada spring 2009 invitation turned inside out.) Which was your favorite? We invite you to comment below.

WASHINGTON -- Jody Powell, the longest-serving and probably closest aide to former President Jimmy Carter, died on Monday at his home near Cambridge on Maryland's Eastern Shore, said Jack Nelson, the journalist and his friend. He was 65.

Rep. Joe Wilson's two-word shout-out at the president last Wednesday has unleashed a torrent of words from pundits, bloggers and talking heads. But one word in particular has been the beneficiary of his outburst: racism. Now everyone wants to talk about it.

"So this is where the road to nowhere ends." Thus begins a recent travel story in The Independent newspaper of London, which recounts a visit to Cape Finisterre, in the extreme northwest corner of Spain. It's a place that the author, James Donald, traveled to once he reached the end of the famed Santiago de Compostela trail and just kept going.

To celebrate the introduction of women's wear to Thecorner.com, the virtual store owned by Yoox that has previously sold only cutting-edge designers for men, the photographer and director Nick Knight has created "Portent," a short film featuring the designs of Martin Margiela, Haider Ackermann and Proenza Schouler, among others. Grant Achatz has just begun an eight-part series on pairing food and wine, on The Atlantic web site. Achatz is a great chef, and his restaurant in Chicago, Alinea, is a joy, so I am very interested in his thoughts.

Tonight's meeting of the South Orange Board of Trustees will include the hiring of three police officers, a resolution supporting marriage equality for gay residents and the imposition of liens on several properties to be cleaned up.

On Monday, the authors of three books apparently recommended to American readers by the leader of Al Qaeda in his latest communique might be wondering how one goes about returning an unsolicited endorsement to a shadowy militant who has been in hiding for eight years.

Remember the Astor trial? The ongoing case raised questions about whether noted philanthropist Brooke Astor, diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease, understood what she was doing when she changed her will in 2004, diverting millions that had long been promised to charities to her son, Anthony Marshall. Allegations also arose that her son and a co-defendant -- charged with conspiracy, fraud, larceny and forgery -- manipulated a confused centenarian into parting with her treasured $10 million painting.
Hester Prynne, that's who - at least in the fantasy baseball team fielded by Novel-T, a line of literary-themed T-shirts on view yesterday at the Brooklyn Book Festival.

It's hardly a secret that Jay Leno, who begins his new prime-time talk show tonight, is a car guy. What's less known is that he's also a green car guy. The big garage he occasionally writes about features such historical electric cars as a Baker Electric from 1909, an early Owen Magnetic hybrid-type vehicle and a 1925 Doble steamer. He also converted a 600-horsepower Z06 Corvette to run on E85 ethanol.

Another mainstay Super Bowl advertiser will return for Super Bowl XLIV, to be broadcast by CBS on Feb. 7, 2010. GoDaddy, the Web site registrar, announced on Monday that it had purchased two 30-second spots from CBS. That will make six Super Sundays in a row to include advertising for the godaddy.com Web site.

I recently read a very interesting article about a pizza place in Chicago that is too busy. It's called Great Lake, and now that it's been named the best pizza in America by GQ magazine and been written up in The Chicago Tribune, it can take hours to get a table and up to 90 minutes to get your pizza.

PRAGUE | Burcak, fermented grape juice with a flavor that lies somewhere around spiked grapefruit juice or hard cider, has accumulated myths -- it helps you replace your old blood for new healthier stuff, for example -- but also a following. You don't have to be Jewish to appreciate "Reinventing Ritual," the contemporary art and design show that opened Sunday at the Jewish Museum and runs through Feb. 2. But it helps. Not that you won't admire Jonathan Adler's torso-like menorah that owes more to '60s modernism than traditional pieties. Or, Karim Rashid's funky hot pink version. Or, the little garden shed that could, doubling as a sukkah, where an observant family takes their meals during Sukkot, the harvest festival. And how amusing is the video by Francisca Benitez, showing Williamsburg sprouting with sukkahs? Sukkahs on balconies. Sukkahs on sidewalks. Here a sukkah. There a sukkah. And have you ever seen a stout Hasid wield a two-by-four?

On Friday, Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain issued a public apology to Alan Turing, a mathematician and computer pioneer whose work as a code breaker during World War II helped defeat Nazi Germany. Mr. Turing was convicted of "gross indecency" in 1952 for having a homosexual affair and was forced to endure injections of female hormones. Two years later, killed himself by biting into a poisoned apple.

A team of six undergraduates at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has converted a 2010 Mercury Milan hybrid into a pure battery electric car. By comparison, Tesla Motors says that its $3,000 Home Connector unit can fully charge its Roadster in less than four hours.

Yesterday, as I came down the Bryant Park steps after the Diane von Furstenberg show, worming my through the picture-snapping onlookers, I saw an angel. She was about five feet tall, dressed in white tights with earphones strapped to her head, and she had on a pair of feathery wings. The young woman was dancing by herself in the crosswalk. I looked at her and she looked back, as if to say, "Never see an angel before?" I crossed the street. A huge black Cadillac was waiting at the light, its silver rims spinning backward. I ducked into the subway, taking the R train to Prince Street to see Ralph Rucci's collection. I had missed the show in order to do a one-on-one conversation with Juergen Teller at the Visual Arts Theatre. On the way downtown, I mulled over DVF's show, its all-encompassing theme an oasis. Which, naturally, meant many prints, beaded embellishments, and soft, floating dresses with sarong ties in the front. It was not a stretch of the imagination, not as crisp and clear as her fall show, but the collection was high on things to wear, and the generally loose cut was appealing. I love a sack, now and then.

This weekend, the California legislature voted to approve a requirement that the state get 33 percent of its electricity from renewable resources by 2020. If signed into law by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, it would be the largest "renewable portfolio standard" in the country.

When the Crosby Street Hotel opens in downtown Manhattan at the end of the month, it will be the first property outside of London for Firmdale Hotels, the boutique chainlet dreamed up by Kit and Tim Kemp. Craig Markham, the company's all-around make-it-happen man, told me they didn't want to do a London hotel in New York, and when I toured the place last week, I could see what he meant. An understated entrance on a quiet cobblestone street, a private garden, a green roof and a planted "meadow" several stories up - it's certainly the New York many aspire to. But there's a hefty, and welcome, dose of England, too.

The Associated Press reported yesterday that the ratings for "The Oprah Winfrey Show" were down 7 percent last year, understandable against a backdrop of atomizing audiences, but not something you tend to hear about the invincible Ms. Winfrey. The A.P. points out that other daytimers like Jerry Springer and Martha Stewart are down double digits, which is a little hard to figure given that so many Americans are stuck at home on their couch without a job. But Ms. Winfrey has always managed to defy larger trends, so she is opening her 24th season with a Whitney Houston exclusive and a return of Dr. Phil after seven years. Still, she may be up against some self-created turbulence, according to the A.P.

One of the most terrifying and catastrophic weeks in Wall Street history unfolded a year ago. Lehman Brothers collapsed into bankruptcy. Merrill Lynch agreed to be bought at a fire-sale price. Carmelita Jeter of the United States ran to victory in the women’s 100 meters at the World Athletics Final, clocking 10.67 seconds in the third-fastest time on record Sunday in Thessaloniki, Greece. Reviews of “All the Rage” by the New Chamber Ballet at City Center Studio 4 and of the American Dance Guild Performance Festival at Manhattan Movement and Arts Center.

After years of talk and prototypes, some manufacturers believe that the electric vehicle is poised to become more than just a science experiment.
Fashion blogs and blog networks are helping to give young entrepreneurs an early entry into journalism and winning some of them a place in the notoriously competitive fashion industry.
Larry Keigwin and Peter Quanz presented their new dance responses to a work by Steve Reich in a lively exercise in compare and contrast at the Guggenheim Museum over the weekend.
The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.
“Race Music” at the Beckett Theater examines the pitch and pull between generations and among ethnicities as relations in a changing United States evolve.
Jenny Allen discusses her influences, her husband Jules Feiffer and her experiences with cancer, the impetus behind her new play.

Norway’s left-leaning prime minister, Jens Stoltenberg, has asked voters to renew their commitment to one of the world’s most advanced social welfare models.

Samuel Maoz’s graphically violent film about the 1982 Israeli invasion, “Lebanon,” won the Venice Film Festival’s Golden Lion for best picture on Saturday, Reuters reported.

A consortium of major record labels has filed suit against “The Ellen DeGeneres Show,” saying their copyrights to more than 1,000 songs were violated when they were played on the show without permission, The Associated Press reported.
The appearance of Kurt Cobain as a playable character in the video game Guitar Hero 5 has created friction between the game’s publisher, Cobain’s widow and former band mates.
A spokesperson told Playbill that tickets for “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark” would go on sale Oct. 31 despite recent financial troubles that stalled work on the coming Broadway musical.
“Tyler Perry’s I Can Do Bad All by Myself” garnered about $24 million in ticket sales over the weekend, according to box-office tracking services.
With two victories Sunday in a day-night doubleheader, the Philadelphia Phillies mathematically squashed any possibility of postseason baseball for the Mets.
Alex Rodriguez and Manager Joe Girardi were ejected, but Hideki Matsui drove in five runs and Derek Jeter scored three times to help the Yankees avoid a sweep.
New releases by Nelly Furtado, Lil Boosie, Tyondai Braxton and Kid Cudi.
Following an impassioned speech by Coach Rex Ryan, the Jets’ rookie quarterback Mark Sanchez played like a veteran and the defense shut down one of the N.F.L.’s most potent offenses.
A small crowd gathered outside the Fuse studio on Seventh Avenue in Manhattan to watch Jay-Z in concert on Friday night.
The diagramed deal was Board 77 at theBermuda Bowl on Saturday. United States did well at both tables to generate a good swing.
A delegation criticized President Robert Mugabe for continuing to block the replacement of the attorney general, regional governors and central bank chief.
With its 250 jewel-toned tiles spanning 53 feet, LeWitt’s “Whirls and Twirls (MTA)” provides a surprising visual jolt for the subway commuters at Columbus Circle.
Mr. Jones gave a majestic performance of songs by Alan and Marilyn Bergman at the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel on Wednesday.
Olympia Snowe, a Republican senator key to the health care debate, urged President Obama to take any plan for a new government-run program “off the table.”
Juan Martín del Potro stunned Rafael Nadal in straight sets and will face Roger Federer, who beat Novak Djokovic.
Two concerts, one featuring two experimental Austrian composers, and one of a finely polished performance of Steve Reich’s “Music for 18 Musicians,” at Le Poisson Rouge on Saturday.
If you find thinking fun and you like puzzles, and if you aren’t totally flummoxed by portable electronics, Professor Layton and the Diabolical Box is 2009’s game for you.
“The Lost Symbol,” Dan Brown’s overdue follow-up to “Angels & Demons” and “The Da Vinci Code,” brings sexy back to a genre that had been left for dead.
China took steps toward imposing tariffs on U.S. automotive products and chicken meat in response to American tariffs on tires.
A tantrum by Serena Williams in the semifinals may have overshadowed the win by Kim Clijsters, but Clijsters took the spotlight in the final Sunday.
A diverse throng of listeners came to Carnegie Hall to hear the New York Philharmonic with Trey Anastasio, from the rock band Phish.
A Nobel Peace Prize winner, Dr. Borlaug developed high-yielding crop varieties that helped to avert famines worldwide.

Two days after the eighth anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington, Osama bin Laden apparently released a new audiotape, entitled ''An Address to the American People,'' news agencies reported Monday. The tape appeared on As-Sahab, the Arabic-language Web site used by Al Qaeda to deliver its messages.

GOTTSCHALK--Alfred. It is with great sadness that the Board of Directors of Leo Baeck Institute NY notes the loss of our long time colleague and friend. Dr. Gottschalk's contributions to our deliberations were unfailingly valuable and will be greatly missed. Bernard Blum, President Carol Kahn Strauss, Executive Director

The next generation of radio listeners might not remember the olden days of scrolling through stations by turning a knob on a car or home stereo. Instead, the radio they listen to could very well be on their mobile phones. Pandora, which runs a popular streaming radio Web site, on Wednesday released its application for phones running the Android software from Google. It's available for download in the Android Market. Pandora is available on the iPhone, BlackBerry and Palm Pre. Of the 65,000 people who register for a Pandora account each day, 45,000 do so on mobile phones, said Tim Westergren, above, Pandora's founder. ''I'm beginning to think that our future is going to be more mobile-centric than I had even thought, and sooner,'' he said.

Rise and Fall of Cowboys Lauded after Oklahoma State's season-opening victory against Georgia, the first-year defensive coordinator Bill Young was the target of criticism after the No. 5 Cowboys' 45-35 loss to Houston on Saturday.

HART--Robert John Kirkland of Vero Beach, Florida died on September 10, 2009 at Indian River Medical Center in Vero Beach. He was 93. Beloved husband of Marian Hodges Hart, his wife of 62 years. Devoted father of Mimi, Bobby, John and Charlie. Loving grandfather to Schuyler, Nancy, James and Gifford. Bob was a graduate of Deerfield Academy and Princeton University, class of 1940. He served in World War II as Captain in the 18th field artillery battalion, fighting in all five campaigns in the European theatre, earning a purple heart and two bronze stars and was discharged in 1945 as a Major. He was vice-president of Valley Metallurgical in Essex, Connecticut, and was also founder and President of Hart Metals, Inc. in Tamaqua, Pennsylvania. He lived with his family in Lawrence, New York where he was an active member of that community until he and his wife moved to Vero Beach, Florida. Always an avid golfer, Bob continued to play and shoot his age until the age of 91! A memorial service will be held at St. Joachim's Church in Cedarhurst, NY at a date to be determined. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Parkinson Disease Association, 135 Parkinson Avenue, Staten Island, New York 10305.
EIBER--Audrey, died September 11, 2009. She leaves children Marcy, Shelley and Selwyn, brother Gilman, and beloved companion Howie.

At the Coex Convention Center in this city's southern district, a site best known for sleek business exhibitions, Kang Dal-soo, 76, joined the rush to check out the ''silver job fair'' offering 2,000 private sector and 4,700 public sector jobs for retirees. ''It seems I need to learn text messaging in order to deliver flowers,'' Mr. Kang said anxiously after an interview at a courier company's booth. He wanted to work -- even though flower delivery was not his ideal job -- but he was worried about having to master a new technology and wondered if he would be able to keep the job even if he got it.

FRETZ-BROWN--Beverly, a leader in developing housing for low-income urban, rural and immigrant families in California, died of cancer on September 12 in Sacramento, where she had been director of policy and housing development for the Sacramento Housing and Redevelopment Agency. She was 67 years old. Born in Philadelphia, she was a graduate of Chatham College and Indiana University, where she studied political science and development with an emphasis on Africa. After field work in Nigeria, she joined the Housing Assistance Council in Washington DC, where she directed national water and wastewater projects. "I can't think of a significant housing policy in the city or county of Sacramento that doesn't have Bev's hand print on it," said Stan Keasling, CEO of the Rural Community Assistance Corporation. A multi-family housing program in Yuba County, Beverly Terrace, is named after her. The program won a statewide award as the best of its kind. In Sacramento she helped turn a crime-ridden 500-unit development into 476 award-winning affordable homes for families and seniors. She was also instrumental in changing a law that allowed discrimination against poor neighborhoods by not providing them with water service. Ms. Fretz-Brown is survived by her husband, Marcus Brown; three daughters, Jessica, Anna-Martha and Barbara; a brother, Philip Fretz, of Milton, DE: a sister, Barbara Crossette of Upper Black Eddy, PA and two grandchildren. Remembrances may be made to Living Beyond Breast Cancer, 354 W. Lancaster Ave., Ste. 224, Haverford, PA 19041.

GOTTSCHALK--Alfred. The Trustees and Staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage - A Living Memorial to the Holocaust mourn the passing of Trustee and former President Alfred Gottschalk. A visionary leader in the Jewish community, Fred's contributions to Jewish education and the training of Jewish religious and communal leaders will be felt for generations, as will his devotion to repairing the world after the Holocaust. Our condolences to Dee and the family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chair David G. Marwell, Director

LIEBMAN--Dr. Irving, 78, passed away on September 13th, 2009 with his family by his side in his home in New York City after a long battle with cancer. Beloved husband of 41 years of Doris, devoted father of Elissa, Cheryl, Darlene and Jason, adored Grandfather of Katie, Jake and William, brother of Herbert and Grace, he will be deeply missed by all who had the good fortune to know his quick mind, wit and funny, vivacious spirit. A lifelong resident of New York City, Irving was born in Brooklyn where he attended New Utrecht High School followed by Brooklyn College and later The Chicago Medical School. As a Board Certified orthopedic surgeon, he built a thriving private practice in Manhattan and remained actively engaged in his work until the time of his passing. He was an attending physician at Cabrini Medical Center. He split his time between his homes in New York City and East Hampton where he enjoyed spending summers at the beach with family and friends. Irving is preceded in his death by his father Benjamin and his mother Stella. Funeral service will be on Tuesday, September 15th at 9:30am at Temple Emanu-El at Fifth Avenue and 65th Street followed by an afternoon burial at Shaarey Pardes Accabonac Grove Cemetery in East Hampton, New York. Donations may be made to Dana Farber20Cancer Institute Head and Neck Oncology Research Fund.

The 2009-10 regular season of the National Football League opened on Thursday with a win by the Steelers over the Titans, 13-10, above. During broadcasts of regular season games last year, the top 20 companies spent just over $1.02 billion on ads. The top spenders included auto companies, with the federal government standing in for General Motors, beer and beverage manufacturers and wireless carriers. When advertising spending during the playoff games and the Super Bowl was added to the regular season for last year, the total surpassed $2.6 billion. SHELLY FREIERMAN

He is greatly missed already and will live in our hearts always. Viewing will be held at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, September 14 from 6-9pm. Funeral will take place on Tuesday, September 15, 11:00am at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 74th Street between 1st and 2nd Avenues.

WINDELS--Paul, Jr. The members of the Federal Bar Council extend our deepest condolences to the family and friends of Paul Windels, Jr. who served as President of the Federal Bar Council from 1965 to 1966. He was widely respected and a valued friend of the Council. He will be greatly missed. Robert J. Giuffra, Jr. President Federal Bar Council

MANDEL--Stephen Frank, of Darien, CT, of pneumonia, on September 11th at Stamford Hospital. Born in New York at Doctors' Hospital on April 27, 1931, of Dorothy Buchman Mandel and Richard Henry Mandel. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Dartmouth College and the Stanford Graduate School of Business. He is survived by his wife, Ann Safford Mandel, and his sons, Stephen F. Mandel, Jr., and his wife, Susan, of Greenwich, CT, and Edward Safford Mandel and his wife, Betsy, of Chevy Chase, MD, five grandchildren: Kate, Ben, Tom, Ned and Mollie Mandel, and his brother, Richard H. Mandel, Jr., of Denver, CO. In his professional career he was President of Allstate Welding Products in Elmsford, NY, and International Welding Products in Greenwich, CT. As a longtime community leader, he was devoted to the Darien Library, where he was Board President and an Honorary Trustee; Explorer Post 53 Emergency Medical Service; Gallivant; as president of the Darien Community Fund (United Way); and Dartmouth College, among many others. A private service in his memory will be held for his family. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Darien Library, 1441 Post Road, Darien, CT 06820, or Explorer Post 53, P.O. Box 2066, Darien, CT 06820.

Bills at Patriots Buffalo fired the offensive coordinator Turk Schonert after their first-team offense scored one field goal and produced five turnovers in 15 preseason series. Running back Marshawn Lynch is suspended for three games and Terrell Owens played only a handful of snaps before sustaining a toe injury that could nag him all season. The Bills even released the starting left tackle Langston Walker last week. Their offense is in midseason form, but that season is spring.

GOTTSCHALK--Dr. Alfred. The Board, administration, faculty, and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion mourn the tragic death of our beloved visionary, builder of Reform Judaism, and champion of the Jewish people. An advocate for women's rights, he ordained the first women rabbis in America and Israel, was the architect of our campuses in Los Angeles, New York, Jerusalem and Cincinnati. He devoted his life to regenerating Jewish life and learning, and was a founding leader of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum and Museum of Jewish Heritage. His love of Israel was unwavering. His enormous contributions will endure as a sacred legacy. Our heartfelt sympathy to Gina Gottschalk and their children, Marc (Devora) and Rachel (J.B.) and grandchildren, and to his beloved wife Deanna and her children Andrew (Dawn) and Charles (Amy) and grandchildren. Funeral services today in Cincinnati. Memorial services to be announced in New York, Los Angeles, and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, Pres. Barbara Friedman, Chair Burton Lehman, past Chair Stanley P. Gold, former Chair

Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is having to defend the sale of the troubled carmaker Opel to a Canadian-Russian consortium, just days after hailing the deal. Criticism of the deal, which was announced on Thursday, grew over the weekend, beginning with unions that said more jobs would be cut than expected.

CASPERSEN--Finn M.W. Harvard Law School mourns the passing of Finn M.W. Caspersen, beloved friend and visionary believer in the power of education. Finn served as Chairman of the Dean's Advisory Board from 1996-2009 and chaired the Law School's most recent fund-raising campaign, the largest and most successful campaign in the history of legal education. As an exceptional friend and supporter of the School, he inspired others with his remarkable generosity and vision; his devotion to his law alma mater was unsurpassed. His extraordinary legacy at Harvard Law School includes the Caspersen Student Center. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Barbara, their sons, Finn Jr., Erik, Samuel, and Andrew, and the entire Caspersen family. Martha Minow Dean, Harvard Law School

FISHMAN--Kenneth Jay, of Deerfield Beach, FL died Saturday, September 12 at North Broward Medical Center, of complications from Lymphoma. He was 61. He is survived by his son, Eli J. (Laura) Fishman of Eastern Long island, NY and his sisters, Adele (David) Greenblatt of Coconut Creek, FL, and Lorraine (Stephen) Sonnabend of Key Biscayne, FL. Ken was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY and attended New Utrecht High School. He was a talented artist and made his living as a finish carpenter and custom woodworker. He moved to Florida in 1991 to enjoy the warm climate by the ocean. He will be much missed by his family and friends. A memorial service will be held in New York in mid November, time and place to be announced.

RAAB--Lillian, 94, is mourned by her extended, loving family. Born Lillian Golembek November 19, 1914, in the Bronx, she died September 11th in Manhattan. Her immediate survivors are three children and their spouses, Michael (Michi), Jane (Richard Alderson) and Jennifer (Michael Goodwin), and five grandchildren, Virgil, Naomi, Scott, Miranda and Harry, all of New York, and her brother Richard, of Tucson, AZ. Daughter Wendy and husband Harry preceded her in death. Widowed in 1965, Lillian overcame hardship and tragedy to build a successful family life for her children as a para-professional in Public School 173 in Washington Heights. She leaves a legacy of strength and independence that, combined with her extraordinary generosity, continues to inspire all who knew her. The family welcomes donations to the Williams Residence for Seniors, 720 West End Avenue, NY, 10025, or to the Lillian Raab Scholarship Fund, Hunter College Foundation, 695 Park Avenue, NY, 10021.

Adrian Peterson, left, rushed for 180 yards and 3 scores in the Vikings' 34-20 win at Cleveland. Peterson scored on two 1-yard runs and an electrifying 64-yarder in which he broke five tackles. Drew Brees, who tied for the league lead last year with 34 touchdown passes, threw six in the Saints' home opener, a 45-27 win over the Lions. Eight Saints caught at least one pass; five scored.

SCHINDLER--Joan, a gifted interior designer, died on September 1st, 2009. Prior to launching her own firm in 1982, she studied at the New York School of Interior Design and went on to partner with her mother Cele Pollock, an established designer. Over the course of her career, she took part in the opening of the Polo Ralph Lauren flagship store in Beverly Hills, designed specialized interiors for a school for children with learning disabilities, created the prototype for a chain of croissant shops, and worked on countless residential projects on both coasts as well as in Europe. Her work has appeared in House & Garden, Elle Decor, Food & Wine, and a recent project was the House Beautiful selection for Kitchen of the Year in 2007, a cover story for the magazine. She is survived by daughter Jo Wood-Brown, son Les Goldberg, three grandsons Christopher Goldberg, Charles Goldberg, Charles Henry Wood, and great-grandson Charles Goldberg Jr. There will be a memorial service on October 11th.

LIPMAN--Belle Ackerman. The University of Pennsylvania mourns the passing of Mrs. Belle Ackerman Lipman, mother of Ira A. Lipman, a member of the Board of Overseers of the Wharton School, and the grandmother of two Pennsylvanians, Gustave and Joshua. We fondly remember Mrs. Lipman as a native Philadelphian with an exuberance for life that enriched the lives of all whom she met. We gratefully note that her son established the Mark and Belle Lipman Criminology Library Fund at Penn in 1985, and that their portraits today hold a place of honor in the Information Commons in Van Pelt-Dietrich Library Center. On behalf of all Pennsylvanians, I extend our deepest sympathy to Ira and his family. We will never forget Belle and the wonderful example she provided to everyone to live life to the fullest. Amy Gutmann President University of Pennsylvania

Forget the $64,000 question. For the chip industry, we're up to the $10 billion question. That's just about how much money the government of Abu Dhabi has thrown at the ultracompetitive, often volatile chip-making business. Last year, Abu Dhabi pledged to spend at least $6 billion to create a new chip-making venture in partnership with Advanced Micro Devices.

LANGER--Leonard C. R.,Educator, Banker and Sailor, of Annisquam, MA, age 87, died September 6, 2009. Mr. Langer's wife, Nancy, died in 2002. He is survived by his three sons, William, Leonard and Stephen and their wives, along with six grandchildren, a great-granddaughter, and a brother, Bertrand Langer. Burial will be private and no service is planned, but a reception celebrating his life will be held at the Annisquam Yacht Club in Gloucester, MA at 11am on Sunday, September 20th. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mr. Langer's name may be made to the Cape Ann Historical Assoc., 27 Pleasant Street, Gloucester, MA 01930. For complete obituary and to send online condolences, please visit: grondinfuneralservices.com.

WINDELS--Paul, Jr.,died peacefully on September 8. Beloved husband of the late Mary Patricia Ripley Windels; father of Paul Windels III, Mary Hyde Windels, James Hazen Ripley Windels, and Patrick Dillon Windels; and grandfather of Patrick Emmons Windels, Thomas Ripley Windels, George Gunderson Windels, Mary Catherine Yuelan Windels, and Paul Eugene Ruhao Windels. Alumnus of Brooklyn Friends School, Brooks School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. Served in the United States Army in World War II attaining the rank of Major and saw combat in numerous engagements. Chief Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York (1953-57) and Regional Administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission (1957-61), during which time he led the prosecution of the so-called boiler room operators and the investigation of Cady, Roberts & Co., the initial insider trading case, in 1959. Lead Partner Windels, Curry & Rice, Windels, Merritt & Ingraham, Windels & Marx, and Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives and thereafter of counsel to Windels, Marx, Lane & Mittendorf. Chair of the Judicial Nominating Committees for Senators James L. Buckley and Alfonse M. D'Amato. President of the Federal Bar Council. President of the Board, Brooklyn Law School and the Lycee Francais de New York. Trustee of the Lexington School for the Deaf, the Knox School, the French Institute, and the Atlantic Foundation. A funeral service will be held on Monday, September 14, 2009, at 10:00am at St. James Episcopal Church, Route 25A, St. James, New York. A memorial service will be held at Brooklyn Law School during the fall. He was a man of unique qualities and character, deeply committed and loyal to his family and friends, who will be sorely missed.

LIEBMAN--Irving. We mourn the death of our member and extend deepest sympathy to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

BIRDSALL--Douglas C.,former President and CEO of New York Air, passed away on September 11 while jogging at Tod's Point in Greenwich, CT. Mr. Birdsall, 66, began his 35-year career in aviation at Eastern Airlines and went on to hold a number of senior airline industry positions. Mr. Birdsall was one of the first to create and implement the concept of "yield management" a practice now known as "revenue management." He was one of the principle architects of the first international "airline alliance," a structure that is now embraced by the industry globally. Most recently, Mr. Birdsall founded newParadigm, a consumer product company best known for "theRefresher," a low-cost modular bathroom intended to provide modern bathroom facilities for those who could not afford them. Well known for his generosity, he founded the Angelo Delgrosso Scholarship Fund at Westchester Community College, and his contributions to the relief organization AmeriCares was critical commercial airline support for disaster relief missions. A wine enthusiast, a scholar, and an avid runner, Mr. Birdsall brought values and tradition to the ones he loved. Mr. Birdsall, a resident of Greenwich, CT, was born in Port Chester, NY, the son of the late Lester and Viola Birdsall. He is survived by his wife Marilyn, and three children, Cheryl Skowron, Michelle Judice and Todd Birdsall. He is also survived by his two sisters, Carol Schiro and Kathy Casino, three brothers, Topper, Hank and Skipper Birdsall, and six grandchildren. Family and friends may call at the Craft Memorial Home, Port Chester, NY, September 14 from 4-8pm. A Mass will be at St. Catherine of Siena Church, Riverside, CT, September 15 at 9am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Angelo Delgrosso Scholarship Fund at Westchester Community College.

Lt. Assaf Ramon, the son of Israel's first astronaut, Col. Ilan Ramon, who died in the space shuttle Columbia disaster in 2003, was killed Sunday when an F16-A plane he was piloting crashed in the hills near Hebron in the West Bank. Officials said Lieutenant Ramon's plane went down during a routine flight as part of the Israeli Air Force's advanced pilot training course. They added that the commander of the air force had appointed a committee to examine the causes of the crash, which were not immediately clear.

SENATOR Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who is leading the effort to develop bipartisan health care legislation, plans this week to unveil his ''mark'' -- the proposal to be taken up by the Senate Finance Committee, of which he is chairman. Reaction to his plan could finally reveal whether the ''bipartisan six'' subgroup that Mr. Baucus has been working with for months will stick together or whether Democrats will head off largely on their own.

If you’re looking for an excuse to eat chocolate, Swedish researchers have good news. People who eat chocolate appear to have increased survival rates after a heart attack, reports Nicholas Bakalar in today’s Science Times.

During any road race, it’s impossible not to be inspired by the disabled runners in your midst. Whether you’re at the front or back of the pack, you often see someone pushing a wheelchair or a runner guiding a blind athlete.

Lehman Brothers is arguing that Barclays received at least a $5 billion windfall when it bought the bank’s North American brokerage business and some real estate within days of its collapse and bankruptcy filing a year ago, and it is asking a federal judge to revise the deal.

A regulatory agency of the British government is investigating the architecture charity headed by the Prince of Wales following a complaint that the charity is trying to influence planning decisions, The Times of London reported. The Charity Commission, which oversees British charities, has asked the Prince’s Foundation for the Built Environment to explain its relationship with Prince Charles after an anti-monarchy group, called Republic, filed a complaint that said the Prince was using the foundation to enforce his “personal tastes.” Among other architectural disputes that the Prince found himself in this summer, he was accused by Richard Rogers of abusing his power after he intervened to have Lord Rogers removed as the designer of a housing project and criticized his design as “unsympathetic.” Hank Dittmar, the chief executive of the Prince’s foundation, told The Times of London that it was complying with charity law. “We value the Prince of Wales’s presidency of the organization and his vision, but we take our own decisions,” he said.

While some may debate the wisdom of putting Patti LuPone on stage with pistols in her hands, she will soon be taking on the role of the sharpshooter Annie Oakley in a revival of “Annie Get Your Gun.” The Ravinia Festival in Highland Park, Ill., said that Ms. LuPone would play the title role in a series of staged concerts of that Irving Berlin musical to be held from Aug. 13 through 15. The concerts, which are timed to the 150th anniversary of Oakley’s birth, will also star Brian Stokes Mitchell as the marksman Frank Butler, and will be directed by Lonny Price (“110 in the Shade”). The music will be performed by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Paul Gemignani. A concert version of “Gypsy” that was performed at Ravinia in 2006 and starred Ms. LuPone as Mama Rose (another role made famous by Ethel Merman) led to revivals at New York City Center in 2007 and on Broadway in 2008.

TORONTO — The Toronto Star counted about 250 in attendance Monday at a press conference and protest sponsored by critics of the Toronto International Film Festival’s decision to spotlight Tel Aviv in its first City-to-City film program. The gathering, at Ryerson University in Toronto, included John Greyson, the Canadian filmmaker who had earlier triggered the controversy by pulling his own work from the festival. The critics have said Tel Aviv selection serves the aims of an Israeli government that say has dealt harshly with Palestinians. Their opponents — including several dozen who attended a Jewish Defense League-sponsored demonstration against the protest on Monday — have defended both the choice and Israeli policy. By a count published in the Star on Tuesday, celebrities aligned against the Tel Aviv selection include Harry Belafonte, Viggo Mortensen and Julie Christie, while those who have defended it include Jerry Seinfeld, Natalie Portman and Sacha Baron Cohen.

The numbers are in for Jay Leno’s first appearance in his new time 10 P.M. slot. On the Media Decoder blog Bill Carter reports that “NBC succeeded in creating a television sensation with the premiere of Jay Leno’s new prime time hour as almost 18 million viewers showed up. Mr. Leno’s audience was almost NFL-sized – two games on NBC last week reached just over 20 million and were the most watched sports events since the Super Bowl.

A planned rock music project intended to raise awareness about global warming will be missing at least one prominent voice. Peter Garrett, the former lead singer of the rock band Midnight Oil who is now Australia’s minister for the environment, heritage and the arts, said that he would not participate in recording a new version of his band’s hit song “Beds Are Burning” for an organization called TckTckTck, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Garrett, who was first elected to Australia’s House of Representatives in 2004, worked with the Global Humanitarian Forum in Geneva to update “Beds Are Burning” for a version that will be released for free downloading on Oct. 1. An array of musicians and notable figures, including Duran Duran, Bob Geldof, Marion Cotillard, Youssou N’Dour and the retired Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, are expected to lend their voices to the song. But a spokesman for Mr. Garrett told Agence France-Presse that though he “absolutely supports the cause,” he would not sing on the recording.

The New York public broadcaster WNET.org said its subsidiary Educational Broadcasting Corp. is under federal investigation over how it handled grants by the National Science Foundation for production of the PBS children’s math show “Cyberchase.” In a statement, WNET said that the civil investigation, first reported on Sunday by Crain’s New York Business, began in 2008, “and concerns how the grant funds were applied and accounted for under federal grant regulations.”

Days before it begins its 2009-2010 season, the Metropolitan Opera has announced a casting change for its opening production of Puccini’s “Tosca” directed by Luc Bondy. In a news release, the Met said that the Georgian baritone George Gagnidze will sing the role of Scarpia in the production’s premiere on Monday. He is replacing Juha Uusitalo, the Finnish bass-baritone, who has withdrawn due to illness, the Met said. Mr. Gagnidze, who was already scheduled to sing the role in performances on Oct. 17 and in April and May, will also take over from Mr. Uusitalo in performances on Sept. 24 and 28, and Oct. 3, 6, 10 and 14. Mr. Gagnidze made his Met debut singing the title role in “Rigoletto” at the start of the year, and sang Scarpia in a concert performance of “Tosca” with the New York Philharmonic in June 2008.
President Obama will be David Letterman’s guest on Monday night.
The marquees of Broadway theaters will be dimmed for one minute on Tuesday at 8 p.m. in honor of Larry Gelbart, who died on Friday. He was 81.

TORONTO — The Swedish drama “The Ape” is a psychological mystery viewed from the perspective of one man seeking answers to some very dark questions. Jesper Ganslandt, the film’s director, found that the way to tell a mysterious story was by not even letting his lead actor know what it was about. He discussed his approach to making the film.

The crowd at the Emmy Awards is filled with many of the same faces every year — the result of popular television series getting renewed over and over. But there are always a few people on the red carpet who make you say… who? Leading up to Sunday’s Emmy telecast, we’ll be talking to first-timers and other nominated actors who might not be as familiar to viewers as the Alec Baldwins, Sally Fields and William Shatners of the world.

The film, based on the memoir by Simon Carr, explores how to navigate a father-son relationship in the midst of tragedy. Mr. Owen spoke about working with his young co-star, Nicholas McAnulty, and what the child actor taught him about playing a scene.

The South Orange Health Department announced today that it will be giving seasonal flu shots, not to be confused with swine flu shots, on the evening of Tuesday, Oct. 6. Women who are pregnant or nursing must bring a note from their doctor permitting them to receive the shot. Residents over 18 can get the shots at the Baird Center from 5 to 7 p.m. Medicaid Part B patients will be able to receive the shots for free by showing their cards, others will be charged $20 for the shots. Stay tuned for information about the local availability of a swine flu vaccine.--By Tina Kelley

A driftwood sculpture, pieced together by an unidentified creator, stands like a mute sentinel along the Hudson River in Riverside Park. The Times noted the phenomenon of anonymous riverside driftwood sculptures four years ago. "Since at least the spring," Anemona Hartocollis wrote, "someone has been gathering branches worn smooth and silvery by the river, and assembling them into abstract designs. Some incorporate delicately balanced stones; some are tied with found rope. Some are small, others 6 to 8 feet tall. They are anchored among the boulders that line the river from about West 115th Street north almost to the Fairway supermarket at 132nd Street."

A little-discussed feature of the Toronto International Film Festival is the tendency of government officials of all sorts to drop in on the proceedings. They have every right. The festival receives support from about a dozen federal, provincial, municipal agencies, including the Canada Council for the Arts and the government of Ontario. Still, it can be a little unnerving to find a minister, mayor or other functionary dropping in to take a bit of credit for the proceedings, and share a good-natured thought about festival choices -- like, for instance, one official's onstage meditation last week about a long-go decision to screen "Prospero's Books."

An obituary on Aug. 29 about James Lord, a biographer and memoirist of the arts world of Paris after World War II, misstated the surname of his companion and adopted son. He is Gilles Roy-Lord, not Foy-Lord.
An obituary on Sunday about Norman J. Seaman, a concert impresario, misstated his date of birth in 1923. It was March 21, not March 3.

An article in some editions on Sept. 6 about the United States’ 2-1 victory against El Salvador in World Cup soccer qualifying misstated the locations of the Americans’ qualifying matches in October against Honduras and Costa Rica. The United States will play at Honduras and at home against Costa Rica, not the reverse in each case.

An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about planned film studios in Michigan misidentified the developer of an unfinished 160,000-square-foot building in Allen Park, which is to form part of Unity Studios. Samir A. Danou, a local developer, began the project — not the Visteon Corporation.

An article on Friday about individual investors’ returning to the stock market misstated the year-to-date gains of the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index. At the time the article was written, on Thursday, the S.& P. 500 was up about 15.6 percent for the year, closing at 1,044.14. (On Dec. 31, 2008, it closed at 903.25.).
Domonique Foxworth, a cornerback with a yen for history, has been acquiring a treasure trove of African-American memorabilia.

Credits for two charts with an article in some editions on Sept. 4 about campaign spending by the four Democratic candidates for New York City comptroller misidentified the source of the data. It was from the New York City Campaign Finance Board, not the City Board of Elections.

An article on Sept. 6 about President Obama’s new actions to encourage greater retirement savings misidentified the government agencies that are publishing new guidelines for automatic enrollment in employer plans. They are the Treasury Department and the Internal Revenue Service; the Labor Department is not involved.

An article on Monday about a Congressional race in Tennessee included several errors. The Congressional district, the Ninth, had its boundaries redrawn before the 1972 elections, not in 1973. The incumbent, Steve Cohen, said of his record in Congress, “I vote like a black woman,” not “I vote like a 45-year-old black woman.” And a park named for a Klan founder, Nathan Bedford Forrest, that Mr. Cohen voted not to rename is a city park, not a state park. (There is a state park by the same name.).
After all the rain, after all the fury, after all the distractions of this most hurly-burly of tennis tournaments, the 15th day of the U.S. Open had something to give.

An article on Thursday about Sultan Munadi, a former member of the Kabul bureau staff of The New York Times who had recently rejoined the paper temporarily as an interpreter and was killed on Sept. 9, misstated the circumstances behind his resignation from The Times in 2005. He joined an Afghanistan public service radio station and production company owned by a friend. He did not start the radio station and production company. The article also misstated his reason for leaving that business. It was so he could study abroad for a Master’s Degree in public policy, not because the business was struggling.

Hours after an incident Sunday night at the MTV Video Music Awards in which Kanye West, above left, interrupted an acceptance speech by Taylor Swift, above right, musicians were lining up to criticize him. Mr. West halted Ms. Swift’s receipt of an award for her video “You Belong With Me” to say he believed the prize should have gone to Beyoncé and her video for “Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It).” He was ejected from the show at Radio City Music Hall, but his punishment continued in the blogosphere. Katy Perry, who sang at the awards show minutes before Mr. West’s surprise appearance, wrote him a vulgar message on her Twitter feed, concluding that his treatment of Ms. Swift, the 19-year-old country singer, was tantamount to stepping “on a kitten.” Kelly Clarkson wrote an open letter to Mr. West on her blog that asked him: “What happened to you as a child?? Did you not get hugged enough?” On his own blog Mr. West offered an apology to Ms. Swift and her mother, adding that he still believed Beyoncé’s video was “the best of this decade.”.

The stagehands union filed a petition with the National Labor Relations Board on Monday requesting that the group supervise an election of Joyce Theater stagehands to certify the union’s local as their collective bargaining representative. The petition, from Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, was filed after the Joyce Theater Foundation failed to respond to the local’s Aug. 14 request for voluntary recognition, according to a news release from Local 1. Billy Zavelson, a spokesman for the foundation, said, “The Joyce Theater has not seen the petition from Local 1 so cannot comment at this time.” In August, Local 1 stated that the vast majority of the Joyce’s stagehands had recently signed authorization cards selecting the local to bargain on their behalf. In an Aug. 14 letter the union’s president, James J. Claffey Jr., suggested that the Joyce select a neutral third party to review the signed authorization cards. Local 1 represents 3,000 employees including stage and studio electricians, set carpenters, sound designers and special effects workers.
NBC scored with its first “Sunday Night Football” broadcast of the regular season.

So much for the Beatles: in the week when long-awaited remastered editions of their catalog were finally released, the No. 1 position on the British album sales chart was claimed by Vera Lynn, the British singer of World War II ballads, Agence France-Presse reported. Last month Ms. Lynn, 92, known for her performances of songs like “(There’ll Be Bluebirds Over) the White Cliffs of Dover” and “We’ll Meet Again,” became the oldest living artist on the British Top 20 chart when her collection “We’ll Meet Again: The Very Best of Vera Lynn,” reached the No. 20 position. That album was rereleased by Decca Records to coincide with the 70th anniversary of Britain’s declaration of war on Germany. The Beatles albums, released Wednesday, did not perform too badly: on the British chart “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” was No. 5, “Abbey Road” was No. 6, “Revolver” was No. 9, and “Rubber Soul” was No. 10.

The New York Philharmonic said on Monday that the financier Henry R. Kravis had donated $10 million to pay for a composer-in-residence post, as well as a $250,000 prize every two years to a working composer. The award carries with it the obligation to write a piece for the Philharmonic. Under its new music director, Alan Gilbert, who opens the season on Wednesday, the orchestra has increased its contemporary-music activities. Magnus Lindberg, above, a Finn and a favorite of Mr. Gilbert, has already been appointed the first in-house music scribbler and his “Expo” will have its world premiere Wednesday night. Besides writing pieces for the orchestra he will oversee its contemporary-music endeavors. The residency and the prize are named after Mr. Kravis’s wife, Marie-Josée Kravis.

Russian prosecutors have opened a criminal investigation into the possible embezzlement of funds intended for the restoration of the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, Bloomberg News reported. The 185-year-old theater, home to both the Bolshoi Ballet and Bolshoi Opera, closed in July 2005 to undergo renovations that were supposed to be completed last year. But the project is now not likely to be finished until at least 2011. Bloomberg said auditors had found violations in an inquiry into the Office for Construction, Redevelopment and Restoration, the federal agency in charge of the Bolshoi project. In 2003 the agency struck a deal with the firm ZAO Kurortproekt to design the second phase of the renovation. But over the next six years, investigators said, the agency paid the firm three times for the same work, for a total of about $31 million. A spokeswoman for the agency declined to comment to Bloomberg.

The Ukrainian government said Monday that Elton John, below, cannot adopt a child from that country because he is too old and is not married, The Associated Press reported. On a tour Saturday of a Ukrainian orphanage, Mr. John, 62, said he and his partner, David Furnish, who made their relationship official in 2005 under Britain’s civil partnership law, wanted to adopt a child named Lev, who is 14 months old and H.I.V. positive. “I don’t know how we do that, but he has stolen my heart,” Mr. John said, according to The A.P. “And he has stolen David’s heart, and it would be wonderful if we can have a home.” But Yuriy Pavlenko, Ukraine’s minister for family, youth and sports, said that could not be allowed. “Elton John will not be able to adopt a Ukrainian child, and if he files that request, we will unfortunately deny it,” Mr. Pavlenko told The A.P. “The law is the same for everybody.”.

GOTTSCHALK--Dr. Alfred. The Board, administration, faculty, and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion mourn the tragic death of our beloved visionary, builder of Reform Judaism, and champion of the Jewish people. An advocate for women's rights, he ordained the first women rabbis in America and Israel, was the architect of our campuses in Los Angeles, New York, Jerusalem and Cincinnati. He devoted his life to regenerating Jewish life and learning, and was a founding leader of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum and Museum of Jewish Heritage. His love of Israel was unwavering. His enormous contributions will endure as a sacred legacy. Our heartfelt sympathy to Gina Gottschalk and their children, Marc (Devora) and Rachel (J.B.) and grandchildren, and to his beloved wife Deanna and her children Andrew (Dawn) and Charles (Amy) and grandchildren. Funeral services today in Cincinnati. Memorial services to be announced in New York, Los Angeles, and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, Pres. Barbara Friedman, Chair Burton Lehman, past Chair Stanley P. Gold, former Chair

A gentle man of incredible strength and integrity. An entrepreneur and WWII hero. He will be greatly missed.

SCHWALBE--Mary Anne. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee and the Board of Directors, Commissioners and staff of the Women's Refugee Commission are profoundly saddened by the death of our beloved colleague Mary Anne Schwalbe. After a career as a prominent educational administrator, Mary Anne immersed herself in the cause of refugees, playing a pivotal role in the effectiveness of our organizations. She was the founding executive director of the Women's Refugee Commission from 1990 to 1994 and remained engaged in its work since then; a board member since 1997 of the International Rescue Committee - UK, in whose founding she was instrumental; and a tireless volunteer and senior advisor to the International Rescue Committee. Fearless traveler, she visited refugee sites worldwide, ensuring that the needs of uprooted people, especially women and children, were being met. We express our deepest sympathies to her husband, Douglas; her children, Douglas, Will and Nina Schwalbe; and their spouses and her grandchildren. International Rescue Committee, Alan R. Batkin and Jonathan L. Wiesner, Board Co-Chairs George Rupp, President Robert P. DeVecchi, President Emeritus Women's Refugee Commission Glenda Burkhart and Dina Dublon, Board Co-Chairs Carolyn Makinson, Executive Director

8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER In this Season 8 premiere, 16 contestants get second chances to transform their bodies and their lives. The roster includes Daniel Wright, above, who went from 454 to 312 pounds during Season 7 and is returning to finish the job; Shay Sorrells, a social worker who spent much of her childhood in foster care and whose weight of 476 pounds makes her the heaviest player in the show's history; Sean Algaier, a youth minister who wants to help himself so he can help others; Amanda Arlauskas, a college student; and Abby Rike, a teacher who lost her family in an accident. The season begins with a bus trip to the weight-loss ranch and an unexpected stop at a beach where the contestants face their first challenge: complete the last mile of the marathon the four finalists ran at the end of the previous season. The winner will receive immunity at the week's weigh-in and get the chance to pick his or her teammate. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICASerena Williams rehashes her performance at the U.S. Open.

WARMBRAND--Jacob "Jack", of Freehold, NJ, on September 13, 2009. Beloved companion and life partner of Carol Conard of New York City for 47 years. Loving brother of Martin of New York City and Louis of Cranford, NJ, and Estelle Trachtenberg of Blauvelt, NY and Dorothy Spatt of Great Neck, NY as well as uncle to one nephew and ten nieces. A proud veteran of the Army Air Corps and the U.S. Air Force, who received a combat commission while serving on bombing missions in WWII in Europe and in Asia, survived bailing out of his bomber after it was hit by enemy fire, served in the Korean War and went on to have a distinguished military career of more than 20 years. He retired as a major. Jack went on to have a very successful career in the coffee business and worked tirelessly for Jewish charities. For B'nai Brith International, he was the longest serving president of the Max Case Unit that was dedicated to gaining recognition for the accomplishments of Jewish athletes. Jack was instrumental in creating the National Jewish American Sports Hall of Fame. Friend to many sports figures and entertainers, he distributed food to poor Jewish families on New York's Lower East side during Passover. Interment will follow an Orthodox Jewish graveside service held at 11am, Wednesday, September 16, at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY.
DUNN--Oscar L.,1914-2006. With Oscar's spirit remember your high school band, support "C" students, then go fishing with a friend after mixed doubles. "Back home again in Indiana..." Alex

SCHWALBE--Mary Anne, died on September 14, at age 75, of pancreatic cancer. She was an educator and advocate for refugees and displaced persons. She earned her A.B. from Radcliffe College. After working in theater for Irene Selznick and Frederick Brisson and The Playwrights Company, she joined the Radcliffe Admissions office and eventually became Associate Dean of Admissions and Financial Aid for Harvard and Radcliffe. In 1979, she moved back to New York and became Director of College Counseling at Dalton and then Head of the Upper School of Nightingale-Bamford. In 1989, she took a leave to work in a refugee camp in the northeast of Thailand, and became committed to the cause of refugees. In 1990, she helped found The Women's Commission for Refugee Women & Children as its first Staff Director. She was also the founder of the International Rescue Committee's UK Board. Her work on behalf of refugees brought her to 27 countries, often during war. She served on 22 boards, including Brearley (where she went to school), Radcliffe College, and The College Board. She received an Honorary Doctorate from Marymount Manhattan and the De La Salle Service Award. She was the first woman to be President of the Harvard Faculty Club. She was also an Elder of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church and was working to help build traveling libraries in Afghanistan. Her husband, Douglas, her children Douglas, Will, and Nina, their spouses Nancy, David, and Sally, and her five grandchildren adored her. In lieu of flowers, she asked that donations be made to the IRC, the Women's Refugee Commission, The Brearley School, Harvard/Radcliffe, Marymount Manhattan College, or De La Salle Academy. A celebration of her life will be held in late autumn.

Bob started the first sales promotion agency in America, and was the creator of the American Express Gold Card. He was the author of "The Problem is They Don't Know the Problem", and the founder of the Robert M. Sandelman Foundation. He is survived by his wife Linda.

Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, said Monday that he would oppose any resolution rebuking Representative Joe Wilson of South Carolina for heckling President Obama during his speech to Congress last Wednesday night. Anticipating that House Democrats would offer a resolution on Tuesday formally admonishing Mr. Wilson for shouting ''You lie!'' at the president, Mr. Boehner accused them of ''petty partisanship.''

They shared a corner table Monday, chewing over health care and the economy, while having a lunch of fish, pasta and salad at Il Mulino, a restaurant in Greenwich Village. It was the first time in more than a year that President Obama and former President Bill Clinton had sat down alone for a meal and a free-flowing talk about the White House and the challenges around the world. The last time they did so, Mr. Obama was still a candidate who had defeated Mr. Clinton's wife for the Democratic nomination in a sometimes heated race, and the two men were trying to demonstrate cordiality toward each other.
