President Obama's embattled health care plan will get full-throated support from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on Tuesday, although the federation will urge the president to push farther than he may be prepared to go. Delegates to the federation's convention in Pittsburgh are set to approve a resolution that calls for a far-reaching overhaul of the health care system, including a government-run option to compete with private insurers. The president, who will be addressing the convention Tuesday, has said he supports the public option but has also indicated he will not insist on it.

MILES--Jesse M.,77, retired Co-Chairman of Ernst & Young Intl., died peacefully at his home on September 11, 2009. Jesse was a loving husband, father and grandfather and was a role model for his entire family. He will be greatly missed. After graduating from the University of Florida, he joined Arthur Young in 1954 and enjoyed a distinguished 38-year career. He was instrumental in the merger between Arthur Young and Ernst & Whinney in 1989. He is survived by his beloved wife of 50 years, Catherine, six children, Jesse Jr., Cathy, Teresa, John, Thomas and Robert and 16 grandchildren. He is predeceased by his son, James Matthew Miles. A funeral mass will be held September 16th at 11am at St. Michael the Arch Angel in Greenwich, CT.

A major component of the proposed health care overhaul is an expansion of Medicaid, the state-federal insurance program for the poorest Americans. It is an idea that, philosophically at least, Democrats tend to favor more than Republicans. But in the current debate, Democrats have reason to feel conflicted. Many of the states that have the most stringent Medicaid eligibility rules, and so would get significant extra amounts of federal aid to add people to the rolls, tend to vote Republican, and a large number of them favored John McCain over Barack Obama last year.

DUNHAM--Florence Atkins, died peacefully in her New York apartment on August 24th at the age of 103. Florence left behind a son, Robert Ross, and three grandchildren, Andrea, Charlotte and Christopher Ross. Her husband of 56 years, Donald, predeceased her by nine years. She asked her family to remember that she led a long and happy life. She lived in Romania, Switzerland and Italy where her husband worked as a Foreign Service officer. She later accompanied him to Australia, where he represented the United Nations for Papua New Guinea. They lived in an elegant apartment on Riverside Drive for some 40 years next to the Hudson River, which she loved ever since graduating from Barnard College. A warm friend and devoted mother, Florence will be missed by all of us.

Norwegian voters appear to have returned their Labor-dominated government to office, narrowly endorsing Prime Minister Jens Stoltenberg's pursuit of expanded public services and rejecting angry demands by some of his opponents to crack down harshly on immigration. According to official results with 99 percent of the votes counted early Tuesday, Mr. Stoltenberg's three-party left-wing coalition won 86 seats in the 169-seat Parliament. That would give it just enough margin to continue as the only left-of-center government in Scandinavia and one of the few remaining in western Europe.

WOODRING--Carl. The Keats-Shelley Association of America mourns the death of our longtime officer, director and honorary director. A distinguished scholar and teacher, he was also a kind, generous and supportive mentor to generations of students and colleagues among whom he created a lasting sense of community. We will miss his genial and creative presence.

Will the emergence of a malpractice provision in health care legislation prompt lawyers to pull back on financial contributions to members of Congress? Time will tell, of course. But so far in the 2010 election cycle, lawyers and law firms have given incumbent members of Congress more money than any other industry has given, $13.8 million, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. That surpasses the $8.3 million given by health care professionals, who are ranked No. 2.

An article on Friday about individual investors' returning to the stock market misstated the year-to-date gains of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. At the time the article was written, on Thursday, the S.& P. 500 was up about 15.6 percent for the year, closing at 1,044.14. (On Dec. 31, 2008, it closed at 903.25.)

PINTOMorris J.,of New York, NY died on September 14. He was 84. Beloved husband of Camila, his wife of 61 years; father of Jennifer Pinto Safian and Valery Barry; brother, grandfather and great-grandfather. Born in Tangiers, Morocco and raised in England and the United States, he was a graduate of The Lawrenceville School and Yale University. Morris proudly served the United States in WWII, earning a Bronze Star for his bravery, and was a devoted supporter of Israel and Sephardic charities worldwide. He instilled in his loved ones a commitment to service and freedom and will be greatly missed. For funeral service information, call Riverside at 212-362-6600.

Allow a laboratory mouse to run as much as it likes, and its brainpower improves. Force it to run harder than it otherwise might, and its thinking improves even more. This is the finding of an experiment led by researchers at National Cheng Kung University in Taiwan and placed online in May.

While the average family now begins saving for college as a child enters preschool, more than two-thirds are putting aside too little to meet their college savings goals. These are among the findings of a survey of 1,200 parents of children under age 18 released Wednesday night by the Gallup Organization and Sallie Mae, the company that manages nearly $200 billion in education loans.

Dick Morris, the Fox News commentator, syndicated columnist and former political strategist for Bill Clinton, takes on a seemingly unlikely subject — the spiraling cost of college tuition — in an article recently posted on his Web site, dickmorris.com.
The year since Lehman Brothers collapsed has brought many changes for Wall Street, including the part that works on deals.

Updated | 1:03 p.m. James Patterson, one of the world’s most prolific authors and a frequent collaborator with (sometimes unnamed) co-writers, is working on a new thriller with a best-selling Swedish writer, Liza Marklund.

Update | 10:15 p.m. Mary Travers, whose ringing, earnest vocals with the folk trio Peter, Paul and Mary made songs like “Blowin’ in the Wind,” “If I Had a Hammer” and “Where Have All the Flowers Gone?” enduring anthems of the 1960s protest movement, died Wednesday night in Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. She was 72 and had lived in Redding, Conn.

The crowd at the Emmy Awards is filled with many of the same faces every year — the result of popular television series getting renewed over and over. But there are always a few people on the red carpet who make you say… who? Leading up to the Emmy telecast on Sunday night, we’ve been talking to some first-timers and other nominated actors who might not be as familiar to viewers as the Alec Baldwins, Sally Fields and William Shatners of the world.

In Wednesday’s New York Times you’ll find a story about the cast of the FX comedy “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia,” which is presently touring with a live production of “The Nightman Cometh,” the so-bad-it’s-good stage musical performed in the show’s fourth-season finale. After an appearance Wednesday at the Beacon Theater, the series’s stars — Rob McElhenney, Charlie Day, Glenn Howerton, Kaitlin Olson and Danny DeVito — will continue on to Philadelphia (for real), followed by Seattle, San Francisco and Los Angeles.

TORONTO — The documentary “The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers” looks back at a defining moment in American politics when, in 1971, Mr. Ellsberg, a Pentagon official, leaked the secret history of the Vietnam War to newspapers, including The New York Times.

“Someday,” Bob Dylan sang, “everything’s gonna be different when I paint my masterpiece.” Is this different enough to qualify? Nearly 100 paintings made by Mr. Dylan, an artist better known for his throat than for his palette, will go on display next year at the Statens Museum for Kunst (Danish National Gallery) in Copenhagen, Reuters reported. The exhibition, which is planned to open in fall 2010, will include the world premiere of 30 acrylic paintings from Mr. Dylan’s “Brazil Series,” as well as paintings from his “Drawn Blank” series that were previously shown in Britain and Germany. (Before you ask, a representative for Mr. Dylan told Reuters that he did not know what the new paintings would depict or how the singer chose the names of his series.) In a statement, the museum’s chief curator, Kasper Monrad, said, “Bob Dylan’s visual artistic practice has only been discussed by art historians to a limited extent so critical examination and interpretation are called for.” Dylanologists will recall that a sample of the singer’s painting can also be found on the cover of his not exactly beloved 1970 album “Self Portrait.”
What we’re reading on Wednesday morning.

TORONTO — In the film adaptation of C.D. Payne’s book, “Youth in Revolt,” Michael Cera takes on the role of Nick Twisp, a mild-mannered teen whose infatuation with a girl leads him into a life of rebellion. Mr. Cera plays both Nick and his naughty alter ego, Francois. He responded to some of the criticism he has received about playing variations on the same roles in his films.
The writer and director Rodrigo Garcia has made a name for himself with female-driven dramas like “Things You Can Tell Just By Looking At Her” and “Nine Lives.”

In a rare week when new releases from the Beatles and Jay-Z duked it out on the album sales charts, the British pop group and the Brooklyn rapper are both entitled to boast about their accomplishments.

A dispute between the British band Coldplay and Joe Satriani, the rock-guitar virtuoso, has ended remarkably quietly. A representative for Mr. Satriani told Billboard that a copyright infringement lawsuit filed by Mr. Satriani against Coldplay had been dropped, despite an earlier claim by the guitarist that the band, fronted by Chris Martin, above left, had copied one of his songs. In December, Mr. Satriani filed the suit, saying that the Coldplay song “Viva La Vida” made use of “substantial original portions” of his composition “If I Could Fly,” an instrumental track. Coldplay responded that any similarities between the songs were “entirely coincidental, and just as surprising to us as to him.” In a legal filing in April, lawyers for Coldplay said that “If I Could Fly” should not receive copyright protection because it “lacks originality.” The details of the case remain sealed, but Billboard said that the settlement would not require Coldplay to admit any wrongdoing.

The revival of “Hair” has brought the hippies back to Broadway; is the Great White Way now ready for the hipsters? Regina Spektor, the singer-songwriter and mainstay of the East Village music scene, will lend her talents to a planned Broadway musical based on the fairy tale of Sleeping Beauty. In a news release, press representatives for the musical, called “Beauty,” said Wednesday that Ms. Spektor would collaborate with the lyricist Michael Korie (Broadway’s “Grey Gardens”) and the director Tina Landau (“Superior Donuts”), who is adapting the project from a one-act play, also called “Beauty,” produced by the La Jolla Playhouse in 2002. The musical, to be produced by Elephant Eye Theatrical (“The Addams Family”) will feature music by Ms. Spektor, lyrics by Mr. Korie and a book by Ms. Landau. The project is planned for the 2011-2012 Broadway season following an out-of-town tryout. No casting has yet been announced.

The August Wilson Center for African American Culture, a $39.5 million multidisciplinary facility in downtown Pittsburgh, is scheduled to officially open its doors Thursday with a celebration and tribute. It is among a handful of black cultural institutions in the country with its space and scope. The 65,000-square-foot building is home to seven exhibition galleries, a 486-seat theater, an education center, a 4,000-square-foot gallery for art exhibits and multiple-use spaces for community events. The two-story, nonprofit center was designed by the architect Allison Williams, a principal of Perkins + Will in San Francisco. Years in the planning, the center was named in honor of the legacy of Mr. Wilson, the Pittsburgh native and Pulitzer Prize- and Tony Award-winning playwright who died in 2005.

If a single donation of $1 million can transform the fortunes of a financially strained orchestra, how should it react to two such donations? That is the happy quandary that the Charlotte Symphony now finds itself in, The Charlotte Observer reported. On Tuesday, the orchestra said it received a $1 million gift from the family of C. D. Spangler Jr., the construction magnate and former president of the University of North Carolina, through its C. D. Spangler Foundation, and a second $1 million gift from Jane and Hugh L. McColl Jr. Mr. McColl retired as the chief executive of Bank of America in 2001. The orchestra, which has struggled with deficits since 2002, had mounted a fund drive and before the gifts was about two-thirds of the way towards its goal of $1.77 million, including $510,000 in pledges from its board. The Arts & Science Council has said it will give the orchestra $900,000 if it meets that fund-raising goal. As for the two million-dollar donations, Jonathan Martin, the orchestra’s executive director, told The Observer: “This has been a humbling experience for us. We’re profoundly grateful.”
This is the kind of news the publishing industry has been waiting for.

Meryl Streep will ditch Julia Child’s apron to reprise the role of Mother Courage in a one-night benefit performance of “Courage in Concert” at the Public Theater on Oct. 19. On Wednesday, the Public said in a news release that Ms. Streep, who played the title role in its 2006 Shakespeare in the Park production of Bertolt Brecht’s “Mother Courage and Her Children,” would be rejoined by her costars from that production, including Kevin Kline, Jenifer Lewis, Austin Pendleton and Frederick Weller. The concert, which is a benefit for the American Jewish World Service and Partners in Health, will feature songs from “Mother Courage and Her Children” (translated by Tony Kushner with music by Jeanine Tesori) as well as appearances from the cast of the Broadway “Hair” revival and other special guests. The Public’s 2006 production was directed by George C. Wolfe. Tickets for the benefit will go on sale Thursday.

As expected, the audience for Jay Leno’s second night in prime time fell off sharply from his opening night, but it was still a big, dominant win for the former “Tonight” show host with an average of 10.7 million viewers. The numbers were also good among the viewers NBC most cares about, younger adults. But a few hints of concern may forming around the edges of all the sunshine for NBC.

When Tom Ford's "A Single Man" got picked up for distribution by the Weinstein Company at the Toronto film festival, it was one of the big deals in a week lacking in big deals. Which means the public will get to pass judgment sooner than later on that burning question: But can he direct? Let's just say there's already Oscar buzz for Colin Firth, who plays George Falconer, an aging gay college professor in Los Angeles who lost his lover (not partner - the film is set in the 1960s) in a car accident and along with him the will to live. Ditto for Julianne Moore, who plays his best friend, a boozy, divorced British woman still in love with him after a youthful affair decades ago. Nicholas Hoult (the no-longer-a-boy from "About a Boy") is the student who flirts with Falconer, pulling him back from the brink of suicide. Awards season aside, the movie will certainly have fashion and design hounds panting.

The relation between the food and fashion worlds is as Gordian a knot as one could hope to find. One industry is represented by binary codes; rail-thin size 0's walking down a runway like ones on parade. The other world is made up almost entirely of pork belly. But amazingly the two have quite a bit to do with each other. For though models may live in an eternal Yom Kippur, designers love to eat. "The American Fashion Cookbook," an elegant and, of course, skinny hardcover assembled by the Council of Fashion Designers of America and published by Assouline, features the favorite recipes of some of the country's hungriest designers.

Companies, like people, are complex. On the surface, it's not always evident what makes someone tick. Dig a little deeper, however, and you might come across something -- a passion, a past experience, a goal -- that provides an overarching explanation for that person's actions, statements and decisions. The same is true for companies, which, after all, are made up of people, except for one crucial difference: While it's O.K., even intriguing, for a person to go through life being mysterious, enigmatic and complex, a company's motivations need to be clear to all involved, especially job seekers.

The recession has been a boon to no one - except, perhaps, the preachers of the new frugality. All over the Web, in bookstores and on TV, experts, both credentialed and self-appointed, are eager to tell you how to eat, drink, improve your home, expand your wardrobe and, ahem, travel the world without spending too much money.

What do Paul Krugman, Rush Limbaugh, George Will, Thomas Friedman and David Brooks have in common? Not much, we hear you, but they are actually virtually united as the top five in The Atlantic50, a just-hatched feature of The Atlantic Wire, a new digital franchise dedicated to iterating and serving up fresh printed perspectives. We know, we know, the Web isn't really short on opinions -- everyone with a modem has one -- but The Atlantic Wire is an attempt to distill the clutter down to the thinkers and talkers who matter. There are editor's picks, highlighted topics and all manner of rankings of who is shouting down his or her opponents most effectively.

FRONT PAGE.

An obituary on Sept. 6 about the nuclear physicist Louis Rosen misstated the given name of the young colleague at Los Alamos, N.M., who confirmed to Edward Teller that the first man-made thermonuclear reaction had occurred in 1951. He was Norris Bradbury, not Norman.

An obituary on Sunday about Lou Bender, a Columbia basketball star who helped popularize the game in New York City, misidentified the championships he led Columbia to in 1930 and 1931. They were Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championships, not Ivy League titles. (The Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League was popularly referred to as the Ivy League at the time, but the league was not officially formed until 1954.).
Cristiano Ronaldo had a successful Champions League debut for Real Madrid, scoring twice Tuesday night in a 5-2 victory at Zurich.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about a Silicon Valley company that uses voice mail to connect entertainment figures with their fans misspelled the given name of its chief technical officer. He is Ujjwal Singh, not Uttwal.

An article on Monday about the potential sale of BusinessWeek misstated the year the magazine was founded. It was 1929, not 1926. The article also misstated the length of time that the BusinessWeek site Business Exchange had been operating. While the company had been working on it for about two years, the site was publicly introduced only one year ago.

An article on Monday about the involvement of Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, in the race to succeed him misstated the number of people who have run the office since 1941. It is three, not two. (Besides Mr. Morgenthau and Frank Hogan, another long-serving district attorney, Richard Kuh held the office for most of 1974.).

An article on Aug. 31 about the reasons behind the sudden closing of Café des Artistes, a storied Upper West Side restaurant, misspelled the surname of a former ABC news correspondent who said she was a fan. She is Lynn Sherr, not Scherr.
Cyrus R. Vance Jr. won the Democratic nomination for Manhattan district attorney. He faces no G.O.P. opposition in November.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a defrocked Roman Catholic priest who is challenging his conviction of rape and assault of a child misstated, in some editions, the ages at which the child was raped. It was from age 6 to 12 — not age 6 to 9.

A map in the Prescriptions column on Tuesday with an entry about the disparity of state eligibility requirements for Medicaid carried an erroneous label with a scale for states that make it easier to qualify for Medicaid and for those that make it more difficult. The states that make it harder were colored lighter and the states that make it easier were darker, not the other way around. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/prescriptions.

An article on Tuesday about Tennessee Valley Authority plans to spend millions on economic development in Roane County, Tenn., site of a huge coal ash spill, misstated the amount the authority has already spent to buy out 142 property owners. It is $40.2 million (not billion).

Days before it begins its 2009-10 season, the Metropolitan Opera has announced a casting change for its opening production, Puccini’s “Tosca,” directed by Luc Bondy. The Met said that the Georgian baritone George Gagnidze would sing the role of Scarpia in the premiere on Monday. He is replacing the Finnish bass-baritone Juha Uusitalo, above with Karita Mattila, who is playing the title role. Mr. Uusitalo has withdrawn because of illness, the Met said. Mr. Gagnidze, who was already scheduled to sing the role in performances on Oct. 17 and in April and May, will also take over from Mr. Uusitalo in performances on Sept. 24 and 28, and Oct. 3, 6, 10 and 14. Mr. Gagnidze sang Scarpia in a concert performance of “Tosca” with the New York Philharmonic in June 2008.

A regulatory agency of the British government is investigating the architecture charity led by the Prince of Wales following a complaint that the charity is trying to influence planning decisions, The Times of London reported. The agency, the Charity Commission, has asked the Prince’s Foundation for the Built Environment to explain its relationship with Prince Charles after an antimonarchy group, called Republic, filed a complaint that said the prince was using the foundation to enforce his “personal tastes.” Among other architectural disputes that the prince found himself in this summer, the British architect Richard Rogers accused him of abusing his power after he intervened to have Mr. Rogers removed as the designer of a housing project and criticized his design as “unsympathetic.” Hank Dittmar, the chief executive of the Prince’s foundation, told The Times of London that it was complying with charity law. “We value the Prince of Wales’s presidency of the organization and his vision, but we take our own decisions,” he said.

If you’ve been keeping tabs on Willem Dafoe’s extremely violent film “Antichrist,” you know that his co-stars may be wary of taking some lumps. Still, the Public Theater has found a few actors to appear alongside him in its production of “Idiot Savant,” a new work of philosophical comedy written and directed by Richard Foreman. The Public said that Mr. Dafoe, who is to play the title character, would be joined by Elina Löwensohn, Joel Israel, Eric Magnus, Daniel Nelson and Alenka Kraigher. The play is to begin previews on Oct. 27 and open on Nov. 4. Its limited run is scheduled to end on Dec. 13.

While some may debate the wisdom of putting Patti LuPone, below, onstage with pistols in her hands, she will be taking on the role of the sharpshooter Annie Oakley next year in a revival of “Annie Get Your Gun.” The Ravinia Festival in Highland Park, Ill., said that Ms. LuPone would play the title role in staged concerts of that Irving Berlin musical to be held Aug. 13 through 15. The concerts, timed to the 150th anniversary of Oakley’s birth, will also star Brian Stokes Mitchell as the marksman Frank Butler, and will be directed by Lonny Price. The music is to be performed by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Paul Gemignani. A concert version of “Gypsy” that was performed at Ravinia in 2006 and starred Ms. LuPone as Mama Rose led to revivals at City Center in 2007 and on Broadway in 2008.

FASHION GIANTS With Bronx Roots

KALISH--Harry I.,88, passed away on September 12, 2009 at his home in Cupertino, CA, where he lived with his wife of 65 years, Mildred Armstrong Kalish. Harry's service in the Coast Guard during WWII enabled him to attend the University of Iowa under the GI Bill where he received a Ph.D. in Psychology in 1952, studying with some of the most noted behaviorists of the time. After Assistant and Associate Professorships at the University of Missouri, and Duke and Adelphi Universities, he founded the Psychology Dept at the then-new SUNY at Stony Brook in 1961. By 1970, Harry had assembled a young staff of 40 full-time faculty members, and the department was cited by the National Academy of Sciences as one of the six top psychology departments in the country for the coming decade. Harry assumed administrative responsibilities at Stony Brook from 1971 to 1975, as Dean for Professional and Paraprofessional Programs and Vice President for Liberal Studies. He then returned to the Psychology department and retired as Chairman in 1985. He was a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the American Psychological Association. During retirement he and Millie lived in Sarasota, FL, and Brevard, NC before moving to California. Harry's seemingly inexhaustible trove of Yiddish jokes, told in an authentic accent, enlivened many a party. He is also remembered for his cantor-quality singing voice and his facility with the harmonica and autoharp. Harry is survived by his sister, Shirley, his sons Doug and Greg, four grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. The family welcomes memorial donations to The Stony Brook Foundation for a scholarship in Harry's name.

Zakes Mokae, a Tony-winning South African actor whose partnership with his countryman, the playwright Athol Fugard, in plays like ''The Blood Knot'' and ''Master Harold ... and the Boys'' brought the insidious psychological brutality of apartheid to the attention of a world audience, died on Friday in Las Vegas, where he had a home. He was 75 and also lived in Cape Town. The cause was complications of a stroke he had on May 6, said his wife, Madelyn. He had previously received diagnoses of Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease, she said.

MAHONEY--Dr. William, died at age 88. An emeritus professor and former chair of the Department of Art and Education at Teachers College, Columbia, he inspired legions of students to pursue careers in the arts and in education. He is survived by his wife of sixty years, Alice Henry, children Ellen, Christine, William, and sister Mary Ellen Fischer.

The Great Society lives. While everyone is talking about Medicare, Lynda Bird Johnson Robb is stepping up to remind everyone that it was her father, former President Lyndon B. Johnson, who signed Medicare into law in the first place. Ms. Robb appears in a video released Tuesday on behalf of the Alliance for Retired Americans and its campaign to mobilize older Americans to support an overhaul of the health care system. In the video, Ms. Robb says she is distressed to see Medicare being maligned in the current debate and urges older Americans to help push for health insurance for everyone.

Although the White House has signaled that a so-called public option may not be integral to a health care overhaul, some interest groups are trying to pressure Democrats to keep the idea of a government-run insurance plan on the table. Health Care for America Now, a coalition of more than 1,000 labor unions and advocacy groups, rolled out a $1.2 million advertising campaign on Tuesday, urging passage of a public option and demonizing the health insurance industry, which opposes the idea.

SCHWALBE--Mary Anne. The Board, Faculty, Alumni, and Students of De La Salle Academy mourn the passing of our dear friend and Trustee Emerita, Mary Anne Schwalbe. Throughout her life, Mary Anne was devoted to improving the lives of women and children in New York City and throughout the world. She served as a Trus- tee of De La Salle from 2000 until 2007, sponsoring three students during that period and working tirelessly to ensure that our students received the highest quality education. She received De La Salle's Service Award at our 2008 commencement, where both our Principal and our Board Chair told the graduates, "If you want to make a difference in the world, here is your role model." We extend our deepest sympathies to her husband, Douglas, her children Douglas, Will, and Nina, and their spouses and her grandchildren. Brother Brian Carty, FSC Principal and Founder Raymond J. McGuire, Board Chair

WARMBRAND--Jacob "Jack", of Freehold, NJ, on September 13, 2009. Beloved companion and life partner of Carol Conard of New York City for 47 years. Loving brother of Martin of New York City and Louis of Cranford, NJ, and Estelle Trachtenberg of Blauvelt, NY and Dorothy Spatt of Great Neck, NY as well as uncle to one nephew and ten nieces. A proud veteran of the Army Air Corps and the U.S. Air Force, who received a combat commission while serving on bombing missions in WWII in Europe and in Asia, survived bailing out of his bomber after it was hit by enemy fire, served in the Korean War and went on to have a distinguished military career of more than 20 years. He retired as a major. Jack went on to have a very successful career in the coffee business and worked tirelessly for Jewish charities. For B'nai Brith International, he was the longest serving president of the Max Case Unit that was dedicated to gaining recognition for the accomplishments of Jewish athletes. Jack was instrumental in creating the National Jewish American Sports Hall of Fame. Friend to many sports figures and entertainers, he distributed food to poor Jewish families on New York's Lower East side during Passover. Interment will follow an Orthodox Jewish graveside service held at 11am, Wednesday, September 16, at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY.

TESSER--Dorothy. Our family mourns the passing of our very special "Aunt Dot," who never forgot any of us on every big and small occasion. We extend our condolences to the entire Tesser family and Ed Peck. Iris and Howard Perry and family Poppy and Ronny Wurtzburger and family

BLUM--Robert B.,former President of Craftex Mills of Pennsylvania, age 93, died in Jupiter, FL on September 14. In WWII he was Captain of PT122 in the south Pacific. He served on the boards of the Philadelphia Maritime Museum, the Seaman's Church Institute, St. Peters School, St. Andrew's School in Delaware and FAU Honors College. Bob is mourned by his wife, the former Leslie Rogers, his children, Robin Smith, Robert M. and Nicholas Blum, Jay Blum (deceased), five grandchildren, one great-grandchild and his sister Jean Seder.

NASH--Cornelius C. Neil Nash, 48, died on September 9th after years of a heroic battle with brain cancer, Neil's legacy is one of kindness and inspiration in the face of his baffle. For the past 16 years Neil has fought and triumphed over numerous run-ins with the disease, constantly turning the medical community on its head while keeping his own- Neil was a real New Yorker and lived in Manhattan most of his life. He loved the city and was often the very embodiment of its struggles and triumphs. As a close friend states; "A big part New York City's beauty is that it often feels so fragile and so grand at the same time. Neil Nash was the same; he was always grand and epic even during the hardest times." For the last 10 years he was an acclaimed project manager who oversaw a wide array of projects in New York and throughout the US. Neil helped manage several large institutional restoration projects after hurricane Katrina, as well as built high-end residential projects throughout New York City, and a prominent soup kitchen and social services agency in Brooklyn. A statement from close friends reads; "No matter what Neil was going through personally he always maintained an optimism and willingness to help others, laugh out loud, and be the most stylish guy in the room. His sense of humor, rigorous honesty, and openness always made Neil a magnet for great conversations and connection with everyone he encountered." Cornelius is mourned by his wife Martha Brophy, his children Jedidiah and Campbell, his sister Juliana Nash Stenerson, his mother, Juliana vanderVloed Nash, and a huge family and circle of friends too numerous to mention.

LeBron James signed in Manhattan on Tuesday. It was not the signing Knicks fans had hoped to see. James was at a Barnes & Noble autographing his new book, ''Shooting Stars,'' co-authored by Buzz Bissinger. A line looped around the aisles on the second floor and snaked around the building. James was met by photographers, who were quickly shuffled off by the store's security after the first couple of books were signed.

RISMAN--Robert Edward. Born August 31, 1960 in Birmingham, AL, died September 14 in Greenwich, CT. Beloved husband of Nancy Margolis Risman. Cherished son of Leone Risman and the late Dr. George Risman, and brother of Keith Risman. Mr. Risman graduated from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania with a B.S.E. in accounting and received an M.B.A. in finance from Columbia Business School. Mr. Risman spent 23 years in the finance industry, most recently as Head of International Equities Sales and Trading for Macquarie Group (USA) in New York City. Mr. Risman is survived by three beloved children: Philip, Tucker, and Carly. A memorial service will be held at Greenwich Reform Synagogue, 257 Stanwich Road, Greenwich, CT on Thursday, September 17th at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in memory of Robert Risman to the University of Pennsylvania, The Penn Fund (send checks payable to: The Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania, 3451 Walnut Street, Room 601, Philadelphia, PA 19104) or The Red Ribbon Foundation (send checks payable to: The Red Ribbon Foundation, 270 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06830.)

MANDEL--Stephen F. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Darien Library mourn the loss of a steadfast friend, thoughtful leader, and generous supporter. Stephen F. Mandel served as a Trustee of the Library from 1985 to 1991 and was President of the Board of Trustees from 1988 to 1991. He was named an honorary Trustee of the Library in 1991. He co-chaired the Library's 1982-84 expansion Capital Campaign with his wife, Ann Safford Mandel, and was an honorary co-chair of the Library's New Building Campaign that led to the opening of the New Darien Library in January 2009. Insightful analysis, thoughtful mentoring, great common sense, and a twinkle in his eye were hallmarks of his success as a businessman and his commitment to community service. His advice at important moments was treasured and comforting. To his wife, Ann, and to his family, we express our sorrow for their loss, tempered by our belief that Steve's was a life well and truly lived. To our friend Stephen Frank Mandel's memory, we pledge to remain committed to the ideals of service that he demonstrated so thoughtfully, so successfully and so well.

FAHEY--Sr. Theresa, RSHM, 80, died in New York City, September 10, 2009. A Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for 60 years, she served in RSHM Schools in Tarrytown, NY, Canada, France and England. She ministered at Marymount School of New York, the Jesuit Secondary Education Association, Bronx, NY, the National Pastoral Life Institute, New York, NY. BORLAUG--Norman. The Rockefeller Foundation mourns the passing of Norman Borlaug, Nobel laureate and distinguished colleague. As the Green Revolution's engineer, Norman not only bred hardier, higher-yielding seeds, but also cultivated political will to assure that smallholder farmers could sow, fertilize, irrigate, and move more productive harvests to market. He saved a billion lives and counting. More than half of all people eat rice and wheat varieties containing genes introduced by Norman and other Rockefeller Foundation scientists during the 1960s. The world is more peaceful and humane as a consequence. Judith Rodin, President, Rockefeller Foundation James F. Orr III, Board Chair, Rockefeller Foundation

Daisuke Matsuzaka was starting for the Red Sox for the first time in almost three months Tuesday night. He was also trying to prove that he should be starting for the Red Sox next month. So far, the proof is compelling. In Matsuzaka's first start since June 19, he pitched six scoreless innings to help the Red Sox beat the Los Angeles Angels, 4-1, at Fenway Park. He allowed three hits, struck out five and walked three in a 93-pitch effort. The Red Sox are hoping that Matsuzaka, who has been troubled by a strained shoulder this season, can be their fourth starter in the postseason.

SCHWALBE--Mary Anne. The monuments to Mary Anne Schwalbe are many and widely dispersed. Everyone who knew her built their own version out of fondness. Her compassion for others was profound. Bryan O'Rourke

HIRSCH--Adam, of Brooklyn, NY, died suddenly at his home in Brooklyn on Sunday September 13, 2009. He was 44. He is survived by his parents, Lawrence and Liselotte Hirsch, sister Jan, and brothers Jordan (Marjorie) and David (Esther). He was a beloved uncle, cousin, and friend to many. He was a mensch among menschen.

BEILIN--Ruth (Kelly), passed away peacefully at home on September 15, 2009 at the age of 90. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Respected and adored mother of Peter (Debra), Amy (Kenneth) and George (Stephanie). Extraordinary grandmother to Jamie, Kim (Brett), Jonathan (Rebecca), Keith (Diane), Lauren (Ricky), Andrew, Ari, and Evan. Loving great-grandmother to Marley, Jed, Rio, Rex, Bo, Roscoe, Josey, Felix, Eloise, and River. She was deeply loved by her sister, Mildred, brothers Buddy and Dick, and her late sister, Evelyn. She embraced her entire life around family, friends, and faith. She wrote her greatest achievements were her 64 years of marriage, her three children, and her scholarship to Art School. She was an accomplished artist and sculptress and was a founding member of Beth Tikva Synagogue in Lake Worth, FL. She loved the outdoors, especially the ocean, and the many years of playing in the sand building boats with her grandchildren. Rest in peace, Kelly, you are with your Joey, now. Services Wednesday, 11:30am at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

Daniel Murphy had two of the Mets' four hits. Pat Misch (1-3) went five innings and allowed eight hits and four runs. ... Major League Baseball released details of the 2010 schedule Tuesday. The Mets will open at home against Florida on Monday, April 5, and will close at home against Washington on Sunday, Oct. 3. In between, they will play an interleague schedule that, beyond the Yankees, will consist of games against Baltimore, Cleveland, Detroit and Minnesota. The Mets will spend the final week of the season at home, which is not necessarily a good omen. In 2007 and 2008, the Mets spent the final week of the season at Shea Stadium, tripping over themselves and missing out on the postseason. JAY SCHREIBER
OPPENHEIMER--Frederick, age 97, died on September 13, 2009. Loving husband of the late Hilda Katz Oppenheimer, father of Gerald, Richard and Joan, grandfather of Julia, Suzanne and Jonathan.

SCHWALBE--Mary Anne. President Judson R. Shaver and the Board of Trustees of Marymount Manhattan College express profound sadness at the passing of Mary Anne Schwalbe. A former trustee, devoted supporter and dear friend, Mary Anne endowed the Mary Anne Schwalbe Scholarship to support refugee or international students at Marymount Manhattan. In 2008 the College awarded Mary Anne an Honorary Doctorate. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community extends its deepest sympathies to Mary Anne's husband, Douglas, and their family.

SCHWALBE--Mary Anne. The Dalton community mourns the passing of Mary Anne Schwalbe, former College Counselor, and member of the Board of Trustees and long term friend to the School. Her wisdom, warmth and generosity of spirit blessed countless members of our community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Ellen C. Stein Head of School

For most Germans, it was a rare -- even shocking -- scene. There, on television, were coffins holding the bodies of three soldiers, all in their early 20s, all killed in Afghanistan, all draped with the national flag. The soldiers, Martin Brunn, 23; Oleg Meiling, 21; and Alexander Schleiernick, 23, were memorialized July 2 at a service in Bad Salzungen, in the eastern state of Thuringia, where their armored infantry battalion has its headquarters. The three were killed in the Kunduz region, where most of Germany's 4,000 troops are based, bringing to nearly three dozen the number of German soldiers killed in Afghanistan.

Loved dearly by three children, Susan Post, Barbara Wolf and Richard Wolf; six grandchildren, five great-grandchildren, and a sister, Lucille Bralower. McDONALD--James Scott, of New York City, on September 13, 2009. Beloved husband of Karen Hunter McDonald, devoted father of Scott, Hunter and Isabel. Born January 26, 1953 to Lloyd and Alice McDonald in Auckland, New Zealand, Jim showed exceptional promise from an early age. A gifted student and tennis player, he graduated from Harvard College, in 1975, and the University of Virginia School of Law in 1977. He began his career as a highly successful attorney at Choate, Hall & Stewart in Boston, where he became a partner in 1984. In 1986 he joined Pell Rudman & Co., a wealth management firm in Boston, where he served as President and CEO. In January 2001, Jim came to New York to become President and CEO of Rockefeller and Company. He expanded the company from a multi-family office to an internationally-recognized investment firm that serves a broad number of families and institutions. Jim was a member of numerous committees and organizations, including serving as a board member of NYSE Euronext (formerly the New York Stock Exchange). In addition, he was chairman of the board of the Japan Society of New York and a member of the Council of Foreign Relations. He also served as a trustee of the Nightingale-Bamford School in New York and as chair of the board of trustees of Fessenden School in West Newton, Massachusetts. A memorial service will be held on Monday, September 21, 4:00pm at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave. and 90th Street, New York City. Burial will be in Prout's Neck, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Harvard College, Friends of Harvard Squash at Harvard College or the University School of Virginia School of Law.

THE overnight temperature is dropping toward frost this week and probably won't rise above it until May. Most of the cruise ships are gone, and with them the fudge buyers, the lobster seekers and the chowderheads who clog the Old Port neighborhood in the summer.

Until the time of her death CeCe was an active Senior Paralegal at the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. She was with the firm for over 50 years. CeCe was predeceased by her devoted husband, James "Big Jim", and her brother, Francis "Buddy" Donovan. She is survived by her son, James W. McDonald Jr., his wife, Linda Cassano, and grandson, Anthony James "Tony". Cece is also survived by her beloved sister, Jane Barbara, and numerous nieces and nephews and their spouses and children all of whom were devoted to her. She was also beloved by her many friends, young and old. Family will receive friends on Wednesday, 7-9pm and Thursday, 3-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10am at St. Francis DeSales, 96th Street and Lexington Ave. Interment to follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Burn Unit at Weil Cornell Medical Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital.

President Obama may not have much trouble convincing the nearly 160 million people who receive health insurance through their employers that the system needs to be fixed, if a new survey of employer health benefits is any indication. The average cost of a family policy now exceeds $13,000 a year, having doubled over the last decade, according a survey released Tuesday by the Kaiser Family Foundation.

WRIGHT--Sarah Elizabeth (Kaye). Acclaimed novelist, poet, social activist, passed away September 13. Born in Jim Crow Wetipquin, MD, she plunged into the great movements for peace, justice and Black freedom. Her novel, This Child's Gonna Live, a "prose poem of excruciating beauty," was hailed as a masterpiece by the NY Times. Beloved by family, friends and all those whose lives she touched, she embodied the limitless possibilities of the human spirit. She is survived by her husband who idolized her, her loving children Michael and Shelley, devoted siblings and grandchildren, of whom she was so proud.

The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Tuesday that it was ''very likely'' that the recession had ended although he cautioned that it could be months before unemployment rates dropped significantly. ''Even though from a technical perspective the recession is very likely over at this point, it's still going to feel like a very weak economy for some time as many people will still find that their job security and their employment status is not what they wish it was,'' Mr. Bernanke said in response to a question about unemployment trends. ''That's a challenge for us and all policy makers going forward.''

Summer winds down, and that early evening glass of wine goes from crisp white and pretty rosé to something red and more substantial. Earthy, rustic reds from the sprawl of the Languedoc, many of them balancing fruit and tight minerals without making huge demands on the wallet, suit the moment. And they can be poured through dinner. They need food alongside, and to start, this silken chicken liver mousse hints at the more noble foie gras of the region. Its texture is well bred but it also delivers a brash, curried edge that can look the more muscular of these wines straight in the eye.

The White House's Middle East envoy, George J. Mitchell, is set to hold an additional meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu here on Wednesday, according to Israeli and American officials, as part of an effort to pave the way for a resumption of Israeli-Palestinian negotiations. Mr. Mitchell met Mr. Netanyahu for two hours on Tuesday, then headed to Ramallah in the West Bank for meetings with Palestinian leaders. He joined the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, for a meal breaking the daily Ramadan fast. Mr. Mitchell is trying to put together a package of gestures and confidence-building measures that will allow the sides to restart the stalled talks.

(13, 49) NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC OPENING NIGHTS GALA CONCERT Alan Gilbert, above, makes his debut as the music director of the New York Philharmonic -- he is the first native New Yorker to assume the role -- at the orchestra's 168th-season premiere, and ''Live From Lincoln Center'' is there. The program opens with ''Expo,'' an overture written for the occasion by Magnus Lindberg, the Philharmonic's composer in residence, and includes Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' and Messiaen's ''Poèmes Pour Mi,'' performed by the soprano Renée Fleming. Alec Baldwin, the new voice of ''The New York Philharmonic This Week,'' the orchestra's weekly national radio broadcast, is host. In ''Vienna Philharmonic Summer Night's Concert 2009,'' presented at 10 by ''Great Performances,'' Daniel Barenboim conducts the orchestra on the grounds of the Schönbrunn Palace. The night-theme program features ''A Little Night Music'' by Mozart, ''A Thousand and One Nights'' by Johann Strauss and ''A Night on Bald Mountain'' by Mussorgsky. Mr. Barenboim does double duty as the pianist in de Falla's ''Nights in the Gardens of Spain.'' 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYAmy Poehler promotes the return of ''Parks and Recreation'' (Thursday at 8:30 p.m. on NBC) before moving to ''The View,'' and its guest host La Toya Jackson, at 11 on ABC.

I LEARNED how to make good crab cakes 20 years ago from Johnny Earles, a chef and friend in the Florida Panhandle. When I say ''good,'' I mean crab cakes made predominantly from crab, seasonings, a tiny bit of mayo as binder (you need something) and not much else. And for a long time I barely tinkered with the recipe. Why would I? Everyone loved it. Then it occurred to me that I could make a formidable crab cake in a style that mimics tod mun, the Thai fish cake that, when made right, packs astonishing flavor. The challenge was replacing the mayo; it seemed odd to include it in a Southeast Asian dish. And then I realized I could take the tod mun imitation one step further and use the time-honored technique of including puréed fish as a binder.

The only thing more surprising than Mike Bell's 143 rushing yards for the Saints on Sunday was how far he had to go to get them. Bell was a star as an undrafted Broncos rookie in 2006, rushing for 677 yards and a team-high 8 touchdowns, but he fell out of favor after Denver asked him to move to fullback and signed Travis Henry. Overweight and seemingly indifferent, Bell had only six carries in five games in 2007, and the Broncos cut him last July.

FRANK--Peter F.,of Middleboro, MA, formerly of New York, passed away on September 14th at his home peacefully from an illness. Father of son Douglas and his wife Michelle, and daughter Pamela and her husband Afshin as well as grandfather to Felicia and Veronica Frank of Weymouth, MA, and Kion and Niki Khosravi of Mill Valley, CA. Peter also leaves behind a beloved friend and caretaker "Sattie." Peter enjoyed classical music and traveling the world with his son, as well as frequent trips to the west coast to visit his daughter and her family. Relatives and friends are invited to share condolences at the home of Douglas and Michelle Frank in Weymouth on Sunday, September 20th from 12-4pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests you have dinner with a loved one and share special thoughts we take for granted in our daily life.

Watch out, offensive coordinators, because the early returns on teams that fired theirs before the regular season are promising. The offense that the departed Buffalo Bills coordinator Turk Schonert said was ''Pop Warner'' looked pretty good for most of the night against the Patriots on Monday. Trent Edwards used the no-huddle effectively, completing 15 of 25 passes for 212 yards and 2 touchdowns, with no interceptions. Tailback Fred Jackson, replacing the suspended Marshawn Lynch, had 57 rushing yards and 83 receiving yards. On the Bills' final touchdown drive, Edwards executed a nifty inside handoff to Jackson. He hid the ball on his hip as he looked downfield, as if to throw, before handing it off. The fake froze the Patriots' defense for an extra moment and gave Jackson an opening for a big gain.

SULLIVAN--Caroline I.,71, died on September 13, 2009 at her residence in Manhattan. She moved back to Manhattan from Pawling, NY in January 2009 after being diagnosed with a brain tumor. After raising her children, Caroline went back to school and received her BA/MA in urban policy from Stony Brook University in Long Island. She then worked for the city of New York for 25 years, starting in the New York City Urban Fellows Program and then worked as a staff analyst for the Controller's office. Caroline quickly rose through the ranks and was appointed the Executive Director for the Office of Payroll Administration until she retired in 2001 as the First Deputy Commission for the Office of Labor Relations. Caroline was married to Daniel Joseph for 48 years before he passed in 2003. She is survived by her four children, Daniel, John, Caroline and Elizabeth and their families and her sisters Ruth Schlieper, and Florence Gaddis. We would be remiss to forget her fifth "child", her niece, Ruth Anne Lazarus. Caroline had many interests including traveling, cooking, entertaining, reading, shopping, and attending the ballet and theatre. She will always be remembered for her hospitality, work ethic, and keen intellect. Caroline had many names including; mom, grandma, aunt, sister, godmother, surrogate mom, mentor and friend. She took pride in her relationships with her family and friends, which are too many to mention. She will be greatly missed. Visitation will be in Pawling, NY at Horn and Thomes Funeral Home on Wednesday, September 16, 2-4pm and 7-9pm and the mass will be at St. John's Church in Pawling on September 17 at 11am. Memorial donations may be made to either St. John's Church in Pawling or the Pawling Historical Society.

Kanye West may have said on Monday night that he owes Taylor Swift a more personal apology, but Jay Leno owes Mr. West a vast debt of gratitude. Mr. West's solipsistic but touchingly unpolished mea culpa gave the premiere of ''The Jay Leno Show'' a serendipitous and very helpful boost. Advance booking, not last-minute lobbying, brought Mr. West to Mr. Leno's new set. Mr. West's timely star turn -- an apology for his outburst on Sunday's MTV Video Music Awards -- was a lucky fluke, so the first show didn't really give viewers a chance to judge NBC's 10 p.m. experiment: the much ballyhooed shift in prime-time programming that Time magazine predicted could determine ''the future of television.'' The future of ''The Jay Leno Show'' is likely to look almost exactly like ''The Tonight Show'' past.
In today’s Personal Best column, Gina Kolata explores the benefits of group running.

The maximum annual Pell Grant scholarship would increase to $5,550 in 2010 and to $6,900 by 2019 — from $5,350 now — under legislation passed today by the House of Representatives. The measure now moves on to the Senate, where it is also expected to win passage.

On this week’s Popcast: Jon Pareles reviews Jay-Z’s latest album, “The Blueprint 3″; Ben Ratliff discusses Tyondai Braxton’s “Central Market”; and Shilpa Ray performs live and talks to Ben Sisario about the perils of rock rebellion. Sia Michel is the host.
What we’re reading on Thursday morning.

Has the pop-cultural universe just collapsed on itself? The picture you see above is not a Photoshop trick — it’s a scene from a coming episode of “The Oprah Winfrey Show” in which Ms. Winfrey (arguably the most powerful force in daytime television) meets Jon Hamm and January Jones of “Mad Men” (arguably the most popular television series in our minds).

Confirming the reports of music bloggers everywhere and satisfying the wishes of anyone who has worked at a college rock radio station since the early 1990s, the rock band Pavement said it would reunite for a series of performances next year. Known for its low-fidelity recordings and sardonic lyrics, the band, consisting of Stephen Malkmus, Scott Kannberg, Mark Ibold, Bob Nastanovich and Steve West, played its last show in 1999 at the Brixton Academy in London. On Thursday, the Web site of Matador Records, the band’s longtime label, said that Pavement would perform on Sept. 21, 2010 at Rumsey Playfield in Central Park. In its Web post, the record label said, “Things worked out really well when Diana Ross played Central Park in 1983, and we have no reason to suspect Pavement’s return to the live arena won’t generate similar headlines.” Testing the limits of indie-rock fans’ abilities to make long-term plans, tickets for the 2010 Central Park concert will go on sale Friday.

Going into Week 3 of “Glee” on Wednesday night, the stakes were high. The pilot, first shown way back in May, was fresh and funny and moving. It was “Gay Friday Night Lights.” (All right, “Openly Gay Friday Night Lights.”) But the second episode, when it finally arrived, was predictable and slightly maudlin and, despite what you might have read elsewhere, did not contain one laugh-out-loud joke. O.K., it was pretty funny when the mailman hit the windshield the second time.

President Obama has announced three new members to the President’s Committee on the Arts and Humanities, the committee said on Wednesday. The three new appointees are George Stevens Jr., the founding chief executive of the American Film Institute and producer of the Kennedy Center Honors; Margo Lion, the theater producer whose Broadway credits include “Hairspray,” “Angels in America” and “Jelly’s Last Jam”; and Mary Schmidt Campbell, the chairwoman of the New York State Council on the Arts and dean of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. Mr. Stevens and Ms. Lion will serve as co-chairs of the committee, which works with federal cultural agencies and in the private and public sectors to further the White House’s cultural objectives, and Ms. Campbell will serve as vice chairwoman. The appointments are effective immediately.

A memorial service for Merce Cunningham, the dancer and choreographer who died in July, will be held on Oct. 28 at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan, the Cunningham Dance Foundation said Thursday. The memorial, which will be open to the public, will run from 4 to 9 p.m., and will feature the Merce Cunningham Dance Company performing “Events” — what Mr. Cunningham called performances made from combinations of works from the company’s repertory. They will be arranged by Robert Swinston, Mr. Cunningham’s longtime assistant, and will be preceded by excerpts from the Cunningham dance “Second Hand.” The MCDC Music Committee will also perform, and additional artists are expected to be announced in the coming weeks. Further details can be found online at merce.org and armoryonpark.org.

In a review of the Sam Mendes film “Away We Go” in The New York Times, A. O. Scott described that director as “a literary tourist from Britain who has missed the point every time he has crossed the ocean.” So how will Mr. Mendes handle the adaptation of a literary work about New York whose author and narrator both have roots on the opposite side of the Atlantic? We may soon find out: Variety reported that Mr. Mendes’s production company has joined with Oprah Winfrey’s Harpo Productions and Focus Features to create a film adaptation of the Joseph O’Neill novel “Netherland” that Mr. Mendes may direct. The novel, which follows a Dutch-born stockbroker in New York from the 1990s to the present decade, won the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for Mr. O’Neill, an American citizen of Turkish and Irish descent who was raised partly in the Netherlands. Christopher Hampton will write the “Netherland” screenplay; a cast and release date were not announced.

With five nominations, the Puerto Rican hip-hop and reggaetón duo Calle 13 leads the finalists for the 10th annual Latin Grammy Awards, announced on Thursday morning in Los Angeles. Calle 13, with one Grammy and five Latin Grammys already under its belt, was nominated for album of the year and best urban music album for “Los de Atrás Vienen Conmigo,” and its “No Hay Nadie Como Tú,” with Café Tacuba, is up for record of the year and best alternative song; Calle 13’s “La Perla” is also up for best short-form music video. Ivan Lins, José Lugo, Jorge Luis Piloto, Ivete Sangalo, Gilberto Santa Rosa, Caetano Veloso and Wisin & Yandel — another Puerto Rican reggaetón duo — were each nominated three times. Besides “Los de Atrás Vienen Conmigo,” the contenders for album of the year are Andrés Cepeda’s “Día Tras Día,” Luis Enrique’s “Ciclos,” Mercedes Sosa’s “Cantora 1” and “Regência: Vince Mendoza,” by Mr. Lins and the Metropole Orchestra. The ceremony will be held in Las Vegas on Nov. 5 and broadcast live by Univision.

The crowd at the Emmy Awards is filled with many of the same faces every year — the result of popular television series getting renewed over and over. But there are always a few people on the red carpet who make you say… who? Leading up to Sunday’s Emmy telecast, we’ve been talking to first-timers and other nominated actors who might not be as familiar to viewers as the Alec Baldwins, Sally Fields and William Shatners of the world.

TORONTO — With “Bad Lieutenant Port of Call: New Orleans,” the director Werner Herzog set out with his star Nicolas Cage to achieve what he called “the bliss of evil.” The film explores the life of a New Orleans police officer (Mr. Cage) who spends his nights snorting coke, bedding a prostitute, racking up gambling debts and striking deals with drug dealers.

For whatever reason, this spring is apparently the season for cross-dressers on Broadway. A few weeks before the transfer of the Menier Chocolate Factory’s revival of “La Cage aux Folles” opens at the Longacre Theater, Broadway will see a return visit from Dame Edna Everage, the garrulous, garishly attired alter ego of the comedian Barry Humphries. In a news release, publicists for the new Dame Edna show, which is to be called “Dame Edna: It’s All About Me,” said on Thursday that it would be directed by Jerry Zaks (“Six Degrees of Separation,” “Lend Me a Tenor”) and that its limited run would begin in March at a Shubert Theater to be determined. This is Dame Edna’s third trip to Broadway, following “Dame Edna: The Royal Tour” in 1999, which won a Tony Award for special theatrical event, and “Dame Edna: Back with a Vengeance” in 2004.

The eminent American composer Leon Kirchner, who was also a pianist, a conductor, and an influential professor at Harvard University, died at his Central Park West apartment in Manhattan on Thursday morning. He had been receiving home hospice care for several weeks, and died of congestive heart failure, said Lisa Kirchner, her daughter. Mr. Kirchner was 90.

Thank you for being…an amiga? Disney is resurrecting one of its classic comedy franchises, “The Golden Girls,” with a Latin twist. The company said Thursday that it had started production on what it called a “Latin American reversioning” of “The Golden Girls” in Caracas, Venezuela, with an eye toward Spanish-language markets. Disney said it would also seek to distribute the show in the United States, although it did not specify a network for it. The program, titled “Los Años Dorados,” will maintain the spirit of the original, which was a staple of NBC in the 1980s. The new characters may not be named Blanche, Dorothy, Rose, and Sophia, but the house-sharing plot line and the Miami setting will remain the same. Disney has also produced Spanish-language editions of “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Desperate Housewives.”

TORONTO — “A Serious Man,” the latest film from the Coen brothers, is the most personal from the duo. While its story is fictional, much of the world of the film is based on their experience growing up in the Midwest.

Feinberg, the Obama administration's executive pay czar, is planning to disclose the salaries for the 25 most highly paid employees at a variety of companies within 30 days, according to TheStreet.com, citing comments attributed to him in an analyst's research report. Attorney General Jerry Brown of California said today that he had begun an investigation into whether the three major credit rating agencies -- Standard & Poor's, Moody's Investors Service and Fitch Ratings -- acted improperly during the credit boom by assigning super-safe, triple-A ratings to structured products that later turned out to be extremely risky, and in some cases, worthless.

Jared C. Monti, a team leader with the 3rd Squadron, 71st Cavalry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division, died during a Taliban ambush in the mountains of Nuristan Province on June 21st, 2006.

In this week's Political Points Podcast: A key senator's long-awaited attempt at a bipartisan health care bill has indeed united left and right--- in opposition. President Obama now has his work cut out for him as he attempts to persuade all 59 Democrats and at least one Republican in the Senate to give him the 60 votes needed to get a bill into conference. His simultaneous call for an overhaul of financial regulations, meanwhile, is losing urgency as the economic crisis fades and a slow recovery begins. But it is not dead yet. Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who is chairman of the banking committee, is betting his political future that he can push through a tough bill by the first few months of next year, before the midterm elections make it impossible. Fighting an uphill battle for re-election amid voter concerns that he has been too close to Wall Street, Dodd is counting on passing a regulatory overhaul that proves his critics wrong.White House correspondent Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Washington correspondent Stephen Labaton and chief financial correspondent Floyd Norris join co-hosts Sam Roberts and David D. Kirkpatrick

One of the highlights of the 25th anniversary of London Fashion Week, which officially kicks off tomorrow, is the Burberry show on Tuesday night. The event will mark the first time in 10 years that Burberry has shown in London and not in Milan. If there's one thing that the label's designer, Christopher Bailey, loves as much as a trench coat, it's his iPhone. Over the next five days, Bailey will be sending us photos that he took with it. Today's image is of the show space being constructed in front of the Chelsea College of Art and Design in Westminster. "It is such an iconic, great part of London with the Thames, the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben," Bailey says, "and it's also where we shot our last ad campaign."

During New York fashion week, most of the attention invariably goes to the women's shows. But during the past few seasons, more and more men's-wear designers have been slowly but surely sliding into the schedule. The guys have established their own mini-fashion week, and their presentations are, in fact, often more exciting than those of their women's counterparts. As the White House and Congress continue debating how best to provide coverage to tens of millions of Americans currently without health insurance, a new study (PDF) is meant to offer a stark reminder of why lawmakers should continue to try. Researchers from Harvard Medical School say the lack of coverage can be tied to about 45,000 deaths a year in the United States - a toll that is greater than the number of people who die each year from kidney disease.

If Ralph Lauren was down on his luck today, Isaac Mizrahi was pure jubilation. Taking a cue from a Broadway production, with a jazzy composition by Ethan Iverson, Mr. Mizrahi sent out a collection full of wit, soul and just a tiny bit of melancholy. Maybe it's that sublime quality of feeling that Mr. Mizrahi manages to inject in his fashion shows that makes you, for a few moments, feel human.

BARCELONA | Not since they had neighboring studios in the notorious "Bateau Lavoir" building in Paris's Montmartre neighborhood in the early 1900s have Picasso and Kees van Dongen likely seen so much of each other. An exhibit centered on the Dutch-born artist, featuring 78 works by him (with an additional four by Picasso) is on view through Sept. 27 at Barcelona's Museu Picasso (Montcada 15-23, 34 93 256 3000; www.museupicasso.bcn.cat). The show offers a rare chance to not only see these two important 20th-century artists side by side and also to see Van Dongen's work in rare depth.

The most talked-about game this week is Tennessee at Florida, mainly because of the brashness of Volunteers Coach Lane Kiffin. But the outcome of that game is not seriously in doubt. If the Gators don't emerge from the Swamp victorious it will be a major upset. (The same goes for Texas Tech at Texas, with the Longhorns expected to exact revenge for last season's last-second loss.) So, in an effort to up the degree of difficulty for our team of prognosticators, the Tennessee-Florida game is not one of the five that will be picked this week. Though, to be honest, even when there is total agreement we often turn out to be wrong. Look no further than last week's Notre Dame-Michigan game.

New Canaan, Conn., just 45 miles from New York City, is one of the most affluent towns in the United States. It has a charming New England village atmosphere, some 90 midcentury modern houses, and excellent public schools.

While not referring directly to the Great Depression, Ralph Lauren cited hard times as the inspiration for this morning's spring 2010 showing of faded jeans, bib overalls and humble floral dresses. Mr. Lauren has often made reference to work wear (think of his cowboy-inspired clothes), but fashion that revives images of the Dust Bowl and the dirty 30s raises questions about judgment. I wondered, looking at the collection-which was weak by Mr. Lauren's usual standards-what the discussions in his studio were about such a theme. Can hard times and their associated misery ever be an acceptable theme for a fashion show? And if the clothes don't really attempt to explore legitimate modes of American dress, and instead remain on the surface-a little faded and ripped denim with rhinestone sandals-isn't that somehow worse?
CruiseNow.com, a cruise news and deals site, is offering a seven-night Bermuda cruise, sailing from New York, for $449 a person on the Norwegian Dawn.

More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a recent government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science? Today, New York Times "Really?" columnist Anahad O'Connor begins a weekly series exploring the claims and the science behind alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

It's easy to forget the notion of the concrete jungle when you're looking at New York City through the cuts, carats, colors and clarity of monumental pieces of bling. Imagine the Guggenheim Museum covered in pavé diamonds? Or Central Park dripping in emeralds? Or even the Brooklyn Bridge in 24-karat gold? A slew of jewelry companies have done exactly that, creating landmark pieces inspired by everything from taxi cabs to the Statue of Liberty. A diamond as big as the Ritz? Ha! When last we left the founders of Skype, Janus Friis and Niklas Zennstrom, they were trying to buy back their baby from eBay, to which they had sold it in 2005. And they were not having much success. (Whether this was because the bid they made with some private equity partners was too low, or because eBay wouldn't give them the time of day is a matter of considerable dispute.) They were also busy suing eBay, claiming that it was using peer-to-peer technology that remained their intellectual property -- and which they no longer wished to license to eBay. Such a move, if upheld by the courts, would effectively shut down Skype.

Wall Street on April 4 was a scene of absurdity: a thousand people engaged in a giant pillow fight under the shadow of the New York Stock Exchange and a stone's throw away from the iconic bull statue. White feathers and fluff were flying. Police officers, reporters, tourists and pillow attackers became a pulsing throng, punctuated with moving white clumps. Thump, thump, thump. It was just one of dozens of events during World Pillow Fight Day.
