Today's idea: Welcome to the "post-journalistic" age, in which ideologues now provide the "reporting" that feeds the 24-hour news cycle. "The collapse of journalism means that the quest for information has been superseded by the quest for ammunition."
Google has acquired a Carnegie Mellon University spin-off that seeks to cut down on spam and fraud at Web sites while digitizing books.

Magna International's planned acquisition of Opel is proof that carmakers have lost the upper hand in the industry by outsourcing development work to suppliers and relying on them for technological know-how, a top General Motors executive said, according to Reuters.
Twitter is closing a round of funding that will value the company known for its 140-character, stream-of-consciousness blogs at $1 billion, TechCrunch reported.
The government will have another month to seek an indictment against or reach a settlement with a former Goldman Sachs Group programmer accused of stealing trade secrets, Reuters reported.
Citigroup plans to pay back $20 billion it owes the government when the bank sees more concrete signs of recovery, the bank's chief executive, Vikram Pandit, said on Wednesday.
Chrysler Group will present a five-year business plan by the end of November that outlines numbers and the path out of two years of difficulties, its chief executive said on Wednesday.

AMSTERDAM | Navigating through Amsterdam's pantheon of world-class museums, it's easy to overlook some of the city's smaller venues-- for instance, the Verzetsmuseum, the Dutch Resistance Museum, where the mission is mostly educational. One current exhibit, though -- centering around the work of the cartoonist Fritz Behrendt -- is well worth a visit for aesthetic reasons as well.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan - From his study here, 85-year-old Arbab Hidayatullah, former police chief, former intelligence officer, and now writer, dispatches some of the most scathing, pithy assessments of what is going on in Pakistan.

Carlyle Group, the world's second-largest private-equity firm, said any potential initial public offering of its shares is "a long way off," responding to a report that it may seek an I.P.O. in as soon as six months.
Initial public offerings in Hong Kong by Metallurgical Corporation of China and Sinopharm Group raised a combined $3.5 billion, people with knowledge of the sales told Bloomberg News.

Dubai World, a Dubai government holding company, filed a lawsuit in the United States this week against the former head of a subsidiary it accuses of fraud costing the United Arab Emirates firm millions of dollars.

Generations ago, industrialists and financiers extracted fortunes from the copper and gold mines dug into the canyons near Salt Lake City. Now, their modern-day counterparts are resisting a government proposal that could shut down what has become another gold mine of sorts, The New York Times's Eric Lipton writes.

Stock markets stampeded higher on Wednesday, and major Wall Street benchmarks touched their highest levels of the year on optimism that an economic rebound was under way, The New York Times's Jack Healy reported.
The founders of Skype are escalating their legal battle with eBay.

Offering the lure of cheap government-guaranteed financing, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation moved on Wednesday to push its efforts to have private investors buy distressed mortgages from troubled banks.

From one perspective, the life sciences industry - the biotechnology companies that develop drugs and treatments to combat disease and the biomedical firms that create medical devices - is a picture of expanding horizons and confidence, The New York Times's James Flanigan writes.
After taking a walloping in the wake of bankruptcies, senior creditors finally get a small win, Breakingviews.com says.
Is Vivendi mulling an initial public offering for its 20 percent stake in NBC Universal?
Melena Ryzik peeks behind the curtain at the Marc Jacobs Spring 2010 fashion show.
An article last Thursday about Amy Sohn, who wrote a novel about Park Slope, Brooklyn, misstated the year that she and her husband bought a co-op there. It was 2004, not 2005.

A Currents article last Thursday about an ink stamp designed to protect against identity theft, using information from the company’s Web site, misstated the price of the stamp. Each Kes’pon ID Guard Stamp costs $19.99; that is not the price for three stamps.
The N.B.A.’s 57 referees met for seven hours Wednesday and unanimously rejected the N.B.A.’s latest offer, but are determined to reach terms on a new contract.
Alex Gonzalez hit a bases-loaded blooper down the left-field line with two outs in the ninth to give the Red Sox a 9-8 victory over the Angels.

David Clarkson scored two power-play goals as the Devils bounced back from blowing a two-goal lead in the third period to beat the Rangers, 3-2, in a preseason shootout in Newark. Travis Zajac scored in the sixth round of the shootout to lift the Devils in their preseason opener under Coach Jacques Lemaire.

The United States and Canada have a tentative deal to settle a dispute over charter flights that threatened to disrupt the N.H.L. and N.B.A. seasons, Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada said. The United States has insisted that Air Canada cancel all of its season-long sports charters, saying they violate United States law because they operate within the United States rather than between two countries. The N.H.L. regular season begins Oct. 1, the N.B.A. season Oct. 27.

Television ratings for the United States Open final Monday between Juan Martín del Potro and Roger Federer were up from last year. Del Potro’s five-set upset of Federer, the five-time defending champion, drew a 2.3 rating and 5 share on CBS — up from the 1.7 rating and 4 share for the 2008 final with Andy Murray, which was also on a Monday because of rain delays.

Misty May-Treanor will return next weekend to the beach volleyball tour in Glendale, Ariz., and be reunited with Kerri Walsh, her partner for two Olympic gold medals. It will be their first competition together in 2009. Walsh sat out most of the season after having a baby in the spring, but returned last month.

N.B.A. referees unanimously rejected the latest contract offer from the league on Wednesday, during a seven-hour meeting at a Chicago hotel. But they have not given up on making a deal to avert a lockout. After voting by 57 to 0 to reject the N.B.A.’s latest offer, the referees agreed to stay indefinitely at the hotel until a new contract was done. Lamell McMorris, the chief negotiator for the referees union, called it “a lock-in.”.
Leading by 5-4 in the bottom of the ninth with closer Francisco Rodriguez on the mound, the Mets botched a win they had worked hard for.

Charges of harassment and possession of human growth hormone have been dropped against Kurt Angle, an Olympic gold medalist who became a professional wrestler. Angle, 40, was arrested last month in the Pittsburgh suburb of McKees Rocks after a call to the police from his ex-girlfriend, who had a protection order against him. The authorities said they found vials of human growth hormone in Angle’s car, but he said he had a prescription.

Major League Soccer will for the first time suspend all of its games during the opening group stage of the World Cup next year, the league said. The group phase, which is set to begin June 11, features 48 of the 64 games in the World Cup. M.L.S. said its final game before the World Cup would be played June 10, with the break continuing through at least June 25, when the final game of the group stage is scheduled. ¶Two days after his two-game ban was overturned, Eduardo da Silva scored the winner as Arsenal rallied to win Wednesday at Standard Liège, 3-2, in the Champions League. Arsenal trailed by two after only five minutes. champions (AP).
Spain and Serbia clinched the final two spots in the quarterfinals at the European championship.

The Yankees won again Wednesday with a game-ending hit, Francisco Cervelli playing the hero this time. I'm not sure if the Elias Sports Bureau tracks this, but I'm pretty sure it's the first time since the 1992 playoffs that a third-string catcher named Francisco has had a walk-off hit. (Sorry, Pirates fans.)
Leodis McKelvin’s fumble led to New England’s winning touchdown; then he found the game’s score next to an obscenity spray-painted on his lawn.

Update | Monday, Sept. 21, 3:00 p.m. Mr. Kennerly's post inspired one of the longest comment threads we've seen on Lens. He wrote to us on Monday to address both the criticism and the support that he received:

I.B.M. is providing more evidence on Thursday that its "smarter cities" program is more than a marketing campaign. The company is starting a project with Dubuque, Iowa, that over the next several years will use sensors, software and Internet computing to give the city's government and citizens the digital tools to measure, monitor and alter the way they use water, electricity and transportation.
A recruiting commercial for the Marines from 2008.
Private insurance companies were pleased with the lack of a public option in a new health care proposal.
FRONT PAGE.

An editorial on Wednesday about the slow progress of climate change legislation incorrectly identified the location of an upcoming international summit on global warming. It will be held in Copenhagen, not Stockholm.

An Our Towns column last Thursday described Michael Bellone, a former nightclub bouncer who worked as a volunteer with firefighters and the police at ground zero in Lower Manhattan for months after Sept. 11, 2001. He helped recover the remains of victims and, as part of an effort to keep alive the memory, now has a fire truck that bears the names of all 343 members of the Fire Department who died that day.
A review on Tuesday about “Is Life Worth Living,” at the Mint Theater in Clinton, misstated the telephone number for information. It is (212) 315-0231.
An article on Wednesday about Tim James, a former first-round N.B.A. draft pick who is now serving in the Army, misidentified a common military rifle. It is an M-16, not M-15.
Lebanon’s president designated Saad Hariri prime minister on Wednesday, asking him to try again to form a new government.
José Manuel Barroso won a parliamentary vote endorsing his second term as European Commission president on Wednesday.
Francisco Cervelli produced the Yankees’ 14th game-ending hit this season, the most in club history since 1943, when they had their record 17.

An article on Wednesday about Juan Martín del Potro, the 20-year-old United States Open champion from Argentina, referred incorrectly to his hometown, Tandil. It is a city of about 110,000 residents; it is neither a “tiny town” nor a “tiny village” as it was characterized in different editions.
The Hungarian government said Wednesday that it would take one detainee from Guantánamo Bay in Cuba.
Gunmen burst into a drug treatment center in the northern border city of Ciudad Juárez and shot to death 10 people, the second such attack this month.
An article on Wednesday about the election of the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Richard L. Trumka, misspelled the surname of the group’s new secretary-treasurer. She is Liz Shuler, not Schuler.

An article on Tuesday about the mounting debt load of Istithmar, one of Dubai’s most prominent investment funds, omitted credit for a news organization that earlier reported on the fund’s difficulties. Bloomberg News reported on Sept. 10 that the fund was halting investments as part of a restructuring effort, and followed that on Monday with a more detailed report on the fund’s problems.

An article in some editions on Monday about the coming trial of State Senator Hiram Monserrate of Queens, who is accused of slashing his companion, quoted incorrectly from comments that Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, made at a forum on domestic violence in 2005. He said, “We have become leaders in successfully prosecuting domestic violence cases without the cooperation of the victim, who is so often reluctant — or fearful — to testify against her batterer.” He did not say “against her accuser.”.
Reviews of the Rodarte, Oscar de la Renta, Tory Burch, Michael Kors and Narciso Rodriguez shows.
The investigation into a man who traveled to New York last week deepened, and agents in New York and Washington examined items seized at homes in Queens.

A picture in some editions on Wednesday with an article about the defeat of at least four incumbents in City Council primaries was published in error. It was of Helen M. Marshall, the Queens borough president — not of Councilwoman Helen Sears, one of the defeated incumbents.
The New York Aquarium is moving ahead with a $100 million expansion project, quadrupling its number of sharks.

An article on Saturday about the future of Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico misstated the ancestry of one of the two American journalists recently released from prison in North Korea. (Mr. Richardson played a minor advisory role in their release.) Laura Ling is Chinese-American — not Korean-American, which is the ancestry of Euna Lee, who was also released.

The Beijing Journal article on Monday, about the raucous street merchants of Beijing, misspelled the name of a Qing Dynasty emperor said to have favored the kind of singing caged grasshoppers hawked by one merchant during the summer. It is Qianlong, not Qianglong.
The prosecution began its closing arguments in the trial of Brooke Astor’s son, Anthony D. Marshall, and the estate lawyer Francis X. Morrissey Jr.
An article on Tuesday about the annual meeting of the Central Committee of China’s governing Communist Party misstated the committee’s size. It has 204 members, not “2,000 or more.”.
One of the most compelling personalities in the world of style has been mostly a no-show during New York Fashion Week.

An article on Tuesday about the sale of a house next door to President Obama’s home in Chicago misstated the name of a dog that lives there and misidentified her owners. She is Rosie, not Roxy, and she belongs to the tenants of the property’s carriage house — not to the owners of the property for sale, Bill and Jacky Grimshaw.
Four incumbents, and possibly six, were thrown out, and eight more seats were left open, seven by members seeking citywide office.
Asian-American candidates fared well in Tuesday’s Democratic primaries, winning in three City Council districts and leading in the vote for comptroller, a citywide office.
The Democratic primaries Tuesday gave a relatively new group a chance to show strength as it backed three of the four candidates who unseated incumbents on the City Council.
The rookie quarterback Mark Sanchez faces his first big test in the A.F.C. East when the Jets play the Patriots at Giants Stadium on Sunday.
The Obama administration, under pressure to show it is succeeding, has delivered to Congress a list of ways to measure American progress in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

Owners trying to sell their homes in a tough market are turning to Catholic tradition and burying statues of St. Joseph for help.
The health care proposal has Democrats pondering how to keep all 59 Democrats and attract at least one Republican.
Julia Child may have been America’s best-known “French chef,” but in Paris few know her fabled cookbooks, let alone her name.
Congregation Derech Emunoh, in the Rockaways, has been housed in a trailer for seven years, after a fire. Now even that home is about to be lost.
The president made a pitch for Chicago’s bid and said Michelle Obama, a lifelong Chicagoan, will lead the U.S. contingent when the I.O.C. votes on a host city Oct. 2.
Representative Chellie Pingree said the Coast Guard has rescinded a rule that prohibited lobstermen from fishing in the waters around a Maine island.
The beating of a black female Army reservist outside a restaurant is being investigated as a possible hate crime, federal authorities said.
Representative Michael E. Capuano said he would run for the late Edward M. Kennedy’s Senate seat.
The Senate voted to permit Amtrak passengers to transport handguns in their checked baggage.

Facing criticism for her handling of federal stimulus money, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said she would not start any new border construction projects while the department reviewed how projects were selected.
A judge set a Nov. 10 execution date for John A. Muhammad, the leader of the 2002 sniper attacks in the Washington area that left 10 dead.

The House ethics committee said it would put off for now an expanded investigation into whether Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. of Illinois or his representatives tried to buy President Obama’s former Senate seat.

In its first day on sale “The Lost Symbol,” by Dan Brown, below, sold more than one million copies in hardcover and e-book versions in the United States, Britain and Canada, according to the publisher, Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group. The company said that it had fired up the presses again and printed 600,000 more hardcover copies to add to the five million already in print. On Tuesday Barnes & Noble and Amazon said that “The Lost Symbol,” Mr. Brown’s first novel since his worldwide phenomenon, “The Da Vinci Code,” set records for the best-selling adult fiction title on the first day of sale. Barnes & Noble, Amazon and Sony all said that e-book versions of “The Lost Symbol” went straight to No. 1 on their electronic best-seller lists, although all declined to say how many units were sold. A spokeswoman for Knopf Doubleday said the company did not break out e-book downloads specifically.

“Someday,” Bob Dylan sang, “everything’s gonna be different when I paint my masterpiece.” Is this different enough to qualify? Nearly 100 paintings by Mr. Dylan, an artist better known for his throat than for his palette, will go on display next year at the Statens Museum for Kunst in Copenhagen, Reuters reported. Among the works will be “Train Tracks,” right. The exhibition, to open in fall 2010, will include the premiere of 30 acrylic paintings from Mr. Dylan’s “Brazil” series,” as well as paintings from his “Drawn Blank” series that were shown in Britain and Germany. A representative for Mr. Dylan told Reuters that he did not know what the new paintings would depict or how Mr. Dylan chose the names of his series. In a statement the museum’s chief curator, Kasper Monrad, said, “Bob Dylan’s visual artistic practice has only been discussed by art historians to a limited extent, so critical examination and interpretation are called for.”.
University business schools sought corporate types who knew the basics but something extra.

A dispute between the British band Coldplay and Joe Satriani, the rock-guitar virtuoso, has ended remarkably quietly. A representative for Mr. Satriani told Billboard that a copyright-infringement lawsuit filed by Mr. Satriani against Coldplay had been dropped, despite an earlier claim by the guitarist that Coldplay had copied one of his songs. In December Mr. Satriani filed the suit, saying that the Coldplay song “Viva la Vida” used “substantial original portions” of his composition “If I Could Fly,” an instrumental track. Coldplay responded that any similarities between the songs were “entirely coincidental, and just as surprising to us as to him.” In a legal filing in April, lawyers for Coldplay said “If I Could Fly” should not receive copyright protection because it “lacks originality.” The details of the case remain sealed, but Billboard said that the settlement would not require Coldplay to admit any wrongdoing.

The August Wilson Center for African American Culture, a $39.5 million multidisciplinary complex in downtown Pittsburgh, is scheduled to open officially on Thursday with a celebration and tribute. It is among a handful of black cultural institutions in the country with such vast space and scope. The 65,000-square-foot building is home to seven galleries, a 486-seat theater, an education center, and multiple-use spaces for community events. The two-story nonprofit center was designed by Allison Williams, a principal of Perkins & Will in San Francisco. Years in the planning, the center was named in honor of Wilson, the playwright, above, who died in 2005. He was a Pittsburgh native who won two Pulitzer Prizes and a Tony Award. The center’s inaugural season, which began last week, includes performances by the jazz violinist Regina Carter, the Philadelphia Dance Company and several plays by Mr. Wilson.

As expected, the audience for Jay Leno’s second night in prime time fell off sharply from his opening night, but Mr. Leno, the former host of “Tonight,” scored a big win with an average of 11.1 million viewers. The numbers for “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC were also good among the viewers the network most cares about: younger adults. But a few hints of concern may be forming for NBC. Mr. Leno saw his audience fall about 15 percent from his first half-hour to his second on Tuesday night. That would be good for any late-night hour, but it is usually not a good sign for 10 p.m. network shows that need to feed as big an audience as possible into the news on local stations. Among those younger viewers, those between the ages of 18 and 49, Mr. Leno declined about 35 percent from night to night — again about what was to be expected.
John Chachas, managing director of Lazard, is considering a bid in 2010 for the Senate seat held by Harry Reid of Nevada.

Bolstered by “The Jay Leno Show,” NBC won the night by a slight margin, garnering an average of 9.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 for the premiere of “The Biggest Loser,” according to Nielsen’s estimates, the series’s highest-rated fall debut in five years. CBS was runner-up, with a lineup that included a rerun of “NCIS” (12 million) and the two-hour season finale of “Big Brother” (7.9 million). ABC ranked third with the finale of “Shaq Vs.” (4.3 million) and a repeat of a Barbara Walters interview special with Patrick Swayze (6.1 million). Fox finished in fourth with the finale of “More to Love” (4.3 million).

The revival of “Hair” has brought the hippies back to Broadway. Is the Great White Way now ready for the hipsters? Regina Spektor, below, the singer-songwriter and mainstay of the East Village music scene, will lend her talents to a planned Broadway musical called “Beauty,” based on the Sleeping Beauty tale. Ms. Spektor will collaborate with the lyricist Michael Korie (Broadway’s “Grey Gardens”) and the director Tina Landau (“Superior Donuts”), according to a release from press representatives for the musical. Ms. Landau, who is writing the book of the musical, is adapting the project from a one-act play, also called “Beauty,” produced by the La Jolla Playhouse in 2003. “Beauty,” to be produced by Elephant Eye Theatrical (“The Addams Family”), will feature music by Ms. Spektor, lyrics by Mr. Korie and a book by Ms. Landau. The project is planned for the 2011-12 Broadway season after an out-of-town tryout. Casting has not been announced.
Oliver Stone follows up his 1987 tale of Wall Street greed with a character finishing a sentence for insider trading and facing the financial inferno of 2008.

AT New York Fashion Week, the wizards of the hair and makeup worlds turned their backs on the sumptuously lacquered looks of fall, approaching the new season with a lighter hand. To reinforce looks that ranged from robustly bohemian to languid and ethereal, most were sparing with paint box and spray, and even opted at times to let nature take its course. At the Diane Von Furstenberg show (top left), Orlando Pita insisted on virgin hair styled without benefit of foams or gels. Others mimicked nature by whipping up looks that were all wispy tendrils, loose plaits, chignons and, at Altuzarra, straight flowing hair, setting off pale faces enlivened here and there with transparent strokes of pink on cheeks and lips (middle left). The faintly sun-blushed effect brought to mind a Botticelli Venus, or, in contrast, a subtly subversive girl next door.

Mobile Air Mouse is an application that turns an iPhone into a remote trackpad or mouse. This may require some explaining. The Air Mouse, which costs $2.99, lets users control an on-screen cursor using the iPhone's accelerometers to sense movement.

MA--Si-Hon, dies at 84. The violinist and teacher, Ma Si-hon, died Saturday, September 12, in a nursing home in suburban Philadelphia. He had been in failing health for some time. Mr. Ma was the president of the Si-Yo Music Society which presented an annual series of chamber music concerts in New York from 1971-2004. The first concerts, with the participation of his wife, the pianist Tung Kwong-Kwong, who survives him, were performed in the Chinese School in Chinatown. Because of their popularity they soon transferred to the Schimmel Auditorium of nearby Pace University. Eventually the concerts were moved to Merkin Hall near Lincoln Center. Some of the musicians who collaborated with Mr. and Mrs. Ma in the Si-Yo Concerts were clarinetist, Stanley Drucker, Soprano, Benita Valente, Cellist, Jerry Grossman, violist, Raphael Hillyer, and many more. Mr. Ma owned and performed on the Joachim Stradivarius violin, which is thought to be the instrument Joseph Joachim played when he give the first performance of the Brahms Violin Concerto. Ma Si-Hon was born near Canton, China, on April 3, 1925 and came to this country from China in 1948. He enrolled at the New England Conservatory, where he studied with Richard Burgin, receiving a Masters degree in 1950 and the Artists Diploma in 1952. In 1951, he became the first violinist to receive the Heifetz Award at Tanglewood. In the 50s he played in the Cleveland Orchestra under George Szell, later leaving to join Tung Kwong-Kwong for several years of touring and performing in Europe, appearing at the Salzburg and Dartington Festivals, among many others. They continued to tour in the 1960s and 1970s in America under Columbia Artists Management. The Mas made several tours of the Far East, performing and teaching both in Taiwan and Mainland China as well as Hong Kong and Bangkok. In 1958, he invented a new mute for stringed instruments which is placed behind the bridge and does not have to be removed when not in use, a great improvement over the older standard mute. It was given the name "The Si-Hon Mute". From 1971 to 1994, Ma Si-Hon was a professor of music at Kent State University in Ohio. During that period he maintained his performing career and also continued to teach in New York City. In addition to his wife, Ma Si-Hon is survived by two sisters, nieces and nephews. The Funeral Service for Mr. Ma will be held on Saturday, September 19th 12:00 noon, at George Washington Memorial Park, 80 Stenton Ave., Plymouth Meeting, PA 19462.

A little more than a year ago, Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, setting off the largest Chapter 11 case in American history and affecting thousands. As of Sept. 11, 9,763 claims had been filed in federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan. At right is a sampling of the kinds of claims filed against Lehman's bankruptcy estate in the United States. Claims are due Sept. 22.

McDONALD--James Scott, of New York City, on September 13, 2009. Beloved husband of Karen Hunter McDonald, devoted father of Scott, Hunter and Isabel. Born January 26, 1953 to Lloyd and Alice McDonald in Auckland, New Zealand, Jim showed exceptional promise from an early age. A gifted student and tennis player, he graduated from Harvard College, in 1975, and the University of Virginia School of Law in 1977. He began his career as a highly successful attorney at Choate, Hall & Stewart in Boston, where he became a partner in 1984. In 1986 he joined Pell Rudman & Co., a wealth management firm in Boston, where he served as President and CEO. In January 2001, Jim came to New York to become President and CEO of Rockefeller and Company. He expanded the company from a multi-family office to an internationally-recognized investment firm that serves a broad number of families and institutions. Jim was a member of numerous committees and organizations, including serving as a board member of NYSE Euronext (formerly the New York Stock Exchange). In addition, he was chairman of the board of the Japan Society of New York and a member of the Council of Foreign Relations. He also served as a trustee of the Nightingale-Bamford School in New York and as chair of the board of trustees of Fessenden School in West Newton, Massachusetts. A memorial service will be held on Monday, September 21, 4:00pm at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave. and 90th Street, New York City. Burial will be in Prout's Neck, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Harvard College, Friends of Harvard Squash at Harvard College or the University School of Virginia School of Law. Jim was a man of great wisdom, warmth and caring. He blessed us all with his generosity and compassion. We shall miss him always.

Unless government programs for the unemployed are refined, high jobless rates could persist beyond 2010, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned on Wednesday. ''A recovery may be in sight,'' the group said in its annual employment outlook, referring to economic output. ''But the short-term employment outlook is grim.''

Chemicals found in small amounts in common household cleaning products that have been linked to asthma, birth defects and fertility problems in higher doses are listed in a report, ''Household Hazards: Potential Hazards of Home Cleaning Products,'' issued in 2007 by Women's Voices for the Earth, a nonprofit group. Monoethanolamine: Found in some laundry detergents, all-purpose cleaners and floor cleaners.

At the same moment on Wednesday that Senator Max Baucus was introducing his long-awaited blueprint for a health care overhaul, executives from nationally prominent medical groups were meeting nearby to discuss how to make more clinics and hospitals look like them. Among the attendees were executives from the Cleveland Clinic, Geisinger Health System, Bassett Healthcare and eight other health care systems in which doctors are paid a salary and patients are generally given care coordinated among a variety of specialists. Such systems have been cited by President Obama, Congressional leaders and policy experts as medical exemplars, providing high-quality care at reasonable cost.

Kodak has introduced two all-in-one inkjet printers that it says can yield lab-quality photos and sip, rather than gulp, ink. In fact, Kodak says the new models can save an average of $110 a year on ink when compared with similar inkjets, although there is no way to verify this claim (more on that later). The ESP 3250 ($130) has a 1.5-inch color LCD for image previews and navigation, as well as the usual memory card slots for computerless printing. The ESP 5250 ($170) adds built-in Wi-Fi connectivity and a larger 2.4-inch color LCD.

European leaders are set to endorse a call for more government control over bankers' pay ahead of the Group of 20 summit meeting next week in Pittsburgh. In a statement expected to be adopted at a European Union meeting in Brussels on Thursday evening, the leaders called on G-20 members to stand by commitments made this month in London ''to encourage sound risk management and a strong link between compensation and long-term performance, while ensuring a level playing field.''

Change is built into the DNA of Wall Street, and the movement of bankers from one firm to another is commonplace. But the once-in-a-generation turmoil that roiled the financial world last year -- from the sale of Bear Stearns to the collapse of Lehman Brothers to the near-failure of the American International Group -- helped set off a great scrambling of Wall Street's talent. Some bankers jumped from one bulge-bracket firm to another. A substantial number, including top dealmakers, moved to boutique firms, with some hanging their own shingle. Others departed for nonbank companies like hedge funds and private equity firms. More than a few left the world of finance altogether. DealBook examined data compiled by Thomson Reuters of banker movements from July 2008 to May 2009. (The figures do not account for bankers who subsequently left their new employers.) What emerged was a sampling of the rearrangement of personnel that continues even now in reshaping the financial sector.

Ernie Harwell, the beloved Detroit Tigers broadcaster for 42 years, made a rare visit to Comerica Park for Wednesday night's game against the Kansas City Royals. Earlier this month, the 91-year-old Harwell revealed that he has an inoperable and incurable form of bile duct cancer. Harwell, who retired in 2002, spoke to the crowd during the third inning Wednesday, after a video tribute to him on the scoreboard. ''In my almost 92 years on this earth, the good Lord has blessed me with a great journey -- and the blessed part of that journey is that it will end in the great state of Michigan,'' he said. The Tigers went on to defeat the Royals, 4-3. NICK BUNKLEY

PELTZMAN--Beatrice, 83, of New York City passed away suddenly on 15th of September, 2009. Beatrice reached the shores of her beloved United States after narrowly escaping from the Nazis in occupied Brussels, Belgium. She survived both her parents and brother. Beatrice married her adored husband Nils in 1952. They remained married until his untimely death in 1973. Always the survivor, she thrust herself into the role of manager of her husband's pharmacy, while simultaneously raising her three boys by herself. While still in her 50s, Beatrice attended Dominican College of Blauvelt, NY and eventually received her Masters in Social Work from Fordham University. She became a much loved advocate for the aged. Until her movements were severely hampered by Parkinson's disease, she was an intrepid world traveler. She had a special affection for Paris. Beatrice also became an amateur painter in her later years. She was a devoted and loving mother to Alan, Richard and Roger Peltzman and their wives, Cynthia Peltzman, Marla Stern and Sharon Panulla. She is also survived by her loving grandchildren, Rachel, Allison, Reece and Drew Peltzman. Funeral services will be held at 11:30am on Friday, September 18, 2009 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., (at 91st St.), New York, NY.

Tacitly acknowledging that many consumers don't have an ethernet connection anywhere near their TV, Sony introduced a Blu-ray player last week that can connect to the ethernet wirelessly. But the feature comes with a price: about $80. That's what you'll pay at Amazon for the awkwardly named Linksys by Cisco Wireless-N Ethernet Bridge that Sony recommends you use to get the broadband signal into the Blu-ray player. (The Bridge, once plugged in, picks up a signal from your home's wireless router. Other brands of wireless bridges can also be used.)

José Manuel Barroso on Wednesday won a parliamentary vote endorsing his second term as European Commission president, confounding his critics by securing a larger-than-expected majority. The European Parliament voted 382 to 219 to approve Mr. Barroso, who was the only candidate for the post and already had the unanimous support of the heads of all 27 member states. There were 117 abstentions.

Major League Soccer will for the first time suspend all of its games during the opening group stage of the World Cup next year, the league said. The group phase, which is set to begin June 11, features 48 of the 64 games in the World Cup. M.L.S. said its final game before the World Cup would be played June 10, with the break continuing through at least June 25, when the final game of the group stage is scheduled.

This article is by David E. Sanger, Thom Shanker and Eric Schmitt. WASHINGTON -- The Obama administration delivered to Congress on Wednesday about 50 measures to determine whether a broad military and nation-building campaign to stabilize Afghanistan and Pakistan was succeeding, paving the way for the White House to argue that the American combat effort in the region would not be open-ended.

AT first glance, the molded black leather Yves Saint Laurent bodysuit is strict and scary, maybe even off-putting. The surprise is just how versatile it is. The garment, so erotically charged it would have fogged up Helmut Newton's lens, actually makes an elegant scaffolding on which to hang all sorts of looks -- and lends itself to subversive role-playing. You can be the lady who lunches in cardigans and tweeds; the astral voyager, who accentuates her streamlined shape with a sharp-shouldered jacket and leggings; the soignée tomboy, shrugging a boyfriend blazer and easy-going track pants over her leather armor; or the modern Cyndi Lauper, dressing up her corsets with crinolines and lace. If the YSL is too rich -- $2,300 at Yves Saint Laurent boutiques -- there are myriad variations in stores this fall. And like the best of today's fashion, a leather bodysuit or bustier can give a piquant new spin to things you already own. Then all you need do is stock up on some racy thoughts to back it up.

Barclays, the British banking giant, said Wednesday that it had sold $12.3 billion of illiquid assets to a fund set up by former executives of the bank to reduce its vulnerability to swings in the credit markets. The sale to Protium Finance, a fund run by two former employees, Stephen King and Michael Keeley, is being financed by a $12.6 billion loan from Barclays and $450 million mainly from two unidentified investors in Britain and the United States. Mr. King once led Barclays' principal mortgage trading group, and Mr. Keeley was a member of Barclays Capital's management committee.

In his review of Audra McDonald’s performance in the Shakespeare in the Park production this summer of “Twelfth Night” at the Delacorte Theater, Charles Isherwood writes, “Ms. McDonald limns the surging music of love’s unfolding with touching truth.” For those Bard lovers who didn’t get to hear Ms. McDonald, the soundtrack for the show from Hem will soon be available. On Oct. 27, the Brooklyn-based band will release the album on Waveland/Nettwerk Records which features vocals from Anne Hathaway, Ms. McDonald, Raúl Esparza, David Pittu and Jon Patrick Walker and includes a duet for Ms. Hathaway and Ms. McDonald, “Full Fathom Five,” using lyrics from “The Tempest.”

It might be hard to envision the gritty, weathered blocks of Manhattan and New York City’s outer boroughs as a canvas, but this weekend, more than 100 artists, urban explorers, interactive technologists and public space advocates will treat it that way. They are creating a city-wide art installation as part of the annual geek-art event known as the Conflux Festival.

At the top of the hardcover list this week is “Stitches: A Memoir” by David Small, who recounts his not-so-happy childhood. The graphic memoir includes an account of an operation the author underwent when he was 14 years old. He was told by his parents that it was to remove a cyst in his neck, but he later discovered it was because he had throat cancer. For nearly a decade after, the surgery left his voice barely above a whisper. In The New York Times, Eric Konigsberg wrote this profile of Mr. Small, who also writes and illustrates children’s books.
Last week, Fox Broadcasting announced that Ellen DeGeneres would be stepping into Paula Abdul’s shoes as the fourth judge on American Idol.

TORONTO — After directing the drama “4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days,” Cristian Mungiu decided he wanted to mix things up. So his latest project is a collaborative one in which he wrote the screenplay, called “Tales From the Golden Age.” The film looks at the same period as “4 Months,” Romania under Communist rule, but this film injects humor and includes several episodes that play off of urban legends of the period. Mr. Mungiu recruited other directors to help shoot episodes for the project. He discussed the film and his role in bringing it together.

Update | 3:06 p.m. “You ready?” asked Josh. “Always,” Reva said. And thus the soap opera “Guiding Light” ended its long run with a final episode Friday morning on CBS. The show’s ultimate couple, played by Kim Zimmer, who created the role of Reva in 1983, and Robert Newman, who first appeared on the show in 1981, closed the episode with a declaration of love at the local lighthouse before driving away in a pickup truck, the Associated Press reported.

TORONTO — The acclaimed Hong Kong filmmaker Johnnie To has infused a bit of French and English into his latest action film, “Vengeance,” which Manohla Dargis called “a brilliantly directed genre study” when she viewed it at Cannes.
Oprah Winfrey has anointed a new book club choice with “Say You’re One of Them,” a collection of short stories by Uwem Akpan.

Update | 1:19 p.m. Clearly Pavement fans are happy to have the band back. Pre-sale tickets for the Central Park show at Rumsey Playfield announced yesterday sold out in minutes, so the group has added second and third shows on Sept. 22 and 23. Find out more about tickets here.

The president of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation has responded to the addition of a gay judge and the progress of a same-sex dance couple on the popular television show, “So You Think You Can Dance.” Jarrett Barrios said that the addition “gives America a bold example of how to treat gay people with the same respect and fairness as everyone else,” Reuters reported. Earlier this week, Adam Shankman, an openly gay choreographer who directed the movie “Hairspray,” was added to the judging panel. A same-sex Latin ballroom couple has also moved on to a new round of competition in the show. The response followed an incident in May when the producer and judge Nigel Lythgoe told another male couple that their performance would alienate viewers of the show and wrote a message on Twitter that offended many gay people. His tweet prompted a call for action by GLAAD as well as an apology.

Mark Morris can breathe a sigh of relief for his dance company despite this difficult economic time for arts organizations. The company has been awarded a $720,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the largest single award from the foundation to the group. “This grant will allow us to address current as well as future economic challenges the Dance Group faces,” Nancy Umanoff, the executive director of the company, said in a statement. “We must assess the way we conduct our operations so that we can sustain our vibrant dance and music institution.” The award is broken into two categories, with $520,000 in support of new strategic initiatives for the company’s programs and $200,000 to strengthen cash reserves.

This decade’s great food writing glut, kicked off by Anthony Bourdain’s memoir “Kitchen Confidential” in 2000, hasn’t left many literary kernels unpopped. There’ve been books about nearly every aspect of killing, growing, cooking, drinking and eating. I know: I like food writing, and I’ve read or skimmed through nearly everything that’s come out.

The pioneering public radio host Ira Glass is calling an end to the television version of “This American Life.” Citing a taxing workload for his staff members, Mr. Glass said he hoped to work with the premium cable channel Showtime again, but would steer clear of a full-season TV order.

The comedy “Harmony and Me” looks at the life of a 30-year-old (Justin Rice) who has been dumped and can’t seem to get past it. Populated with a cast of both actors and nonactors, the film derives its humor from the awkward ways its characters try to express themselves. The Austin filmmaker Bob Byington spoke about his approach to the project, which first played in New York as part of New Directors/New Film and returns tonight for a one-week engagement at the Museum of Modern Art.
A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

Earlier this week, Room for Debate examined how the word "socialism" is used as shorthand and epithet in current politics and in other eras of American history. Many of President Obama's opponents, like those at the demonstration in Washington last weekend, insist that he's a socialist.

When I approached Yogi Berra on Tuesday at Yankee Stadium and asked him if he had heard the news about Lonny Frey, he said, "Oh, no." Berra's response meant that he knew what was coming next as I told him that Frey, his former Yankee teammate, had died in Coeur D'Alene, Idaho, on Sunday. He was 99 years old.

Dick Cook, the longtime chairman of Walt Disney Studios, has resigned, according to the studio. Mr. Cook, Disney's highest-ranking film executive, has been a fixture at the company for decades and helped shape a company strategy that has refocused on family fare after predecessors branched into more conventional Hollywood films.

"Work formerly done by reporters and producers is now routinely performed by political operatives and amateur ideologues of one stripe or another, whose goal is not to educate the public but to win. This is a trend not likely to change."

Stepping up an effort to unmask online attackers responsible for a wave of malicious advertisements aimed at Windows PC users, Microsoft on Thursday filed suit in Washington state Superior Court against the unknown individuals behind five companies that it alleges distributed "malvertising" that entangled its customers in fake-antivirus scams and infected them with other malicious software.

The fourth quarter of the year, which began with September, is the most important sales quarter for mobile phone companies.
The results from a closely watched Hollywood labor election are in, and the big winner is John Wells.

When name-brand 17-inch CRT displays cost $500 -- about 10 years ago -- ViewSonic's cheaper models offered a viable, quality alternative to units from Apple and others. When my expensive Apple display died in the 1990s, I became a satisfied customer of a new ViewSonic tube-based model.

On Friday, a federal court in Ohio issued a temporary restraining order blocking the state from attempting for a second time to execute Romell Broom, a convicted murderer whose execution by lethal injection earlier this week was halted after technicians were unable to find a usable vein for more than two hours. The state had planned to try to execute Mr. Broom again next week, but his attorneys filed suit on Friday, claiming that a second attempt would violate the constitutional ban on "cruel and unusual punishment."
Let's be honest, fanny packs are not the height of fashion. Whether you call it a belt pack, bum bag or hip sack, they stir up visions of tourists trapped in Times Square.

A signature look has emerged during the last days of New York Fashion Week: draped dresses worn with shoes that make a statement.

President Obama on Friday dismissed the notion that his race has played a central role in the sharp criticism of him and the policies of his administration, saying that he is merely the latest in a long line of presidents who have been accused of leading the nation toward Communism or socialism.

Representative Roy Blunt, the former Republican whip who is giving up his House seat in Missouri to run for the Senate, offered his take on life these days in the nation's capital to those gathered at the conservative Values Voter Summit on Friday.

In recent days, the partisan debate over policy "czars" appointed to positions in the Obama administration has reignited and spilled over onto the floor of the Senate and onto the White House blogs. Just at Friday's "Values Voter Summit" of conservatives, Republican officials like Mike Huckabee, the former presidential candidate and former Arkansas governor, labeled Washington the "land of czars," while Representative Mike Pence, Republican of Indiana, called for a "czar-free zone."

Executives at General Electric say they believe that Vivendi, the French conglomerate, will exercise its right later this year to sell its stake in NBC Universal, a move that could lead to NBC Universal's being spun off into a separate public company in 2010, according to people briefed on the matter who spoke anonymously in order to discuss internal deliberations.

When Bill Belichick addressed reporters in New England on Friday, he briefly stopped with the usual boring non-answers after being asked about Giants Stadium. Belichick used to coach with the Giants, and this game, on Sunday against the Jets, will be his last at the stadium (unless the Patriots meet the Jets there in the playoffs).

In this Sunday's Travel section, the writer Henry Alford travels to Seattle, the most recent stop for the fanatical followers of Wagner's Ring Cycle. These self-described "Ring Nuts" spend much of the year traveling from opera house to opera house - from London to Vienna to places as remote as Manaus, Brazil - to immerse themselves in more than 15 hours of music that, depending on one's point of view, is either the greatest work of art ever, or the apotheosis of overwrought Romanticism and a blatant celebration of anti-Semitism.

Diego Maradona's trip to a fat farm in Italy has cost him more than a few pounds.

Seven former directors of the Central Intelligence Agency asked President Obama on Friday to shut down the new Justice Department inquiry into past abuses during interrogations of terror suspects, arguing that it "will seriously damage" the nation's ability to protect itself.

The Securities and Exchange Commission will urge more public disclosure from hedge funds if Congress follows through with plans to make them register with the agency, the agency's chairwoman, Mary L. Schapiro, said Friday.

If you feel your digital photos are not quite compelling enough to justify investment in a digital photo frame, here's a fresh incentive. Hewlett-Packard has created a photo frame called the DreamScreen that adds social networking, Internet radio and a media player.

Last weekend, the New Amsterdam Market made its Fall 2009 debut in the former Fulton Fish Market space, where it will be held with some regularity through the end of the year and, if New Yorkers are lucky, into the next. For a few hours last Sunday, the dark space under the elevated highway was colored with visitors and food vendors from far and near.Nova Kim, a mushroom gatherer from Randolf, Vt.; Cellars at Jasper Hill, a cheese aging facility in Vermont's Northeast Kingdom; and Taza, producers of Mexican-style chocolate from Somerville, Mass., were just a few of the many who trucked their wares into Manhattan for the day. There were local sellers, too: Sara Jenkins with her porchetta sandwiches, Anne Saxelby and her cheeses and Nathalie Jordi serving her nectarine and blackberry People's Popsicles.

His work includes an examination of insurance coverage in Switzerland and a comparison of the Swiss and Dutch systems. He spoke to the freelance writer Anne Underwood.

Gov. David A. Paterson has ordered state agencies to place a hold on any current and future contracts with Acorn, the community organizing group that drew widespread condemnation after a hidden camera caught some of its employees dispensing tax advice to actors posing as a pimp and a prostitute.

It was a familiar picture in June: civil strife on the streets of Tehran. Then it seemed to vanish, as the government cracked down on protesters and photojournalists. On Friday, however, such images reemerged as an opposition rally was formed out of a government-organized anti-Israel march. Another picture (Slide 6) had a chilling echo of the past for anyone who remembers the Tank Man of Tiananmen Squre.

George Clooney was the name on most filmgoers' lips at the Toronto International Film Festival, which wraps up tomorrow. (And do Torontoers ever like to talk about movie stars - they line up everywhere to get a glimpse of them.) But the buzz beneath the buzz is about the little guys, who are trying to sell their films in a dismal economic climate. It may be a while before American audiences hear much about these movies, but here are a few indie contenders that had the festival chattering."The Good Heart" The Icelandic director Dagur Kari reunites Brian Cox and Paul Dano, who starred together in 2001's "L.I.E.," for a story about a charmingly misanthropic bar owner who takes in a homeless young man and shows him the ropes. The film is set in New York City but was filmed almost entirely in Iceland. So will Reykjavik become the new Vancouver?

It may be fashion week in London, but tomorrow evening there, a truly naked design will be unveiled. In honor of its 25th anniversary, Absolut Vodka will unveil No Label, a limited-edition, label-less and logo-less bottle that will make its global debut (though not in the United States). No Label is part of "In an Absolut World, There Are No Labels," an ambitious initiative by the vodka manufacturer to question prejudice and established norms of sexual identity.
The Times's Adam B. Ellick stumbles across an antique camera on the streets of Jalalabad, Afghanistan. The result is a passport photo in five minutes.

Our colleagues at City Room report that John Sexton, the president of New York University since 2002, has agreed to remain in his job until "at least 2016,'' at the urging of the school's board of trustees.
The last time the Giants and Cowboys met, Eli Manning has a hard time staying upright. The Cowboys collected eight sacks on their way to a 20-8 victory in December.

The Wild Rose was a much beloved and decrepit nightclub in Bridgehampton, N.Y., where patrons danced to live music, imbibed too much beer, and attained happiness and/or illness and/or pregnancy. It had been an entertainment establishment for almost a hundred years: Will Rogers twirled his lasso there in the '20s; politicians were caught with their lassos exposed in the '40s; and all manner of bands played one-night stands at the Wild Rose so they could bunk upstairs for a long weekend in the chichi Hamptons.

Ernie Anastos vaulted onto the world stage when he said a bad word on television. He apologized, his bosses said they were disappointed, and thousands of YouTube viewers watched the moment again and again. His explanation? According to news reports, he meant to say, "Keep plucking that chicken."

Speaking of Julia Child, as people seem to be doing, her version of bouillabaisse was among the first things I cooked when, in the mid-70s, I returned from my first trip to Provence. I doubt I've made it the same way twice since then. But I was at my friend Bob's house the other day and we decided to more-or-less follow the recipe, since we had just about everything it took. The drill is pretty easy, once you assemble the ingredients, but assembling the ingredients can take a while.

That is the conclusion reported by National Public Radio, in a piece that aired Tuesday morning. The piece was about a program called Healthy San Francisco, which offers uninsured residents access to a network of neighborhood clinics that emphasize preventive and coordinated care. Healthy San Francisco is financed in part by a mandate on companies with 20 or more employees. Companies with up to 100 workers must pay at least $1.23 for every hour worked by each employee to cover that employee's health care costs; those companies that don't provide insurance or other forms of reimbursement pay the minimum to cover the employee's participation in Healthy San Francisco.

Grit, sweat, vomit, tears  boot camp is no cakewalk. And that's what a new advertising campaign from the United States Marines will show potential recruits. James Dao writes in today's paper that the Marine Corps newest advertising campaign, which begins Saturday, comes on the heels of much higher recruitment numbers this year. Unlike past campaigns, featuring, say, the Marines' stately Silent Drill Platoon in dress uniform or a free climber morphing into a Marine while conquering a treacherous mountain face, the ad looks more like a survival reality show.

The House voted yesterday, on a largely party-line vote, to cut subsidies for student loans given to banks, and to instead make the loans directly. As I understand it now -- and I am not an expert -- the government already takes the risk and puts up the cash. So it is not clear to me that this is much of a change in reality. Perhaps the expertise of bank lending officers is needed, but I doubt there is much of that applied when the bank profits from making the loan, not getting it repaid.

An article in the Escapes pages on Sept. 4 about Siesta Key in Florida, which is renowned for its sand, misstated the sand’s chemical composition. It is 99 percent quartz, not 99 percent “limestone quartz.” (Limestone is not one of the varieties of quartz.).

A review on Sept. 2 of the documentary “American Casino,” about the country’s financial meltdown, misstated the surname of a lawyer who was quoted in the film as saying that “reverse redlining,” the practice of singling out minority borrowers to seek loans on unfavorable terms, is “the civil rights issue of the 2000s.” He is John Relman, not Belman.

An article on Wednesday about questions surrounding the suicide of Finn M. W. Caspersen, a New Jersey philanthropist who was under investigation for tax evasion, misstated the relationship between Mr. Caspersen and Clarence Hodson, the founder of what became the Beneficial Corporation and the namesake of the Hodson Trust, two organizations that Mr. Caspersen ran for many years. Mr. Caspersen’s grandfather was Mr. Hodson’s secretary, but the families were not related; Mr. Hodson was not Mr. Caspersen’s ancestor.

An article on Tuesday about the purchase of Mint.com, a personal-finance Web site, by the financial software company Intuit misstated part of the name of the research company that employs Stessa Cohen, an analyst who commented on the acquisition. It is Gartner Research, not Garter Research. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the name of one of Intuit’s popular software applications. It is Quicken, not Intuit.

BECKER--Ivan (Van) E.,retired President and CEO of Blessings Corporation died on September 17th of pancreatic cancer. ROSENTHAL--Robert C.,47, died suddenly on September 13, 2009 in his Ridgewood, New Jersey home. Bob was predeceased by his father Rabbi Richard Rosenthal and survived by his mother Barbara, wife Ardys and children Hannah, Robbie and Daniel, brother David and sister Deborah Calderon. His love of mountain sports, travel and adventure was exceeded only by his unswerving devotion to his family. Bob was CEO of Savile Finance Group, a global investment firm that he founded in 1993. Donations in his memory may be made to GreenChimneys.org; Green Chimneys, 400 Doansburg Road, Box 179, Brewster, NY 10509-0719.

EISENBERG--Leon. It is with deep sorrow that the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the passing of Leon Eisenberg, distinguished physician and researcher, inspired teacher and mentor, advocate of social medicine, and dedicated Fellow of the Academy for over forty years. To the medical community, he contributed pathbreaking work in child psychiatry and an abiding concern with the relation between the practice of medicine and the lives of patients. As the Communications Secretary of the Academy for seven years, he informed our work with his gentle humor and his wide-ranging knowledge and interests. He helped to ensure that merit and diversity were the hallmarks of our membership and that the communication of information and ideas across fields and professions was our responsibility to society. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Carola; to his family; and to all those touched by his wisdom and generous spirit. Emilio Bizzi, President Louis W. Cabot, Chair of the Academy Trust and Vice President Leslie Berlowitz, Chief Executive Officer

President Obama scrapped his predecessor's proposed antiballistic missile shield in Eastern Europe on Thursday and ordered instead the development of a reconfigured system designed to shoot down short- and medium-range Iranian missiles. In one of the biggest national security reversals of his young presidency, Mr. Obama canceled former President George W. Bush's plans to station a radar facility in the Czech Republic and 10 ground-based interceptors in Poland. Instead, he plans to deploy smaller SM-3 interceptors by 2011, first aboard ships and later in Europe, possibly even in Poland or the Czech Republic.

After watching President Obama's pragmatic maneuvering over missile defense, staunch Eastern European allies like Poland and the Czech Republic appeared likely to become more realistic and less idealistic about United States foreign policy in the future, not to mention a lot less likely to fall in line behind the United States. The decision to suspend plans for placing missile interceptors in Poland and a radar station in the Czech Republic did not come as a tremendous surprise after months of signals from Washington. But for politicians who backed the American plan, it was a disappointment and even an embarrassment.

The N.F.L. is considering an outside agency to run its drug-testing program, if legal challenges by players prevent the league from enforcing its program, the N.F.L.'s top lawyer said. ''If you get to the point where you can't resolve this, in litigation or through a collective agreement, I guess you would have to give some serious consideration to turning the program over to some outside agency, whether the Olympic drug-testing people,'' Jeff Pash, the N.F.L.'s chief labor counsel, said in a telephone interview.

McDONALD--James Scott, of New York City, on September 13, 2009. Beloved husband of Karen Hunter McDonald, devoted father of Scott, Hunter and Isabel. Born January 26, 1953 to Lloyd and Alice McDonald in Auckland, New Zealand, Jim showed exceptional promise from an early age. A gifted student and tennis player, he graduated from Harvard College, in 1975, and the University of Virginia School of Law in 1977. He began his career as a highly successful attorney at Choate, Hall & Stewart in Boston, where he became a partner in 1984. In 1986 he joined Pell Rudman & Co., a wealth management firm in Boston, where he served as President and CEO. In January 2001, Jim came to New York to become President and CEO of Rockefeller and Company. He expanded the company from a multi-family office to an internationally-recognized investment firm that serves a broad number of families and institutions. Jim was a member of numerous committees and organizations, including serving as a board member of NYSE Euronext (formerly the New York Stock Exchange). In addition, he was chairman of the board of the Japan Society of New York and a member of the Council of Foreign Relations. He also served as a trustee of the Nightingale-Bamford School in New York and as chair of the board of trustees of Fessenden School in West Newton, Massachusetts. A memorial service will be held on Monday, September 21, 4:00pm at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave. and 90th Street, New York City. Burial will be in Prout's Neck, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Harvard College, Friends of Harvard Squash at Harvard College or the University School of Virginia School of Law. Jim was a man of great wisdom, warmth and caring. He blessed us all with his generosity and compassion. We shall miss him always.

There were no speeches on Wednesday night when Alan Gilbert conducted his first concert as the music director of the New York Philharmonic. Many words have been spoken and written about the significance of Mr. Gilbert's appointment since it was announced two years ago. For this season-opening concert, broadcast on public television's ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series and relayed on an outdoor video screen to Lincoln Center Plaza, music would have to do the talking. And it did, eloquently and excitingly. Every orchestra promises a new day when a new conductor takes over as music director. But with the coming of Mr. Gilbert, a 42-year-old New York native, the son of Philharmonic violinists past and present, the promise could turn out to be quite true. His program was not just a collection of terrific pieces that made musical sense together but a statement of purpose. Yet what mattered was the music itself and the fresh, dynamic music making. There was no trace of agenda on this celebratory night.

The new plan that President Obama laid out for a missile shield against Iran on Thursday turns Ronald Reagan's vision of a Star Wars system on its head: Rather than focusing first on protecting the continental United States, it shifts the immediate effort to defending Europe and the Middle East. It is a long way from the impermeable shield that President Reagan described in glowing terms in 1983, an announcement that turned into a diplomatic triumph even while it was a technological flop. Ever since, missile defense has always been more about international politics than about new military technology.

Reliance Industries raised 31.9 billion rupees ($664 million) selling shares to the public. Petroleum Trust, a unit of Reliance, sold 15 million shares at an average price of 2,125 rupees apiece, according to a filing with the Bombay Stock Exchange. Reliance, an exploration and refinery company controlled by Mukesh Ambani, said on Saturday that it might buy fields overseas and hedge risks of investing in India, where a gas-pricing dispute is shaving $100 million off monthly sales. The sale came after Reliance surged 77 percent in Mumbai this year, more than triple the 20 percent gain in the MSCI World Energy Index.

A new study tries to calculate the human cost of tens of millions of Americans' doing without health insurance. Researchers from Harvard Medical School say lack of insurance can be linked to about 45,000 deaths a year in the United States, a toll greater than the number of people who die annually of kidney disease.

Mary Travers, whose ringing, earnest vocals with the folk trio Peter, Paul and Mary made songs like ''Blowin' in the Wind,'' ''If I Had a Hammer'' and ''Where Have All the Flowers Gone?'' enduring anthems of the 1960s protest movement, died on Wednesday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. She was 72 and lived in Redding, Conn. The cause was complications of chemotherapy for a bone-marrow transplant she had several years ago after developing leukemia, said Heather Lylis, a spokeswoman.

-- ''LET go, let go. ... Let goooo!'' I heard a voice shout from above as I skidded downhill on my stomach over soggy, muddy grass. As I unhooked myself from the harness of my hang glider, hurrying to make way for the next student's attempt at flight, a feeling of dread washed over me. What if I can't do this? ''O.K.,'' I said out loud to myself, taking a deep breath. ''Relax.'' But my command had no effect. ''You cannot be the worst person in the class,'' I told myself, in hopes of getting my brain and body to get their act together.

Airbus predicted on Thursday that demand for new aircraft would remain healthy over the next 20 years, based on expectations of steady air traffic growth in the developing world and the rapid expansion of low-cost carriers. The prediction comes even as the world's airlines are suffering a second consecutive year of steep losses. The company, a unit of European Aeronautic Defense and Space, forecast that airlines would buy nearly 25,000 new jets through 2028, with a market value of $3.1 trillion. That represented an increase of 2.7 percent from its previous forecast in February 2008, when air carriers were reeling from the initial effects of the global economic crisis.

The developer Bruce C. Ratner, who received final state approval Thursday to build an $800 million arena in Brooklyn for the Nets, is inching closer to selling a majority stake in the team to a Russian billionaire, according to two executives briefed on the negotiations. Ratner, who bought the team for $300 million in 2004 with plans to move it to a new home in Brooklyn, has acknowledged in recent weeks that he is talking to potential investors. The arena, which would be known as Barclays Center, is the centerpiece of a planned 22-acre residential and commercial development project.

All it took was an early thaw for the drinking water here to become unsafe. There are 41,000 dairy cows in Brown County, which includes Morrison, and they produce more than 260 million gallons of manure each year, much of which is spread on nearby grain fields. Other farmers receive fees to cover their land with slaughterhouse waste and treated sewage.

The White House on Thursday took the first steps toward addressing a problem that many doctors say is driving up health care costs: exorbitant malpractice claims and sky-high premiums for liability insurance. President Obama directed Kathleen Sebelius, right, secretary of health and human services, to announce within 30 days that the department would begin accepting proposals from states, localities and various health organizations for demonstration projects devised to improve patient safety and doctor-patient communication; ensure timely payments to injured patients; and reduce insurance liability premiums for providers. The projects are a concession to Republicans by the president, who has said he does not perceive medical malpractice to be a big factor in the cost of health care and does not think liability awards should be capped.

Bikers went faster than we did as they zipped along the towpath, now a biking and walking trail. Even Rollerbladers and joggers passed us going in the same direction. At top speed, motor thrumming, we plowed along at a very relaxed five miles an hour.

On the way to the Proenza Schouler show Wednesday night, a nice-looking young man crossed Ninth Avenue near the High Line wearing a plain gray blazer, jeans, gray socks and, to kick up his look, Crayola-colored plastic quarterback heels from the fall 2007 Balenciaga women's collection. If the message in fashion this season is that anything goes, he sure got the memo. It was really great for two reasons: The designers did not fall into the recessionary trap of playing it safe; and they kept their look youthful and full of Juicy Fruit colors.

Under the new health care proposal from Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, a drug industry offer to help Medicare patients save money could end up costing the Medicare program itself a lot more money. In June, the drug industry reached a big cost-savings deal with Mr. Baucus and the White House, meant to reduce the nation's drug bill by $80 billion over 10 years. One way was to give Medicare patients a 50 percent discount on the price of brand-name drugs during the period each year when many patients find themselves in a coverage gap known as the doughnut hole.

Here's one thing that can be said for the new Cowboys Stadium, where the Dallas Cowboys will play their first home game of the regular season on Sunday against the Giants: it's not Mickey Mouse architecture. With a $1.15 billion price tag and a flying saucer-like form, the stadium's design mercifully avoids the aw-shucks, small-town look that has become common in many American stadiums over the years. There's no brick cladding, no fake wrought ironwork, no infantilizing theme restaurants that seem as if they had been commissioned by Uncle Walt for the Happiest Place on Earth.

KIRCHNER--Leon. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, a composer of magisterial power and versatility. We have lost a friend. American music has lost a giant.

The shadowy craters near the south pole of the Moon may be the coldest places in the solar system, colder even than Pluto, NASA scientists said as they unveiled some of the first findings from the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter spacecraft. The orbiter, launched in June, officially began its one-year mission to map the Moon's surface this week. But it had begun returning data during three months of testing and calibration. Among the data, thermal measurements showed that daytime temperatures over much of the surface reached 220 degrees before plummeting at night. But the bottoms of the craters, which lie in permanent darkness, never warm above minus 400 degrees. Those ultracold temperatures have trapped and held deposits of ice for several billion years. The ice could prove a valuable resource to future explorers, not only drinking water but also, when the water molecules are broken apart, hydrogen and oxygen.

If the words "male model" bring to mind Zoolander or Brüno in leopard bikini briefs, then you haven't seen the latest crop of guys walking the runways. Meet Tyler Riggs, a Florida native who is dominating the men's-wear industry, walking in over 30 shows last season and appearing in campaigns like Louis Vuitton and D&G, as well as in countless editorials. Yet despite his successful career wearing other people's clothes, Riggs maintains a consistent personal style that even inspires the designers and editors who dress him. "A stylist still has some of my clothes, which we used during a recent shoot," Riggs says.Riggs is just one of a new generation of male models who have evaded the stereotypes of their profession, trading in big hair and big egos for a more laid-back style. For him, that usually means worn-in A.P.C. jeans, a vintage rock 'n' roll T-shirt purchased in an East Village thrift store and a motorcycle jacket given to him by Neil Barrett. Here's how to get the look (no promises that it'll be as easy to pull off as it is for a model):

Oprah Winfrey, left, has anointed a new book club choice: “Say You’re One of Them,” a collection of short stories by Uwem Akpan. Ms. Winfrey’s selection virtually guarantees blockbuster sales. Her last choice, “The Story of Edgar Sawtelle,” the first novel by David Wroblewski, has been a mainstay of best-seller lists and has sold 766,000 copies in hardcover and 14,000 copies in paperback, according to Nielsen BookScan, which represents about 70 percent of sales. “Say You’re One of Them,” published last year by Little, Brown & Company, has been widely praised by critics. Mr. Akpan, a Nigerian who is a Jesuit priest, wrote five stories, some of novella length. Each is set in a different African country, and they are narrated by children in poverty. The book won the 2009 Commonwealth Writers’ Prize for best first book from Africa and the PEN/Beyond Margins Award.

The former Libyan intelligence agent convicted in the 1988 Lockerbie bombing has posted a 298-page dossier of legal documents on the Internet to support his claim of innocence in the attack on Pan Am Flight 103, which killed 270 people. The former agent, Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, abandoned his appeal of his 27-year sentence as a condition for his release last month by the Scottish government, which freed him because he was terminally ill with prostate cancer. Mr. Megrahi said that he had ''been deprived of the opportunity to clear my name'' by the end of the appeal process. A spokesman for the Scottish government, Richard Baker, said, ''He remains in the eyes of Scottish justice the murderer of 270 people.'' The documents are posted at www.megrahimystory.net.

Keith Floyd, a British chef who revivified the television cooking-show format in the 1980s by injecting his own brand of wit, flamboyance and spontaneity verging on chaos, died Monday in Bridport, Dorset. He was 65 and lived in Montfrin, France. The cause was a heart attack, said James Steen, the ghostwriter of Mr. Floyd's autobiography.

Uwe E. Reinhardt, a Princeton economist, has a gloomy forecast in assessing Senator Max Baucus's health care proposal. Mr. Reinhardt, right, writing Friday on the Economix blog, says the Baucus plan gives the insurance industry almost everything it could have wanted. But he describes a potential ''winner's curse.'' Because the Baucus plan does little to control runaway medical costs, Mr. Reinhardt says, insurers will still need to raise premiums year after year to keep up -- fueling the rising fury of a public that, under the Baucus rules, would be forced by a federal mandate to buy the increasingly expensive insurance. (Mr. Reinhardt dismisses the proposed insurance alternative, from new nonprofit cooperatives, as ''mice that roar.'')

The Blackstone Group agreed to buy 50 percent of Broadgate, the largest office complex in London's main financial district, from the British Land Company in a transaction that values the properties at £2.1 billion ($3.4 billion), British Land said Friday. The sale of Broadgate is the biggest in the British capital since the commercial-property slump began two years ago. Blackstone, based in New York, will pay £77 million for the stake and assume £987 million of debt, British Land said.

The Phoenix Mercury rookie forward DeWanna Bonner won the sixth woman award. Playing 20 minutes a game, Bonner averaged 11.2 points and 5.8 rebounds, and led all rookies with five double-doubles. Bonner received 20 of 38 votes from a national panel of sportswriters and broadcasters. Angel McCoughtry finished second with 10 votes, and Shavonte Zellous was third with four.

The Goldman Sachs Group said Friday that it agreed to sell a 126.7 billion yen ($1.4 billion) holding in the Sanyo Electric Company to the Panasonic Corporation, reaping 59 billion yen in investment gains. Goldman will sell nearly 100 million preferred shares that are convertible into common stock, 54 percent of its stake in Sanyo, the company said. Goldman agreed last December to sell the stock at 1,310 yen for each share, 87 percent higher than the purchase price. Goldman converted the remaining stake into 818.9 million common shares and might sell its remaining holdings, it said.

American Airlines is seeking support from its global partners, including British Airways and Qantas, to improve its bid to create an alliance with Japan Airlines, people with knowledge of the discussions said Friday. The latest proposal comes as another carrier, Delta Air Lines, tries to line up members of its SkyTeam alliance, including Air France-KLM, in an effort to make a competing bid for the Japanese carrier. Japan Airlines, the largest carrier in Japan, is scrambling to meet a mid-October deadline to present a turnaround plan to the Japanese government. The airline said this week that it planned to cut about 6,800 jobs over the next three years and eliminate a number of unprofitable routes.
