In the early '90s, when his place in pop music was being considered by his record company, Jon Secada recalled on Wednesday evening, one executive suggested he might be ''the Latin Johnny Mathis.'' Like Mr. Mathis, Mr. Secada, who was born in Havana and brought up in Hialeah, Fla., pitches woo to the ladies, and his new album, ''Expressions,'' includes his version of the Mathis signature hit ''Chances Are.'' But vocally Mr. Secada bears only a distant resemblance to an ethereal crooner with one foot on a pink cloud and the other kicking up stardust in celestial climes. Dressed in a gun-metal gray suit and a black T-shirt at Feinstein's at Loews Regency, he embodied upscale, post-''Miami Vice'' suavity. An aggressive physical performer who illustrates song lyrics with a prizefighter's body language, he is less a crooner than an impassioned belter who doesn't spend time building up a ballad. Cutting directly to the chase, he conveys feverishly impassioned intensity with minimal expressive shading. In quieter moments his voice can settle into a husky borderline falsetto.

BERGMANN--Arthur, 81, suddenly on September 17, 2009 in West Palm Beach, FL. Formerly Deputy County Executive, Suffolk County Long Island. Survived by two brothers Ted (Beverly) of Pacific Palisades, CA and George (Marla) of Ft. Lauderdale, FL.

For the first eight months of her husband's presidency, Michelle Obama has made a practice of steering clear of most policy debates, spending more time in the public eye promoting the White House's vegetable garden than its agenda. But a speech on Friday, which Mrs. Obama delivered to leaders of several women's groups, signaled the beginning of an increased role in the health care debate.

In a clear break with the Bush administration, the Food and Drug Administration has decided to require makers of an intravenous anti-nausea drug that had been the subject of a Supreme Court case to put a strict warning on its label. The drug, Phenergan, which is also known as promethazine, can cause gangrene and serious tissue damage when unintentionally injected into an artery. In 2000, Diana Levine, a Vermont musician, had her hand and forearm amputated after such a mistaken injection. She sued Wyeth, the drug's maker, claiming the company should have put a more forceful warning on the drug's label. She won a $6.8 million judgment.

(HBO) MADAGASCAR: ESCAPE 2 AFRICA (2008) Ben Stiller, Chris Rock, David Schwimmer and Jada Pinkett Smith reprise their roles as the voices of a group of New York zoo animals -- a caged lion, a yakety zebra, a neurotic giraffe and a voluptuous hippo -- that crash-land their rickety plane on the African continent in this animated sequel. Sacha Baron Cohen does a turn as a deranged lemur, Bernie Mac plays a lion's lion, and Alec Baldwin chimes in as -- who else? -- the resident bad guy. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said the movie was ''good enough in patches to make its distracting star turns, storybook clichés and stereotypes harder to take than they would be in a less enjoyable movie.'' 10:30 A.M. Mike Henry could not get comfortable in his stance. He knew the line judge was watching him. This was only a scrimmage, but Henry, a 6-foot-5, 289-pound freshman lineman, was trying to move up the depth chart for the Tulane Green Wave. The whistle blew and a blur of black and white stripes came running his way. ''You need to get down, and stay down,'' the official said in a voice that swiveled Henry's head and widened his eyes. It was not the tone but the timbre of Sarah Thomas's voice.

The Swiss government said Friday that it planned to appoint up to five judges to deal with appeals arising from an agreement with the United States to hand over data on accounts at UBS that the authorities suspect were used by some American clients to evade taxes. Andrea Arcidiacono, a spokeswoman for the Federal Administrative Court in Bern said the government had agreed to the court's request to add up to five judges and extra support staff to its existing 72 judges to handle the expected appeals.

After watching the bitter debate on Thursday night between top campaign advisers to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., you would be forgiven for thinking there is bad blood between the two strategists. ''To quote one of Michael Bloomberg's Republican colleagues, you lie!'' Eduardo Castell, who is managing Mr. Thompson's campaign for mayor, told Howard Wolfson, the media strategist for Mr. Bloomberg.

There is nothing cautious about the way Alan Gilbert has begun his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic. First, for the season-opening gala concert on Wednesday, he conducted a boldly adventurous program that included a new work and a seldom-heard Messiaen song cycle. Then on Thursday night, for his first subscription program, Mr. Gilbert chose the longest of Mahler's nine symphonies, the Third, an elusive and complex score full of treacherously exposed passages. Even the movements that seem bucolic on the surface are abuzz with intricate inner details.

President Obama made five appearances on the Sunday morning talk shows, with the proposed health care overhaul emphasized on all of them. An article on Page 34 this weekend about Carl Jung and a book he wrote about struggling with his own demons misspells the name of a street in Zurich where, before it was published, the book was held for years in a bank safe-deposit box, and a correction in this space on Saturday also misspelled the name. It is Bahnhofstrasse, not Banhofstrasse or Banhoffstrasse. The article also misstates the location of Bollingen, the town where Jung built a stone tower as a summer residence. While it is on the north shore of Lake Zurich, it is south of the Jung family home in Küsnacht.

An article last Sunday about the ways that Pedro Espada Jr. is using his power as majority leader of the State Senate referred incorrectly to state law covering farmworkers, whose lot Mr. Espada is pushing to improve. State law does in fact require that they be paid minimum wage. (As the article correctly noted, they are exempt from rules requiring overtime and disability insurance, though a bill now before the Senate would rescind those exemptions.).

An article last Sunday about lawyers who have been disciplined for comments they made online misstated the source of a statement saying that one lawyer’s remarks “fail as protected free speech under the First Amendment.” That statement came from a brief submitted by the Florida bar to the state Supreme Court, which reviewed the lawyer’s punishment; it was not from the state Supreme Court’s ruling in the case.

To the Editor: I read the article “Two for the Road” (Aug. 30) with delight and mild annoyance. It is fantastic that the authors took a two-week couples’ vacation cross country, living out of their minivan. Still, I have to say, after driving and tent camping through our national parks for two months this summer with my three children (ages 5, 7 and 9) from Illinois to California, back up through Canada and finally to Michigan, my “five for the road” trip was definitely incredible, the best summer ever, yet most definitely not “Edenic.” More than not, cheesy popcorn was flying, “SpongeBob SquarePants” blaring, prayers singing (that our 2001 Honda minivan would make it home). Jeff Ericksen.

To the Editor: Andrew Ferren’s article “Spanish Village of Rainbow Weddings” (Sept. 6), about one elected official’s willingness to perform weddings for all couples, is a charming story. In my book, the tiny village of Campillo de Ranas has suddenly become a must-see place to travel, with its abundant hiking trails and gorgeous natural pools, not to mention the apparent good manners of its own people. Thank you, Francisco Maroto, for honoring the love that two people can have for each other regardless of gender.

A map on Sept. 13 with the cover article about Prouts Neck, Me., where Winslow Homer lived and painted, mislabeled two highways. The Interstate highway running north and south through Portland is I-95, not I-495, and the Interstate running northeast of Portland to Brunswick is I-295, not I-95. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/travel. And the article misstated the relationship between Prouts Neck and the town of Scarborough. Prouts Neck is in fact part of the town of Scarborough; it is not south of the town.

ROSENTHAL--Robert C.,47, died suddenly on September 13, 2009 in his Ridgewood, New Jersey home. Bob was predeceased by his father Rabbi Richard Rosenthal and survived by his mother Barbara, wife Ardys and children Hannah, Robbie and Daniel, brother David and sister Deborah Calderon. Bob exuded a passion for living life to the fullest with his family, large circle of friends and business colleagues from around the world. His love of mountain sports, travel and adventure was exceeded only by his unswerving devotion to his family. Bob was CEO of Savile Finance Group, a global investment firm that he founded in 1993. Also Bob served as Chairman of Pali Capital, an international brokerage firm. During his career Bob served on the board of numerous public and private companies. Bob grew up in Tacoma, Washington and graduated from the University of Washington. He was buried in his hometown next to his father Rabbi Richard Rosenthal. Donations in his memory may be made to GreenChimneys.org; Green Chimneys, 400 Doansburg Road, Box 179, Brewster, NY 10509-0719.

Sofia Vergara, 'Modern Family' Practically a loaded semiautomatic aimed at those who don't think beautiful women can be funny, Sofia Vergara scene-steals her way through ''Modern Family,'' the droll ABC comedy about a group of disparate suburban households being filmed for a Dutch documentary. A Colombian by birth and a star of Hispanic television, Ms. Vergara plays the libidinous young trophy wife of Ed O'Neill's track-suit-wearing chump-change of a husband. Satirizing the stereotype of the Latina sexpot coolly enough never to career into Charo territory, she displays gifts that extend way beyond the physical with a talent for slice-and-dice emasculating that already seems Emmy worthy.

FOR many of his 85 years, Franklin W. Hobbs III has managed to distill good fortune from bad luck. Orphaned at 10, he wound up in the care of loving -- and wealthy -- grandparents. After World War II snatched him from Harvard, the G. I. Bill sent him back for a master's in business administration. Rocky moments in his career often led to lucrative, fulfilling opportunities. And so it was on Iwo Jima in the winter of 1945.

FRIDAY night used to be the place television shows went to die if they couldn't get a slot on Saturday. Then, five years ago, CBS put death itself on the menu: ''Ghost Whisperer'' presented an antiques-store owner, Melinda Gordon (Jennifer Love Hewitt), as a kind of travel agent for the deceased, helping unsettled souls enter the hereafter.

SPITZ--Ruth Sachere, longtime Democratic Socialists of America Board Member, political activist, and Lecturer at Empire State College, died June 24, 2009 at 90. She served on the Ohio State Commission on the Status of Women, and Boards of the Association for Union Democracy and the Women's Labor Rights Organization. Her commitment to progressive action will be missed. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 26, 2009, 6:30-8:30pm at St. Judson Church just off Washington Square Park, New York City, entrance at 159 Thompson Street. Contributions in her memory may be sent to DSA.

An article on Page 34 this weekend about Carl Jung and a book he wrote about struggling with his own demons misspells the name of a street in Zurich where, before it was published, the book was held for years in a bank safe-deposit box, and a correction in this space on Saturday also misspelled the name. It is Bahnhofstrasse, not Banhofstrasse or Banhoffstrasse. The article also misstates the location of Bollingen, the town where Jung built a stone tower as a summer residence. While it is on the north shore of Lake Zurich, it is south of the Jung family home in Küsnacht.

FRUGAL TRAVELER BLOG

At times, central Harlem seems to be an urban scene straight out of central casting: Step off the No. 2 or 3 train at the 116th Street stop one evening, and the air is filled with the snap-snap of double Dutch jump ropes hitting the pavement and girls tensely debating just whose turn it is. Old men hunker down over folding domino tables, and young men preen and spar with one another. But mixed with these Spike Lee-esque vignettes is another Harlem, chugging on in defiance of the recession. It includes slick boutiques and cafes, bars that attract Hollywood types and places for music that make you wonder when exactly Harlem's Renaissance happened -- then, or now? 4:30 P.M. At the start of World War I, said Jeffrey S. Gurock, the author of ''When Harlem Was Jewish, 1870-1930,'' central Harlem had a Jewish population of 125,000. That heritage lives on at Lee Lee's Baked Goods, 283 West 118th Street, (917) 493-6633, where Alvin Lee Smalls bakes the most buttery rugelach (70 cents each, but try and buy just one) in a small bakery appointed like a country kitchen. Mr. Smalls, who is black, is known for his old tongue-in-cheek window sign that once advertised the cinnamon and raisin pastry as ''rugelach by a brother.''

Since 1962, Abercrombie & Kent has been organizing high-end travel packages to exotic locales: it's not unusual to see statements like ''Save up to $4,500 per Person in India'' on its Web site, which gives a sense of the package's total price. With a new Web site, at www.akphilanthropy.org, and a nonprofit wing, Abercrombie & Kent Philanthropy, or AKP, the company has extended its reach from luxury to grassroots.

Like a naval commander with an undefeated battle record, Kelsey Grammer has been unchallenged as television's most consistently on-target interpreter of jovial elitism for nearly three decades. Rebounding both from heart problems and his amusing but canceled Fox series, ''Back to You,'' he returns to network television this fall as the star of ''Hank,'' an ABC comedy predicated on the idea that there's no humbling a fallen honcho. In it Mr. Grammer plays a businessman, once a Fortune cover boy, who lost it all and finds himself forced to return to modest suburban living. ''Hank'' is only a middling exercise in recession-compatible programming, but Mr. Grammer remains a pleasure to watch, elevating the material as if he were Olivier doing a former Merrill Lynch chieftain.

SIMON--Melvin. The Steven L. Newman Real Estate Institute at Baruch College, City University of New York, and its founding chairman, William Newman, mourn the passing of our valued advisory board member, respected colleague, financial supporter and friend, Melvin Simon. Born in Brooklyn and raised in the Bronx, Mel was the pioneering founder of the largest shopping mall corporation in America, The Simon Group. Mel's accomplishments in his private and professional life were attributable to his great passion and vision, and his innate understanding of the essential decency within other people. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. His wise counsel and warm friendship will be sorely missed, but the sterling values he represented will endure as a touchstone for us all.
''I think it's based on racism. There is an inherent feeling among many in this country that an African-American should not be president.''

The return of ''Dexter,'' Showtime's thrilling psychological deconstruction of a vigilante serial killer played by Michael C. Hall, benefits even further this season from the reappearance of Keith Carradine as Special Agent Frank Lundy. A lauded profiler for the F.B.I. with a penchant for calming routines and cucumber sandwiches, Lundy won the heart of Dexter's sister, Deb (Jennifer Carpenter), during the series's second season only to be written off last year under the pretext that he had to hunt murderous sadists on the West Coast. Mr. Carradine's subdued easy sexuality made it a no-brainer that Deb would fall deep down the well for a balding man twice her age. Now Lundy is back in Miami to track down John Lithgow's Trinity Killer while inadvertently making a mess of Deb's love life. Through it all he makes us grateful that a thinking woman's sex symbol of the '70s could be so compellingly well cast.

RUBENSTEIN--Gerald, on September 17, 2009. Beloved husband of nearly 56 years of Harriet. Devoted brother, loving father to Lee and Caryn. Cherished grandfather to Mara and Adam. Worked in the textile industry for more than 40 years. Active volunteer and loyal member of Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst. Service 11:30am, Monday, "Boulevard-Riverside" Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.
BLOCK--Hilbert, 87, of Aventura, FL, died September 13, 2009. Service was held on September 16th.

THE Hispanic Society of America, the lonely gem of a museum in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, is usually visited -- when visited at all -- for the collection of world-class Goya, El Greco and Velázquez paintings amassed there by its founder, the railroad heir and scholar Archer Milton Huntington. But the society also boasts one of the world's best libraries of material relating to Spain, Portugal and the Americas, a collection accessed through an unassuming side door, which opens onto a small reading room presided over by portraits of great thinkers like the philosopher José Ortega y Gasset and scattered with heavy oak table placards commanding ''Silence.''

GERBE, the century-old French manufacturer of high-end hosiery, is having a major moment. In the last couple of months, its polka-dot Plumetis tights have been splashed across the pages of nearly every fashion magazine. German Vogue put them on the September cover, the model Anja Rubik wearing them with little else. Why all the fuss? Well, ever since Balenciaga paraded them on the fall runway (left), the spotty stockings have become the season's chicest accessory for under $40. Wear them with a silk dress and a pair of booties for a good dose of Parisian la la.

Zach Galifianakis, 'Bored To Death' Upstaging Jason Schwartzman's aggressively affectless performance in the new HBO half-hour series ''Bored to Death,'' Zach Galifianakis takes a 21st-century archetype -- the urban loser man-child with no evidence of an Equinox membership -- and rescues him from the cliché he is fast becoming. An underground comic who came to broader attention in ''The Hangover,'' Mr. Galifianakis deploys exquisite timing and an entirely original brand of eccentricity in his role as sidekick to Mr. Schwartzman's arrogant but going-nowhere 30-ish Brooklyn novelist. While Mr. Schwartzman can't seem to summon up much in the way of the character's presumed margin of likability, his co-star, as a sex-deprived cartoonist, delivers just enough soul beneath the schlub.

Marriott is offering 20 percent off the lowest available rate at thousands of its hotels, including the JW Marriott, Renaissance, Courtyard and Residence Inn brands. The sale, good for travel between Sept. 25 and Dec. 13, is available for stays of at least two nights from Thursday to Sunday, and covers most hotels in North America, South America, Europe, Asia, Caribbean and Latin America. For example, the deal brings a stay at the JW Marriott Cancún, above, in late September to $199 a night, from $249.

''I JUST want to make sure you know it's a comedy.'' Those were the words of a Warner Brothers publicist as I made my way this summer into a screening of ''The Informant!,'' the latest movie directed by Steven Soderbergh. It struck me at the time as an odd thing for her to say. If I didn't know that the movie, which stars Matt Damon as an agribusiness executive turned F.B.I. snitch, was meant to be funny, wouldn't that be clear soon enough? And anyway, I pride myself on a certain cinematic savvy. No one had to tell me beforehand that ''District 9'' was science fiction or that ''The Hangover'' was an earnest warning about the perils of binge drinking.

MORIARTY--Virginia Shaw, died peacefully on September 16, 2009 at The Forest at Duke, a retirement community in Durham, NC. The daughter of Thomas Aloysius Shaw and Helen McGuire Shaw, she was born on March 16, 1922 and raised in Garden City, NY. She attended Garden City High School and graduated from Katherine Gibbs College where she pursued studies in fashion design and merchandising. She began her career in the textile industry in Manhattan, and then moved to San Francisco to become an apparel buyer at the White House department store. Returning to New York, she became Fashion Editor at Parents Magazine before retiring in 1966. She then devoted her time to charitable endeavors, particularly as a board member of the Virginia Day Nursery, one of the city's oldest non-profit day care facilities originally established to care for children of working mothers, where she also served as Treasurer for several years before resigning. Thereafter, she lived in San Francisco, London and Ferrington Village in Pittsboro, NC. She is survived by her husband Eugene Vincent Moriarty, her two children, Kathleen Hill Moriarty and Kevin Shaw Moriarty and her sister Mary Jane Shaw Harvey, as well as nieces, nephews and friends. A memorial mass will be held at The Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan with interment at the Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury, New York at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Benevolent Fund of The Forest at Duke, 2107 Pickett Road, Durham, NC 27705.

LEHRMAN--Gertrude, (nee Pritzker), 88, on September 2, 2009 in Culver City, California. Former wife of Daniel S. Lehrman, mother of Nina, of Kulu, India, and June, of Culver City. Except for the first two years of her life, spent in Russia, and the last three, spent in California, Gert was a dedicated New Yorker. A wonderful pianist, trained by Alexander Siloti at the Juilliard School, she taught music from 1955 to 1976 at three high schools in Queens (Jamaica, Francis Lewis and W. C. Bryant), where she put on fantastic shows and introduced generations of students to great music. Later, she accompanied the Tarumi Violinists of Flushing on their world tours. A lovely woman inside and out, an impassioned bridge player, a fervently concerned citizen, she leaves behind a loving and sorely bereft circle of friends and relations. Condolences may be sent to jlehrman@igc.org.

THE HOME COOK Eliza Smith, 62, came to New York from Liberia in 1969 and spent years working for the state government, in mental health. Her husband, who was from South Carolina and died in 1986, loved her traditional Liberian recipes. So did their friends, and in the mid-1990s, one of them offered to pay her to cook for him weekly. Soon, neighbors and friends of friends were calling, asking if they could come by and eat in her kitchen or take meals home. She also catered weddings, graduations and other parties.

Last week's fight between the Yankees and the Blue Jays was one of the worst incidents of the season, with Toronto pitcher Jesse Carlson walking away with a welt on his head and Yankees Manager Joe Girardi sporting a bruise near his left eye. Unfortunately for baseball, this particular fight happened as many Americans were lamenting the lack of civility in society. Fighting has always be a part of baseball, but things are nowhere near as bad as they were in the supposedly good old days. Over the course of less than a year in the early 1930s there were three particularly nasty incidents that time has largely forgotten and that make last week's scrap look tame in comparison.

Matt Bomer, 'White Collar' If there is anyone on television who will be able to rival Jon Hamm in the exercise of properly carrying himself in a leanly proportioned dark suit, it is Matt Bomer, formerly of ''Chuck'' and now the star of the promising new USA series ''White Collar.'' As Neal Caffrey, a brainy con man who definitely isn't shopping at Syms, Mr. Bomer is all impish charisma and boyish masculinity. He could charm you into a fugue state. A prison escapee who bolted to find a long-lost girlfriend, Neal is captured by his former law-enforcement nemesis, but instead of being sent back to lockup, he is put to work for the Feds. Caffrey can outsmart the best of them, and Mr. Bomer makes it seem entirely plausible that someone who looks like a Brioni model could have an I.Q. as high as a physicist's.
SAMOSE--Celia. In loving memory of your birthday, September 19. Grandchildren

STEINBRECHER--Phyllis. Phyllis would do everything to save, support, and cheer on an adolescent who lost his or her way... and she did. And, so too, for the families who needed reassurance that their child or grandchild might someday rise from many a struggle throughout their school years. Her generosity of spirit, kindness, and wisdom gave way to hope and promise. Her optimism for the future was reflected in the eyes of so many who were lovingly guided by Phyllis. This was her gift and this will be her lasting legacy. Ann, Robert and Jessica Freedman

''DO not get out of the car!'' the private security guard barked at the driver from the back seat of a black van carrying Michael Moore and five striking workers from the United Steelworkers union (Local 6500). The event was the screening of Mr. Moore's latest film, ''Capitalism: A Love Story'' at the Toronto International Film Festival and, as with most premieres, the sidewalk was packed with people waiting for the limousine doors to open.

A film entry in the Week Ahead report on Sept. 6 misstated the name of the story by Julio Cortázar that was the basis of Michelangelo Antonioni's ''Blow-Up'' (1966), part of the Film Society of Lincoln Center's Latinbeat festival. The story is ''Las Babas del Diablo,'' not ''Las Babas de Diablo.'' The entry also misstated the name of a second story by Cortázar that served as the basis for Manuel Antin's ''Odd Number'' (1962). It is ''Cartas de Mamá,'' not ''Cartas a Mamá.''

DURING a recent evening shoot the wardrobe trailer for ''The Good Wife'' on CBS sat outside a courthouse in Jamaica, Queens. The clothes in it were trial-ready: sober, simple and uniformly dark. ''My biggest challenge on this show is black,'' Daniel Lawson, the show's costume designer, said with a sigh. A year ago Mr. Lawson was dressing the leads on ''Lipstick Jungle'' for their stiletto-stomping adventures in the glittering precincts of Manhattan. ''On that show, it was all about the clothes,'' he said. ''They wore sequins at home. Who wears sequins at home?''

GLADSTONE--Leonard Jay, passed away at his home in Palm Beach on September 16, at the age of 82. Adoring father of his daughter Amy and her husband Lew, his son Danny and his wife Carol and his son David and wife Megan. Proud grandfather of Jake, Beth, Sam, Jack, Ali and Nicole. Beloved brother of Ted and Alexandra Gladstone, numerous nieces and nephews and their spouses and children. Lenny enjoyed many things-his family, the ocean, sailing, photography, gadgets, laughter and sweets. His house was a welcome haven for the entire family to congregate and enjoy his wit, creativity, advice and presence. Lenny will be dearly missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 22, 2009 at 11am at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 89 Baldwin Road, Mount Kisco, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alzheimer's research would be appreciated, so that one day there will be a cure for this terrible disease.

NBC's ''West Wing'' is long defunct, but many of the policy issues it raised rage on. Case in point: health care. In one episode in 2005, the Democratic presidential nominee, played by Jimmy Smits, admitted in a debate that he was not especially happy with the health care plan he had proposed.

Jack Manning, a character actor familiar to theater, film, television and radio audiences for more than a half-century, died on Aug. 31 at his home in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif. He was 93. Mr. Manning, who in later years was also known as a stage director and acting teacher, died of natural causes, his wife, Francie, said.

-- It was just over two years ago that Barack Obama, then the junior senator from Illinois with aspirations to the presidency, famously pronounced during a Democratic debate in Charleston, S.C., that he would be willing to hold direct talks, without preconditions, with the president of Iran. This week, President Obama will have the chance to do just that, when Iran's fiery, diminutive, Israel-bashing, legitimacy-challenged president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, joins Mr. Obama and other world leaders who are descending on New York City to speak at the first United NationsGeneral Assembly in the new kinder, gentler, Barack Obama era.

HAPPY DAYS A lot of my married friends take a vicarious interest in my personal life. It's usually just nosy, prurient fun, but sometimes smacks of the sort of moralism that H. G. Wells called ''jealousy with a halo.'' At 42, I've never been married and don't want kids. I recently had dinner with some old friends, a couple with two small children, and when I told them about my typical Saturday in New York City -- doing the Times crossword puzzle, stopping off at a local flea market, maybe biking across the Brooklyn Bridge -- they looked at me as if I was describing my battles with the fierce and elusive Squid-Men among the moons of Neptune. The obscene wealth of free time at my command must've seemed unimaginably exotic to them, since their next thousand Saturdays are already booked.

DON'T get her wrong. Victoria Beckham loves a mini -- a cut-up-to-there little nothing of a dress, like the Lilliputian Giles Deacon sheath she wore on Fashion's Night Out. But as a designer Ms. Beckham has become known for her corset dress: a long, lean hourglass number that falls, Joan Holloway-style, just below the knee. ''It's timeless,'' she said last week as she presented her spring designs, updated with a little shoulder padding. ''And flattering on everybody.'' Perhaps that is the reason for the proliferation this fall of dresses that hit at the knees and hug the curves. Or, maybe, after a couple seasons of bum-grazing rocker dresses, the silhouette simply seems fresher and more

As the 2009 I.B.A.F. World Cup of Baseball finishes its second round this weekend, the United States finds itself poised to potentially repeat as champions in a tournament in which it has traditionally fared poorly. Led by the power hitters Pedro Alvarez, ranked No. 12 in Baseball America's Top 100 prospect list, and Justin Smoak, ranked No. 23, the United States, ranked No. 4 by the I.B.A.F., is 4-0 in the second round after going 2-1 in the first round with the help of eight innings of two-hit pitching from the Braves prospect Todd Redmond.

(CBS) THE 61ST PRIMETIME EMMY AWARDSNeil Patrick Harris, left, who almost single-handedly boosted ratings as host of the Tony Awards, tries to spin the same magic for this ceremony, broadcast live from the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles -- and maybe take home a statuette for comedy supporting actor for ''How I Met Your Mother.'' For Mets fans who have not suffered enough this year, conjuring the memory of Art Howe could finish them off. But the cold, irrefutable numbers require the mention of Howe, who presided over two of the least inspiring seasons in Mets history. After defeating the Washington Nationals, 3-2, on Saturday, the Mets are on pace to win 70 games, which would be their worst performance since they won 66 in 2003, Howe's first year as the manager.

How dangerous is Florida A&M's LeRoy Vann? Well, he returned two punts for touchdowns, going 95 and 80 yards, in the Rattlers' victory against Winston-Salem State on Sept. 10. It was the first time in team history that a player had returned two punts for scores, and it gave Vann five touchdowns on punt returns in his career, another team record. (Last season, he had three touchdowns on punt returns and three others on kickoff returns).

STERN--Matilde, (nee Bloch), born March 17, 1910 in Pforzheim, Germany-died September 4, 2009. Resided in Frankfurt, Barcelona, Cape Town, then New York. She will be greatly missed by son Carlos, daughter Barbara Garris, grandchildren Leslie, Pauline, David, Michael, great-grandchildren Julian and Arianna, relatives and friends world-wide.

STARRING--Nancy Donaldson, formerly of Mount Kisco, NY, died on September 11 in Tucson, AZ, from injuries sustained in a car accident. She was 83 years old. Mrs. Starring was raised in Ardsley-on-Hudson and Millbrook, NY, the daughter of Renee duPont Donaldson and John Willcox Donaldson and the granddaughter of Senator T. Coleman duPont (R.-Del.) of Wilmington and Dr. Frank Donaldson of Baltimore. She graduated from Oldfields School in Glencoe, MD, attended Finch College, and then became a noted medical illustrator for Dr. George Humphreys, the chief of surgery at New York Presbyterian Hospital during the Second World War; her illustrations are still in the archives there. She married Mason B. Starring 3rd of Irvington, NY, in 1947. After living in Washington, DC, where her husband was with the CIA, Mrs. Starring moved to Mount Kisco when he worked on Wall Street. She was active in the Mount Kisco community, and was instrumental in building the original Cisqua School there; later she served as chairman of the alumnae association at Oldfields. Mrs. Starring became a well-respected landscape architect in Westchester and Fairfield Counties; she was also an avid tennis player, pianist and Broadway lover. After moving from Mount Kisco, she had homes in New Canaan, CT, Portsmouth, NH, Tucson and Antigua, West Indies. Mrs. Starring was a former member of the Jupiter Club of Hobe Sound, FL, and the Mill Reef Club in Antigua; she had been an honorary member of the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club in Bedford, NY. She was predeceased by her husband and two brothers, Malcolm and Coleman Donaldson. She is survived by her daughter, Renee S. Janssen (and her husband Peter A. Janssen) of Fairfield, CT; her son, The Rev. Malcolm F. Starring (and his wife Jan Starring) of Littleton, NH; five grandchildren, John and Brian Cartwright, and Katherine Ang, Caroline Simon, and Paul Starring; eight great-grandchildren and her brother John W. Donaldson of Tucson. Burial will be in the family cemetery in Wilmington at a future date.

GOODY--Joan. Noted Boston architect Joan Goody died of pancreatic cancer on September 8 at her home on Beacon Hill. Elegant and smart, stylish and witty, Goody left her imprint on Boston, improving its civic and architectural profile. She was the senior member of Goody Clancy, a firm known for its award-winning work in preservation--Massachusetts State House, Harvard Yard and Trinity Church; for its city planning--the transformation at Harbor Point from a dismal housing project into a mixed-income neighborhood; and for its work for universities projects at Harvard, Yale and Brown among them. She was chair of the Boston Civic Design Commission, where she championed humanistic qualities in architecture, and received a lifetime achievement award from the Boston Society of Architects. Ms. Goody had taught at Harvard and was president of Boston's Saturday Club where Professor Charles Fried described her as "gifted, serious and focused". A fellow of the American Institute of Architects, Ms. Goody grew up in Flatbush, crediting her years at the Ethical Culture School with fostering confidence and creativity. She graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Cornell University in 1956 and earned her MA from the Harvard Graduate School of Design. In 1960 she married Marvin Goody and joined his growing firm. He died in 1980. Four years later Ms. Goody married Peter Davison, poet and editor, and was again widowed twenty years later. She is survived by her loving stepchildren, Lesley Davison of West Palm Beach, Angus Davison of Belmont, four grandchildren and a cousin, Janice Bennett of New York. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to MGH Palliative Care Service, 55 Fruit Street, Boston MA 02114.
International BARRELS OF GOOD WILL,

Allow a laboratory mouse to run as much as it likes, and its brainpower improves. Force it to run harder than it otherwise might, and its thinking improves even more. This is the finding of an experiment led by researchers at National Cheng Kung University in Taiwan and placed online in May. In the study, scientists had two groups of mice swim a water maze and in a separate trial had them endure an unpleasant stimulus to see how quickly they would learn to move away from it. For the next four weeks they allowed one group of mice to run inside their rodent wheels, an activity most mice enjoy, while requiring the other group to push harder on minitreadmills at a speed and duration controlled by the scientists. They then tested both groups again to track their learning skills and memory. Both groups of mice performed admirably in the water maze, bettering their performances from the earlier trial. But only the treadmill runners were better in the avoidance task, a skill that, according to brain scientists, demands a more complicated cognitive response. The mice who raced on the treadmills showed evidence of molecular changes in several portions of their brains when viewed under a microscope, while the voluntary wheel-runners had changes in only one area. ''Our results support the notion that different forms of exercise induce neuroplasticity changes in different brain regions,'' Chauying J. Jen, a professor of physiology and an author of the study, says.

RUDNICK--Selma, passed on September 13. Beloved wife of the late Norman, mother of Evan and Paul, and sister to Hilda and Lil. Selma worked for Partisan Review, the Pennsylvania Ballet and the All Star Forum, and she loved dance, the theater, poetry, fresh flowers, Marim- ekko dresses and above all, her many treasured friends. She will be missed and celebrated.

Miles. The minimum number of miles that the actor and cross-dressing comedian Eddie Izzard ran nearly every day over seven weeks on his 1,100 mile run across Britain to raise money for Sport Relief, a British charity. Mr. Izzard, 47, who appeared in FX's ''The Riches,'' and the movie ''Valkyrie,'' trained for five weeks. ''The small toes have lost their nails and they look like alien monsters but I'm told they will grow back,'' he said after staggering across the finish line in Trafalgar Square.

YOU'D think someone controlling billions of dollars in assets would live on Park or even Fifth Avenue. But Lexington Avenue is a street of surprises, including Bernard Madoff's former apartment house at the corner of East 64th Street, built in 1927 for a Social Register crowd that eschewed the typical well-to-do East Side address for an old shoe life in the slow lane. Compared with the prestige of Fifth, Madison and Park, Lexington above 59th is a sort of hand-me-down address, with altered brownstones and midgrade apartment houses, in keeping with its lower rung on the social ladder.

Survived by sons Donald (Darien, CT) and Thomas (Wayland, MA), daughters Holly Grillo (Nashua, NH) Barbara Quinn (Wickford, RI), nephew John Boyd (Colum-bia, SC), niece Nina Mahaffey (Santa Barbara, CA), nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

They managed two sacks, but more important, they hit the opposing quarterback, Matt Schaub, nine times, including four hits by linebacker Bart Scott. To beat Brady and New England, pressure will be paramount. Coach Rex Ryan likes to send different Jets to different gaps at different times, be they safeties, cornerbacks or linebackers. Against the Texans, Ryan even blitzed Kris Jenkins, a 360-pound nose tackle, from the middle linebacker position.

The Transportation Security Administration is introducing yet another security layer to the passenger-screening process. Now, in addition to removing shoes, belts and laptops and being limited to liquids of no more than 3.4 ounces in a zip-top plastic bag, passengers may be stopped if they are carrying what security personnel consider suspicious looking powder. Using a new kind of explosives-detection technology, the agency has begun screening certain powders at airport checkpoints by taking a sample of the powder and doing an on-the-spot test.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

The Fordham defense kept slamming into Columbia quarterback M. A. Olawale on Saturday, then growling at him. But he kept popping up, looking to the sideline for the next play. A white towel stayed in the belt of his pants, and his white socks never sagged below midcalf. The Lions won only two games last year, and Columbia made it apparent early Saturday that it will lean heavily on the unflappable Olawale, a senior who would like to be a doctor. He responded by pushing Columbia to a surprising 40-28 road victory in the Lions' season opener at Coffey Field.

IT was no way to treat a senior citizen: sending a 1959 Chevrolet Bel Air hurtling into a collision with a 2009 Malibu, with both cars traveling 40 miles an hour. As the video produced by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety shows, the outcome wasn't pretty. The windshield dislodges, the driver's door opens and the front half of the Bel Air goes through something between crumbling and what looks like imploding as the dummy in the driver's seat flies around like Peter Pan.

ENCOURAGED to take photographs by his friend and mentor James Dean, Dennis Hopper carried a camera everywhere in the 1960s, prodigiously shooting the artists, musicians, movie stars and fashion designers who would define his generation. Among the 600 roles of film that survived are wonderfully intimate images of Ike and Tina Turner playing music at Mr. Hopper's house, Andy Warhol and crew hanging out at the Factory (top left), Jane Fonda fooling around on the beach in Malibu (bottom left), Peggy Moffitt sharing a moment with the art dealer Irving Blum (center) and Rudi Gernreich posing with his models. All of them, along with several large-scale paintings, are now on view at the Tony Shafrazi Gallery in Chelsea. ''Yeah, they used to tease me, 'Oh, here comes the tourist,' '' Mr. Hopper recalled in ''Dennis Hopper: Photographs, 1961-1967,'' an extensive companion book that lends insight into his images and subjects. Of Mr. Gernreich: ''He was quite the sensation ... and one of the first people to actually pay me to take photos, which I was always thankful for.''

SIMON--Melvin. Mel was a real estate visionary who changed the very fabric of retailing in America. We have lost a dear friend who was larger than life and will be missed tremendously. We offer our deepest condolences to Mel's loving family. Suzy, Richard, Jean and Paul Finkelstein

MADERIA--Lewis Neilson, died peacefully at his home on Jupiter Island on September 14. He was 90 years old. Mr. Madeira was born on the "Main Line" of Philadelphia, until he went to The St. George's School in Newport, RI. He later became a lifetime Trustee, was President of the Board of Trustees for many years, and leaves Madeira Hall in his name. He attended The University of Pennsylvania where he was an enthusiastic athlete. While there, he joined the First City Troop. He served his country as an Artillery Captain in World War II in the South Pacific, and in Korea. Upon returning home from service, he co-founded Amtrol, Inc. in West Warwick, RI. Mr. Madeira was an accomplished angler and golfer. His clubs included The Jupiter Island Club, Seminole Golf Club, and The Anglers Club, all near his home in Florida. Also, Piping Rock, The Hope Club, The Dunes Club and Point Judith. The Ekwanok Country Club in Manchester was near his summer residence in Vermont. He took great pride in his sport fishing and cruising boats. Mr. Madeira was driven by service and some of those accomplishment included being the President of Save the Bay, and the Atlantic Tuna Club. He was a Commissioner for the Town of Jupiter Island for eight years. He was a member of the Christ Memorial Chapel Vestry Board. He Chaired the Jupiter Island Club Dock Committee and was a member of the Buildings and Ground and Employee Education Fund Committees. He is survived by his wife Joan Dillon Hay Madeira and his brother Harry Madeira; his daughter Ann Madeira Leonard and daughter in-law Ellen Leahy Madeira, wife of his late son Lewis N. Madeira, Jr. (Sandy); his grandchildren, Aaron Hoffman, Tyler and Sarah Leonard, and David and Lawrence Madeira. He also leaves eight great-grandchildren and is warmly remembered by his stepchildren John, David, Sandra, and Laura Hay, and Lisa Hay Morrin. A memorial service will be held at Christ Memorial Chapel on Jupiter Island in early December by the family. The St. George's School of Newport, RI will be having a service on December 12th. In lieu of flowers, donations to Treasure Coast Hospice of Stuart, FL would be much appreciated.

Wasted as one of Nora Walker's ex beaus on the dependably awful ''Brothers & Sisters,'' Chevy Chase has received material more worthy of his gifts for satiric smugness on ''Community,'' a funny, single-camera comedy on NBC, about college life far removed from Cambridge. As Pierce Hawthorne, a retired entrepreneur who made his fortune in disposable wipes, Mr. Chase does ludicrous entitlement to the hilt, playing someone so bored that he searches for his Act II at Greendale Community College. The character's turtleneck and beads telegraph New Age delusions, but it is his self-satisfied political incorrectness that reveals just how moronically out of it Hawthorne really is. ''I've been divorced seven times,'' he says. ''Sometimes I think I'm doing something wrong.'' Just try to out-deadpan Mr. Chase on a line like that.

After being criticized for allowing 77 points and 1,000 yards in losses to Colorado State and Toledo, Colorado defeated Wyoming, 24-0, the Buffaloes' second shutout under Dan Hawkins.

OPENING CEREMONY'S kicky faux-fur collection, inspired by the forthcoming Spike Jonze film adaptation of ''Where the Wild Things Are,'' isn't your average movie merch. With its savage three-quarter coats and slightly surrealist bell skirts, it doesn't scream obsessed film fan. Slightly kooky fashion devotee, maybe. ''We wanted everything to stand out on its own,'' said Humberto Leon of Opening Ceremony. ''The fact that each piece is inspired by the film's characters is like a great hidden secret.'' Designed in collaboration with Mr. Jonze, the collection also includes jewelry by Pamela Love -- mixed-metal pieces festooned with feathers and claws, and etched with slash marks like those the wild things make as they're running through the forest. ''It's such a beautiful movie, so full of emotion,'' Mr. Leon said. ''We wanted to capture some of that.''
Television Ginia Bellafante

All journalists want to write a story that makes a big splash. John T. Elson, the religion editor at Time magazine, was no exception. But in 1966 he got more than he bargained for. For more than a year, Mr. Elson had labored over an article examining radical new approaches to thinking about God that were gaining currency in seminaries and universities and spilling over to the public at large.

''Good habits formed at youth make all the difference,'' Aristotle said. Maybe the recent financial crisis could have been averted if some of its players had practiced basic principles of money management as children. In an effort to turn future generations into better financial stewards, Naomi Schachter, president of Financially Free, runs Camp Millionaire for children. At a session last month in Allentown, Pa., participants learned about money, work, savings and investments through role playing, games and other activities.

MILLER--Mary Lib. The "First Lady of Harness Racing" and the widow of Hall-of-Famer Delvin G. Miller, passed away September 1, 2009, at her home in Bay Hill, Orlando, FL. Mrs. Miller was born December 6, 1920, in Winston-Salem, NC. She married Delvin Glenn Miller, a harness horse trainer and driver, in 1946. The Millers purchased Meadow Lands Farm in Meadow Lands, PA, converting the farm into a major breeding operation with the purchase of their prolific stallion, Adios. In 1963 Mr. Miller founded The Meadows race track which hosted the Adios Stake every August (now the Delvin Miller Adios) and Grand Circuit racing for a week. The Miller home was renowned throughout the trotting world as a center of hospitality. Beginning in the 1960s, the Millers developed Meadowcroft Village near Avella, PA, as a museum of 19th century rural life, providing a charming and educational destination for thousands of Western Pennsylvania school children and families. The Miller Museum on the site chronicles Mr. Miller's family history and his extraordinary eight decade career in harness racing. Mrs. Miller served as a Trustee of the Harness Racing Museum & Hall of Fame in Goshen, NY. In 2007, the harness writers and the harness racing community of Pennsylvania established the Mary Lib Miller Award for outstanding contribution to Pennsylvania Harness Racing. There will be a memorial service to celebrate Mary Lib Miller's life on September 28, at 11am at Meadowcroft Village, Avella, PA, followed by a reception for family and friends.

I WAS walking in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, near the Outpost Cafe on Fulton Street, when I noticed that the mugwort plants on the block had gone to seed and become quite rangy. Then I discovered an odor and a fan-shaped leaf under my clogs. This is how you usually find ginkgo. You're ambling innocently along a city block enjoying one of those lovely days that Billie Holiday was crooning about, when suddenly you notice a smell so putrid that you stop in your tracks and the moment is interrupted like a needle flying off a record. You think, Why don't people pick up after their dogs?
FALL ALL

Julianna Margulies, 'The Good Wife' Julianna Margulies has appeared on television only sporadically since she left ''ER'' nearly a decade ago, and for this viewer absence did not make the heart grow fonder. Her appearance as a hard-drinking, ethics-schmethics defense lawyer on the short-lived Fox drama ''Canterbury's Law'' only made the heart grow annoyed. But Ms. Margulies's hardened vulnerability leaves her perfectly suited to the title role on ''The Good Wife,'' a CBS series that seeks to capture the essence of the age as a net might trap a butterfly. Standing beside her philandering political husband at his penance-seeking news conference, Ms. Margulies deftly balances loss and disgust with a determination to reclaim an identity long ago submerged. She is a better Jenny Sanford than Jenny Sanford.

GIVEN THE LIMITATIONS OF HIS ROLE, that of a poor but handsome sex-object abused by the rich women at Kellerman's Mountain House, Mr. Swayze is also good. He's at his best--as is the movie--when he's dancing. --Review of ''Dirty Dancing'' by Vincent Canby in The New York Times. Patrick Swayze died last week at the age of 57.

A signature look has emerged: draped dresses worn with shoes that make a statement, often with killer heels. The combination is what many of the most stylish guests chose to wear last week to the New York designer collections. After the shows, women were frequently seen changing to flip-flops. But no one is going to give up those heels. The 1940s draping is breathing new life into the one-piece dress. It also sometimes appears only on a skirt or a neckline. Care should be taken with draping, however; it can look matronly. As for handbags, they have been completely eclipsed by the shoe. One of the big surprises at the showings was the presentation of Tory Burch, who had championed flats, but this time showed her models in high heels (inset).

X-MEN ORIGINS: WOLVERINE The Marvel superhero with animal senses, retractable claws and an adamantium skeleton (Hugh Jackman) and how he got that way, directed by the South African filmmaker Gavin Hood (''Tsotsi''). With Liev Schreiber, Taylor Kitsch and Ryan Reynolds. A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times in May that, ''the outsize emotions that give any decent superhero epic its adolescent, pop-operatic gravity are diminished by the sheer hectic confusion of the storytelling.'' He is survived by his wife Barbara Dominick, his children Nick, Wendy, Molly and Seth Dominick, three stepchildren and five grandchildren. Friends may call at the Powelton Club in Newburgh, October 2 from 4-6.

World War II pilot; Yale graduate '45; US Hockey Olympian, 1948; radio and television advertising, New York, Hartford, Boston; outdoors adventurer; companion extraordinaire.

MITRANI--Victor, on August 7, 2009, age 86. Adored husband of Dodi (Degenshein). Loving father and grandfather. Raised in Bloomsburg, PA, Vic served his community as a Boy Scout, honorary fireman; and to his country as a WWII Lt. in the European Theatre. A Repatriation Officer in Salzburg, Vic helped transfer thousands of displaced persons; and was part of an underground network assisting Jews who desperately wanted to get to Palestine. Treasurer for Mitrani Family Foundation 1960-76, and Sales VP, 1960-75, for Milco Industries, Bloomsburg and NYC. Former member Lone Star Boat Club. Giving his time for NY Executive Volunteer Corps, Vic helped hundreds of entrepreneurs realize their dreams. Always a gentleman, Vic will never be forgotten.

BACHER--Donald. On August 21st, 2009, Don, 78, husband of Constance; father of Stephen, Christopher, Pamela, Julie, and Kerry MacNayr; stepfather of Peter Andrews; brother of Fred; and grandfather of six passed away peacefully at his home in Littleton, New Hampshire, surrounded by his family. He attended Dartmouth College (class of 1953), received his law degree from Boston University and served in the Naval Air Corps. As a legal editor for Matthew Bender & Co., as in his life, he would separate the wheat from the chaff and find the salient pearls of wisdom in the voluminous noise and excess that permeates our legal system and lives. Although he hated all things technological, he was one of the first to work "virtually," starting in 1970 when there were no personal computers -- he lived in Vermont and New Hampshire and sent his work to New York. A longtime member of the New Hampshire Civil Liberties Union, Don filed a key case against the controversial Seabrook Nuclear Power Plant arguing that consumers should not be charged the costs of the plant while it was under construction a position later written into law by the NH State Legislature. Later, in a much-publicized case, he took up and prevailed on an issue of church/state separation regarding religious works on public property. His pro bono ACLU activities and donations, and his lifetime of legal reference work made and continue to make a significant impact on NH and federal law. Don's passions were his children, just causes, gourmet food, tennis, wine, travel, opera and organic gardening, not necessarily in that order. His undoubtedly correct and unwavering opinions were never influenced by others. He possessed a dry wit and an intellect that never ceased to amuse, entertain and provoke thought in those around him. He was an anchor in the storm and a voice of reason amidst the chaos. As a father, he successfully imparted his humor, values, ethics and goodness to all his six children, and with his unfailing kindness and generosity could always evoke a smile, even in the most difficult of times. He will be sorely missed by his family, friends and those whose lives he touched. The family suggests that in lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the New Hampshire branch of the American Civil Liberties Union (NHCLU) in memory of Donald Bacher.

“The 39 Steps,” the longest-running play of any Broadway production to open in the last seven years, will conclude its two-year run on Jan. 10, 2010, its publicists announced Monday. By that date it will have played 771 performances in New York, starting on Jan. 4, 2008, and officially opening Jan. 15 at Roundabout Theater Company’s American Airlines Theater. It moved that April to the Cort Theater, and then, in January of this year, to the Helen Hayes Theater, where it will remain through its last months.

The “Tosca” that makes its debut tonight at the Metropolitan Opera is bound to annoy a least a few opera patrons. It abandons the sumptuousness and true-to-life quality of the long-ensconced production by Franco Zeffirelli, whose renditions of the classic Italian operas are slowly being phased out at the house. The new production, by Luc Bondy, is a stripped-down affair, of a piece with the Swiss director’s starker, darker stage view.

Update | 11:30 p.m. The boos poured out loudly and lustily after the Metropolitan Opera’s gala opening night performance of Puccini’s “Tosca” Monday night. The vocal thumbs down was not directed at the voices. Karita Mattila, who sang Tosca, and her tenor co-star, Marcelo Alvarez as Cavaradossi, received healthy ovations. So did James Levine, the Met’s music director and the conductor that night.

MINNEAPOLIS - A few days ago, catcher Joe Mauer of the Minnesota Twins told reporters he was more focused on the American League Central divisional race than winning his third batting title, even though to do so would be historic. Mauer, if he can hold off Seattle's Ichiro Suzuki, will be the first catcher in baseball history to win three. Ernie Lombardi earned two with the Cincinnati Reds, in 1938 and 1942. The received wisdom is that President Obama had a bad August and a not so great early September, what with contentious town-hall meetings, high unemployment numbers, falling poll numbers, less than firm support from members of his own party, biting Republican attacks on Obama-care, questions about his citizenship and his loyalty, dark suspicions of his motives for speaking to schoolchildren, comparisons with Hitler, accusations of socialism and being branded in public as a liar. He has been criticized for not making his case, and for making his case too often (see Mark Leibovich's piece on overexposure). Every speech he makes is said to be the speech on which the viability of his presidency depends. Expectations of a Republican revival, once abysmally low, rise every day. Commentators predict that it will soon be 1994 in America again.

If you've hit the Appalachian Trail in recent months and you feel like it's been a bit more crowded than usual, you may not be imagining things. According to a front-page article in The Wall Street Journal, a number of the newly unemployed have decided to take this forced time off and realize the dream of a lifetime: walking the entire 2,200-mile stretch of the Appalachian Trail from Georgia to Maine. The Journal cites trail monitors who estimated that more than 1,400 hikers set out from northern Georgia this spring, a significant jump from the normal average of 1,000, with hundreds more "thru-hikers" joining the route as the summer progressed.

In my Findings column, I discuss reasons for the longevity gap between the United States and most other developed countries. Our shorter life expectancy has often been blamed on the health-care system's failings. But after looking at mortality trends and treatment patterns, Samuel H. Preston and Jessica Y. Ho of the University of Pennsylvania reach another verdict: "We conclude that the low longevity ranking of the United States is not likely to be a result of a poorly functioning health-care system."

LONDON - Saturday began with a joint presentation by two of London's most buzzed-about designers, Mark Fast and Mary Katranzou. This season, Katranzou pumped up the psychedelia of her prints, which had an auto-body airbrushed effect. Fast showed new versions of his skintight knitwear in more subtle tones of khaki, lilac and buff; soft ruffles added a new dimension. Most notable was his use of plus-size models. Natalie Hubbard, his casting director told me at his after-party that Fast had changed both his stylist and lineup at the last second, looking for more diversity. The new designer Sykes also broke the casting norm and showed models of all different ages. Louise Gray had an upbeat presentation made all the more vibrant with accessory gems made by Judy Blame and by the presence of Blame himself, who was wearing a baseball hat with a customized chain veil shielding his face. Pam Hogg's fun show gathered together Boy George, Roisin Murphy, Siouxsie Sioux and Peaches Geldof in the front row. Hogg's friends Alice Dellal, Anouck Lepere, Daisy Lowe and Liberty Ross walked in the show. Later that night, Mark Fast had an intimate dance party at the Groucho, where Alison Mosshart from the Kills spun a mostly '60s set. Drea Hemmingway, Natalia Vodianova and Nicholas Kirkwood joined Fast on the dance floor, the "It" girls in his sexy dresses and Fast in buffalo plaid flannel.

When Ken Friedman's newest restaurant, the Breslin, opens on Oct. 8 at the Ace Hotel, few diners will know the hours spent debating table F-209. "It's 10 inches too long," Friedman says in a worried voice a few weeks before opening. He's sitting at the booth with Robin Standefer, a partner in the design firm Roman and Williams, which helped design both the restaurant and the hotel (the Standard and the Royalton hotels, too). "It'll be difficult to slide into the booth," she agrees and whips out a tape measure. The two contemplate the 10 inches glumly; never before has 10 inches been so glumly contemplated.

LONDON - As if we needed further proof that models look good even when they look bad. ... I was speaking with Dree Hemingway at the Mark Fast after-party in London yesterday and was complimenting her on her new peroxide blond hair, which reminded me of the Proenza Schouler show. Hemingway said she had gone to the Proenza Schouler casting straight from her flight from London and that her hair had been dirty and stringy and darker at roots. They took a few Polaroids and let her go. Later, Hemingway's friend, the hairstylist Didier Malige, told her that the designers ended up using her Polaroids as inspiration for the hair in the show.

Among the many debuts at this week's London Design Festival, the British magazine editor-turned-designer and creative director Ilse Crawford brings us Seating for Eating, a collection of settles, benches and stools in solid walnut with copper feet. The pieces, which are made by De La Espada, are described on Crawford's Web site as "reassuringly familiar but carefully detailed" - which, in fact, describes a lot of Crawford's interiors for restaurants, clubs and hotels, from Manhattan's Soho House to the venerable London dining spot Kettner's.

The Scarlet, the new 36-room hotel on England's Cornwall coast, is notable not so much for its rich modernist details - infinity pools, giant glass walls with views of the beach below - but for its thoughtful eco-minded design. Set on National Trust-protected land, the hotel has an indoor pool heated using solar panel energy and an outdoor swimming area filled with captured rainwater and filtered by reeds and other sieving plants that stand in for chlorine. Log fires warm the giant red teacup-shaped seaweed hot tubs overlooking the sea. The hotel also harvests its gray water, which is eco-speak for recycling the water that flows from showers and bathtubs and using it to flush the toilets. And the roof is planted with more than 5,000 plugs of sage-colored sea thrift to collect rainwater runoff. Over time, the sea thrift will multiply and eventually cover the structure enough that it will resemble a hanging garden on the sea cliff.

This past week, I visited a place that newspapers forgot, or was it the other way around? While working on an article about Time Inc.'s decision to parachute into Detroit for a year, I tried to get used to the fact that the newspapers there get delivered only three days a week and the other days, it is tough to find them. Too bad, because between a city where stories seem to lie around every corner and with such a really talented bunch of journalists on hand, it would be nice to have a newspaper plop into the middle of things more often. Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about James S. McDonald, the chief executive of Rockefeller & Company, a wealth-management firm, referred incorrectly to Harvard College, suggesting it had changed its name since he graduated from it. Its name then was the same as it is now; he did not graduate “from what was the Harvard College.”.

A review on Wednesday of the documentary “The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers,” about the man who leaked a classified history of the Vietnam War, misstated the source of that history. It was prepared by the Defense Department, not the RAND Corporation, where Mr. Ellsberg, a former Pentagon analyst who had contributed to the history, went to work.

A headline in some editions on Friday with an article about the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, misstated the amount of money the company raised in credit markets. The amount was $2.9 billion, not $2.6 billion.

An article in the Personal Tech pages on Sept. 10 reported on smartphone applications to help in fitness and diet programs, including a Calorie Tracker application from LiveStrong.com that was described as free for the iPhone and iPod Touch. After the article was published, it was learned that while the application was free upon its introduction in November 2008, in March 2009 LiveStrong began charging $2.99 to iPhone and iPod Touch users, the same price it charges for BlackBerry users.

An article in some editions on Thursday about Ernie Harwell, the longtime voice of the Detroit Tigers, who has incurable cancer, referred incorrectly to the start of his broadcasting career. He began as a radio commentator in Atlanta in 1940; his start did not come in 1948 with the Brooklyn Dodgers.

An article in some editions on Friday about the changing composition of the City Council, poised to consist of more minority members than white ones for the first time starting in January, gave an outdated title for Frank J. Macchiarola, who was chairman of a redistricting commission in 1990 and 1991. He is chancellor of St. Francis College in Brooklyn, no longer its president.

The NYC column on Friday, about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s apparent attempt to upstage his rival, William C. Thompson Jr., by holding a rally the same night Mr. Thompson won the Democratic primary, rendered the name of the publisher of a Bloomberg biography incorrectly. It is PublicAffairs, not Public Affairs.

An article on Sept. 11 about cost-cutting methods used by clothing designers included an incorrect statement by Oscar de la Renta about the source of silk faille used by Prada. While Mr. de la Renta said he uses faille from South Korea, Prada says it buys silk only from Italian mills and has not been using the South Korean fabric.

LUCKS--Dr. Abe H.,devoted physician, died peacefully on September 19, 2009 at age 98. Dr. Lucks, formerly of Cedarhurst, NY, is survived by his beloved wife of 67 years, Vivian Kramer Lucks, and by his cherished children, Karen and Dr. Steven Metzger, and Joan and Paul Feinstein. He was an adoring grandfather to Marcie Nadler (Simon), Debbie Falik (Adam), Leslie Levin (Marc), and Ross Feinstein, and loving great grandfather to eight great-grandchildren. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1911 to Jennie and Karl Lucks, Dr. Lucks attended Boys High School, Brooklyn College of Pharmacy, and the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine. Dr. Lucks was a board certified family practitioner. He practiced pharmacy and medicine at the same address in South Ozone Park, NY for over 70 years, and was recognized by "Ripley's Believe It or Not!" for this achievement. He was extraordinarily devoted to his patients, revered and respected by all. His happiest moments were spent surrounded by his entire family. As the patriarch of the family, he was a role model and imparted his strong work ethic, moral principles, and most importantly, the love and devotion of family. A funeral will be held on Tuesday, September 22, 2009 at 10:30am at Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Avenue, Rye, NY.

Acknowledging once again that humans are better than computer algorithms at some tasks, Google said on Wednesday that it had acquired ReCaptcha, a start-up that grew out of a research project at Carnegie Mellon, for an undisclosed amount. Captchas are those strange word puzzles that Web sites use to distinguish humans from automated spamming software and other nasty ''bots.'' ReCaptcha, founded by the inventor of the captcha, the computer scientist Luis von Ahn, puts this test to practical use, taking words from decaying old newspapers and other texts that computers can't read and letting people identify them, thus proving that they are people.

KOGAN--Marjorie D.,at Lenox Hill Hospital on September 20 after a long illness. Predeceased by her husband, Nathan B. Kogan, she is survived by her sons, Michael and Barton Kogan and by her sister Jeanne R. Theodore. Mrs. Kogan was active for many years in New York City politics, civic affairs and philanthropy. She shaped and lead the volunteer program at the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men and founded and chaired the "Services to Adolescence through the Release of Tension" (S.T.A.R.T.) program at Riker's Island Prison to assist inmates. She chaired the election campaigns of her dear fiend, Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley and served as Executive Aide to Manhattan Borough Presidents Motley and Percy Sutton. Mrs. Kogan was a founding member of Manhattan's Community Board Eight on which she served for many decades. She was appointed by Mayor Abraham Beame to the New York City Board of Corrections. She served as long-time President of the philanthropic Brand Foundation of New York. She was a tireless fighter for civic betterment in many areas of her beloved city's life. Her dedication, her warmth and charm, her lively humor and kind heart will be missed by all whose lives she touched. The family will receive visitors Tuesday evening, September 22 form 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral Services on Wednesday, September 23 at 11:30am at Campbell's. Interment follows at Beth Olam Cemetery. Shiva will be observed Wednesday evening from 7-9pm at Mrs. Kogan's home and on Thursday from 7-9pm at Congregation Shomrei Emunah, 67 Park St., Montclair, NJ.

Count the American speedskater Catherine Raney among the athletes, coaches and officials of several sports surprised by Canada's approach to hosting the Winter Games in February. Raney, who spent more than seven years living in Canada and training with the Canadian national team, was told after the 2006 Olympics that the Canadians did not want foreign athletes training with them leading to the 2010 Games in Vancouver.

OXENBERG--Elliott, died peacefully at home on September 18, 2009. He was the husband of Cynthia, father of Ruth, uncle of Julia, father-in-law of Rob and grandfather of Clea, Ted and Tristan. A Greenwich Village dentist for many years, Elliott deeply loved jazz music and played beautiful piano. He was a graceful downhill skier and continued to dream about days on the slopes through his two year struggle with Lewy Body Dementia. He had a long life, well lived, with love for people at the heart of it. A memorial will be held this fall.

Horace Carter, the editor and publisher of a small-town North Carolina newspaper whose stubborn, angry opposition to local activities of the Ku Klux Klan helped quell the expansion of the Klan in the Carolinas and won a Pulitzer Prize in 1953, died Wednesday while being transported from a hospital in Wilmington, N.C., to his home in nearby Tabor City. He was 88. The cause was a heart attack, the second one Mr. Carter had suffered within 10 days, his son, Russell, said.

In television, nothing succeeds like success. So it was Sunday night at the 61st annual Primetime Emmy Awards, where five of the top six categories featured repeat winners from last year. ''30 Rock'' and ''Mad Men,'' which garnered the most nominations in their respective comedy and drama categories, took home the top awards yet again. NBC's ''30 Rock'' won the best comedy award for the third straight year, while AMC's ''Mad Men'' won best drama for the second straight time. Tina Fey, the creator of ''30 Rock,'' which focuses on the backstage action at a comedy series much like ''Saturday Night Live,'' thanked the executives of NBC for keeping the show on the air despite its relatively low viewership and ''even though we are so much more expensive than a talk show.'' But backstage, she discounted the possibility of winning yet again next year. ''There's no way we're standing up here again,'' she said.

A creative and successful entrepreneur, a skilled photographer, a fine sailor, Leonard lovingly encouraged and inspired others to pursue their dreams. DUKE--Danielle Myriam, 74, died September 19, 2009. Devoted wife, mother and grandmother. Danielle was born on June 7, 1935 in Paris, France. Danielle was a Holocaust Survivor, surviving as a hidden child during the war. Danielle is survived by her husband, Jack, daughter and son-in-law, Michelle and Roger Nettler, son and daughter-in-law, Robert and Laurie Duke and four grandchildren, Deborah, Gabriella, Maxwell and Harrison. Danielle's family writes, "Our beloved Danielle lived her life with a generosity and caring that was truly felt by all who knew her. Danielle's bravery was an inspiration to us and we are honored to have been part of her life. Danielle will be deeply missed and her powerful spirit will live on with us forever." Services will be held on Tuesday, September 22 at 1pm at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza in Great Neck, NY.

Every so often, Britons like to measure their present against a past that time has in some ways overtaken, as doughty, imperial folk with a reach far beyond their island shores, suffused with a backs-to-the-wall fighting spirit, conjuring victory against the odds. From Shakespeare's Henry V rallying his troops against the French at Agincourt in 1415 to the English soccer team beating the West Germans in the 1966 World Cup, to coming out on the winning side in two world wars, this is a narrative built on the high points of national memory, a connect-the-dots guide to an old land's sense of what it has done, and can do, best.

FREEDMAN--Mae, on September 19, 2009 at age 86. Beloved wife of the late Jerry, sister of the late Murray and Rose, daughter of the late Louis and Rae Garfield, adored mother of Howard, Robert (Diane), Barry (Meryl) and Miles (Nora) Freedman, cherished grandmother of Sam, Jonathan, Justin, Harris, Lindsay, Hallie (Rick Grodin) and Ross (Beth) and exuberant great-grandmother of Jack. She will forever be missed by all who knew her and let's hope she hits the jackpot in heaven.

The receivers wore wristbands and the offense read from whiteboards held aloft on the sideline to improve communication. They ran a hurry-up offense the whole game. They moved players around to try to pick up the blitz. But nothing the New England Patriots tried Sunday in their 16-9 loss to the Jets could hide the obvious: Tom Brady is not himself, and the Patriots' offense is in disarray. Except for five magnificent minutes against the Buffalo Bills -- and a big gift from Leodis McKelvin in the form of a fumbled kickoff return in the last two minutes -- the Patriots have sputtered, and they would be 0-2, with tough home games against Atlanta and Baltimore in the next two weeks.

The central figure in what authorities describe as a widening inquiry into a possible plot to detonate explosives in the United States had been trained in weapons and explosives in Pakistan and, according to court papers released Sunday, had made nine pages of handwritten notes on how to make and handle bombs. The court papers, released after the arrests in Colorado of Najibullah Zazi and his father, as well as that of an imam in Queens, showed that during a search in New York of the younger Mr. Zazi's rental car on Sept. 11, agents found a laptop computer containing an image of the notes. According to a criminal complaint, the notes ''contain formulations and instructions regarding the manufacture and handling of initiating explosives, main explosives charges, explosives detonators and components of a fusing system.''
WRAY--Albert. Math teacher, musician, marvelous man, wonderfully eccentric character and friend, beloved by so many, especially me. I will miss you so! Your Sweet Love

When the finale of the 2009 PGA Tour playoffs for the FedEx Cup begins Thursday at East Lake Golf Club in Atlanta, many of the questions about the success of the multimillion-dollar conclusion to the official golf season in the United States will have been answered. Yes, the No. 1 seed is Tiger Woods, and he is the odds-on favorite to win the Tour Championship. And, yes, he could just as easily lose the Cup if any of the remaining top five seeds -- Steve Stricker, Jim Furyk, Zach Johnson or Heath Slocum -- can pull off a victory at East Lake.

A reader's comment in the Prescriptions column on Thursday in reaction to the health care proposal introduced by Senator Max Baucus misstated the maximum penalty a family might face under the plan for not having insurance coverage. As an accompanying article reported, the highest possible penalty would be $3,800 a year, not $1,500.

WARD--Marcia, 75, the loving wife of John, mother of Kathryn and grandmother of Marguerite passed away peacefully and suddenly on September 10th, 2009 at home in Florida. A gifted student, Marcia attended Bryn Mawr College for which she retained a lifelong love and attachment. A painter, a writer, a progressive thinker and a classical music lover, it was her good fortune to experience the cultures of numerous countries during her husband's international banking career. They lived in New York, Rio de Janeiro, and Paris for many years before retiring in Florida. Their great pleasure was to cruise around the world, circling and visiting many continents. Indeed, Marcia had a full life and will be remembered as a true, kind, decent, compassionate and charitable lady who will continue to live in the hearts of her friends and family and with the undying love of her husband, John.

The top 10 films from Memorial to Labor Day weekends earned just under $2.4 billion. The summer take had remained at about $2 billion from 2004 to 2006, and jumped to almost $2.5 billion in 2007, driven by several third-time installments.
