SMITH--Catharine Carton: Artist and art collector, family matriarch and long-time resident of the Hartford area, died on Friday, September 18 in Bloomfield, CT. She was 97. Born December 14, 1911 in Chicago, she married Paul P. Swett, Jr. in 1933. She and her family lived in West Hartford, CT, Washington, DC and Baltimore, MD. Mr. Swett died in 1980. In 1983 she married Olcott D. Smith and moved to Farmington, CT. Mr. Smith died in 2000. She moved in 2008 to the Duncaster Lifecare Community in Bloomfield. From age 14 on, she summered in Jamestown, RI. Mrs. Smith painted watercolors of sea and countryside and collected late 19th and early 20th century American landscapes. She played golf and tennis into her 80's and went sailing two months before she died. She was giving, gracious, relished her friends and cherished her family (more than 100 members at her death). Distinguished by her impeccable dress and manners, she looked for the best in others and tried always to be at her best. Survivors include her brother, Dr. Robert W. Carton of Winnetka, IL: two sisters-in-law; sons, Steven C. Swett of Norwich, VT and Thomas C. Swett of Unionville, PA (her son, Bradford N. Swett died in 2005); three daughters-in law, four step-children and their spouses; eight grandchildren, ten great grandchildren, twelve step- grandchildren, fifteen step-great grandchildren and dozens of nieces and nephews. She will be buried at Riverside Cemetery, Pleasant Valley, CT. A memorial service will be held at noon on Wednesday, October 7 at Old St. Andrews Episcopal Church, Bloomfield, CT.

Updated | 1:05 p.m. The prolific directors Harold Prince and Susan Stroman are planning a return to Broadway with a musical that they say will convey the grandeur and mystery of 19th-century Europe and the Middle East, feature several well-known Broadway performers and cost a mere $7 million.

Send in the clowns, and possibly a few scalpers: the long-rumored Broadway revival of “A Little Night Music” is officially a go, with a couple of big names joining the production. Publicists for the musical said on Tuesday that Catherine Zeta-Jones (an Academy Award-winner for “Chicago”) would make her Broadway debut in the revival, alongside Angela Lansbury (who recently won her fifth Tony Award, for “Blithe Spirit”) and Alexander Hanson, who also appeared in the production’s previous incarnations at the Menier Chocolate Factory and the Garrick Theater in London. The musical, directed by Trevor Nunn, is to begin previews at the Walter Kerr Theater on Nov. 24 and open on Dec. 13. Adapted from the Ingmar Bergman film “Smiles of a Summer Night,” “A Little Night Music” features a book by Hugh Wheeler and score by Stephen Sondheim, including perhaps his best-known song, “Send in the Clowns.”

For some, the Emmy Awards on Sunday may have represented the last of the important entertainment awards shows this year, but for many New York theatergoers and practitioners, there was yet another important event: The fifth annual New York Innovative Theater Awards, which were held on Monday night. Think of the IT Awards as a younger sibling of Tony and OBIE, one that honors achievement in Off Off Broadway theater.

In 14 short words, the CW network has turned around an otherwise pointless morning and given us reason to believe again: Heather Locklear will reprise her role as scheming vixen Amanda Woodward of “Melrose Place,” the network said Tuesday in a news release. (The word vixen was the network’s choice, not ours.)

Updated | 5:31 p.m. The thin, chilly air of Park City, Utah, proved beneficial to the independent films “Like Water for Chocolate” and “Little Miss Sunshine” when they had their premieres at the Sundance Film Festival. Will the warmer climes of Yulee, Fla., be as kind to musical adaptations of those movies that the Sundance Institute will produce there this fall? In a news release, the institute said that its Sundance Institute Theater Lab at White Oak would produce two stage projects from Oct. 25 through Nov. 7: The first is a musical version of “Little Miss Sunshine,” originally written by Michael Arndt and directed by Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris, with music and lyrics by William Finn (“Falsettos”) and a book by James Lapine (“Sunday in the Park With George,” “Into the Woods”), which Mr. Lapine will also direct. The second is a musical adaptation of “Like Water for Chocolate,” the Laura Esquivel novel and Alfonso Arau film, which will be composed by Lila Downs and Paul R. Cohen, with lyrics by Ms. Downs, a book by Quiara Alegria Hudes (“In the Heights”), and directed by Ted Sperling and Jonathan Butterell. Casting for the musicals was not announced.

From January 1985 to June 2006, Tom DeLay represented the 22nd district of Texas in the House of Representatives, serving as the Republican Party’s House whip for eight years, and House majority leader for two years. Here he is, dancing the cha-cha with his professional partner, Cheryl Burke, on Monday’s debut of “Dancing With the Stars” to the tune of the Troggs’ “Wild Thing.” (Mr. DeLay’s dance routine begins — with an air-guitar solo — about four minutes into the video clip.)

Ballantine Books, an imprint of Random House, said Tuesday that it would publish a memoir by Jenny Sanford, the wife of Mark Sanford, the Republican governor of South Carolina. At a news conference in June, Mr. Sanford admitted to having an extramarital affair with a woman in Argentina after having told his staff he was away hiking on the Appalachian Trail.

Books that address the topic of contemporary slavery were among the honorees of the 2009 Dayton Literary Peace Prize, whose winners were announced on Tuesday. The selection committee for the prize, which recognizes “the power of literature to promote peace and nonviolence,” said in a news release that its nonfiction prize would go to “A Crime So Monstrous: Face to Face With Modern Day Slavery,” by E. Benjamin Skinner, and that its fiction prize would go to “Peace,” a World War II novel by Richard Bausch. Both prizes come with an award of $10,000; the committee said that Mr. Skinner is donating his honorarium to Free the Slaves, the American wing of Anti-Slavery International.

In its first week on sale, “The Lost Symbol,” Dan Brown’s follow-up to “The Da Vinci Code,” sold more than 2 million copies in hardcover, audio and electronic book editions in the U.S., Britain and Canada, according to the publisher, Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group.

I first interviewed the photographer Sam Haskins in 2004. At the time, his brand of unstudied girlie glamour - popularized in his seminal '60s books ''Cowboy Kate & Other Stories,'' "November Girl" and ''Five Girls'' - was influencing fashion photographers, designers and stylists, just as it had done for over three decades. Not that the South African-born Haskins was thrilled with the collective air kiss. "A lot of it is mindless homage," he bristled on the phone from Australia, where he now lives. Last week, I caught up for a one-on-one video interview with Haskins, who was in town to promote "Fashion Etcetera," his first book in over 20 years. (On Sunday, Haskins suffered a moderate stroke in his hotel room, and he remains in the hospital.) Published in partnership with the designer Tommy Hilfiger, the monograph is available in a standard version ($67.50) and in a special edition ($100) - both of which are sure to prolong the fashion world's longstanding crush on him (and the countless salutes to his oeuvre). But as Hilfiger, who has made references to Haskins's work in recent collections, says: "The real thing is the real thing. There's only one Sam Haskins."

Case Study is a bimonthly posting on all things alcoholic by Toby Cecchini, T's spirits columnist.Your past always catches up with you. Growing up in Wisconsin, I had an ingrained awareness - and disgust - of the state's insular signature drink, the brandy old-fashioned. It was what people drank before and after football games or ice fishing. I considered it insipidly sweet and townie lowbrow, and I left before I was enough of a drinker to be proven otherwise.

Peering through a fold in "Aberrant Sidewalk," an installation by Kathryne Hall in Joyce Kilmer Park at East 161st Street and the Grand Concourse in the Bronx. The installation in its entirety looks like a section of sidewalk folded over itself several times. According to Ms. Hall's Web site, "Declining faith in future stability is thought to cause tectonic shifts in perception, which coincide with the appearance of aberrations in the infrastructure." It says the work is meant to lead "the viewer to question the function of urban infrastructure and the security of the built environment, consider the mundane as a subject for sculpture, or simply to smile in amusement."

Tests on the South African runner Caster Semenya continue, as race officials try to decide whether the 18-year-old athlete - who says she is female - is a man or a woman. Martha Wilson, an American writer living in Canada, is not a runner, and she thinks she is certain of the sex of her daughters. I was recently on a whirlwind tour of Mexico for business - in Cancún/Riviera Maya and Mexico City - but, as always, I managed to find some time to check out a few new places. The big story in Mexico is this year's collapse in tourism: between N1H1 and all the media reports about crime and narco-terrorism, the country has taken a big hit. That's a shame because, as I'm reminded every time I visit, the country has so much to offer.This is, of course, low season, particularly on the Caribbean coast, so even the party town of Cancún was quiet. I stayed at Aqua, one of the few design-y properties in town, the first entrant in a new brand from the big Mexican hotel company Grupo Posadas (perhaps best known for Fiesta Americana). It was a nice return for me; I'd stayed at Aqua when it was brand new back in 2005, before it got hammered by Hurricane Wilma. Posadas fully restored the hotel, and I can report it's back to its former self: a glimmering temple of marble (tons of marble), with sleek white rooms, a Michelle Bernstein restaurant, a nice suite of interlocking infinity pools overlooking the beach and a kind of Zen spa vibe that's a departure for Cancún. The place was pretty empty, which had its pluses (virtually no one at the pool) and minuses (a slightly eerie feel in the cavernous public spaces).

“Alfred Hitchcock’s The 39 Steps,” the longest-running production of any Broadway play to open in the last seven years, will end its run on Jan. 10, 2010, its publicists announced Monday. By that date it will have played 771 performances. (The actors Jill Paice, right, and Sean Mahon.) A national tour is to begin in November at the Shubert Theater in New Haven after a month at the Seattle Rep. The play is based on both the 1935 Alfred Hitchcock movie “The 39 Steps” and the 1915 novel by John Buchan. The play opened in January 2008.

From Sept. 25 to 30, London's Barbican Centre (Silk Street; 44-20-7638-4141; www.barbican.org.uk; Barbican tube stop) will aim to prove that enlightenment can occur in a formal setting too, by hosting a series of concerts exploring devotional, spiritual and sacred music from around the world. The Transcender Weekender series will feature music designed to encourage contemplation, meditation, and if all goes well, even ecstasy.

I had high hopes for the Monday shows in London, and they were certainly fulfilled: by 11 a.m. I had already seen two great shows. The boys at Meadham Kirchhoff showed a very poetic and romantic collection of white, black and taupe crochet and cotton cropped anoraks and boleros; the effect was softer than in the past two seasons, when the duo seemed obsessed with shredded and laced denim. Marios Schwab also went in a softer direction, combining multiple outfits in one and mixing elements from different historical periods - a modern cropped tunic with slick vertical pleats, for instance, was worn over gathered Renaissance-inspired skirts.Meanwhile, Christopher Kane mixed different shades of gingham with corset boning and cutouts, for a simultaneously sweet and sexy effect; pale chiffon dresses layered and embroidered with panels of knife pleating closed the show. (Kane's sister Tammy looked amazing wearing one with a Versus bag and shoes at the after-party.)

Only Watch, the biennial charity event started in 2005 to benefit those affected by Duchenne muscular dystrophy, will bring watch enthusiasts and collectors from all over the world to Monaco for the Patrizzi and Co. auction of 30 one-of-a-kind timepieces on Sept. 24. I had a viewing of the watches when they were being exhibited at Tourneau in New York City before continuing to Milan and then finally to Monaco. They all are astonishing, and I want to share a few standouts.

Standing in the only operating room in the only medical hospital in all of Guinea-Bissau, Marco Vernaschi watched a nurse take an unsterile needle out of her pocket and, without anesthetic, suture a woman's vagina after a difficult childbirth. The woman screamed. Mr. Vernaschi took a photograph. Moments later, she was required to walk out of the filthy room and go home.

The National Book Awards are jumping on the “American Idol” bandwagon. Readers can now vote on the best work of fiction to win the National Book Award in the past 59 years. The winner will be announced on Nov. 18 at the National Book Awards ceremony in New York. The six finalists show that the recent renaissance in short stories may have historical precedent. Four of the finalists for the best of the National Book Awards are short-story collections: “The Stories of John Cheever,” William Faulkner’s “Collected Stories,” “The Complete Stories” of Flannery O’Connor and “The Collected Stories of Eudora Welty.” The two other selections are Ralph Ellison’s “Invisible Man” and Thomas Pynchon’s “Gravity’s Rainbow.” In July the National Book Foundation, which administers the awards, invited 600 former judges, winners and finalists in all of its categories (the prize is also awarded for nonfiction, poetry and young people’s literature) to select three of their favorites from the 77 past fiction winners. (In some years the fiction award went to more than one author.) The 140 who answered returned the six finalists. Readers can vote at nbafictionpoll.org through Oct. 21.

Redmond O’Neal, below, the 24-year-old son of Farrah Fawcett and Ryan O’Neal, has pleaded no contest to a charge of possessing heroin while out on bail for another drug charge, Reuter’s reported. He was ordered by a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge on Friday to spend at least one year in a residential drug treatment program. Mr. O’Neal and his father were arrested together on suspicion of having drugs last September when the authorities went to the Malibu, Calif., home of the elder Mr. O’Neal to check on Redmond. Ryan O’Neal, 68, was sentenced in January to an 18-month rehabilitation program. In exchange for the no-contest plea, and on the condition that Mr. O’Neal successfully complete the drug-treatment program and three years of probation, the court suspended a six-year prison term.

A Pennsylvania state budget deal that would extend the state sales tax to arts and cultural institutions, including performance spaces and museums, has consumers and arts organizations in Pennsylvania “shocked and angered,” The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. The Inquirer said on Sunday that the provision, agreed upon by lawmakers in Harrisburg late last week, would call for the creation of a special fund that would receive the lion’s share of tax revenue from tickets. While details were still unclear, the report said that “some portion” of the fund would then be returned to the theaters and museums themselves. The tax would not be extended to movies or sports events, although it would be imposed on zoos. The sales tax in Pennsylvania is 7 percent. The plan was reported by The Inquirer on the same day that it published an article about the Philadelphia Orchestra’s multimillion-dollar deficit.

The roof above Shakespeare’s grave is in danger of caving in, and the church where the grave rests, above, Holy Trinity in Stratford-upon-Avon, is hurriedly trying to raise £50,000, or about $81,000, for repairs, BBC News reported. The supporting beam of the chancel, the section of the church that houses the altar and Shakespeare’s burial site, needs some quick work done, the Rev. Martin Gorick, vicar of Holy Trinity Church, said. The beam’s deterioration was discovered three weeks ago by workmen on the roof. They were doing some urgent repairs, Mr. Gorick said, “and the workmen found the odd bit dropped off.”.

Confirmed: The sound of sad vampires is indie-rock. We already knew that Thom Yorke and Death Cab for Cutie were going to be on the eagerly anticipated soundtrack to “The Twilight Saga: New Moon,” the second film in the “Twilight” series. But the full track list for the album, released on the MySpace Music site on Monday afternoon, shows that they are not the exception. The 15-song soundtrack has plenty of gentle-voiced indie acts, including the Brooklyn bands Grizzly Bear and Hurricane Bells; the Swedish singer Lykke Li; Sea Wolf, a group from Los Angeles; and a collaboration between Bon Iver and St. Vincent. “This is a much more somber movie than ‘Twilight,’ ” Alexandra Patsavas, the music supervisor for the film, said in an interview recently. “There is a lot of love lost.” But it’s not all wispy and folky: the rock bands the Killers, Muse, Black Rebel Motorcycle Club, OK Go and Editors are also included. The album will be released on Oct. 20, and the film opens on Nov. 20. The soundtrack to “Twilight,” the first film in the series, was released last November and according to Nieslen SoundScan it has sold 2.2 million copies, a figure that big pop stars don’t always reach these days, let alone soundtracks.

KOGAN--Marjorie D.,at Lenox Hill Hospital on September 20 after a long illness. Predeceased by her husband, Nathan B. Kogan, she is survived by her sons, Michael and Barton Kogan and by her sister Jeanne R. Theodore. Mrs. Kogan was active for many years in New York City politics, civic affairs and philanthropy. She shaped and lead the volunteer program at the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men and founded and chaired the "Services to Adolescence through the Release of Tension" (S.T.A.R.T.) program at Riker's Island Prison to assist inmates. She chaired the election campaigns of her dear friend, Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley and served as Executive Aide to Manhattan Borough Presidents Motley and Percy Sutton. Mrs. Kogan was a founding member of Manhattan's Community Board Eight on which she served for many decades. She was appointed by Mayor Abraham Beame to the New York City Board of Corrections. She served as long-time President of the philanthropic Brand Foundation of New York. She was a tireless fighter for civic betterment in many areas of her beloved city's life. Her dedication, her warmth and charm, her lively humor and kind heart will be missed by all whose lives she touched. The family will receive visitors Tuesday evening, September 22 from 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral Services on Wednesday, September 23 at 11:30am at Campbell's. Interment follows at Beth Olam Cemetery. Shiva will be observed Wednesday evening from 7-9pm at Mrs. Kogan's home and on Thursday from 7-9pm at Congregation Shomrei Emunah, 67 Park St., Montclair, NJ.

Perhaps nothing in medicine more aptly depicts the paradoxical statement ''doing better, feeling worse'' than high blood pressure. Despite an extraordinarily easy way to detect it, strong evidence for how to prevent it and proven remedies to treat it, more Americans today have undetected or poorly controlled hypertension than ever before. The aging of the population is a reason but not the only one, said Dr. Aram V. Chobanian, a hypertension expert at Boston University Medical Center. As he summarized the problem in an interview and in The New England Journal of Medicine in August, Americans are too sedentary and fat. They eat too much, especially salt, but too few potassium-rich fruits and vegetables.

Mary MacEachern Graduated from Hunter College in 1938, worked in radio and advertising, and taught in New York City Public Schools until her retirement in 1982. A funeral service will be celebrated in the chapel of the funeral home on Tuesday, September 22 at 1:30pm. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.

WARD--Marcia, 75, the loving wife of John, mother of Kathryn and grandmother of Marguerite passed away peacefully and suddenly on September 10th, 2009 at home in Florida. A gifted student, Marcia attended Bryn Mawr College for which she retained a lifelong love and attachment. A painter, a writer, a progressive thinker and a classical music lover, it was her good fortune to experience the cultures of numerous countries during her husband's international banking career. They lived in New York, Rio de Janeiro, and Paris for many years before retiring in Florida. Their great pleasure was to cruise around the world, circling and visiting many continents. Indeed, Marcia had a full life and will be remembered as a true, kind, decent, compassionate and charitable lady who will continue to live in the hearts of her friends and family and with the undying love of her husband, John.

French officials this week will shut down a camp on the northern French coast where hundreds of Afghans, Pakistanis and other illegal migrants have gathered for years in the hope of making clandestine journeys across the English Channel. The camp, labeled ''the jungle'' by migrants and this city's residents alike for its location among the thorn bushes and sand dunes of Calais, has been a source of tension since late 2002, when migrants started to camp out around the port after the closing of a Red Cross center in nearby Sangatte.

SHIELDS--James Christie, 83, Collegiate Teacher. James Christie Shields, former English teacher and department head at Collegiate School, died on September 20, 2009 at Riddle Hospital in Media Pennsylvania. Mr. Shields was the son of Presbyterian missionaries. He was born in Addis Ababa, Ethiopa, grew up in Khartoum, The Sundan, and went to school at the Schutz American School in Alexandria and Assiut, Egypt. He returned to his country in 1942, and, after a few years at Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts, he joined the U.S. Naval Reserves for the duration of World War II. He served as a hospital corpsman with the U.S. Marine Third Division in the Pacific Theater, taking part in the Iwo Jima and Okinawa campaigns and the Guam battle aftermath. After his honorable discharge in 1946, he earned a B.S. degree from Monmouth College, Monmouth Illinois, worked as a news reporter for the Pittsburgh Sun-Telegraph, and earned a M.A. degree from the University of Pittsburgh. He also studied at Yale University for three years. He held post of Instructor in English for two years at the University of Hawaii in Honolulu and for six years at Middlebury College in Middlebury, Vermont. In 1963, Mr. Shields joined the English Department of Collegiate School in New York City. Two years later, he took a leave of absence to become the Associate Director of Professional and Public Education for the New York City Division of the American Cancer Society. He returned to Collegiate in 1968. In addition to teaching, he became Faculty advisor for student publications and director of Curriculum and Chairman of the Curriculum Committee. 1n 1971 he was named Head of the English Department, a position he held for the next eighteen years, stepping down in 1989 and retiring in 1991 after twenty-five years of service to the school. Mr. Bruce Breimer, Collegiate's college advisor, wrote at the time of Mr. Shield's retirement, "First and foremost a teacher extraordinaire of literature and letters, Jim deserves the lion's share of the credit for cultivating Collegiate's widely recognized stature as a "writers" school... during the late 1960s and early 1970s. Jim chaired the curriculum committee that designed and instituted the innovative elective-oriented liberal arts course of study which diversified and expanded Collegiate's Upper School curriculum." In 1987, Mr. Shields was one of thirty teachers named by Pomona College as among the most outstanding teachers in the U.S. In 1988, his alma mater Monmouth College conferred on him the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters for his distinguished career as a teacher. In that same year Collegiate School awarded him the prestigious title of Adam Roelantsen Fellow. Since his retirement, Mr. Shields has been studying and writing in the field of Eqyptology. Mr. Shields is survived by his sister, Mrs. Sara S. Shane of Swarthmore, PA; a nephew, John B. Shane of Waterbury, VT; and a niece, Mrs. Barbara Schwaner, of Hawthorne, NJ.

SMITH--Catharine Carton: Artist and art collector, family matriarch and long-time resident of the Hartford area, died on Friday, September 18 in Bloomfield, CT. She was 97. Born December 14, 1911 in Chicago, she married Paul P. Swett, Jr. in 1933. She and her family lived in West Hartford, CT, Washington, DC and Baltimore, MD. Mr. Swett died in 1980. In 1983 she married Olcott D. Smith and moved to Farmington, CT. Mr. Smith died in 2000. She moved in 2008 to the Duncaster Lifecare Community in Bloomfield. From age 14 on, she summered in Jamestown, RI. Mrs. Smith painted watercolors of sea and countryside and collected late 19th and early 20th century American landscapes. She played golf and tennis into her 80's and went sailing two months before she died. She was giving, gracious, relished her friends and cherished her family (more than 100 members at her death). Distinguished by her impeccable dress and manners, she looked for the best in others and tried always to be at her best. Survivors include her brother, Dr. Robert W. Carton of Winnetka, IL: two sisters-in-law; sons, Steven C. Swett of Norwich, VT and Thomas C. Swett of Unionville, PA (her son, Bradford N. Swett died in 2005); three daughters-in law, four step-children and their spouses; eight grandchildren, ten great grandchildren, twelve step- grandchildren, fifteen step-great grandchildren and dozens of nieces and nephews. She will be buried at Riverside Cemetery, Pleasant Valley, CT. A memorial service will be held at noon on Wednesday, October 7 at Old St. Andrews Episcopal Church, Bloomfield, CT.

BIENSTOCK--Freddy. (Age 86). On September 20, 2009. Legendary music publisher and loving husband to Miriam, father of Caroline (wife of Douglas Rodriguez) and Robert (husband of Ellen), and grandfather of Theodora, Francesca, Lily, Ben and Max, passed away at his New York City home after a long illness. An irreplaceable music industry icon for over a half-century, he emigrated to the United States from Austria immediately before World War II and went from a first job as stock boy for the Chappell & Co. music publishing firm to becoming its Chairman within four decades. Freddy's rise was profiled in the New York Times on June 4, 1985. Throughout his career, Freddy was closely associated with such major composers, songwriters, hit makers and music business icons as Leiber & Stoller, Cliff Richards, Bobby Darin, Ray Davies, U2, John Sebastian, Tim Hardin, Eric Burdon, James Brown, Peter Allen, William Bolcom, Ernesto Lucuona, Norman Dello Joio, Carol Bayer Sager, Kander & Ebb, Koppleman & Rubin, Marvin Hamlish, Stephen Sondheim and, most significant of all, Elvis Presley, with whom he worked closely from the beginning of Elvis's career to the time of his death, and who, during his most successful years, would rely on Freddy to choose the songs he recorded. The founder and CEO of the highly successful Carlin America Carlin Music international publishing conglomerate (which is named for his daughter Caroline), the Bienstock companies are preeminent Broadway Musical publishers (Fiddler on the Roof, Cabaret, Company, Follies, Godspell, etc.) with additional extensive catalogs in the Classical, Country, American Song Standards, and Classic Pop genres. A commanding music industry visionary and innovator until his death, Freddy Bienstock immeasurably enhanced the lives of his family and numerous friends and colleagues in the world of music and will be deeply mourned by everyone fortunate to have known him. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mr. Bienstock's honor should be sent to Children's Rights; 330 Seventh Avenue; 4th Floor, New York, NY 10001.

Moving swiftly to limit damage from Formula One racing's worst scandal while saving the participation of a powerful and wealthy sponsor, the sport's ruling body confirmed Monday that France's Renault racing team had fixed a Grand Prix in Singapore last year by staging a crash, but stopped short of expelling Renault from Formula One. After a hearing at its Paris headquarters, a disciplinary tribunal of the International Automobile Federation, known as the F.I.A., described the deliberate crash as a matter of ''unparalleled severity'' and said the Renault team's actions ''not only compromised the integrity of the sport but also endangered the lives of spectators, officials, other competitors and Nelson Piquet Jr.,'' the Brazilian driver involved in the crash.

LUCKS--Dr. Abe H.,devoted physician, died peacefully on September 19, 2009 at age 98. Dr. Lucks, formerly of Cedarhurst, NY, is survived by his beloved wife of 67 years, Vivian Kramer Lucks, and by his cherished children, Karen and Dr. Steven Metzger, and Joan and Paul Feinstein. He was an adoring grandfather to Marcie Nadler (Simon), Debbie Falik (Adam), Leslie Levin (Marc), and Ross Feinstein, and loving great grandfather to eight great-grandchildren. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1911 to Jennie and Karl Lucks, Dr. Lucks attended Boys High School, Brooklyn College of Pharmacy, and the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine. Dr. Lucks was a board certified family practitioner. He practiced pharmacy and medicine at the same address in South Ozone Park, NY for over 70 years, and was recognized by "Ripley's Believe It or Not!" for this achievement. He was extraordinarily devoted to his patients, revered and respected by all. His happiest moments were spent surrounded by his entire family. As the patriarch of the family, he was a role model and imparted his strong work ethic, moral principles, and most importantly, the love and devotion of family. A funeral will be held on Tuesday, September 22, 2009 at 10:30am at Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Avenue, Rye, NY.

Grassley of Iowa.

An entry in the Prescriptions column on Aug. 22 about an appearance on the ''Daily Show'' by the former New York lieutenant governor Betsy McCaughey misstated her political affiliation. Ms. McCaughey has been a registered Democrat since September 1997; she is not a Republican. (Before 1997, she did not declare a political preference when she registered to vote.)

Aroldis Chapman, the talented Cuban pitcher who defected while at a tournament in the Netherlands two months ago, has moved closer to becoming a major league free agent. Chapman has been granted provisional passive residency in the European country of Andorra, according to Athletes Premier International, his agents. Andorra has a population of less than 85,000 and is bordered by Spain and France.

The European Commission cited a series of e-mail messages to bolster its contention that Intel violated antitrust rules to keep rival Advanced Micro Devices out of the chip market. The documents, European regulators argued, show a pattern of intimidation that they assert was repeated across the industry as Intel bound its customers in a complex web of rebates and incentives aimed at hobbling A.M.D.

When the Senate Finance Committee takes up its health care bill on Tuesday, advocates who favor a public option are planning to stage demonstrations nationwide against the health insurance industry. Supporters of a public option, or a government-run insurance plan, see it as the central component of a true health care overhaul. But the insurance industry strenuously opposes the idea, and it was not part of the proposal introduced last week by the Finance Committee chairman, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana.

When scientists at the Australian Institute of Sport recently decided to check the Vitamin D status of some of that country’s elite female gymnasts, their findings were fairly alarming. Of the 18 gymnasts tested, 15 had levels that were “below current recommended guidelines for optimal bone health,” the study’s authors report. Six of these had Vitamin D levels that would qualify as medically deficient. Unlike other nutrients, Vitamin D can be obtained by exposure to ultraviolet radiation from sunlight, as well as through foods or supplements. Of course, female gymnasts are a unique and specialized bunch, not known for the quality or quantity of their diets, or for getting outside much.
The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday charged two men with running an $8.6 million insider-trading scheme connected to Dell‘s $3.9 billion agreement to buy Perot Systems.
Our daily look at a few shows that promise to be among the day’s more interesting, for all the right — or wrong — reasons.

Could Kiss finally make it into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame? After being snubbed for years — the band has been eligible for the honor since 1999 — Kiss has finally been nominated, along with Abba, Donna Summer, Genesis, the Stooges, the Hollies and, in the first year in which they qualify, LL Cool J and the Red Hot Chili Peppers, the organization has announced. Jimmy Cliff, Darlene Love, Laura Nyro and the Chantels are also on the ballot, and votes will be cast by a group of more than 500 musicians and industry professionals; of the 12 nominees, the five that get the most votes will be announced in January and inducted into the Hall of Fame at its 25th annual ceremony on March 15 at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan. Acts become eligible 25 years after the release of their first record.
What we’re reading on Wednesday morning.

Prosecutors in Mexico said on Tuesday that they are investigating a claim that more than 1,000 items attributed to the artist Frida Kahlo in a private collection and two books are forgeries, The Associated Press reported. The attorney general’s office in Mexico City told The A.P. that a complaint filed by the Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo Trust said that paintings, notes and drawings bearing Kahlo’s signature and featured in the books “Finding Frida Kahlo” and “The Labyrinth of Frida Kahlo: Death, Pain and Ambivalence” are fakes. James Oles, an assistant professor at Wellesley College who has criticized the books, told The A.P. that items in the collection, said to have come from boxes that Kahlo gave to a carpenter, include significant spelling errors, low-quality paintings and other suspicious details. But Princeton Architectural Press, which published “Finding Frida Kahlo,” said it plans to keep selling the book. “In the book, we state that the pieces have not been 100 percent authenticated, that it’s still being researched,” said Katharine Myers, the imprint’s publicity director, according to The A.P.

There is no spectacle in electronic entertainment quite like the land rush at the opening of a highly anticipated new online computer game. In dens, bedrooms, dorm rooms and gaming lairs around the world, hundreds of thousands of people fortify themselves with caffeine and whatever else as they prepare to burst through the gates of a vast new virtual world they intend to live in for years.

Like numerous pop-music performers before him, Michael Jackson will not be hindered in his recording career by his death. A new song by Mr. Jackson, called “This Is It,” will be released next month, Sony Music Entertainment said Wednesday in a news release. The song, which shares its title with the comeback tour that Mr. Jackson was rehearsing when he died in June, will be released as a single on Oct. 12, Sony said. Two versions of that song, which includes backing vocals by Mr. Jackson’s brothers, will also appear on a new two-disc set, also called “This Is It,” which includes previously released and new material, including a spoken-word poem by Mr. Jackson called “Planet Earth”; that set will be released internationally on Oct. 26 and in North America on Oct. 27. That will be followed on Oct. 28 by Sony Pictures’ release of the documentary film “Michael Jackson: This Is It,” which is compiled from rehearsal footage from Mr. Jackson’s planned concerts.

A new documentary about Peter Cooper, the 19th-century industrialist and philanthropist who founded the Cooper Union, will be shown in a free screening at 6:30 p.m. Friday in the union’s Great Hall at East Seventh Street and Third Avenue. Cooper, who made a fortune by, among other things, developing the I-beam that was pivotal in allowing cities to grow vertically through skyscrapers, eventually gave away much of his wealth. Among the areas that concerned him was education for the working class, especially as the old apprentice system was elbowed aside by the industrial revolution. In 1859 he opened the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art to provide free education and training for working people. It was “a revolution in education,” the Princeton historian Sean Wilentz notes in the documentary, “Mechanic to Millionaire: The Peter Cooper Story,” which was produced by the Gardner Documentary Group and will also have showings at the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers on Oct. 7 and the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton on Oct. 11.

While Julia Roberts works in India on her film adaptation of a memoir about a quest for spirituality, some Indians are wishing that she’d take a hike. The Telegraph of London reported that Ms. Roberts, who is in India to shoot a movie version of the Elizabeth Gilbert memoir “Eat, Pray, Love,” angered Hindus there when they discovered that the film had closed off access to a local temple at the start of a religious festival. Worshipers at Ashram Hari Mandir, near Delhi, said that a security team including 350 guards, bulletproof cars and a helicopter had sealed off the temple at the start of Navratri, a nine-day celebration to honor the goddess Durga. Shakuntala Devi, a worshiper who was turned away from temple, told The Telegraph: “Entry for devotees is barred. We were not allowed to enter and pray in the morning by the security. Only those who could manage to sneak in did so but most of us were all sent back.” Ms. Roberts had earlier drawn praise from the Universal Society of Hinduism, which said her interest in the religion had raised its profile.
It was only a matter of time before the movie that taught us about spirit fingers and gave us the rhyme “We cheer and we lead / We act like we’re on speed” spawned its own musical.

A committee charged with examining the future of Brandeis University’s Rose Art Museum – which the school’s trustees voted in January to close as the university’s finances deteriorated – has recommended that the museum remain open. But in a report released Wednesday, the group, made up of faculty members, students and university officials and trustees, stopped short of saying whether the school should or should not proceed with a plan to sell pieces from the museum’s renowned collection to help shore up the university’s endowment.

Broadway will soon be home to a different kind of odd couple: the Geoffrey Nauffts play “Next Fall,” about two gay men grappling with issues of religious faith, will transfer to the Helen Hayes Theater early next year, its producers said on Wednesday. The play, written by Mr. Nauffts, the actor and artistic director of the Naked Angels theater company, opened in June at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater on West 42nd Street, where it ran through August, and starred Patrick Breen as an affirmed atheist and Patrick Heusinger as his lover, a devoted Christian. Casting for the Broadway production was not announced, but the play will retain its director, Sheryl Kaller. “Next Fall” is scheduled to begin previews at the Helen Hayes in mid-February and open on March 11. It will be produced by Barbara Manocherian, Richard Willis and Anthony Barrile in association with Naked Angels.

Next week the Swedish crystal manufacturer Orrefors Kosta Boda will start making arrangements to sell much of its glass-making archive, containing about 5,000 prototype vessels as well as sketches, photos and correspondence dating back to the company’s founding in the early 1700s. A Swedish nonprofit, the Glass Kingdom’s Treasures, is now trying to preempt the sale by raising about $1.7 million to fund museum galleries for the collection in the town of Orrefors, in southern Sweden.

For a second week Jay-Z has the No. 1 album on the Billboard chart, with 298,000 copies of “The Blueprint 3” (Roc Nation/Atlantic) sold in the United States. It had 37 percent fewer sales than it did its opening week, but that was still almost double the album’s nearest competitor this week. Whitney Houston’s “I Look to You” (Arista), released three weeks ago, got a big sales bump after Ms. Houston was interviewed on “The Oprah Winfrey Show.” The album sold 156,000 copies last week, a 77 percent increase from the week before, and lands at No. 2 on the chart. (Jay-Z will probably benefit from the “Oprah” effect as well: he appears on the show on Thursday.)
In his latest documentary, the filmmaker Michael Moore, who has already taken aim at the U.S. auto industry and healthcare system, is hunting even bigger game: the economic foundation of the nation.
Dan Brown and Senator Edward M. Kennedy helped kick off the fall bookselling season and delivered some of the strong sales that booksellers have been craving all year.

Days after its official opening, a new outdoor exhibition and performance space in Lower Manhattan has been tagged with disapproving graffiti. Curbed is reporting that LentSpace, which opened Friday at the northwest corner of Canal and Sullivan Streets, has drawn a visitor or visitors who spray-painted the phrase “This is not art” on some of the works there. The park, which is open from 7 a.m. till dusk daily, is presently displaying sculptures that are meant to comment on conventions of city planning and public art, including pieces made from flagpoles, ladders, concrete, steel and the occasional fluorescent lightbulb.A slideshow about LentSpace and its art can be found here.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J. - The defense that quarterback Kerry Collins will face on Sunday at Giants Stadium should look a bit familiar. Because it's the same defense Collins and the Tennessee Titans faced last season, when Jets Coach Rex Ryan was the defensive coordinator in Baltimore.

PORTLAND, Ore. --- In the last days of her life, Annabel Kitzhaber had a decision to make: she could be the tissue-skinned woman in the hospital with the tubes and the needles, the meds and smells and the squawk of television. Or she could go home and finish the love story with the man she'd been married to for 65 years.

ANAHEIM, Calif. - The Yankees finished their road trip with an impressive if thoroughly unlikely victory Wednesday, with Ian Kennedy setting up a 3-2 victory for Mariano Rivera. It was the Yankees' first series victory at Angel Stadium since May 2004.

Netgear's new Stora network-attached storage device (NAS, in geek speak) comes with a terabyte (1,000) of hard drive space and software to help manage your files for $229. For another $20 a year, Netgear's Stora service lets you access your content and play media files from any Internet-connected computer or smartphone.

I've been watching HDTV since 1982, when the Japanese television network NHK and CBS joined forces to show the world what they thought TV could become. That year, HDTV images shot by Francis Ford Coppola's team were demonstrated to TV executives around the country on square aspect ratio, rear-projection TVs.

London fashion week has truly arrived (not just because T Magazine was front and center at the shows). There were rave reviews for the profusion of conspicuously intellectualized dressing - post-postmodern style. Christopher Kane, the club-kid favorite, hit a new, sonorous note with his Nabokovian thigh-slit pleated gingham chiffon dresses, while the Halston-bound designer Marios Schwab's triptych outfits had, perhaps, two elements too many.

The video's vibrant imagery pushes the boundaries of the imagination, so wind it up and give a spin.

When it comes to Spanish design, technically speaking, Barcelona is the center of the action - Javier Mariscal, Enric Ruiz Geli and the majority of the country's young talents all keep studios there. But the biggest Spanish design event takes place in Valencia, Barcelona's paella-obsessed neighbor to the south. Each year, a surprisingly large number of local furniture manufacturers set up shop here at the convention center, and now the usual smattering of off-site talks and exhibitions has been officially corralled into the first-ever Valencia Design Week, complete with its own Interni guide.

Today marks the opening of Gizmodo's second annual gadget show, highlighting not just the newest technologies and devices but also the oldest, the obscurest and the oddest. A Russian billionaire, an amateur basketball player the size of an N.B.A. power forward, signed a tentative $200 million deal on Wednesday that would make him the principal owner of the New Jersey Nets and an investor in the team's new home, an arena planned for Brooklyn, The New York Times's Charles V. Bagli reported.
Twenty-five years ago, Vicki Nelson and Jean Hepner sustained a 643-stroke rally that lasted 29 minutes in a tennis match that itself took six and a half hours to finish.

It's hard for young designers to stand out during the crush of fashion week. Increasingly, some are addressing the challenge by forgoing live shows altogether; Tim Hamilton, for example, decided to screen "Climb," a video featuring his clothes shot by the artist Collier Schorr. The short film - not to be confused with Miley Cyrus's chart topper of a similar name - featured music by Björn Yttling (of Peter Bjorn and John) and John Hill (Santogold's producer), and was projected on big screens at a party where everyone milled around slinging back a few Stellas. Is the video approach more effective than a plain white runway? Take a look at Hamilton and Schorr's collaboration and let us know what you think.

BERLIN | Every fall since 1996, Berlin takes its turn as the art world's fairest for one extended weekend: From Sept. 24 to 27, the Art Forum Berlin contemporary art fair lets 130 international galleries show their best work in the city's fairgrounds. It also acts as the anchor for off-fairs, events, openings and parties happening at the same time, all taking advantage of the art-minded cultural tourists who descend upon the city.

Fisher knew the twin Ryan boys, Rex and Rob, when they were young, which will add an interesting twist to this weekend's N.F.L. schedule.

LONDON - Returning here for fashion week after an almost 20-year hiatus was already a scary thought - like going back to a fashion party I had attended in my youth with great enthusiasm but that could never be repeated. What could ever top the first John Galliano show or Vivienne Westwood's Pirate collection? And we all know that party clothes never look as good the second time around. What's more, revisiting your past tends to make you doubt your present. Holding up a mirror to your former self is not always a good idea.

Common convention in college football polling has held that once a team earns a ranking, it is essentially its to lose, especially a No. 1 ranking. So even though the Florida Gators didn't rout Tennessee, their 23-13 win kept them unbeaten and still the No. 1 team in the country. And though the Texas Longhorns struggled to beat Texas Tech, a simple W was all they needed to retain their No. 2 ranking. This has simply been the way the world works.

Google is rolling out a new service on Wednesday that will allow users to post notes alongside Web sites that can be read by other users. The service, called Sidewiki, will be a new feature of the Google Toolbar, a popular browser add-on.

People with roots in India, China, Japan, England, France and, of course, the Pacific Northwest have long lived together in Canada's most diverse city. The result? A delicious intermingling of cuisine. Read the full post.

On Thursday, nearly 5,000 college admissions officers and high school counselors will gather for the 65th annual convention of the National Association of College Admission Counseling.

A newborn lamb was picked up from the back of a truck last week even as its mother, along with a hundred or so other sheep, was led to a slaughterhouse near the Hunts Point section of the Bronx. The sad tale was a bit of a Dickensian variation on the more common theme of runaway animals.
As Nielsen seeks to sign up clients for its radio ratings service, it has a message for them: We think you're still hip!

The health care debate is gaining speed as the Senate Finance Committee heads into day two of markups on the proposal offered by its chairman, Max Baucus, and Massachusetts moves closer to filling its vacant Senate seat.

Situated ina light industrial section of Vancouver's Mount Pleasant neighborhood, it seems to date from another era. Cartoon versions of a white-capped chef and a pink-uniformed waitress decorate its cinderblock facade, and arced lettering promises "Hamburgers, Soup, Sandwiches, and more!"

A brief review last Wednesday about the Brooklyn Star restaurant erroneously included an ingredient for its summer squash casserole. It did not contain garlic. The review also referred incorrectly to the restaurant’s wall paneling. It is a combination of custom-made and stock paneling, not just stock.

Steve Wynn has uncovered a pocket of betting fever. Mr. Wynn, the gambling mogul, plans a public offering of 25 percent of his Macao business in Hong Kong to raise $1.6 billion and reduce the debt his empire has racked up in Las Vegas. He couldn't have picked a better time, Breakingviews.com says. Wild speculation has spilled out of the casino and into the stock market.

Commissioner Roger Goodell and DeMaurice Smith, the chief executive of the players union, have sent a joint memo to players emphasizing that the league’s policy on performance-enhancing drugs is still in place. The memo, which also reaffirms their support of the policy, comes in the wake of court decisions that blocked the N.F.L. from enforcing the suspension of two Minnesota Vikings for positive drug tests.
During his first turn as public advocate, Mark Green, now a Democratic candidate for the office, often clashed with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

A New York judge denied a motion by the America’s Cup champion, Alinghi, to disqualify the challenger BMW Oracle Racing because it had not provided a measurement certificate for its 90-foot trimaran. Justice Shirley Kornreich of State Supreme Court said BMW Oracle Racing, owned by the software tycoon Larry Ellison, must provide Alinghi, which is based in Switzerland, with the final documentation at least two weeks before Feb. 8 — the starting date for the showdown off Ras al-Khaimah, United Arab Emirates. Alinghi has been demanding the documentation for more than a year as part of a bitter legal fight. The ruling means BMW Oracle Racing can continue to modify its trimaran, including installing an engine to trim the sails and move ballast. But Kornreich wrote that BMW Oracle’s “unsportsmanlike behavior” had “substantially” reduced Alinghi’s advantage.

David Ngog sent Liverpool into the final 16 of the League Cup with a 1-0 victory at Leeds, and Arsenal was a 2-0 winner over West Bromwich Albion, which played with 10 men after Jerome Thomas was sent off in the 37th minute for slapping Jack Wilshere in the face after they tangled on the ground.

With the Internal Revenue Service poised to take the money from his $10 million purse for his fight Saturday, Floyd Mayweather Jr. agreed to pay $5.6 million in back taxes. Mayweather’s tax lawyer, Jeffrey Morse, said Mayweather had met all his tax obligations.

Summer Squall, who won the 1990 Preakness after finishing second in the Kentucky Derby, was euthanized at Lane’s End Farm in Versailles, Ky. He was 22. Summer Squall finished second in the 1990 Kentucky Derby to Unbridled, then defeated Unbridled in the Preakness after a stretch duel in which he pulled away along the rail. His offspring include the 1999 Kentucky Derby winner Charismatic.

FRONT PAGE.

An article in the Escapes pages on Sept. 11 about Block Island referred incorrectly to its geographical size. While the town of New Shoreham, which encompasses Block Island’s nearly 10 square miles, is indeed Rhode Island’s smallest municipality in terms of population, the smallest in size is Central Falls (a little more than 1 square mile), not New Shoreham.
According to an executive in baseball familiar with the Mets’ plans, the team will not bring back Ramon Pena, a special assistant to General Manager Omar Minaya.
The league has again locked out its referees because of a breakdown in contract talks and will begin training replacements this weekend.

Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about a plan to extend Pennsylvania’s sales tax to arts and cultural institutions misstated the size of the tax. It is 6 percent, not 7 percent. (Allegheny County and Philadelphia add a 1 percent tax for a total of 7 percent, and Philadelphia is to add another 1 percent next month.).

An article on Aug. 24 about the plight of Tour of the Cat and other former champion race horses who end up at risk of being abandoned, euthanized or slaughtered referred incorrectly to the closure in 2007 of the last United States horse slaughterhouses. They were closed by the authorities in Texas and Illinois under state laws, not by the federal government.

An article on Tuesday by Reuters about Dan Rather’s lawsuit against CBS, in which he alleges he was unfairly fired, misstated a ruling that Judge Ira Gammerman, of the New York State Supreme Court, made in the case on Monday. The error also appeared in the headline. The judge ruled on several discovery motions and set a hearing date; he did not reject a bid to dismiss the lawsuit. (A motion by CBS to dismiss the suit is pending before an appeals court.).

The Big City column on Saturday, about 10 thought-provoking questions that Reboot, a Jewish nonprofit organization, is disseminating during the 10 days from Rosh Hashana to Yom Kippur, referred incorrectly to the Reuters sign in Times Square, one place where the questions will be broadcast. (They are also available on a Web site, doyou10Q.com.) The electronic sign is lighted on weekends; it does not go dark.
After two attempts, Bharti and MTN are now awaiting approval by regulatory authorities, and politics, not commerce, could be the deciding factor.
The decision could lead to a ban on the planting of the beets, which have been widely adopted by American farmers.
The listings of lottery results on Thursday and Friday misstated last Wednesday’s winning New York Take 5 numbers. They were 3, 9, 23, 25 and 34.

Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column on Saturday about a guilty plea by a company that supplied glue to the Big Dig highway project in Boston referred incorrectly to a person killed when a ceiling in the project collapsed. She was a passenger in a car, not its driver.

An article on Saturday about a decision by the solar company BrightSource Energy to shelve plans for a solar power farm in California misspelled, in some editions, the given name of a Democratic senator who opposed the project. She is Dianne Feinstein of California, not Diane.

An article on Friday about a new recruiting campaign for the Marine Corps misstated its rank in size among the military services. It is the second smallest, not the smallest. (The Coast Guard is the smallest.).

An article on Saturday about James E. O’Keefe III, the conservative activist who caught on videotape compromising statements by workers at the community organizing group Acorn, included incorrect information from Liz Farkas, an acquaintance of Mr. O’Keefe’s, who spoke in an interview about having read a transcript of one of his earlier projects. The transcript was of an encounter with a nurse at the University of California at Los Angeles; it was not of a nurse at Planned Parenthood.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a coal-fired power plant in West Virginia that is capturing and burying some of the carbon dioxide it generates misstated the materials processed by a plant in North Dakota that captures carbon dioxide and sends it to Canada for storage. That plant, Great Plains Synfuels, converts coal to methane; it does not convert methane to natural gas. (Methane is the principal component of natural gas.).

In its first week on sale “The Lost Symbol,” Dan Brown’s follow-up to “The Da Vinci Code,” sold more than two million copies in hardcover, audio and electronic book editions in the United States, Britain and Canada, according to the publisher, Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group. The company, a unit of Random House, said in a news release that the number represented “the biggest one-week sale in Random House history for a single title.” Though the large number was sure to bolster the mood among beleaguered booksellers, it came nowhere near the record set by “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,” the seventh installment in J. K. Rowling’s boy-wizard series. That book sold 8.3 million copies in the United States alone within its first 24 hours on sale.

The thin, chilly air of Park City, Utah, proved beneficial to independent films “Like Water for Chocolate” and “Little Miss Sunshine” when they had their premieres at the Sundance Film Festival there. Will the warmer climes be as kind to their musical adaptations? In a news release, the Sundance Institute Theater Lab at White Oak in Yulee, Fla., said it would produce two stage projects from Oct. 25 through Nov. 7. The first is a musical version of “Little Miss Sunshine,” originally directed by Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris and written by Michael Arndt, with music and lyrics by William Finn (“Falsettos”) and a book by James Lapine (“Sunday in the Park With George,” “Into the Woods”), which Mr. Lapine will also direct. The second is a musical adaptation of “Like Water for Chocolate,” the Laura Esquivel novel and Alfonso Arau film, which will be composed by Lila Downs and Paul R. Cohen, with lyrics by Ms. Downs, a book by Quiara Alegria Hudes (“In the Heights”) and directed by Ted Sperling and Jonathan Butterell. Casting was not announced.

Send in the clowns, and possibly a few scalpers: the long-rumored Broadway revival of “A Little Night Music” is officially a go, with a few big names attached. Publicists for the musical said on Tuesday that Catherine Zeta-Jones, above left (an Academy Award-winner for “Chicago”), would make her Broadway debut in the revival, alongside Angela Lansbury, above right (who recently won her fifth Tony Award, for “Blithe Spirit”), and Alexander Hanson, who also appeared in the production’s previous incarnations at the Menier Chocolate Factory and the Garrick Theater in London. The musical, directed by Trevor Nunn, is to begin previews at the Walter Kerr Theater on Nov. 24 and open on Dec. 13. Adapted from the Ingmar Bergman film “Smiles of a Summer Night,” “A Little Night Music” features a book by Hugh Wheeler and score by Stephen Sondheim, including perhaps his best-known song, “Send in the Clowns.”.

Ballantine Books, an imprint of Random House, said on Tuesday that it would publish a memoir by Jenny Sanford, below, the wife of Mark Sanford, the Republican governor of South Carolina. At a news conference in June Mr. Sanford admitted to being in Argentina, where he was having an extramarital affair after having told his staff he was hiking on the Appalachian Trail. In a news release, Ballantine said that Ms. Sanford’s book, which does not yet have a title but is planned for a May 2010 release, would be a memoir that “will grapple with the universal issue of maintaining integrity and a sense of self during life’s difficult times,” and would discuss “the emotions, confrontations and heartbreak behind the headlines of her story.” In a statement Ms. Sanford said: “I would like to show others how important it is to stand firm on one’s principles, stay true to oneself, and respond with grace and honesty to whatever hurdles may come.” Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell and DeMaurice Smith, the chief executive of the players union, have sent a joint memo to players emphasizing that the league's policy on performance-enhancing drugs is still in place. The memo, which also reaffirms their support of the policy, comes in the wake of court decisions that blocked the N.F.L. from enforcing the suspension of two Minnesota Vikings for positive drug tests. ''It is important for all players to understand that the Policy on Anabolic Steroids and Related Substances remains in place and that you will be tested this year just as you have been in other years, and a positive test will generally result in a suspension,'' the memo said.

KOGAN--Marjorie D.,at Lenox Hill Hospital on September 20 after a long illness. Predeceased by her husband, Nathan B. Kogan, she is survived by her sons, Michael and Barton Kogan and by her sister Jeanne R. Theodore. Mrs. Kogan was active for many years in New York City politics, civic affairs and philanthropy. She shaped and lead the volunteer program at the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men and founded and chaired the "Services to Adolescence through the Release of Tension" (S.T.A.R.T.) program at Riker's Island Prison to assist inmates. She chaired the election campaigns of her dear friend, Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley and served as Executive Aide to Manhattan Borough Presidents Motley and Percy Sutton. Mrs. Kogan was a founding member of Manhattan's Community Board Eight on which she served for many decades. She was appointed by Mayor Abraham Beame to the New York City Board of Corrections. She served as long-time President of the philanthropic Brand Foundation of New York. She was a tireless fighter for civic betterment in many areas of her beloved city's life. Her dedication, her warmth and charm, her lively humor and kind heart will be missed by all whose lives she touched. The family will receive visitors Tuesday evening, September 22 from 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral Services on Wednesday, September 23 at 11:30am at Campbell's. Interment follows at Beth Olam Cemetery. Shiva will be observed Wednesday evening from 7-9pm at Mrs. Kogan's home and on Thursday from 7-9pm at Congregation Shomrei Emunah, 67 Park St., Montclair, NJ.

Predeceased in 1975 by her husband of 35 years, Paul, Lt. Colonel, USAAF, founder of Gaynor & Co., an advertising and public relations company. Widowed with two teenaged children, Jean's superb taste and knack for real estate took her from Manhattan and Bridgehampton to Rheinbeck, Water Mill, Southampton, and Greenport. Remembered with love by her children, Anne (Douglas May) and Paul, Jr. (Sylvia). Adored NinjaGrandma of Elizabeth Anne May. Thrifty, generous, stubborn, flexible, logical and emotional, she lived her life with honesty and integrity befitting her Scottish heritage. Donations to Peconic Land Trust or Vetdogs.org.

Educator and assistant principal in the New York City public schools, avid reader and world traveler. Engaged and lively to the end. We shall remember her always. Memorial gathering Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., New York City, Sunday, September 27, 10:30am.

WARD--Marcia, 75, the loving wife of John, mother of Kathryn and grandmother of Marguerite passed away peacefully and suddenly on September 10th, 2009 at home in Florida. A gifted student, Marcia attended Bryn Mawr College for which she retained a lifelong love and attachment. A painter, a writer, a progressive thinker and a classical music lover, it was her good fortune to experience the cultures of numerous countries during her husband's international banking career. They lived in New York, Rio de Janeiro, and Paris for many years before retiring in Florida. Their great pleasure was to cruise around the world, circling and visiting many continents. Indeed, Marcia had a full life and will be remembered as a true, kind, decent, compassionate and charitable lady who will continue to live in the hearts of her friends and family and with the undying love of her husband, John.

Federal agents opened fire on three vans carrying at least 70 people suspected of being illegal immigrants when the drivers of the vehicles tried to crash through a California border crossing, officials said. Three passengers in the van were injured and taken to local hospitals, and a passenger in a separate vehicle was also injured. The border was closed for several hours at the San Ysidro crossing, which is considered the busiest such crossing in the world. No agents were hurt, and none of the injuries were considered life-threatening.

George Halvorson, the chief executive of one of the nation's most respected health care systems, Kaiser Permanente, says he is hopeful that all the sausage-making in Washington will succeed in squeezing out a law. BRUCE--Beverlee. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee and the Board of Directors, Commissioners and staff of the Women's Refugee Commission are deeply saddened by the death of our dear colleague Beverlee Bruce. A social anthropologist, development specialist and educator, Dr. Bruce served as Chair of the Women's Refugee Commission from 1995 to 1999. She joined the Board of the International Rescue Committee in 1995 and was chair of its Program Committee from 2000 to 2005. She became an IRC Overseer in 2007. Dr. Bruce traveled extensively to assess the needs of refugee women and children and led the Women's Refugee Commission delegation to the Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing in 1995. We express our deepest sympathies to her son, Darryl Bruce; her sisters, Shirlee Smith and Angela Pickett; and her brother, Eugene Pickett. International Rescue Committee, Alan R. Batkin and Jonathan L. Wiesner, Board Co-Chairs George Rupp, President Women's Refugee Commission Glenda Burkhart and Dina Dublon, Board Co-Chairs Carolyn Makinson, Executive Director

Did anyone see Titans Coach Jeff Fisher blow his top on a muffed punt Sunday? A bobbled punt return by the Texans' Jacoby Jones was plucked out of the air by Tennessee's Jason McCourty. The officials ruled fair-catch interference because the ball did not hit the ground. Fisher heads the N.F.L.'s competition committee, which is why he seldom criticizes the officials. Sure enough, Fisher said after the game: ''The officiating crew made the right call. It was frustrating, but it was correct.''

Bernie Fuchs, a much-imitated artist who created magazine illustrations and advertisements, presidential portraits and postage stamps, and whose vibrant paintings captured middle-class life in pre-Vietnam America, died on Thursday. He was 76 and lived in Westport, Conn. The cause was esophageal cancer, said David Apatoff, a friend and illustration scholar, who said that Mr. Fuchs died in hospice care in Fairfield, Conn.

French authorities dismantled and bulldozed a camp for illegal immigrants outside the port of Calais on Tuesday, rounding up almost 300 Afghans, Pakistanis and others who had gathered there for years in the hope of making clandestine journeys to Britain. Within half an hour, hundreds of paramilitary officers had dragged or escorted away the migrants, arresting 276 people, including 135 teenagers, like the Afghan boy at left. The camp, known as ''the jungle,'' had been used by migrants seeking to sneak across, or be smuggled across, the English Channel to Britain.

The beloved husband of Diane, son of Mildred and the late Samuel, father of Paul and Elisabeth (Richard) Tarlowe, and grandfather of Emily. BIENSTOCK--Freddy. (Age 86). On September 20, 2009. Legendary music publisher and loving husband to Miriam, father of Caroline (wife of Douglas Rodriguez) and Robert (husband of Ellen), and grandfather of Theodora, Francesca, Lily, Ben and Max, passed away at his New York City home after a long illness. An irreplaceable music industry icon for over a half-century, he emigrated to the United States from Austria immediately before World War II and went from a first job as stock boy for the Chappell & Co. music publishing firm to becoming its Chairman within four decades. Freddy's rise was profiled in the New York Times on June 4, 1985. Throughout his career, Freddy was closely associated with such major composers, songwriters, hit makers and music business icons as Leiber & Stoller, Cliff Richards, Bobby Darin, Ray Davies, U2, John Sebastian, Tim Hardin, Eric Burdon, James Brown, Peter Allen, William Bolcom, Ernesto Lucuona, Norman Dello Joio, Carol Bayer Sager, Kander & Ebb, Koppleman & Rubin, Marvin Hamlish, Stephen Sondheim and, most significant of all, Elvis Presley, with whom he worked closely from the beginning of Elvis's career to the time of his death, and who, during his most successful years, would rely on Freddy to choose the songs he recorded. The founder and CEO of the highly successful Carlin America Carlin Music international publishing conglomerate (which is named for his daughter Caroline), the Bienstock companies are preeminent Broadway Musical publishers (Fiddler on the Roof, Cabaret, Company, Follies, Godspell, etc.) with additional extensive catalogs in the Classical, Country, American Song Standards, and Classic Pop genres. A commanding music industry visionary and innovator until his death, Freddy Bienstock immeasurably enhanced the lives of his family and numerous friends and colleagues in the world of music and will be deeply mourned by everyone fortunate to have known him. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mr. Bienstock's honor should be sent to Children's Rights; 330 Seventh Avenue; 4th Floor, New York, NY 10001.

WAGNER--Richard. The Board and Staff of Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation ("Brooklyn A") were shocked and deeply saddened to learn of the passing Monday of the program's long term Director of Litigation, Rick Wagner. Rick was a brilliant and fiery lawyer, deeply committed to the struggle for economic and social justice in the world and in our neighborhoods. Over the years he invested his incredible skills in fighting to achieve those goals at the Center for Constitutional Rights, the law firm of Stolar, Alterman, Wagner & Boop, and for the last 25 years at Brooklyn A. He used his enormous energy, creativity and vision to apply, among the other tools, the federal RICO statute to empower tenants, and in most recent years was a national leader in the fight against predatory lending, mortgage frauds and title rescue scams, protecting low income, mostly minority homeowners in huge and successful battles to save or recover their homes. Rick was truly one of a kind, and will be greatly missed by his clients, by his colleagues and by his huge network of admirers. Funeral and memorial services have not yet been scheduled. For further information, view www.bka.org.

This week: Jon Pareles reviews “Backspacer” by Pearl Jam and Nelly Furtado’s Spanish-language release “Mi Plan.” Also, the Brazilian singer Bebel Gilberto performs in our studio and talks to Ben Sisario about her new CD. Sia Michel is the host.

A painting by Rene Magritte was stolen from a Brussels museum on Thursday morning by two armed men, The Guardian reported. The robbery occurred just after 10 a.m., shortly after the museum, a former home of Magritte, opened, when a man rang the doorbell to ask if visiting hours had started. The man then pointed a gun at the museum attendant while an accomplice went inside. The thieves made museum workers and visitors kneel in a courtyard while they left on foot with a 1948 painting, “Olympia,” a nude portrait of Magritte’s wife. The Guardian said that the two men, who spoke English and French, set off an alarm when they broke a glass plate that protected the painting, but that they had escaped by the time the police arrived. The stolen work is said to be worth about $1.1 million, according to The Guardian.

The pendulum that charts the fiscal fortunes of regional orchestras has, for the moment, swung back in the ominous direction. The musicians of the Colorado Symphony Orchestra agreed to a new contract that will impose a 12.5 percent pay cut and require them to take up to four weeks of unpaid leave, The Denver Post reported. The contract with the Colorado Symphony Association covers the 2009-2010 season already under way as well as the 2010 summer season, and also suspends the association’s contributions to the musicians’ retirement fund. The cuts are expected to save the symphony $1 million. In a joint statement, the orchestra and the association said that they had “worked collaboratively to reach an agreement that will allow the orchestra to maintain a full schedule, operate responsibly within a balanced budget and, most importantly, ensure the excellence of the Colorado Symphony Orchestra.” The orchestra’s coming season is to feature performances by Yo-Yo Ma, Lang Lang and Olga Kern, as well as Marvin Hamlisch, who is performing on its pops program.

Whether you played with dolls or action figures as a child (or even if you admit to occasionally coveting them as an adult), the film industry is assembling a movie for you. The Hollywood Reporter said that Universal had acquired the rights to make a feature film based on Barbie, the impossibly proportioned Mattel doll who has been gazing placidly from store shelves since 1959. The live-action film will be produced by Laurence Mark, a producer of the 2009 Academy Awards who has also produced films like “Julie & Julia” and “Dreamgirls,” but there was no word on who would play Barbie or her anatomically incorrect companion, Ken.

A few costume elements from the musical version of “The Lion King” have avoided that step in the circle of life where they might be recycled or sold to collectors, and were instead donated to the Smithsonian Institution‘s National Museum of American History in Washington. In a news release, publicists for the musical said on Thursday that the mask and headdress of the lion protagonist, Simba, and the costume, shoes and hat of the monkey Rafiki were given to the museum and will become part of its permanent entertainment collection. The costume elements were created by Julie Taymor, who won Tony Awards for her direction and costume design for the musical after its Broadway opening in 1997, and the mask was designed by Ms. Taymor with Michael Curry. Other Broadway shows whose artifacts now reside at the museum include “The King and I,” “Hello, Dolly!,” “Fiddler On the Roof” and “Mame.”

The AMC TV series “Mad Men” is becoming known for the care its makers take to insure that everything viewers see reflects the period in which the show is set. This season, it’s 1963, and in the episode that was shown on Sunday, it was early July when two mainstay characters, the adman Don Draper (Jon Hamm) and the now-former office manager Joan Holloway (Christina Hendricks) found themselves in a waiting room in a hospital sharing Dr Peppers from a vending machine. The scene has sparked a debate over Dr Pepper’s presence in New York City in 1963.

The cast for the coming Off Broadway transfer of “Avenue Q” should look familiar to audiences who have seen that satirical puppet musical on Broadway or on its national tour. Press representatives for “Avenue Q” said on Thursday that its cast at New World Stages would consist of Anika Larsen (from the final Broadway cast and national tour) as Kate Monster/Lucy; Seth Rettberg (a Broadway and tour alumnus) as Princeton/Rod; Cullen Titmus (from the tour) as Nicky/Trekkie Monster; Danielle K. Thomas (also from the final Broadway cast) as Gary Coleman; Sala Iwamatsu (a Broadway veteran) as Christmas Eve; Nicholas Kohn (from the final Broadway company) as Brian; and Maggie Lakis (from the tour) as Mrs. T/Bad Idea Bear. The New World Stages production of “Avenue Q” is to begin previews Oct. 9, with an official opening night of Oct. 21.

Tom Stoppard and Zaha Hadid were among the winners of the Praemium Imperiale arts awards, announced Thursday by the Japan Art Association. The awards, which come with a prize of about $163,000 each, are given for lifetime arts achievement in categories not covered by the Nobel Prizes. They were in established in 1988 to mark the association’s 100th anniversary and to honor Prince Takamatsu, its longtime honorary patron, who died in 1987. In a news release, the association said that in addition to Mr. Stoppard, who is being honored for his theater and film work, and Ms. Hadid, this year’s architecture laureate, it would give awards to the photographer Hiroshi Sugimoto, the sculptor Richard Long and the pianist Alfred Brendel. The awards will be bestowed in a ceremony in Tokyo on Oct. 22.

Fifty years have elapsed since the publication of Robert Frank's "The Americans." As a commemorative exhibition opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art - showing all 83 photographs from the original book - Holland Cotter of The Times discusses Mr. Frank's journeys through the country in the mid-1950s and asks how these influential pictures hold up a half century later. "In the nominally post-racial Obama era, its political urgencies feel less immediate than they once did, but also prophetic. Its mournful tenderness, without being sentimental, seems deeper than ever."

PITTSBURGH -- For the record, the White House was not snubbing Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Great Britain. Such a thought is "silly and absurd." Of course the United States still has a special relationship with Britain. The only reason why the White House turned down five requests from the British for a meeting between President Obama and Mr. Brown this week is because the two talk all the time anyway.

Jana Segarra went big this year in her vegetable garden. "I tell everyone it has to be big to accommodate the wide margin of error!," she writes from her home in Matawan, New Jersey. Her pepper plants succumbed to a mysterious ailment and her broccoli seeds were a non-starter. But Ms. Segarra began her second year of vegetable growing with a bang in early March -- sugar snap peas, lettuce and spinach - and then just kept going.

Not long after President Obama's speech at the United Nations yesterday, Robert Costa at The Corner delivered an assessment from a surprise guest, John Bolton, who coined the catchy critical phrase of the day: "A post-American speech by our first post-American president." (Man, that is catchy.) Bolton is quoted: "It was a speech high on the personality of Barack Obama and high on multilateralism, but very short in advocating American interests."
