The lead picture - taken in the Kandahar Province in Afghanistan by Finbarr O'Reilly for Reuters - shows Canadian soldiers engulfed in a mini dust storm stirred by the rotors of an American helicopter. The image, at least to this viewer, comes with a hint of geopolitical symbolism, just as the Obama administration struggles to settle on a new military strategy for Afghanistan (one with a strong focus on civilian aid, as shown in Slide 2), and allies whose troops are also fighting and dying there look for a way out. In New York, hundreds demonstrated during President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's trip to the United Nations General Assembly. The protesters marched across the Brooklyn Bridge carrying a mile-long green banner covered by tens of thousands of signatures (Slide 7), in solidarity with opposition demonstrators in Iran.

The slender Volkswagen L1 shown recently at the Frankfurt Motor Show was built to set mileage records. The 158-miles-a-gallon-diesel electric hybrid reminded me of another very slender vehicle: "La D.S.," a work by Gabriel Orozco, an artist born in Mexico. It was built as sculpture.

Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has been publicly flirting with a run for governor next year, expressed surprise on Thursday about the Obama administration's efforts to push Gov. David A. Paterson out of next year's race for governor.

Guy Bourdin's first fashion shoot for Vogue France in 1955 included an image of a woman wearing a hat below three butchered cow heads with their tongues hanging out. And his oeuvre didn't exactly get less sensational or surreal from there.Both renowned and reviled for photographs that were often sexually charged and sinister, but always masterfully composed and visually complex, Bourdin revolutionized fashion photography in the latter part of the 20th century. In addition to working with Vogue in France, the United States, Britain and Italy for more than 30 years, the photographer shot for Harper's Bazaar and Photo and created arresting advertising campaigns for Charles Jourdan, Issey Miyake, Chanel, Emanuel Ungaro and Pentax. In an era when wholesome smiles and polyester pantsuits blended into the (faux) woodwork, Bourdin shocked with bare bottoms, bleeding nipples and atmospheres as seedy as Amber Wave's San Fernando Valley and as slick as Joan Collins's lip-gloss.

Contemporary art remains a problem for many people. What's it all about? What should I be thinking? What is the artist trying to communicate? Without a recognizable image to focus, even now, 100 years after Kandinsky first took the leap into non-objective painting, the meaning and the message of abstract art remains a mystery for even some well-educated individuals.

This summer, Marco Velardi, the editor of the hip Italian design magazine Apartamento, spent three days holed up in a barn in Yorkshire, England, elbow deep in a sea of cardboard boxes alongside the furniture design star Max Lamb and his father, Richard. A portion of the boxes' contents - more than 1,000 examples of British studio pottery that the elder Lamb sniffed out at rummage sales over the last 15 years - is currently on view at London Design Week. The Apartamento exhibition, "Richard Lamb: The Everyday Life Collector," perfectly captures the vibe of the magazine, which offers unfiltered glimpses into the homes of creative types. Though Max lives in London now, he says his parents' house in Cornwall "has bits and bobs on every surface, all the dressing tables and side tables. Every time you go, you see something different."

For those (few) of you who have never heard of Zappos, it is the online store based in Las Vegas that sells mostly shoes, has just hit a billion dollars in sales and was just bought by Amazon for fairly close to a billion dollars. A very interesting story and a very impressive track record.

As the news came in last year announcing widespread shuttering of car dealerships nationwide, the artist Josephine Meckseper initiated her own cash-for-clunkers policy. The German-born artist, who links politics to consumerism in her window displays of motley products including anarchist manifestos, lingerie and the occasional toilet plunger‚ reached out to several lots going out of business and offered to buy their signage and other auto-related paraphernalia. The dealers collectively stonewalled Meckseper's request, since one of the conditions of the car dealers' closings was to destroy any and all sales materials given to their franchise. Enter eBay.

Last week Alfie Kohn, the author of "Unconditional Parenting: Moving from Rewards and Punishments to Love and Reason" and "Punished by Rewards," wrote an essay for the Science section that still seems to have Motherlode readers talking. It was about his belief that punishing children sends the damaging message that you do not love them. You should work with them to solve problems, he says, rather than doing things - such as time outs and loss of privileges - to them.

It's the nature of the human beast, I guess, that we talk more about what's wrong in the world than what's good. I mean, nobody comes up to you at a cocktail party and says, "So! How 'bout that polio vaccine!"

Some of you may remember a post I wrote a while back about new iPhone applications that transform your photos into virtual postcards. Around the same time I also tested out a related group of apps that take your images, turn them into actual physical postcards and mail them to recipients of your choosing. These, I gathered, could be an especially useful service for international travelers who purchase one of AT&T's larger data plans, since they're printed and sent from back home, and therefore potentially solve the problem of your cards arriving in the mailbox of friends and family long after you've returned home.Well, maybe. I tested nine apps, sending a postcard via my iPhone to a colleague in New York on Sept. 4. One of them, TapTap Cards, never worked for me after repeated attempts, and my card from the Postcards app still hasn't arrived more than two weeks later. Of the remaining seven, four arrived 10 days later, two took 12, and one 13. Granted, the Labor Day holiday fell in that period, so subtract one business day, but still, the service isn't exactly fast.

I am at the Inc. 500/5000 Conference near Washington. I am told that there are about 1,700 entrepreneurs coming to the conference and awards dinner. Given the state of the economy over the past year, I find that encouraging. I have talked to quite a few people already, and I can tell you that it is a cross-section of small business, inside and outside of the United States. Sure, some of the people here are expanding their businesses at a tremendous rate and are going to get an award on Friday night. At the same time, many others have felt the pressure of the bad economy and have seen their sales go down. The common denominator is that everyone is looking forward to insights and inspiration from not only a distinguished list of speakers but from one another. I plan on sharing some of those insights with you as I make my way through the conference.

A few minutes ago I walked out of the BMW-Sauber building behind the pitlane after a talk with Mario Theissen, the director of the team, and I felt destabilized. That was not due to anything Theissen had said, but because I had walked into a bright paddock area and only vaguely, suddenly, realized that it was no longer daytime - it was 7:30 in the evening and the sky was black. The crescent moon was covered by a thin cloud and it hovered to the right of the giant Ferris wheel, seen from where I stood. Yes, I was back in the full artificial lighting of Formula One's only night race. The lights earlier in the afternoon had not been on, and now that they had been turned on, it was my first re-acquaintance with the feeling of the nighttime paddock that had been so special last year, the first time this race was run.

A man already accused of killing two women and suspected in the deaths of as many as 30 more was charged with raping and murdering five other victims. The man, John F. Thomas, 73, was charged with killing the women from 1975 to 1986. The women, 56 to 80 years old, were all strangled. Mr. Thomas will stand trial for all seven deaths simultaneously. He has pleaded not guilty and is being held without bail. Calls to his court-appointed lawyers were not immediately returned. Mr. Thomas was initially charged April 2 with two counts of murder after a match from a DNA sample implicated him in the sexual assault and death of a retired school administrator and another woman in the 1970s. The five new charges came as the authorities continue to re-examine cold cases for DNA matches.

A committee charged with examining the future of the Rose Art Museum at Brandeis University, which trustees voted in January to close as the university’s finances worsened, has recommended that the museum remain open. But in a report issued on Wednesday, the group, made up of faculty members, students, university officials and trustees, stopped short of saying whether or not Brandeis should proceed with a plan to sell pieces from the museum’s collection to help shore up the university’s endowment. The committee recommended that the museum “should remain what it is and what it has been since its beginnings” and become more integrated into the university’s educational mission. As for selling the works, the group wrote that it assumed that whatever decision the university made, there would “remain a substantial collection of art to be preserved and made available for research, study and cultivation.”.

For a second week Jay-Z, below, has the No. 1 album on the Billboard chart, with 298,000 copies of “The Blueprint 3” (Roc Nation/Atlantic) sold in the United States. It had 37 percent fewer sales than in its opening week, but that was still almost double the album’s nearest competitor this week. Whitney Houston’s “I Look to You” (Arista), released three weeks ago, got a big sales bump after Ms. Houston was interviewed on “The Oprah Winfrey Show.” The album sold 156,000 copies last week, a 77 percent increase from the week before, and landed at No. 2 on the chart. Muse, a British rock band that performed at the “MTV Video Music Awards” on Sept. 13, opened at No. 3 with 128,000 sales of its new album, “Resistance” (Warner Brothers), and Kid Cudi, a protégé of Kanye West, bowed at No. 4 with “Man on the Moon: The End of Day” (G.O.O.D./Universal Motown), which sold 104,000. Miley Cyrus’s “Time of Our Lives” (Hollywood), available only through Wal-Mart, sold 75,000 copies in its fourth week out and fell three spots to No. 5.

Could Kiss, above, finally make it into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame? After being snubbed for years — the band has been eligible for the honor since 1999 — Kiss has finally been nominated, along with Abba, Donna Summer, Genesis, the Stooges, the Hollies and, in the first year in which they qualify, LL Cool J and the Red Hot Chili Peppers, the museum announced. Jimmy Cliff, Darlene Love, Laura Nyro and the Chantels are also on the ballot, and votes will be cast by a group of more than 500 musicians and industry professionals. Of the 12 nominees, the 5 earning the most votes will be announced in January and inducted into the Hall of Fame at its 25th annual ceremony on March 15 at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel in Manhattan. Acts become eligible 25 years after the release of their first record.

A new song by Michael Jackson, called “This Is It,” will be released next month, Sony Music Entertainment announced on Wednesday. The song, which shares its title with the comeback concerts that Mr. Jackson was rehearsing when he died in June, will be released as a single on Oct. 12, Sony said. Two versions of the song, which includes backing vocals by Mr. Jackson’s brothers, will also appear on a new two-disc set, also called “This Is It,” which will have previously available material and new music. The set will be released internationally on Oct. 26 and in North America on Oct. 27.

Prosecutors in Mexico said they were investigating an assertion that more than 1,000 items attributed to the artist Frida Kahlo in a private collection and two books are forgeries, The Associated Press reported. The attorney general’s office in Mexico City told The A.P. that a complaint filed by the Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo Trust said that paintings, notes and drawings bearing Kahlo’s signature and featured in the books “Finding Frida Kahlo” and “The Labyrinth of Frida Kahlo: Death, Pain and Ambivalence” are fakes. But Princeton Architectural Press, which published “Finding Frida Kahlo,” said it planned to continue selling the book. “In the book we state that the pieces have not been 100 percent authenticated, that it’s still being researched,” said Katharine Myers, the imprint’s publicity director, according to The A.P.
Two CBS series started strongly on Tuesday, boosted by a record audience for “NCIS.”

It was only a matter of time before the movie that taught us about spirit fingers spawned its own musical. On Wednesday Universal Pictures Stage Productions said that it had assembled a creative team for “Bring It On: The Musical,” based on the 2000 comedy “Bring It On” and its video sequels. The stage project’s roster includes several alumni of “In the Heights,” including Andy Blankenbuehler, who will direct and choreograph; Lin-Manuel Miranda, who will compose the music with Tom Kitt (“Next to Normal”); and Alex Lacamoire, who will serve as orchestrator, arranger and music supervisor. Jeff Whitty (“Avenue Q”) is writing the book, and Amanda Green (“High Fidelity”) is writing the lyrics. The musical is planned for a regional production in 2011, followed by a national tour.

The Process In pursuit of a great desk lamp, I visited several stores, examining basic features like lighting quality and ease of adjustment on a wide range of lamps. Innovative, energy-efficient technologies caught my attention, as did intuitive design. Then I took about a half-dozen home to see how they fared under real-life conditions. Criteria included intensity and color of light, how hot the lamps got and how good they looked on the job.

At a recent dinner, we had a table full of people thumbing phone keyboards searching for a bit of trivia critical to our lively debate. That killed the conversation dead. Vark.com has one solution. You pose a question that is sent to a few experts at a time until you get an answer. Vark.com, which is short for the site's proper name, Aardvark, is available as a free app on the iPhone, which means you can find answers to those pesky questions where and when you need them.

WITH fall in the air, people are beginning to think about how to warm up their homes. Laura Kirar, an interior and product designer with offices in Manhattan and Miami, suggests focusing on the floor. Hardwood, ceramic tile or concrete can feel downright chilly in the winter, and -- short of installing radiant subfloor heating -- soft floor coverings and area rugs are the best way to add warmth underfoot, she said. But just as important is the statement a rug makes.

Broadway will soon be home to a different kind of odd couple: the Geoffrey Nauffts play ''Next Fall,'' about two gay men grappling with issues of religious faith, will transfer to the Helen Hayes Theater early next year, its producers said on Wednesday. The play, written by Mr. Nauffts, right, opened in June at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater on West 42nd Street in Manhattan, where it ran through August, and starred Patrick Breen and Patrick Heusinger. Casting for the Broadway production was not announced, but the play will retain its director, Sheryl Kaller. ''Next Fall'' is scheduled to begin previews at the Helen Hayes in mid-February and open on March 11.

9 P.M. (13, 49) PBS SPECIAL REPORT ON HEALTH CARE REFORM Three PBS news programs band together to parse health care reform in this 90-minute report. ''Now on PBS'' examines the ways in which reform may change the lives of Americans, especially baby boomers who have their own coverage but are also responsible for aging parents and grown children. ''Nightly Business Report'' investigates the cost of and controversies surrounding employer-provided health care. WAGNER--Richard. The Board and Staff of Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation ("Brooklyn A") were shocked and deeply saddened to learn of the passing Monday of the program's long term Director of Litigation, Rick Wagner. Rick was a brilliant and fiery lawyer, deeply committed to the struggle for economic and social justice in the world and in our neighborhoods. Over the years he invested his incredible skills in fighting to achieve those goals at the Center for Constitutional Rights, the law firm of Stolar, Alterman, Wagner & Boop, and for the last 25 years at Brooklyn A. He used his enormous energy, creativity and vision to apply, among the other tools, the federal RICO statute to empower tenants, and in most recent years was a national leader in the fight against predatory lending, mortgage frauds and title rescue scams, protecting low income, mostly minority homeowners in huge and successful battles to save or recover their homes. Rick was truly one of a kind, and will be greatly missed by his clients, by his colleagues and by his huge network of admirers. Memorial services will be scheduled shortly. For further info, view www.bka.org.

SanDisk has unleashed new CompactFlash memory cards for D.S.L.R. cameras that have read-write speeds of 90 megabytes a second -- which is at least 50 percent faster than existing technology. I recently met with Eric Bone, SanDisk's vice president for retail product marketing, for a look at the new Extreme Pro cards. To compare speeds, he snapped 15 RAW+JPEG frames in burst mode with an Extreme Pro card and an older Ultra II card. It took 11 seconds to shoot 15 frames with the Extreme Pro card; with the Ultra II card, it took 36 seconds.

AS fall marathons draw closer, training runs become longer, which often translates to more chafing. On runs of 10 miles or longer, friction -- either of skin-on-skin or fabric-on-skin -- can start to burn hot spots on a runner's feet, thighs and nipples, as well as under bra straps. The result? Blisters or painfully raw skin. ''Chafing is a triad of friction, heat and moisture,'' said LaJean Lawson, an expert on the study of breast motion during exercise who helps clothing companies develop low-friction sports gear. ''Friction is especially a problem with running because it is a cyclical motion. You can get rubbed the wrong way two to four times per second.''

Pentax continues its concentration on compact, affordable D.S.L.R. cameras with its new K-x, which sells for $650 with a lens kit. The K-x is the cheapest D.S.L.R. on the market that can capture HD video as well as offer Live View. In fact, its entry-level competitors, the Canon Rebel T1i and the Nikon D5000, are priced at least $150 higher. The K-x is simply designed and feels solid in your hands, yet weighs only 20 ounces (with battery). It employs a 12.4-megapixel CMOS image sensor (with built-in stabilization).

MAXWELL--Elizabeth Scheuer, 97, of New York, Charleston, and Toronto, died peacefully September 11, 2009 at St. Clair-O'Connor Community in Toronto. She is survived by her sister, Margaret Wolff, son John Maxwell and daughter Liza M. Lee, three grandchildren, and a great- grandson. She was born in New York City and survived, along with her mother and sister, the great earthquake of 1923 in Yokohama, Japan. She graduated from the Horace Mann School in New York and from Sweet Briar College. She married Charles R. Maxwell, Jr. in 1938, and was widowed in 1972. She moved to Charleston, SC in 1983, where she was active in the Laura Bragg Club and a passionate supporter of the performing arts. She moved to Toronto in 2005. Her life was devoted to the enjoyment of her friends, and her joie de vivre, independence, and keen wit were inspirational. A funeral service will be held at 2pm Thursday, September 24 at the Chapel of Trinity College, Toronto.

Poland and Estonia have the right to challenge limits placed by the European Commission on their carbon emissions, a court said Wednesday, in a potential setback to near-term goals for cutting emissions. The ruling by the European Court of First Instance is a blow to the commission, the European Union's executive body, which has sought strict quotas to stop governments from giving more allowances to favored industries than necessary to meet pollution targets.

The new Privia PX-130 from Casio (available online for $500) is a nice model for those who want an inexpensive digital keyboard that has the feel of a real piano. I tested it last week at a musical-instrument store and I liked what I heard and felt. Strike a chord with force, and it's noticeably louder than a softly formed chord. The keys at the lower registers are slightly more stiff than in the higher register, just as in a real piano, and notes fade convincingly when using the sustain pedal. The PX-130 even handles quickly repeated notes pretty well. The Privia PX-130 includes 16 sounds, like harpsichord, bass or organ. (Changing instruments requires that you press a combination of two buttons, however, which is a bit clunky.)

NELSON--Sara Jones, born December 9, 1945 in Bloomington, Illinois, died peacefully on Tuesday, September 22 from complications due to recent illnesses. Sara was a devoted and loving wife, mother, grandmother, sister, friend, adviser, teacher, and volunteer. Born and raised in Illinois farm country, Sara moved to New York City in 1966 and quickly built her own small town of friends and colleagues on the Upper West Side, where she was a fixture for more than 40 years. She advised hundreds of eighth graders on high school placement at The Cathedral School of St. John the Divine until she retired in 2003. Earlier in her career, Sara taught nursery school, first in Englewood, New Jersey and then at The Calhoun School. She attended the University of Illinois and graduated from New York University in 1968. She was a tireless champion of All Angels' Church, serving on the vestry and as junior and senior wardens. She was also a board member of The Dome Project, an organization that assists challenged youth. She enjoyed spending weekends in Colebrook, Connecticut, relaxing in the quiet surroundings and attending St. James Church in Winsted. She was blessed by a wide and loyal circle of friends, who cherished her warmth, humor, candor and steadfast companionship. She is survived by Norman, her husband of 43 years, sons Matthew and Clark, daughter-in-law Kimberly, grandchildren Eliza and Luke, and sister Ann Wilkerson. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her honor to Incarnation Center (PO Box 577, Ivoryton, Connecticut 06442). Her funeral will be held at The Cathedral of St. John the Divine (Amsterdam and 112th Street) on Saturday, September 26 at 9:30am, with a reception following the service at The Cathedral School of St. John the Divine.

NOW that the dust has settled on the spring fashion collections in New York, it is possible to sum up the news of the season in three simple looks: above-the-knee skirts, above-the-knee dresses and Spanx. The first two, one could argue, represent a return to optimism by those designers who are holding out hope that stocks really do rise with hemlines. The third is bit of a mystery. Or, as Linda Wells, the editor of Allure, put it last week in a video interview, ''perfectly insane.'' What on earth inspired so many designers -- Donna Karan, Alexander Wang and Marc Jacobs, to name just a few -- to put models in visible underwear that came up above their navels?

THERE is nothing like New York Fashion Week to bring out one's inner Amazon. The hordes descending on Bryant Park last week were combat-ready, jostling their way through crowds clad in leather and steel. The spirit of aggression that surfaced on runways as early as a year ago reared its head last week behind the scenes, where models and onlookers were encased in biker jackets, battle boots and jet-toned jeans. At the Monarchy show, Kate Lanphear (far left, bottom) heeded the call to arms, her wrists festooned in spikes and chains. Backstage at Vena Cava (below), stylists dressed uniformly in tough boots, nailheads and fatigues. And at Monique Lhuillier (far left, middle), even the models took on a fierce mien, their kohl-rimmed eyes seeming to signal, ''on your guard.''

If the world were to expire sometime before Friday, the debate between free will and determinism would trace its history from the Greeks, through the battles between Augustine and Pelagius, Erasmus and Luther, the writings of Hobbes, Hume and William James, ending effectively with the questions posed by big-budget American serial television. In the years since 9/11, producers have found rich thematic material in the arguments for and against preordination, resulting in series like ''The Sarah Connor Chronicles,'' ''Lost'' and now ''FlashForward,'' which begins in such a spirit of bracing suspense that I am challenged to recall another pilot that lured me so quickly into addiction. Loosely based on a clunky science-fiction novel of the same title by Robert J. Sawyer, ''FlashForward'' (starting Thursday on ABC) imagines a global blackout in human consciousness -- lasting precisely 2 minutes 17 seconds -- when billions of people around the world experience visions of their lives six months into the future. Specifically they're seeing themselves on April 29, 2010. And while ''FlashForward'' seems to avoid (at least so far) the geeky pretensions of ''Lost,'' which invite so much circuitous decoding, the date hardly seems arbitrary as it carries the symbolic weight of historic incident.

Former President Jimmy Carter’s White House diaries will be published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux in October 2010, Jeff Seroy, a spokesman for the publishing house said Friday. The publisher has acquired world rights to annotated diaries kept by Mr. Carter, who was president from January 1977 until January 1981. While the diaries amount to about 5,000 pages, the book will be about 512 pages of photographs and selections from the diaries. They will include Mr. Carter’s commentary and observations about the people and places that informed his presidency from the vantage point of 30 years later.

U2’s show at Giants Stadium on Thursday night drew 84,472 fans, breaking the attendance record for the stadium that had been set by Pope John Paul II in 1995, according to Live Nation, the concert’s promoter. “We’ve broken every record for attendance in this stadium, including the Pope,” Bono announced from the stage. “I know they’re knocking this place down. “The Wonderful Wizard of Oz,” an adaptation of that classic L. Frank Baum children’s novel written by Eric Shanower and illustrated by Skottie Young, enters our hardcover list at No. 9 this week. In an interview, Mr. Shanower said he’s seen the tale of Dorothy and her traveling companions told in many different forms: the 1939 MGM film, of course, as well as various comics, foreign editions and abridged versions. “Every time there is a new one, it’s always interesting to me to see what they’re going to cut out of the story,” he said. (He added that the back story of the winged monkeys often ends up on the chopping block.) For his telling, Mr. Shanower said: “I tried to bring nothing new. The book is as faithful an adaptation as I could make it.” Discussing the artwork by Mr. Young, Mr. Shanower said: “Skottie managed to capture the whole world of Oz in a new way. The characters are cute when they have to be cute and scary when they need to be scary.”The complete lists can be found here, along with an explanation of how they were assembled. See you next week!

When you consider the problems that Raf Simons has faced since he became creative director at Jil Sander four years ago, it is not surprising that his latest collection seems so free.

When you consider the problems that Raf Simons has faced since he became creative director at Jil Sander four years ago-new corporate owners, the departure of top managers, the loss of key technicians-it is not surprising that his latest collection seems so free. That was the word that kept coming to my mind tonight: freedom. In reality, fashion is not a free state. Designers have obligations to corporate owners, and some of them, as we have seen with other houses, are not very experienced. Designers must also consider retailers, customers, and editors. And, of course, it is often helpful to the creative process, as well as the bottom line, to work with limits.

With this week's United Nations summit on climate change, New York hosted a who's who of global eminences. But who stole the spotlight? It wasn't the leader of the free world (Barack Obama), a jogging Nicolas Sarkozy or even Mahmoud Ahmedinejad. That honor went to Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya's leader and a lifestyle juggernaut worthy of at least intense head scratching. We'll let others assess the finer points of his 100-minute speech, though it was a lulu. We'll leave the ugly details of his shocking decision to pitch his Bedouin tent (the only way he travels) near the backyard of a friend of one of the Lockerbie bombing victims. We'll even gloss over his schwingy all-female retinue of bodyguards. Because we have enough to say about what he's wearing.

"When it comes to getting people here, we're trying to think outside the white-cube box," says Angela Goding, the head of the Junior Associates, the Museum of Modern Art's thirtysomething patron club. Last year, that meant inviting yogis of all ages to come and stretch their limbs in the midst of Pipolliti Rist's "Pour Your Body Out" video installation, located in the museum's atrium. This Saturday, guests can get a workout again at the inaugural event for the "MoMA MiXX" series, which pairs musicians with visual artists for various fund-raising events throughout the year. The MoMA lobby will turn into a nightclub featuring various D.J.'s, including the artists Mickalene Thomas and Derrick Adams. The cool kids' favorite house and dance D.J., Hercules and Love Affair, rounds out the evening. "It's not just a sweaty dance party," Goding says. "We're trying to get into the heads of the artists by letting them express themselves in a different way." Tickets can be purchased at moma.org/momamixx.

I have had a more eventful history with earrings than most men. My progressive dad took me to get my left ear pierced back in 1992, when I was 15, on a family trip to the West Coast. By the time I got to college I had pierced my right ear and put another hole in my left, but a couple years later I took them all out. I hadn't thought about it again until a couple of months ago, when I noticed that the jewelry designer Philip Crangi was wearing two earrings in his left ear and one in his right. His story was similar to mine, albeit a bit more extreme: by the time he got tired of wearing his, in 1995, he had six holes in each ear. (Very '90s). He didn't put any earrings on again until he started designing them specifically for men. "I keep it pretty simple now, with a classic '80s smallish stud," he said. "My favorite is the slotted screw head stud from my Giles & Brother collection."

Young designers at this year's London Design Festival have found a new patron saint in Tom Dixon, who recently moved his studio to a former Virgin Records recording studio in a newly minted business complex called Portobello Dock. The design superstar is not only opening a new showroom there this week but has also collaborated with the complex's developer to fill two of its other buildings with mostly British, mostly emerging designers in a show aptly named the Dock. Dixon may have a reputation for introversion now, but before he was a mega-brand he did a stint throwing parties on the London scene, and he has certainly succeeded in making the Dock the place to see and be seen this week.

In the usually staid world of Paris's palace hotels, the threshold for news can be pretty low - another Michelin star or some new spa rooms will do the trick. But the Hôtel Le Bristol, which happens to have added both those things recently, now has something that few, if any, grande dame hotels will brag about anytime soon: an entirely new wing.Fashioned from five apartments in an adjacent building at the intersection of Avenue Matignon and Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré, the new wing is spread over seven stories and is the culmination of years of planning, development, wrangling and lawsuits. Twenty-six individually decorated rooms and suites are done up with silk and cotton fabrics, faux stucco walls and a handful of antique reproductions and paintings in an old-masters style. The overall look and feel is sort of streamlined traditional - not ornate or overembellished but comfortable and perhaps a bit spartan, considering the price tag. (Hotel officials will only admit to "tens of millions of euros.")

The television season is just a week old, but the buzz about it seems to have grown to thunderous proportions. Every where you look, someone is championing the self-referential glories of NBC's "Community" or singing the praises of Fox's "Glee" and going on (and on) about CBS' "The Good Wife." And it doesn't stop with the broadcast networks: AMC's "Mad Men" is trending toward event status while HBO's "Bored to Death" is building audience and chatter.

By a margin of 52 percent to 27 percent, Americans believe President Obama has better ideas about overhauling health care than Republicans do, according to a national poll conducted by The New York Times and CBS News. And nearly two-thirds of the country supports creation of a government-run insurance plan, or public option. Read the full story.

After the languid days of summer, we're in the mood for some get-up-and-go, so it's the perfect time for a new issue of T: Travel. From our cover story on Vietnam's imperial capital, Hue, to a look at Ticino, where Switzerland shows its Italian side, to a report on a 3,000-acre park in Brazil devoted to some of the world's most extraordinary contemporary art, there's plenty here to make you forget all about those plans for a staycation. If closer to home is more your speed, we stop in Austin, Tex., to consider the latest stage in its evolution, as well as the small town of Boulder, Utah, where a bunch of committed idealists are making a case for sustainable development - and creating a haven for fellow travelers. And because one of travel's latest trends is renewed interest in the tried and true, we've also created a comprehensive guide to what's cool in Paris. (Hint: it's more about La Cigale than Ladurée.) Get packing!

As we wrote about on Thursday, Eric Dane, an actor from "Grey's Anatomy" - aka "Dr. McSteamy" - and his wife Rebecca Gayheart had their attorney Marty Singer file a $1 million suit against Gawker Media for its role in publishing a video of them romping in the altogether. The little imps at Gawker, not ones to let a lawsuit cramp their style, posted the complaint in its entirety. And as it turns out, the actors are not alleging libel, slander or invasion of privacy as a primary cause of the action, but rather that Gawker violated their copyright on the salacious video. The complaint states that "Plaintiffs timely (sic) registered with the United States Copyright Office their rights as authors and owners of the video. The copyright registration number is PAu 3-404-881."

But a few minutes ago during the first practice session of the Singapore race, at 18:41 in the evening, that is precisely what happened as Romain Grosjean, the driver who replaced Nelson Piquet Jr. crashed his car in the same way and in the same corner as the man who caused the scandal that has darkened this F1 weekend crashed last year on purpose to help his teammate win the race.

If you find the large icons in the Windows Vista (and Windows 7) Start menu large and unwieldy, you can knock them down to a more elegant size by adjusting a system setting. Just right-click on the Windows taskbar and choose Properties from the pop-up menu. Click the Start Menu tab in the box that appears and then click on the Customize button. Scroll down until you get to the "Use large icons" line and remove the checkmark from the box. Click O.K. until all the dialog boxes are closed.

Metallurgical Corporation of China, a building and engineering firm that raised $2.3 billion in Hong Kong's biggest initial public offering this year, fell in its debut on the exchange Thursday as investors apparently tired from a deluge of such offerings and judged the stock to be too expensive given an uncertain outlook for China's steel industry.

Nomura's $5.6 billion sale of new shares looks like the latest opportunistic swoop on a frothy equity market, Breakingviews.com says. The move shores up the Japanese bank's balance sheet at a time when its share price has shot up over 60 percent since March. But it's also an implicit acknowledgment that joining the global banking big leagues is darned expensive, the Web site says.

Kentucky state police said that a census field worker who was found hanging from a tree near a cemetery in rural southeast Kentucky this month died of asphyxiation. The body of the man, Bill Sparkman, a 51-year-old part-time census field worker, was found Sept. 12 in a remote patch of the Daniel Boone National Forest. The state police said that Mr. Sparkman was found with a rope around his neck that was tied to a tree, but that he was “in contact with the ground.” The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating whether Mr. Sparkman was a victim of antigovernment sentiment. The authorities have not determined if it was an accidental death, suicide or homicide.

Currently, I benefit greatly from being able to purchase great MedAdvantage insurance cheaply, as it is subsidized heavily. This pleasant circumstance follows years of not being able to afford good coverage at all. I realize health care reform likely will increase the cost of my MedAdvantage program, and it should. I welcome it. It is unfair and, more importantly, poor policy for so many to be so negatively affected by a few people's cushy plan. There must be a better way to offer enhanced Medicare coverage. -- Carl Axelsen, 66, a retired businessman in Portland, Ore., in a comment posted on the Prescriptions blog. He was referring to the Senate Finance Committee's fight over whether to reduce federal subsidies for the Medicare Advantage plans offered by private insurers.
FRANKLIN EVANS '2008/2009

The cascade of injuries to the Giants' defense grew worse Thursday, when safety Kenny Phillips was put on injured reserve with patella femoral arthritis in his left knee. Phillips is out for the season and surgery is possible. ''I just felt I could push it through the season,'' Phillips said in a statement. ''So to get this news is a real shock.''

During the Senate Finance Committee health care debate on Thursday, Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, decided to share his personal experience in fighting high cholesterol. Mr. Schumer, top, said his doctor had directed him to take Lipitor, which is made by Pfizer, and then, after his cholesterol levels had dropped, suggested that he try a less expensive, generic medication. But he switched back after his cholesterol levels went back up. ''I'm taking Lipitor even though it's more expensive,'' Mr. Schumer said.

BELCHER--Valerie Elizabeth Vance, of New York, died suddenly on September 21, 2009. She was the daughter of Geraldine Vance and the late James Vance. Beloved wife of Taylor Michael Belcher. Loving mother of Elizabeth Santos (Louis Zelus) James Santos and Taylor Edward Belcher. Stepmother of John Michael Belcher, sister of Victoria Vance Weiskopf and James Vance (Diane). Devoted aunt to James, Jonathan, Jesse and Jordan Vance, Brandon and Whitney Weiskopf. Valerie attended Our Lady of Perpetual Help Grammar and High Schools in Brooklyn before becoming a nurse. She was great wife, parent, daughter, sister and friend. She also had a deep devotion to animals, volunteering at shelters as well as adopting stray dogs and cats. Valerie worked as a nurse at the Dwight School in Manhattan before moving to Florida and San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. She returned to New York a month ago to be with her family. Valerie was taken from us much too young, was deeply loved and will always be missed and remembered. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue on Saturday, September 26, at 1:30pm.

Tom Stoppard and Zaha Hadid were among the winners of the Praemium Imperiale arts awards, announced Thursday by the Japan Art Association. The awards, which come with a prize of about $163,000 each, are given for lifetime arts achievement in categories not covered by the Nobel Prizes. They were established in 1988 to mark the association's 100th anniversary and to honor Prince Takamatsu, its longtime honorary patron, who died in 1987. In a news release, the association said that in addition to Mr. Stoppard, who is being honored for his theater and film work, and Ms. Hadid, this year's architecture laureate, it would give awards to the photographer Hiroshi Sugimoto, the sculptor Richard Long and the pianist Alfred Brendel. The awards will be bestowed in a ceremony in Tokyo on Oct. 22. ... Two former officials of Medellín, Colombia, will share the Curry Stone Design Prize for a public works plan that helped rejuvenate one of the city's poorest neighborhoods. The administrators for the annual design award said on Thursday that its $100,000 prize would be split by Alejandro Echeverri, the city's former director of urban projects, and Sergio Fajardo, its former mayor, for a plan that brought modern buildings and public spaces to the slums of Medellín over a four-year period. During that time, the city reported a reduction in homicides and an increase in tourism.

RAUCH--Ruth Treiber, 92, died September 23, 2009 in Westminster, Maryland. She is survived by her sister, Marilyn Treiber, daughter Nancy R. Douzinas and husband Kostas, son Philip J. Rauch and wife Lynn, four grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. She was born in Brooklyn, New York, and graduated from Packer Collegiate Institute and Wells College before receiving a graduate degree in German Literature from Columbia University. During World War II, she taught high school German and English in the Albany public schools. She married Louis J. Rauch in 1945 and was widowed in 1992. She was a passionate supporter of the arts and loved travel, horseback riding, and poetry. A memorial service will take place at a future date.

He was the beloved husband of Ginger Saskin Boockvar and the loving father of Kenny, Kathy, Johnny and Danny. He was also the adored grandfather of 10; Elam, Aaron, Jesse, Colette, Nathan, Charlie, Daphne, Ivy, Emma, and Jason. He was the devoted brother of Alan Boockvar and Gail Jurrist, and was a well-loved and respected ophthalmologist in his community. His wife, children, and grandchildren were his greatest joy. He will be greatly missed.

In the last years of the cold war, the ultrasecret research institute that had designed the Soviet Union's nuclear submarines received an unusual request: could it build a high-speed train? The Soviet Union, despite its dependence on railroads, had fallen far behind Japan and Western Europe on high-speed transport. That the order came to the Rubin design bureau suggests that Moscow viewed catching up as a matter of national security.

NIGHTFALL came after the rain had stopped, and in the wet woods columns of fog twisted around dripping trees. It was 10 p.m. on a summer Friday, the forest moonless and still at the trailhead to the Devil's Path. An opening in the woods off the parking lot looked like a dark door. Beyond, a small trail edged into the night, its route unseen. The Devil's Path, an east-to-west voyage along the spine of the Catskills, is often cited as the toughest hiking trail in the East. In 25 miles it ascends six major peaks, plunging into deep valleys between climbs.

GURWIN--Joseph. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the passing of our esteemed Board member and friend, Joseph Gurwin, whose appreciation and support for JDC's endeavors on behalf of Jewish needs overseas manifested itself in many ways. He helped to oversee the evolution of JDC programming in the former Soviet Union, and his generosity enabled us to establish a flagship Jewish Community Center in Dnepropetrovsk, Ukraine--the first designed specifically for that purpose. The founder of Kings Point Industries, he was a strong supporter of high-technology and the advancement of science in Israel, and here in New York, he dedicated much effort to the improvement of geriatric care and a host of other communal needs. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Phyllis; his children, Dr. Eric Gurwin and Laura Flug; and the entire Gurwin family. May his memory be for a blessing. Dr. Irving A. President Obama scored a big victory on Thursday as the Senate Finance Committee rejected a proposal to require pharmaceutical companies to give bigger discounts to Medicare on drugs dispensed to older Americans with low incomes. The victory came at the expense of senators in Mr. Obama's own party who had championed the proposal. The vote, in effect, upheld a deal reached in June by the White House and the drug industry, which saw the agreement as a possible way to avoid more onerous requirements that might be imposed by Congress.

A painting by René Magritte was stolen from a Brussels museum on Thursday morning by two armed men, The Guardian reported. The robbery occurred just after 10 a.m., shortly after the museum, a former home of Magritte, opened, when a man rang the doorbell to ask if visiting hours had started. The man then pointed a gun at the museum attendant while an accomplice went inside. The thieves made museum workers and visitors kneel in a courtyard while they left on foot with a 1948 painting, ''Olympia,'' above, a nude portrait of Magritte's wife. The Guardian said that the men, who spoke English and French, set off an alarm when they broke a glass plate that protected the painting, but that they had escaped by the time the police arrived. The stolen work is said to be worth about $1.1 million, according to The Guardian.

GURWIN--Joseph. The leadership, staff, and worldwide community of the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of our dear and most beloved friend, Joseph Gurwin. A passionate advocate for the Weizmann Institute, Joe was the recipient of an Honorary Doctorate and a member of the President's Circle. He served on the Executive Committee and Board of Directors of the American Committee, and on the International Board of the Institute. His deep involvement over the past decades with the Weizmann Institute, and the Palm Beach Region in particular, will be missed, along with his wisdom, passion, and humility. He made a profound impact on the quality and spirit of the Weizmann Institute, leading by example through his contributions. His many gifts include the establishment, with his late wife, Rosalind, of the Rosalind and Joseph Gurwin Vacuum Processing Laboratory in the Institute's Submicron Research Center. Recently, he and his wife Phyllis established the Phyllis and Joseph Gurwin Fund for Scientific Advancement, which helps move promising research from the laboratory to the marketplace--a gift that exemplifies his practical commitment to the future of Science for the Benefit of Humanity and the Weizmann Institute. Having narrowly escaped the Holocaust, Joe once said, "I believe that we were born in this universe to make it a better place, and in order to make it a better place we have to give back." His generosity in supporting Weizmann research has indeed made the world a better place--and, thanks to his foresight and planning, will continue to produce world-changing science long into the future. Joe's philosophy of compassion lives on in his wife, Phyllis; his children, Laura and Eric; his daughter-in-law, Karen; his stepsons, Gene and Bob Pressman; and his grandchildren, Danielle, Jeffrey, Jason, and Jaclyn, to whom we send heartfelt condolences. May they and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lawrence S. Blumberg, Chairman American Committee Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Marshall S. Levin, Executive V.P. and C.E.O. American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President Weizmann Institute

As the two-day Group of 20 meeting brought leaders of the world's industrialized nations here Thursday, the police were out in force, patrolling on bicycles, foot and horseback, by river and by air. In the afternoon, protesters trying to march toward the convention center where the gathering is being held encountered roaming squads of police officers carrying plastic shields and batons. The police fired a sound cannon that emitted shrill beeps, causing demonstrators to cover their ears and back up, then threw tear gas canisters that released clouds of white smoke and stun grenades that exploded with sharp flashes of light.

BLUMBERG--Bruce Arthur, 64, of Westfield, NJ died Wednesday of mesothelioma. He was born in Somerville, NJ in 1945. Bruce graduated with honors from both Yale University (1966) and Harvard Law School (1969). After a brief stint at a Wall Street firm, he returned to Somerset County to join his family's law firm (Blumberg & Rosenberg, PA) that had been established decades earlier by his father. Over the years, he enjoyed working with clients from a variety of backgrounds and appreciated his loyal staff. Bruce is survived by his parents, Leonard and Adele of Bridgewater, Gwen Jones (his wife of 23 years), his brother Allen, his sister Joyce Kozloff, his daughter Erika, his sons Joshua and Jesse, and his grandson Miles, whom he called "the light of my life". In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Mesothelioma Applied Research Foundation (www.curemeso.org). Funeral services will be held at 1:00pm on Friday, September 25 at Temple Sholom in Bridgewater, NJ.

The global financial crisis knocked Germany and the rest of the world badly off course this year. Yet as the country grinds toward national elections on Sunday, the campaign's most notable absence has been a debate over the direction and future of Europe's largest economy. Neither Chancellor Angela Merkel nor her challenger from the center-left, Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier, has delved deeply into policy matters, preferring to focus on personality and politics. And neither is temperamentally inclined to attack the other.

The vandalism of two installations at LentSpace, the new public art space at the northwest corner of Canal and Sullivan Streets, on Tuesday night was apparently just fine with the artists who made the works. ''This Is Not Art'' was spray-painted on them, but the artists, Ryan Taber and Graham Hudson, asked the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, which organized the exhibition of seven works, to let the graffiti stay, according to Maggie Boepple, the council president. The council respectfully declined the request and not so respectfully set about applying Spot Off to the works, a chemical compound that does just what its name says and that Ms. Boepple said was ''at the ready'' from the day the space opened to the public last Friday. ''While we support everyone's right to express themselves, to deface art is totally unacceptable and disrespectful,'' Ms. Boepple said. The two vandalized artworks are made of construction materials and found objects -- concrete, broken ladders, a flagpole and climbing-wall restraints. Mr. Taber's piece is titled ''Pompey's Folley,'' and Mr. Hudson's is ''Canal St. Commons.''

Liberal Senate Democrats will push to add a government-run insurance program to the health care bill in the Finance Committee on Friday, setting off a potentially explosive debate with Republicans who view the idea as a step toward ''socialized medicine.'' Senators John D. Rockefeller IV, right, Democrat of West Virginia, and Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said Thursday that they would propose the so-called public option because efforts to revamp the health system and cover the uninsured would fail without it.

New York's reigning billionaire, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, cares little for most sports but plays a lot of golf. He likes discreet dinner parties at Gracie Mansion or his own mansion. He wants his private life kept private. New York's latest billionaire, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, loves basketball, kickboxing and skiing. He probably wishes his private life could be kept private: Consider the four days he spent in custody in an Alpine ski resort in 2007 when investigators suspected call girls were being brought in. He was quoted as saying they were students and models, not prostitutes.

In addition to a question-and-answer and autograph session, the group will be performing on Saturday at 3 p.m. (It will also give a free concert at Webster Hall on Sunday at 4 p.m.)

GURWIN--Joseph. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the loss of a great Jewish leader and former chair of our board, Joseph Gurwin. Mr. Gurwin and his late wife, Rosalind, will be remembered for their vision in establishing the Gurwin Jewish Nursing & Rehabilitation Center, a beneficiary agency that has set the standard for quality compassionate care for the elderly. His Jewish philanthropic endeavors were dedicated to saving every life possible through health, science, and the rescue and resettlement of Jews in danger, anywhere in the world. His love for Israel and the Jewish people was matched only by his devotion to his family. His efforts live on in the commitment of his beloved wife, Phyllis, and his children, Eric Gurwin and Laura Flug. If a man's stature is measured by the impact of his charitable deeds, then Mr. Gurwin stood as a giant among us, leaving an inspiring legacy that will be felt for generations to come. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Phyllis; to Eric and his wife, Karen; to Laura; to his grandchildren, Danielle, Jeffrey, Jason, and Jaclyn; and to the entire Gurwin and Pressman families. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Gov. Deval Patrick today named Paul G. Kirk Jr., a former aide and longtime confidant of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy, to Mr. Kennedy's seat. ''He shares the sense of service that so distinguished Senator Kennedy,'' Governor Patrick, a Democrat, said at a news conference in Boston. ''The interests of the commonwealth have never been more vital or at stake in the Congress today.''

HARMAN--Bob, of the Covert Farm in Ovid, NY died on Wednesday, September 16, 2009. Born in Rochester, New York, a son of the late H. A. and Lottie Lee (Covert) Harman. A former professional actor, Bob Harman began his art career doing caricatures of his fellow performers. His paintings, including portraits of Marion Anderson, Archibald Macleish, Dean Acheson and John D. Rockefeller II, are owned by many institutions. In 1971 he created "The Hollywood Panorama" a five by nine foot montage of 1001 film stars against a background of famous sets and Hollywood landmarks. It was published in book form by E.P. Dutton. He followed this with three more books including, "Enchanted Faces"-portraits of film actresses between the two World Wars. Dubbed the "Artist of the Stars", his column "Movie Memories" appeared for five years in a national newspaper. In 2000 he was selected as one of the artists to be represented in the special one year bicentennial exhibit at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, DC. For several years he was retired in Santa Barbara, CA and his family home in Ovid, NY. Funeral Arrangements were completed privately in New York. For condolences, please visit www.covertfuneralhome.com

Terry Francona routinely shows a self-deprecating side while navigating his demanding job as manager of the Boston Red Sox. When Francona was asked last October how many Red Sox fans would consider him one of the finest managers in the major leagues, he said, ''My dad would.'' While Francona is usually not mentioned ahead of Tony La Russa, Joe Torre, Mike Scioscia or Jim Leyland when managers are rated, he has been successful and savvy since taking over the Red Sox in 2004. With Boston's 10-3 victory over Kansas City on Thursday night, Francona now has the second-most victories in franchise history.

In a long and illustrious European coaching career, Ettore Messina has worked for a fair amount of professional basketball owners. None of them, he said, were quite like Mikhail D. Prokhorov, a Russian tycoon who seemed destined to play moneyball in America. ''The guy has a way about him, a vision,'' said Messina, who coached for Prokhorov for four years at CSKA Moscow, a top Russian club.

If you played with dolls as a child (or even if you admit to occasionally coveting them as an adult), the film industry is assembling a movie for you. The Hollywood Reporter said that Universal had acquired the rights to make a feature film based on Barbie, the impossibly proportioned Mattel doll who has been gazing placidly from store shelves since 1959. The live-action film will be produced by Laurence Mark, a producer of the 2009 Academy Awards who has also produced films like ''Julie & Julia'' and ''Dreamgirls,'' but there was no word on who would play Barbie or her anatomically incorrect companion, Ken.

GURWIN--Joseph. With profound sadness the Board of Directors, Administration, Staff and Residents of the Gurwin Jewish Nursing & Rehabilitation Center mourn the loss of our esteemed founding President and benefactor, Joseph Gurwin. Joe was an inspiring, kind and generous gentleman, whose dedication to philanthropy brought lasting joy and an enhanced quality of life to countless people throughout the United States and around the globe. Because of his inability to bring his parents to the United States before they perished in the Holocaust, Joe and his late wife Rosalind took the opportunity to help create a Center that would care for the parents of others in a dignified and compassionate manner. His vision, dedication and leadership through the years have made the Gurwin name synonymous with excellence in caring for the elderly and those in need. He touched countless lives and will forever be remembered for helping to make his dream of "caring for those who cared for us" possible. Our Center will long stand as a legacy to our very special friend. We express heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Phyllis, his children Laura Flug, Eric and Karen Gurwin and his grandchildren Danielle, Jeffrey, Jason and Jaclyn, as well as the Pressman family. Lawrence Simon, Chairman Bert E. Brodsky, President Herbert H. Friedman, Exec VP

Federal officials announced charges against a Brooklyn man on Thursday, saying he traveled overseas intent on joining a terrorist group and fighting United States forces in Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans. Authorities said the man, Betim Kaziu, 21, a former building porter who was born and raised in Brooklyn, flew from Kennedy International Airport to Cairo in February in the first leg of a journey he hoped would take him to Pakistan for militant training. Authorities said that while in Egypt he made repeated attempts to buy weapons and tried to join a terrorist group linked to Al Qaeda. In addition, authorities said, Mr. Kaziu made efforts to travel to Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.

FEDER--Benjamin, died on September 24, 2009 at his home, Clinton Vineyards, in Clinton Corners, NY. He was 86 years old. He had battled cancer with his customary grace and courage. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis Rich Feder and daughters Jenny and Carrie and son, Geoffrey and granddaughter Lila. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., on Sunday, September 27 at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations to Hospice of Dutchess County or the New York Philharmonic Musicians' Fund. A tribute to Mr. Feder will be held at Clinton Vineyards at a later date.

President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, reversing one of the more memorable lines in the annals of speeches at the United NationsGeneral Assembly, declared Thursday that the smell of sulfur had deserted the green marble podium. ''It doesn't smell of sulfur here anymore, it's gone,'' said a grinning Mr. Chávez, who was one of about 40 leaders to address the assembly. ''It smells of something else -- it's hope.'' He was referring to the address by President Obama on Wednesday. Mr. Chávez infamously said from the same pulpit in 2006 that it smelled like sulfur shortly after President George W. Bush had spoken, and he referred to Mr. Bush repeatedly as ''the devil.''

People with pre-existing conditions who have been turned down for health insurance could get a lifeline under the Senate Finance Committee's proposed health plan: they would be eligible to sign up for a high-risk insurance pool that would accept all applicants, regardless of health status. Sounds good, right? Well, not so fast. Many experts say the high-risk pools already available in 35 states are plagued by high costs and inadequate coverage.

GURWIN--Joseph. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the loss of Joseph Gurwin. Mr. Gurwin, whose parents were murdered in the Holocaust, was a Museum Founder and among its earliest supporters, helping to build the institution. We offer our deepest condolences to his wife Phyllis, his children Eric and Laura, and his entire family. Fred S. Zeidman, Chairman Joel M. Geiderman, Vice Chairman Sara J. Bloomfield, Director United States Holocaust Memorial Museum

STEINMAN--Ray. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Loving mother of Monte Steinman, Amy and Peter Blauzvern. Cherished Nana of Adam, David and Sara. Services Sunday, 10am at "Guttermans", 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, L.I.

The New York Red Bulls will open Red Bull Arena on Saturday, March 27, when they host the Chicago Fire for the start of their 2010 M.L.S regular season. Since the league began, the franchise had played in the 79,000-seat Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. The new soccer-specific stadium in Harrison will seat 25,000. The 7 p.m. opener will be televised on ESPN2.

Palau, an island nation in the Western Pacific, is banning fishing for sharks in its waters, Matt Rand, director of the Pew Environment Group's shark conservation program, said Thursday. Mr. Rand said Johnson Toribiong, the country's president, would announce the ban in a speech on Friday at the United Nations. Conservation experts with Pew, a nonprofit organization based in Washington, describe the ban as a first. It will apply to waters covering an area about the size of Texas that are home to scores of shark species, Mr. Rand said. He conceded that Palau, which has a population of barely 20,000, would have difficulty enforcing the ban, but he said he expected other countries would follow Palau's lead on the issue.

Two new ABC comedies had solid debuts on Wednesday night. According to Nielsen's estimates, the ABC series ''Modern Family'' drew 12.7 million viewers, followed by ''Cougar Town,'' which had 11.4 million. Those shows were surely helped by a lead-in from the reality hit ''Dancing With the Stars'' (15 million), and ABC finished second for the night over all. CBS finished first, with a lineup that included its returning sitcoms ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' (7.7 million) and ''Gary Unmarried'' (7.4 million), followed by ''Criminal Minds'' (15.4 million). NBC was third over all with a lineup that included the new hospital drama ''Mercy'' (8.2 million); its ''Jay Leno Show'' was beaten by CBS's ''CSI: NY'' (14.6 million) and ABC's new series ''Eastwick'' (8.5 million). Fox ranked fourth with ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (5.6 million), followed by ''Glee'' (6.6 million).

The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 19 through Sept. 23 with 1,042 adults throughout the United States. The sample of land line telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 69,000 active residential exchanges across the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to ensure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population.

Given the myriad other roles Paul G. Kirk Jr. has played for Senator Edward M. Kennedy -- strategist, divorce lawyer, master of ceremonies at the senator's memorial service, executor of his estate -- his appointment Thursday as the interim appointee to the Senate seat Mr. Kennedy held was both kismet and deeply pragmatic. He is not only as loyal a Kennedy soldier as they come -- crucial at a time when the late senator's dearest cause, a health care overhaul, will be the subject of a contentious vote in Congress.

The cast for the coming Off Broadway transfer of ''Avenue Q'' should look familiar to audiences who have seen that satirical puppet musical on Broadway or on its national tour. Press representatives for ''Avenue Q'' said on Thursday that its cast at New World Stages would consist of Anika Larsen (from the final Broadway cast and national tour) as Kate Monster/Lucy; Seth Rettberg (a Broadway and tour alumnus) as Princeton/Rod; Cullen Titmus (from the tour) as Nicky/Trekkie Monster; Danielle K. Thomas (also from the final Broadway cast) as Gary Coleman; Sala Iwamatsu (a Broadway veteran) as Christmas Eve; Nicholas Kohn (from the final Broadway company) as Brian; and Maggie Lakis (from the tour) as Mrs. T/Bad Idea Bear. The New World Stages production of ''Avenue Q'' is to begin previews Oct. 9, with an official opening night of Oct. 21.

President Obama will announce Friday that the once elite club of rich industrial nations known as the Group of 7 will be permanently replaced as a global forum for economic policy by the much broader Group of 20 that includes China, Brazil, India and other fast-growing developing countries, administration officials said Thursday. The move highlights the growing economic importance of Asia and some Latin American countries, particularly since the United States and many European countries have found their banking systems crippled by an economic crisis originating in excesses in the American mortgage market.

The United States' decision to engage the ruling junta in Myanmar drew the endorsement on Thursday of that nation's most prominent dissident, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, but analysts cautioned that the change would not have a significant effect soon. On Wednesday, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said the United States would pursue engagement, though it would maintain the economic sanctions that had been imposed to punish the government of Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, for its human rights abuses and restrictions on political freedom. The shift represents the most significant modification of administration policy toward Myanmar in decades, but analysts said it was likely to face opposition in Congress, where many members strongly support an antagonistic approach to the junta. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi has long been an advocate of sanctions but has also tried to engage the ruling generals in a dialogue and has said any future government would have to include the military. ''She said she accepts direct engagement, but it must be on both sides,'' her lawyer, U Nyan Win, said after visiting her on Thursday. By both sides, he said, she meant both government and opposition.

The Third Moscow Biennale of Contemporary Art opened on Thursday evening at the Garage Center for Contemporary Culture, an art gallery founded by Daria Zhukova, the companion of the Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich. The French curator Jean-Hubert Martin brought together 78 artists for the main project, titled ''Against Exclusion,'' from countries including Benin, China, Australia and Russia. Installations include live chickens by the Belgian artist Koen Vanmechelen and ''Painting in Absurdistan,'' above, by Gloria Friedmann. Contemporary art has been controversial in Russia in recent years, with criminal charges of ''inciting hatred'' filed against the former director of Moscow's Sakharov Museum, Yuri Samodurov, and the curator Andrei Erofeev for a contemporary art exhibition titled ''Forbidden Art'' that was held there. It has also been profitable and embraced by wealthy Russians as a sign of social status and sophisticated tastes, although the art market has suffered from the financial crisis.

Matchup to Watch: Jets' Defense vs. Titans' Running BacksLed by Coach Rex Ryan and the coordinator Mike Pettine, the Jets rank first over all in total defense for the first time since Week 5 of the 1982 season. They lead the N.F.L. in fewest yards allowed per play (4.19), fewest opponent plays of 20 yards or more (2), fewest points allowed (9) and fewest offensive touchdowns allowed (0).

Matchup to Watch: Derrick Ward vs. Giants' Defense Ward gained 1,025 rushing yards last season for the Giants before leaving for Tampa Bay as a free agent. Last week, the Giants gave up 251 yards on the ground, but beat Dallas, 33-31. Two defensive starters, safety Kenny Phillips and defensive end Justin Tuck, are out for the Giants, with Phillips out for the year. If the Buccaneers score an upset, this could be the reason.

Sonia Sotomayor, the first Hispanic to be named a Supreme Court justice, performed in a much different capacity at Yankee Stadium on Saturday. Sotomayor was a smiling Yankees fan who got to toss out the first pitch before the Yankees played the Boston Red Sox.

I'm not sure what to make of this Sunday crossword by Patrick Berry. There's a gimmick hinted at by the title. I thought I had it figured out, and then I didn't. And then I thought for sure that I had it figured out, only it was even trickier than I then thought. I guess that's the point. I predict there will be a class of solvers who find this annoying. I had enough patience to work it through and, in the end, it's actually very elegant.

1. So much for an improved Michigan team validating the quality of the Big Ten. The Wolverines' limp effort, including a porous defense, against Indiana in a 36-33 win further exposes how watered down that league is. Does the hunt to replace Greg Robinson at defensive coordinator begin Sunday? Indiana got into the red zone five times with just one touchdown. It could have been much worse for Michigan. Robinson got bailed out by a terrible call on an interception with just over two minutes to go. There was simultaneous possession with the Indiana receiver and Michigan defender, and Hoosiers Coach Bill Lynch was so irate he sprinted more than 20 yards and threw his gum in disgust. Were Pac-10 officials in the booth?

Peter Forsberg's comeback trail gets a little brighter as he scores the overtime decider for hometown club Modo Hockey Örnsköldsvik in a 2-1 win over Djurgården at Stockholm. Forsberg, who is 36 and returning to play after retiring from the N.H.L. at end of the 2007-08 season, also sets up Modo's first goal with a beautiful fake shot and cross-ice pass. He now has two goals in two games in the Swedish Elitserien this season after recovering from several foot and ankle surgeries.

Here at Decoder, we think it's only fair that people be good at one thing. Given our limited skill set, the threat of multiplatform players is just a little too daunting. With that in mind, can we just say how offended we are that Lawrence Wright, a staff writer for The New Yorker who won a Pulitzer Prize for his ambitious "Looming Tower," will be gigging in town this Saturday at Hill Country BBQ as the leader of WhoDo, an Austin-based blues and rockabilly band? It's enough of a task to come to grips with Mr. Wright's skills at the keyboard and ability to go long and glorious -- last spring he wrote a heave about Carlos Slim, the Mexican mogul who bought a piece of a certain little newspaper -- but now we find out he pounds a keyboard that makes music as well. And if that isn't sickening enough, WhoDo, which includes some other hacks turned musicians like John Burnett of NPR, will be backing Ruby Jane Smith, the 14-year-old fiddling phenom who has tongues wagging every which way every time she plays. Most journalists, including those of us at Decoder, are challenged to get a toe tapping in time to the music, so excuse us for not jumping for joy at the specter of journo-journeymen musicians. Honesty and craft compel us to mention that we hear the band is wonderful, but it's still a bit much, no?

After facing protests for laying off 98 housekeeping workers at three Boston-area hotels, Hyatt Hotels said it had arranged for a janitorial company, United Service Companies, to offer them full-time jobs at their previous pay rate through the end of 2010. Hyatt declined to rehire them even though Gov. Deval Patrick had called for state employees to boycott Hyatt unless the workers were reinstated. The laid-off housekeepers averaged around $15 an hour with health benefits, while the new housekeepers hired through a temporary agency receive $8 an hour without health benefits. Phil Stamm, general manger of the Hyatt Regency Boston, said, “Every housekeeping employee who wants a job will have one.” Lucine Williams, a laid-off housekeeper, said: “I don’t want Hyatt to find me a job. I want Hyatt to give me back my job. It’s insulting for them to say I’m not good enough to go back to work for them.” Hyatt said it would extend the laid-off workers’ health benefits through March 31, when they would have the option of obtaining benefits through the janitorial company or any other employer they worked for.

An article on Wednesday about a decision by the Environmental Protection Agency to require the nation’s biggest emitters of greenhouse gases to start reporting those emissions misstated the intent of a draft amendment circulated in Congress proposing to restrict the agency’s authority. The amendment, for an appropriations bill, would have prevented the E.P.A. from spending money to regulate carbon dioxide emissions from nonmobile sources; it would not have prevented it from monitoring those emissions. (The amendment was blocked on Thursday by Senate Democrats.).

The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, right, whose dire financial situation has forced deep layoffs and programming cutbacks, has announced that it raised nearly $60 million over the last nine months, a significant turnaround for a museum whose endowment shrank to about $6 million last December from more than $40 million near the beginning of the decade. Half of the total comes from Eli Broad, Los Angeles’s leading cultural patron, who pledged $30 million late last year to bail out the museum. Charles E. Young, chief executive of the museum, told The Los Angeles Times that the institution’s trustees had contributed $16.4 million more and individual patrons had given $3 million, with the rest coming from other sources. “I think it means we’ve come a long way, and we’ve got a long way to go,” said Mr. Young, who took over in late December to oversee a restructuring of the museum’s finances after its director, Jeremy Strick, resigned under pressure.

Marfa, the tiny farm-town-meets-art-retreat in Southwest Texas, is so far off the grid that the Spanish name for the area is el despoblado — the uninhabited place. But the actor Randy Quaid, below, and his wife, Evi, spending time there, came across at least one inhabitant on Thursday, the one with the big star pinned to his chest: Sheriff Danny Dominguez, of Presidio County, who arrested the couple on charges of skipping out on a $10,000 California hotel bill. Mr. Quaid and his wife each posted $20,000 bail on Thursday night after spending several hours in the Marfa jail, The Associated Press reported. Sheriff Dominguez said he had driven the actor to a bank so he could get the bail money. “I like to help everybody out,” he explained. “It’s a small town.”A felony warrant for burglary, defrauding an innkeeper and conspiracy was issued in Santa Barbara, Calif., after the authorities received a complaint in early September that the couple had not paid their bill at a hotel there, according to a news release from the Santa Barbara County Sheriff’s Department.

MARKHAM--Claire, nee Mishkin, died August 22 in Sarasota, FL. Predeceased by her loving husband, Herbert, and survived by her daughters Rita Kremer, Eileen Brakman, and Bonnie Markham, six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. GURWIN--Joseph. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System are greatly saddened by the death of Joseph Gurwin, a dedicated board member and long-time supporter of the health system and LIJ Medical Center. Thanks to Mr. Gurwin's generosity in establishing the Phyllis and Joseph Gurwin Teaching and Education Center at LIJ, physicians have access to state-of-the art facilities, technology and equipment to continue their education by learning about the latest medical advances. His devotion and commitment to helping others remains an inspiration to us all. Mr. Gurwin's friendship and ongoing investment in North Shore-LIJ has made a tremendous difference to thousands of patients and their families in the communities the health system serves. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System Saul B. Katz, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System

He was also the adored grandfather of 10; Elam, Aaron, Jesse, Colette, Nathan, Charlie, Daphne, Ivy, Emma, and Jason.
