GURWIN--Joseph. With profound sadness the Board of Directors, Administration, Staff and Residents of the Gurwin Jewish Nursing & Rehabilitation Center mourn the loss of our esteemed founding President and benefactor, Joseph Gurwin. Joe was an inspiring, kind and generous gentleman, whose dedication to philanthropy brought lasting joy and an enhanced quality of life to countless people throughout the United States and around the globe. Because of his inability to bring his parents to the United States before they perished in the Holocaust, Joe and his late wife Rosalind took the opportunity to help create a Center that would care for the parents of others in a dignified and compassionate manner. His vision, dedication and leadership through the years have made the Gurwin name synonymous with excellence in caring for the elderly and those in need. He touched countless lives and will forever be remembered for helping to make his dream of "caring for those who cared for us" possible. Our Center will long stand as a legacy to our very special friend. We express heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Phyllis, his children Laura Flug, Eric and Karen Gurwin and his grandchildren Danielle, Jeffrey, Jason and Jaclyn, as well as the Pressman family. Lawrence Simon, Chairman Bert E. Brodsky, President Herbert H. Friedman, Exec VP
GURWIN--Joseph. Dear friend, we will miss you. Mimi and Mike

Are the health care commercials that are flooding the nation's airwaves reaching a point of diminishing returns? Nearly $100 million has been spent this year on commercials intended to influence the health care debate, including $30 million in August alone, according to Evan Tracey, founder of the Campaign Media Analysis Group, a research firm in Arlington, Va. ''In just the last 60 days, 49 different groups have aired nearly 100,000 TV commercials about federal health care policy,'' Mr. Tracey wrote recently in Advertising Age.

''Pandorum'' may sound like a disease suffered by fuzzy black-and-white mammals who've been caged a wee bit too long, but the only fuzziness in this apocalyptic nightmare is between the characters' ears. Following in the sci-fi tradition of films like ''Solaris'' and the monumentally creepy ''Event Horizon,'' ''Pandorum'' presents a scenario where the line between reality and hallucination is constantly shifting. Set in the 22nd century, when, we are told, Earth has finally had enough of unchecked human proliferation, the movie unfolds aboard the spacecraft Elysium, a kind of Noah's ark en route to populate a new planet.

RAUCH--Ruth Treiber, 92, died September 23, 2009 in Westminster, Maryland. She is survived by her sister, Marilyn Treiber, daughter Nancy R. Douzinas and husband Kostas, son Philip J. Rauch and wife Lynn, four grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. She was born in Brooklyn, New York, and graduated from Packer Collegiate Institute and Wells College before receiving a graduate degree in German Literature from Columbia University. During World War II, she taught high school German and English in the Albany public schools. She married Louis J. Rauch in 1945 and was widowed in 1992. She was a passionate supporter of the arts and loved travel, horseback riding, and poetry. A memorial service will take place at a future date.

9 P.M. (Starz) CADILLAC RECORDS (2008) Jeffrey Wright, Mos Def and Beyoncé Knowles, above, star as Muddy Waters, Chuck Berry and Etta James in this celebration of Chicago blues and the founding of a recording company in the 1950s by Leonard Chess (Adrien Brody), who sees a potential gold mine in ''race music.'' Darnell Martin's film ''is not -- thank goodness -- another dutiful musical biopic, but rather the group portrait of a remarkable, volatile constellation of artists,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, adding that it would be worth seeing for the music alone. ''Mr. Wright's renditions of Muddy Waters's signature songs are more than respectable, while Ms. Knowles's interpretations of Ms. James's hits -- 'At Last' and 'I'd Rather Go Blind,' in particular -- are downright revelatory. And so, it should be said, is Ms. Knowles's performance.'' 10:30 A.M. MURPHY--Suzanne Crosby, 79, beloved wife, mother and grandmother, of Rye, NY and North Palm Beach, Florida, died September 25, 2009 after several months of being ill. Born in Great Neck, NY, Suzanne Crosby Murphy was the youngest child of John Francis and Emilie Morris Crosby. Raised primarily in Washington, DC and summering in Spring Lake, NJ. She graduated from Georgetown Visitation, a Catholic girl's high school in Washington, DC and earned an associates degree from Georgetown Visitation Junior College. Trained and practiced as a medical secretary, she went on to become a secretary to the well-known first televangelist, Bishop Fulton Sheen in Washington, DC. On November 5, 1955, she married Thomas S. Murphy of Brooklyn and Quaker Hill, NY and moved to Albany, NY. Eventually moving to Rye, NY where they have lived for over 37 years. Her husband was Chairman and CEO of Capital Cities/ABC, Inc. for 26 years. An active local community member, she enjoyed participating in Rye based organizations such as the Rye Youth Council, and was President of the St. Elizabeth's Guild for eight years. She took great joy in tutoring underprivileged children, particularly in the Catholic inner city schools. She was also engaged in wide ranging and numerous philanthropic interests in local, regional and national not for profit organizations. She was passionate about providing opportunities for children and adults to reach their potential, and relieving suffering in the lives of others, particularly in the areas of education and mental health. She served on the Executive Committee of the Catholic Big Sisters of New York City from 1992 to 2000 and was the honoree in 2003 at their Gala. She funded the Suzanne Crosby Murphy Professor in Pediatric Neuropsychiatry Chair at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, held by Dr. Bradley S. Peterson, MD, who is Director of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry, Director of MRI Research. She was a member of the Dames of Malta. In addition to her husband, Thomas S. Murphy, she is survived by four children, Emilie Murphy of Rye, NY, Thomas S. Murphy, Jr. of Greenwich, CT, Kathleen Murphy of Sante Fe, NM and Mary Conlin of Los Angeles, CA; two siblings, Elaine Crosby Murphy of Trenton, NJ and William Crosby of Tampa, FL; and eight grandchildren; Edward Byron, Suzanne Nealy and Larke Ann Nimocks of Rye, NY; Caitlin Brown, Grace Sawyer and Virginia Louise Murphy of Greenwich, CT; Thomas Sawyer and John Crosby Conlin of Los Angeles, CA. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Rye Youth Council or the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club of New York. A viewing will be held at the Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY. Visiting hours are 2-4pm and 7-9 on September 28th. The Funeral Mass at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY will be held on September 29 at 4pm. She will be remembered as Loving, Laughing, Listening and Learning. www.grahamfuneralhomerye.com

In a move that underscores the growing importance of Asia and emerging markets for global financial institutions, the British bank HSBC Holdings said Friday that its chief executive would relocate to Hong Kong next year. HSBC, which is based in London and is the largest European bank, said it would retain its base in Britain and that the move of its chief executive did not mean it was ''pulling away from London.''

ALHADEFF--Nissim, died at the age of 91 on September 24, 2009. He is survived by Catherine, his wife of 55 years; two sons, Joseph and Les, his daughter-in-law Deborah and grandson William Nissim. Nissim Alhadeff practiced as a doctor for over 50 years and delivered thousands of children. He was a survivor of the Holocaust and had a strong spirit and incredible will to live and a vibrant lifeforce til the very end. He brought light, warmth, humor and compassion to all he touched. ALHADEFF--Dr. Nissim. With a twinkle in his eye and a kindly smile, he lit up our lives. He was our compass, beacon and our shining example of love, kindness, warmth and family. We are grateful to have been so lucky to be a part of his life. He will live in our hearts forever. Our heartfelt condolences to Catherine, Joe and Leslie. Eileen and Michael Stein and Family

A bankruptcy judge said after an all-day hearing on Friday that he would rule later on whether to approve Tribune Company's plan to pay managers up to $66.8 million in incentive bonuses, with about half of that going to 10 top executives. The chief executive, Sam Zell, left, whose leveraged buyout of the company in 2007 added $8 billion to an existing debt load of $5 billion, is not in the group of 10. The United States Bankruptcy Trustee and the Washington-Baltimore Newspaper Guild, joined by several other unions, objected to the plan. They challenged the newspaper publisher's contention that suitable cash bonuses were crucial to its ability to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy and return operating cash flow from this year's six-month low of $195 million to recent annual levels of more than a billion dollars. Judge Kevin J. Carey said the competing issues are whether a corporate board should be free to exercise its judgment that a bonus plan would improve business, or whether there was any need for a troubled industry to give bonuses when ''there is no place for management to go.''

Good morning, Nicolas. Did you sleep well, Angela? Wasn't that a good dinner last night, Gordon? Pittsburgh is such a great city; I'm so glad we're holding our G-20 summit here. It was Michelle's idea, you know. I think she would have lobbied for Pittsburgh even if the city hadn't swung for me in the election. O.K., maybe not. So let's get down to business. We made great progress on Thursday, didn't we? Jintao, you agreed to push for more domestic demand in your Chinese economy. That's exciting. My good friends in Europe agreed to seek more investment from the rest of the world, and everybody agreed to be less dependent on American consumers. We even agreed to check up on one another to see if we're all doing what we said we would do.

Allos Therapeutics won approval to sell its first product, a treatment for relapses of a rare type of blood cancer. The Food and Drug Administration cleared pralatrexate, a therapy for people with peripheral T-cell lymphoma who have received previous treatment, like chemotherapy, the company said Friday. Outside advisers to the F.D.A. backed the medicine, Allos's first, in a 10-to-4 vote on Sept. 2. This cancer strikes an estimated 5,600 Americans a year and aggressive cases are usually fatal within five years, according to Allos. Allos plans to market the drug under the brand name Folotyn. Shares of Allos, which is based in Westminster, Colo., fell 28.2 cents, to $7.868.

The chief executive of Cadbury denied Friday that he was warming to the idea of a takeover deal with Kraft, in an attempt to end a controversy about comments he made at a seminar earlier in the week. Cadbury, the British chocolate retailer, said on Friday that the remarks were ''seriously misrepresented'' and that it was in touch with Britain's Takeover Panel about the issue.

Twenty-two large banks in Europe may have accumulated credit losses of close to 400 billion euros for this year and next, according to officials who have seen a draft of conclusions of ''stress tests'' conducted by European regulators. At a meeting next Thursday and Friday in Sweden, European Union finance ministers are planning to publish a report on banking health based on the results of the tests, the officials, who were not authorized to speak publicly, said Friday. European finance ministers are also planning to initiate a stress test soon for European insurance companies, with the results to be assessed in the spring, the officials said.

In talking about mandatory health insurance, President Obama has used the example of car insurance. Where I live, in Tennessee, it is required. For my age and driving experience, I pay $216 per month for insurance for my 2009 Prius. I am paying $457 per month for my health insurance. So yes, I support requiring everyone to have health insurance -- and having it cost less than half of what I am now paying. Sign me up! -- Linda A. Ramsbottom, 60, a construction contractor in Knoxville, Tenn., in a comment posted on the Prescriptions blog.

A roadside bomb and assault-rifle fire killed four United States soldiers and a Marine in three attacks in southern Afghanistan, where new American brigades are pressing offensives against a resilient and dug-in Taliban and other insurgents. The attacks on Thursday in Zabul and Nimruz Provinces pushed the number of American military deaths in Afghanistan to 218 this year, already 41 percent more than in all of 2008. The soaring toll, coupled with the Taliban's growing strength and fears that the Aug. 20 Afghan presidential election may have been rigged in favor of President Hamid Karzai, have stirred increasing opposition in the United States to further troop deployments.

The cellist Yo-Yo Ma’s complete albums are coming out in a luxury box set in October (although you can order ahead of time online; at least 100 buyers have already done so). For a mere $789, Mr. Ma’s 30-year recording career can sit on your shelf. On the pop side of the aisle, a 13-CD Beatles box set in both stereo and mono was released earlier this month; both versions have been selling briskly. There is more on the box-set phenomenon in an article today in The Week in Review.

Over the weekend, I attended an event at the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine recalling the "great work" of Thomas Berry, who died at 94 this year, and honoring the philanthropic efforts of Martin Kaplan. The several hundred attendees were swallowed up by the vaulting space of the enormous building, which -- like most cathedrals -- took generations to build. It's useful to be in such a space when reflecting on epic questions, like figuring out how to provide adequate energy as human numbers and appetites crest in the next few decades without risking a dangerous destabilization of climate.

My grandson's third birthday is at hand, and I'm looking at a toy racing car I won't be giving him. Painted a bright yellow, this nifty little toy seemed just right for him when I paid a buck for it at a big box store. But before I could give it to him, I learned that cheap toys made in China, like this one, can have lead in their paint - particularly reds and yellows - to make them more shiny.

The last three days of college football saw No. 4 Ole Miss, No. 5 Penn State, No. 6 California and No. 9 Miami lose, meaning the new A.P. poll was certain to have a different look. The big beneficiaries were the "little guys." Boise State moved up three spots to No. 5, the first time it has been in the top five during the regular season. Cincinnati rose to No. 10, its highest ranking ever. T.C.U., a winner over Clemson of the ACC on Saturday, is at No. 11, and Houston, which defeated the Big 12's Texas Tech, is No. 12. Iowa, which knocked off Penn State for the second year in a row, made a huge leap, going from being unranked to No. 13.

''I don't know if it's me getting older or the world getting smaller, but it feels harder to get lost,'' says the 38-year-old actor-screenwriter Justin Theroux, who has traveled extensively in Asia and briefly lived in China in his early 20s. (He's also the nephew of the famed travel writer Paul Theroux.) This summer, he drove across the United States with his girlfriend and two dogs: ''The plan was to stick as much to the old Route 66 as possible,'' with a detour to Graceland. Now Theroux, who wrote the screenplay for next year's ''Iron Man 2,'' is off to Belfast to play a ''bad wizard'' in a new film by the director David Gordon Green. So where does he want to go next? ''North Korea - it feels like the weirdest place to go.''

An article in The Times Magazine on Sept. 13 reported on J Street, a new lobbying organization that favors a progressive approach to American foreign policy in the Middle East. The article suggested that one of J Street’s goals is to compete with the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (Aipac) and other established lobbying groups. In reporting the article, the author did not contact anyone currently at Aipac for its views. The Times should have asked a representative of the organization for its response to what it reported.

Technology has transformed communications, increased the efficiency of retailing and helped elect a president. But because education is largely protected from incentives and consequences, it lags in embracing technology. • That must and will change. At a New York City pilot program, School of One, for example, each student has a daily “playlist” tailored to their instructional level, interests and learning style. The school blends online learning, small group sessions and tutoring. It’s a vivid picture of the shift from age cohorts slogging through a textbook to personalized digital learning . • This fall, about two million K-12 students will be learning online at home and at school (about 4 percent of the national student body). By 2020, I believe most high-school students will do most of their learning online. It shouldn’t take that long, but it will. • New tools already make possible a generation of schools that blend the best of online and on-site learning. They will be less expensive and more fun , delivering excellence with equity.

To the Editor: Regarding “In Texas, Seeing the West as It Was” (Sept. 13): As someone who has made the hike to the summit of Guadalupe Peak, I wish you would have mentioned that not only is there no water on the trail, there is no water at the foot of the trail, or anywhere near the trail. All hikers need to carry a couple of gallons of water if they wish to survive the hike without severe dehydration.

To the Editor: Steve Dougherty’s “Love. Death. Intrigue. Warsaw.” (Sept. 13) reminded me that when I was living in Warsaw in the early ’80s, I read that the first business to open in the city after the war was a flower shop. At first I thought this touching and eccentric — emphasizing the romantic over the practical and symbolizing the return of normalcy to daily life. Then I realized that the flowers were needed for all the fresh graves. Thomas Swick.

In the N.F.L., the genius label can only be rented. A few individuals, like Bill Belichick, get to lease it on favorable terms. With his defensive stalwarts retired or scattered around the league and his offense spreading the field despite diminishing returns, Belichick cannot stop the gradual Patriots decline that began in Super Bowl XLII. Like plutonium, New England (1-1) has an extended half-life and is still lethal, even in decay. The Falcons' general manager, Thomas Dimitroff, may replace Belichick, his former employer, as the league's reigning genius. He drafted Matt Ryan and other less-heralded rookie starters (linebacker Curtis Lofton, tackle Sam Baker) last year, then acquired the veterans Tony Gonzalez and Mike Peterson last off-season. Gonzalez already has almost as many receiving yards in two games (144) as Justin Peelle, last year's starting tight end, had in 16 games (159). Peterson has 17 tackles, an interception and 2 forced fumbles. Excellent drafting, wise free-agent decisions: it's all very early-century Belichickian. New England's afterburners will trump Atlanta (2-0) on Sunday, but the Patriots may not be favorites the next time these teams meet.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, September 12th 2009, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

MORELL--Penny. Devoted mother, documentary filmmaker, former advertising executive, editor of Ingenue magazine, and fashion model passed away on September 23rd. She will be deeply missed by her daughter Samantha Rohrbough and loving family. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Penny's name to The ALS Association Greater New York Chapter, 42 Broadway, Suite 1742, New York, NY 10004.

GREENFIELD--Beatrice, died on September 24, 2009 after a long illness. Ms. Greenfield was born on February 5, 1921 in New York City and spent most of her life in the city she loved. She is survived by her beloved daughter Deborah and son-in-law Joe and cherished grandsons David and Michael. As a social worker, Ms. Greenfield devoted her life to the welfare of children and families. Contributions may be sent to the New York Public Library or the Alzheimer's Association.

Black and white are a foolproof combination, especially when the seasons are changing. The pairing shows up everywhere, from a striped raincoat in New York to dotted evening dresses in Newport, R.I. André Leon Talley, above, a Vogue editor, chose it for a resplendent robe. He's surrounded here by a court of two-tone pups. A pinstriped suit is de-sedated by black and white socks and confetti-pattern shoes. Ralph Rucci's black net jacket with elaborate swirls of white, left, has many imitators, far left. Then there's his stunning zebra-print balloon-sleeve bolero.
MARX--Maxine, daughter of Chico Marx, has died at age 91. Her sons Brian and Kevin Culhane are planning a private memorial.

Kevork S. Hovnanian, who came to the United States from Iraq and started a construction company that became one of the nation's largest home builders, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Rumson, N.J. Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. of Red Bank, N.J., announced his death on its Web site but did not disclose the cause. He founded a building company, with his three brothers in 1959.

TIPTOEING THROUGH THE TULIPS, WOODBURN, ORE., MAY 1, 2009 Steve Earnshaw, 56, a Methodist minister from Fountain, Colo., snaps a photo amid a field of coral tulips at the Wooden Shoe Tulip Farm, about 30 miles south of Portland. ''My wife and I were going to visit our son, who lives in Portland. It was the first time we'd been there, so we decided to go around and see the sights. It wasn't really my idea to see the tulips. Even when we drove up to the farm, it was like 'Oh, wow.' But as we began to walk through the tulip fields, I was just sort of overcome by the vividness of the colors. It was just incredible. I've seen so many now, I feel like I'm sort of a tulip connoisseur. I was kind of surprised, actually, at how much I got into the whole experience. I think just because the color -- once you're in it and you're actually walking through the rows -- the color just sort of overtakes a person's senses.'' As told to Austin Considine

PINE--Leo, 98. Devoted husband to Rose Pine, loving father to Marilyn, proud and adoring grandfather to Rachel and Brett. Avid philanthropist, dear friend, skilled printer and WWII veteran. We will miss you so much. Your jokes will live forever.

The label that is releasing the self-titled debut album by Monsters of Folk is Shangri-La Music -- not Merge, which has released recordings by two of the band's members, Conor Oberst and M. Ward.

IMAGINE the Guggenheim Museum covered in pavé diamonds. Or Central Park dripping in emeralds. Or a diamond as big as the ... Chrysler Building. A slew of jewelry companies have created landmark pieces inspired by everything from taxis to the Statue of Liberty. You can get a bird's-eye view of Manhattan skyscrapers on the face of Piaget's latest watch. Stephen Russell has lit up the Chrysler Building with an Art Deco diamond and platinum broach. And Noir Jewelry will sell you the Brooklyn Bridge, in a gold-and-diamond knuckle ring ($250; 212-244-4846).

Hunters Point, on the western edge of Long Island City, has quiet streets, new condominiums priced a few dollars south of those across the East River, and the 48-story Citigroup tower, the tallest building in Queens. Parking is becoming scarcer as the area's charms attract residents, but the 7 train stops at the neighborhood's main artery, Vernon Boulevard, where visitors can see what life is like on the other side of the Pepsi-Cola sign, the area's standout landmark. NOON Begin with a meal at Cafe Henri, 1010 50th Avenue, (718) 383-9315, a popular spot where the weekend brunch draws crowds that spill onto the sidewalk. But the wait is worth it -- besides standard brunch fare like eggs Benedict ($9.75) and bistro staples like onion soup ($7.50), there are the whole wheat crepes: goat cheese and leek ($9), smoked salmon and basil cream ($10.50) and sweet sausage ($8). For dessert try the chestnut cream crepe ($6), which is topped with fresh cream and tastes like sweet potato.
And the new album from the German rock band Tokio Hotel, ''Humanoid,'' will be its second album in English, not its second over all.

HELLING--William Edward, of Franklin Square, NY, passed away on September 17, 2009, following a prolonged illness. He was 83. Bill was born in Brooklyn, and lived his entire life in the metro area that he dearly loved. He is survived by Mia, his devoted wife of 59 years, his four children and seven beloved grandchildren. Services were private, but a celebration of Bill's life will take place on Saturday, October 31, 2009 at Temple Beth Israel in Hempstead, NY. Donations may be made to the American Heart Association in his name.

The requirement that everyone buy health insurance moved a step closer to reality last week -- and possibly a step closer to being challenged in court. Conservatives and libertarians, mostly, have been advancing the theory lately that the individual mandate, in which the government would compel everyone to buy insurance or pay a penalty, is unconstitutional.

Terrelle Pryor, near left, had no passing yards in the first half and finished with 82 as No. 13 Ohio State beat Illinois, 30-0. San Diego State had no rushing yards in the first half of a 26-14 loss to Air Force. Georgia Tech held the ball for 42 minutes, its highest total in 13 years, in beating No. 22 North Carolina, 24-7. Fresno State held the ball for 43 minutes but lost to No. 14 Cincinnati, 28-20.

The American Miklat Committee extends deepest condolences to our friend and esteemed board member, Abby Ellison Kanarek, and her husband, Dr. Yitzchak Kanarek, on the passing of her son, Steven Gil Ellison (z"l). RAUCH--Ruth Treiber, 92, died September 23, 2009 in Westminster, Maryland. She is survived by her sister, Marilyn Treiber, daughter Nancy R. Douzinas and husband Kostas, son Philip J. Rauch and wife Lynn, four grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. She was born in Brooklyn, New York, and graduated from Packer Collegiate Institute and Wells College before receiving a graduate degree in German Literature from Columbia University. During World War II, she taught high school German and English in the Albany public schools. She married Louis J. Rauch in 1945 and was widowed in 1992. She was a passionate supporter of the arts and loved travel, horseback riding, and poetry. A memorial service will take place at a future date.

PARIS CELEBRATING SHOES Shoes, along with chocolate and perhaps George Clooney, are known to be the weakness of many women the world over. Well, one out of three isn't bad: ''Souliers'' (yes, ''Shoes'') is the title and subject of a small but charming exhibition at Maison du Danemark (142, avenue des Champs-Élysées; 33-1-44-31-21-21; www.maisondudanemark.dk), open through Oct. 3.

TALK SHOW One thing about Richard Burton got to me especially. Most actors' claims of ''Why does everybody say I'm so talented?'' strain credulity to the snapping point. But why wouldn't a young boy from the mines of Wales be amazed by the towering gift placed in him by the gods? How could Burton not be stunned to receive a rave review in his first job from a major London critic for the way he, with bucket and brush, wordlessly scrubbed a floor, largely with his back to the audience? I don't think he ever lost that wonderment about his great gift. I raised the idea that even one so lavishly successful as he was might fear the disappearance of all that fairy gold and fame and talent; the old Greek idea of being struck low by the envious gods. He chilled me with his look and tone, saying, ''You mean hubris? Overweening pride and all that?''

The single biggest problem in American education is that no one agrees on why we educate. Faced with this lack of consensus, policy makers define good education as higher test scores. But higher test scores are not a definition of good education. Students can get higher scores in reading and mathematics yet remain completely ignorant of science, the arts, civics, history, literature and foreign languages. Why do we educate? We educate because we want citizens who are capable of taking responsibility for their lives and for our democracy. We want citizens who understand how their government works, who are knowledgeable about the history of their nation and other nations. We need citizens who are thoroughly educated in science. We need people who can communicate in other languages. We must ensure that every young person has the chance to engage in the arts.

8 P.M. (13, 49); 10 P.M. (21) THE NATIONAL PARKS: AMERICA'S BEST IDEAKen Burns, who directed, and Dayton Duncan, who wrote the script, tell a story they say is as uniquely American -- and just as radical -- as the Declaration of Independence: that the most prized places in a nation should be preserved not just for royalty or the rich, but also for everyone. This six-part documentary series travels from Acadia, Yosemite and Yellowstone to the Grand Canyon, the Florida Everglades and the Gates of the Arctic in Alaska to chronicle the evolution of national parks across nearly 150 years. The first episode, ''The Scripture of Nature (1851-1890),'' examines how John Muir, a Scottish-born wanderer, led Congress to pass the 1864 act that protected the Yosemite Valley in California for ''public use, resort and recreation,'' and how a second act in 1872 christened Yellowstone, a ''wonderland'' of geysers, mud pots and sulfur pits in the northwest corner of the Wyoming territory, America's first national park. Above, a Blackfeet Indian in Glacier National Park in Montana.

Is R the new W? Borrowing some tricks from W Hotels, Renaissance, one of those cookie-cutter brands from Marriott, is getting a makeover. This month, the company opened two hotels that represent its new image: the Renaissance ParisArc de Triomphe, above, with its signature wavy all-glass exterior, and the Renaissance New York Hotel 57, a 200-room ''boutique'' hotel in a 17-story Romanesque building that underwent a $40 million renovation.

WEST DUXBURY, MASS. -- Firm in their conviction that the world will come to an end at 10 a.m. next Friday, about 300 members of the denomination known as the Latter Reign of the Apostolic Church, are spending the few remaining hours in prayer, song and exhortation. The scene of their religious activity is Ashdod, a little wooden chapel on the main turnpike between Boston and Plymouth in this town. They believe that the crust of the earth will peel off, destroying the wicked, that only the righteous will survive. -- From a report in The New York Times.

TOPKIS--Gladys Susman, of New York City, died August 25, 2009, of heart failure. She was 81. Born in Brookline, MA, Ms. Topkis was granted a full scholarship to Radcliffe College, from which she graduated magna cum laude in 1948. After moving to New York, she soon began making a name for herself in the field of scholarly publishing, working in the editorial departments of houses such as Praeger Publishers, Free Press, and John Wiley & Sons. In 1978, she began teaching at the University of Denver's Publishing Institute, and continued to teach there, every summer and with enormous pleasure, for the next 30 years. In 1981 she became senior editor at Yale University Press, where she specialized in books on sociology, psychology, and psychoanalysis, many of which went on to win prestigious awards. When she left Yale, in 1998, her departure was marked with a festschrift featuring original papers written for the occasion by a number of internationally prominent psychoanalysts. Though technically retired, she continued to work on a freelance basis, and also acted as the Editorial Director of Felony & Mayhem Press, a small mystery-fiction imprint. She is survived by her daughter, Maggie Topkis, of New York City; by the more than 3,000 students whom she guided towards (or away from) careers in publishing; and by the hundreds of books she edited, all of which would have been much the poorer without her. In lieu of flowers, friends and colleagues are invited to make donations in her name to the Memorial Giving department of the Metropolitan Opera. A memorial service is planned for early November. For more details please email mst@felonyandmayhem.com.

Gateway Playhouse is promoting ''A Chorus Line,'' which made its debut on Broadway in 1975, as a precursor to the reality shows of today. Clever marketing. A more appropriate television reference, however, might be ''In Treatment.'' True, the opening number, ''I Hope I Get It,'' could be the inner theme song of contestants on ''American Idol,'' ''So You Think You Can Dance'' and other popular prime time shows. But the heart of this musical about auditioning for a Broadway musical isn't the competition. It's the personal stories the performers tell Zach, the director who will decide who gets to be in the show and who goes home jobless.

MURPHY--Suzanne Crosby, 79, beloved wife, mother and grandmother, of Rye, NY and North Palm Beach, Florida, died September 25, 2009 after several months of being ill. Born in Great Neck, NY, Suzanne Crosby Murphy was the youngest child of John Francis and Emilie Morris Crosby. Raised primarily in Washington, DC and summering in Spring Lake, NJ. She graduated from Georgetown Visitation, a Catholic girl's high school in Washington, DC and earned an associates degree from Georgetown Visitation Junior College. Trained and practiced as a medical secretary, she went on to become a secretary to the well-known first televangelist, Bishop Fulton Sheen in Washington, DC. On November 5, 1955, she married Thomas S. Murphy of Brooklyn and Quaker Hill, NY and moved to Albany, NY. Eventually moving to Rye, NY where they have lived for over 37 years. Her husband was Chairman and CEO of Capital Cities/ABC, Inc. for 26 years. An active local community member, she enjoyed participating in Rye based organizations such as the Rye Youth Council, and was President of the St. Elizabeth's Guild for eight years. She took great joy in tutoring underprivileged children, particularly in the Catholic inner city schools. She was also engaged in wide ranging and numerous philanthropic interests in local, regional and national not for profit organizations. She was passionate about providing opportunities for children and adults to reach their potential, and relieving suffering in the lives of others, particularly in the areas of education and mental health. She served on the Executive Committee of the Catholic Big Sisters of New York City from 1992 to 2000 and was the honoree in 2003 at their Gala. She funded the Suzanne Crosby Murphy Professor in Pediatric Neuropsychiatry Chair at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, held by Dr. Bradley S. Peterson, MD, who is Director of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry, Director of MRI Research. She was a member of the Dames of Malta. In addition to her husband, Thomas S. Murphy, she is survived by four children, Emilie Murphy of Rye, NY, Thomas S. Murphy, Jr. of Greenwich, CT, Kathleen Murphy of Sante Fe, NM and Mary Conlin of Los Angeles, CA; two siblings, Elaine Crosby Murphy of Trenton, NJ and William Crosby of Tampa, FL; and eight grandchildren; Edward Byron, Suzanne Nealy and Larke Ann Nimocks of Rye, NY; Caitlin Brown, Grace Sawyer and Virginia Louise Murphy of Greenwich, CT; Thomas Sawyer and John Crosby Conlin of Los Angeles, CA. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Rye Youth Council or the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club of New York. A viewing will be held at the Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY. Visiting hours are 2-4pm and 7-9 on September 28th. The Funeral Mass at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY will be held on September 29 at 4pm. She will be remembered as Loving, Laughing, Listening and Learning. www.grahamfuneralhomerye.com

BENJAMIN--Robert Spiers, renowned foreign correspondent in Latin America, died in his home in San Miguel de Allende (Mexico) on September 20, 2009, at the age of 92. Robert was born in Brooklyn, NY, on August 17, 1917. He wrote his first book, "Call to Adventure," at 17 while still a student at Erasmus High School. He wrote five more books and became an award-winning, globetrotting journalist. After the war, he was bureau chief for Time-Life in Santiago, Chile, before moving to Mexico, where he was a New York Times correspondent until he founded his own press agency and PR firm. Robert was married four times. He is survived by his five children (Robert, Gordon, Geraldine, Alan and Diana) and their families; by numerous stepchildren; by five grandchildren; and by one great-grandchild.

Led by Coach Rex Ryan and the coordinator Mike Pettine, the Jets rank first over all in total defense for the first time since Week 5 of the 1982 season. They lead the N.F.L. in fewest yards allowed per play (4.19), fewest opponent plays of 20 yards or more (2), fewest points allowed (9) and fewest offensive touchdowns allowed (0). But the Jets have yet to face Chris Johnson, right, the Titans' dazzling running back, who has a sprinter's speed and leads a rushing attack that averages 163 yards a game, fifth in the league. To beat the Titans, the Jets need to at least slow Johnson and force quarterback Kerry Collins and the Titans' nondescript receiving corps to beat them.

IT was once an automotive rite of passage. That is, thumbing desperately through an encyclopedic owner's manual for instructions on how to get a scissor jack seemingly designed for Barbie's Corvette to hoist a 3,000-pound car. (And who knew tightening the lug nuts in exactly the right order was such a big deal?) For one automaker, the book version of the manual is going the way of Rusty Jones. Chrysler announced on Monday that it would replace its familiar glovebox tome with a user guide for emergencies and a DVD that includes live-action tutorials for commonly used features. The company's 2010 models will be the first to receive the new material, although buyers can request an old-school manual or download one from the company's Web site.

MARKHAM--Claire, nee Mishkin, died August 22 in Sarasota, FL. Predeceased by her loving husband, Herbert, and survived by her daughters Rita Kremer, Eileen Brakman, and Bonnie Markham, six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. For 40 of her active 91 years she worked as a travel agent and relished world travel. Claire spoke several languages, enjoyed good food, and savored life with energy and enthusiasm.

FELDMAN--Ethel Helfant, age 97, on Friday, September 25, 2009; Beloved wife of the late Reuben Helfant and Ben Feldman. Loving mother of Carol and Jerold Horn of Peoria, IL and Sherry Helfant Malone of Pittsburgh. Step-mother of Richard and Harriette Feldman of East Liverpool, OH and Marvin and Vicki Feldman of Palm Harbor, FL. Cherished grandmother of Robin and Stephen Koffman, Jamie Heitner and David Israel, Roberta and Andrew Packer, Andrew Horn and five step-grandchildren. Adored great-grandmother of Theodore and Alexander Koffman, Jack Israel, Leah Packer and four step-great- grandchildren. Daughter of the late Mary and Joseph Blumenfeld. Sister of the late Israel, Adolph and Meyer Blumenfeld and Goldie Rofey. Sister-in-law of Dorothy Blumenfeld and Roslyn Blumenfeld. Dear aunt of many nieces, nephews, great-nieces and nephews. Also survived by beloved companion Viera Uhlarova and devoted caregivers. Ethel's first husband, Reuben Helfant was the founder and president of Thrift Drug Company. After his death in 1968, she established a scholarship in his name at the University of Pittsburgh, School of Pharmacy, which has supported 85 students over 41 years. Her second husband Ben Feldman was a renowned New York Life Insurance Agent and was considered the world's greatest life insurance salesman. He wrote several books on the industry and was an international speaker. She loved to accompany him in his travels and established a fund at the American College in his name. With the support of her two husbands, Ethel shared her four loves family, music, nature and charity. She also established the Ethel B. Feldman Scholarship at the University of Pittsburgh to help students continue careers in elementary education. Ethel graduated in 1933 from H.C. Frick Training School for Teachers and was president of her class. At the same time, she earned a B.S. in Education from the University of Pittsburgh and was a music teacher at Dilworth Elementary School. Ethel was the 15th President of the Ladies Hospital Aid Society (LHAS) of Montefiore Hospital and a life member of the board of the Jewish Healthcare Foundation. She was a major contributor to the United Jewish Federation and the Jewish Community Center. Her many annual donations include the Carnegie Museum, Children's Hospital, The Pittsburgh Symphony and the Community Food Bank. Ethel was a founding investor of First Southern Bank and a member of Boca Rio Country Club for over 32 years. Another recipient of her generosity has been Congregation Beth Shalom where she donated the Helfant Chapel as a fitting tribute to her late husband. Services at Congregation Beth Shalom, 5915 Beacon Street, Pittsburgh, PA on Sunday at Noon. Visitation in the Helfant Chapel one hour prior to services (11am-12 Noon). Interment Beth Shalom Cemetery. Contributions may be made to the Ethel B. Feldman Philanthropic Fund of the Jewish Federation of Southern Palm Beach County, 9901 Donna Klein Blvd., Boca Raton, FL 33428. Services entrusted to Ralph Schugar Chapel, Inc., Pittsburgh, PA 1-888-621-8282.

EARNEST SEWN, the Manhattan denim company, continues its collaborative mood. The knitwear designer Victor Glemaud (pictured) is the latest to team up, joining Repetto, Trovata and Van Cleef & Arpels. Mr. Glemaud assembled a mini unisex collection consisting of his signature cashmere double cardigan, a bomber and a mock-neck zip-up, all available at Earnest Sewn's store in the meatpacking district. The color scheme, which is several shades more somber than Mr. Glemaud's usual exuberant Crayola palette, ''is what I deemed Earnest Sewn to be,'' he explained. ''Which is to say -- dark.'' NANCY MacDONELL

Bucknall, Elizabeth B. Petty and G. Stafford Bucknall. A memorial service will be held Friday, October 9th, 11am, Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. SINCE he came to prominence in the 1960s, the South African-born photographer Sam Haskins has captured, in grainy black-and-white -- and in various degrees of dishabille -- the essence of the It Girl next door. As many fashion shoots attest, generations of stylists and photographers have sampled Mr. Haskins's brand of unstudied glamour, and turned his books like ''Cowboy Kate & Other Stories'' and ''Five Girls'' into rare collectibles. Now Mr. Haskins, 82, is back with ''Fashion Etcetera,'' his first book in over two decades. Published in partnership with the Tommy Hilfiger Group, the monograph is available in a standard version ($67.50) and in a special edition ($100) -- both of which are likely to prolong the fashion world's embrace. ''The real thing is the real thing,'' said Mr. Hilfiger, whose recent collections have referenced the photographer's work. ''There's only one Sam Haskins.'' HORACIO SILVA An exhibition of Mr. Haskins's work is on view at Milk Gallery, 450 West 15th Street, through Oct. 26.

KAHRILAS--Peter Jerome. July 3, 1922 September 22, 2009. Born in New York City to Greek immigrants, he was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and CCNY where he earned his degree in Electrical Engineering. He earned a master's degree at Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn and did graduate work at Columbia University and USC. He worked in the Aerospace industry for Sperry Gyroscope, Hughes Aircraft and Raytheon Missile Systems Division where he was instrumental in the development and testing of the Patriot missile guidance system. His book, "Electronic Scanning Radar Systems Design Handbook" (1976), has been used world-wide by electronics engineers. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Leticia, his children Kim, Peter and Nicholas, and seven grandchildren.

DIOR will kick off the Paris shows on Monday night with a celebrity-filled party in honor of ''Tyen: 30 Years of Creation,'' a pop-up exhibition at the Palais de Tokyo marking three decades of collaboration between the makeup maestro -- who is known simply as Tyen -- and the French fashion house. As recognized for his skill behind a camera as for his ability to paint faces and predict product trends, Tyen has conceived of and photographed some of the company's most successful beauty campaigns, most recently for Hypnotic Poison, starring Monica Bellucci. Obsessed with color and light, he is the man behind Dior hits such as electric blue mascara, photosensitive eye shadow and -- for those late nights at Le Montana -- eyeliner and nail polish that only appears under black light. The show runs until Wednesday. SANDRA BALLENTINE

BERSON--Iolabee "Sis". Our grandmother was one of the most incredible women we have ever known. She was born here in New York, the oldest of four children in the Dworman family. As the only girl, she was raised as "one of the boys." She went to college in Macon, Georgia (where they had never seen "a Jew" before) and then worked in the family's real estate business. When she married our grandfather (to whom she was married for over 60 years -- as different as two people can be but a real love affair) he was a young physician in private practice. However, our grandmother always encouraged him "to dream big" -- as she always did. And so the two of them started to build private hospitals and never looked back. They worked tirelessly -- and side by side. They had two loving daughters together -- Rhetta and Bonnie -- and with that gave birth to a beautiful family tree of grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Our grandmother was a New York icon, known throughout New York as a hard-driven businesswoman but always a lady. All of Manhattan knew "Mrs. Berson" and she wore the title well. In our grandmother's world, you could never be overdressed. She was a spectacle of perfection, bedecked and bejeweled, from head to toe. Our friends called her Queen Elizabeth and they were not far off. She was known at Old Oaks for appearing at the gym in the early morning wearing white gloves and a Chanel suit in full make-up to "run" on the treadmill. Our grandfather worshipped her. He told us that she inspired him to be better and he adored her for that. They had a love affair like no other and their marriage was an amazing example for all of us. We all feel fortunate that our children got to spend such meaningful time with their great-grandmother whom they adored -- and that she got to share with them her stories about how she learned to fly an airplane and rode horses and owned a pet monkey who used to steal her red lipstick. She loved being the focus of their attention and they adored being in her regal presence. We all did. She was truly one of a kind and we will miss her dearly. Nikki and Paul, Sydney, Alex and Ben Aimee and Jonathan, William Lauren and Jon, Molly and Jackson Marla and Gregg, Nathalie and Andrew Dara and Evan, Sasha and Tatum Heather and David, Sam and Lola Rhetta and Max Bonnie and Steven

ALDEN--Renato (Ray) G. Educator, musician, artist, photographer, author and champion of traditional music, died peacefully on September 19 at home in Croton-on-Hudson, New York after a valiant struggle with cancer. He was 67 years old. An accomplished banjo player, band member and teacher, Ray encouraged contemporaries and younger musicians, inspiring their interest and confidence. He made and produced recordings of traditional music throughout the USA, photographing and writing extensively about old-time Appalachian music and culture. He founded the Field Recorders' Collective, producing hundreds of hours of unique traditional music recordings. His interest in music extended to loudspeaker design, about which he wrote two books. Ray was also a gifted mathematics teacher, and taught at Stuyvesant High School in New York City for 25 years where he created new courses, including loudspeaker design and construction. He is survived by his wife, Diane Alden, and cousins living in Italy and Canada. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Field Recorders' Collective, 6206 Washington St., Ravenna, OH 44266 or to the Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South, New York City, NY, 10012. A celebration of his life will be held at the Judson Memorial Church on Saturday, November 7th at 2pm.

WAGNER--Richard, 64, died suddenly Sunday. Litigation Director Brooklyn Legal Services A, formerly staff at Center For Constitutional Rights. Ricky leaves behind his beloved sister Leslie Colvin (Nelson), nephew Adam, and many friends whom he loved and who loved him. He will be remembered for a lifetime of good works on behalf of those most in need. Memorial Service to be set later. Contributions may be made to the Trey Whitfield School Foundation.

MURPHY--Suzanne C. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Suzanne Murphy, President of the Suzanne C. Murphy Foundation, Inc. and beloved wife of Thomas S. Murphy, esteemed Chairman Emeritus of the NYU School of Medicine, Trustee of NYU Langone Medical Center and Life Trustee and Honorary Vice Chair of NYU. Suzanne and her husband have been generous benefactors over the many years of their association with the Medical Center, notable for their endowment of the Thomas and Suzanne Murphy Professorship of Neuroscience, their support of the Norman Wikler Professorship in Medicine, and their extraordinary gifts to biomolecular research and the Centers of Excellence. In addition to their support of NYU Langone, Suzanne supported various medical research projects. Suzanne was a much loved member of the Medical Center community and her absence will be profoundly felt. We extend our sincerest condolences to Tom and their children Emilie Murphy, Thomas S. Murphy, Jr., Mary Murphy Conlin and Kathleen Murphy. Kenneth G. Langone Chairman NYU Langone Medical Center Robert I. Grossman M.D. CEO and Dean

When I began investing philanthropically in 2000, I wanted to address achievementgaps. In searching for answers, I spoke with John Mackiel, superintendent of Omaha's public schools,where I sent my own children. He emphasized early education. It wasn't impossible for disadvantaged students to catch up later -- just a lot harder, and costlier. Looking for a program to replicate in Omaha, I found Educare, on Chicago's South Side. Inside Educare, kids facing the worst odds find, beginning at birth, a full-day, full-year oasis. Visit and you'll see highly trained teachers, down on the floor, talking, singing and inspiring. Today, 8 Educares are open across America, with 12 more in the pipeline, each supported by partnerships of local philanthropies, public schools and early-childhood providers. Educares provide a lever to improve state and federal policies: they show policy makers what ''high quality'' looks like and what investment can produce. Educare students come close to national norms by the time they reach kindergarten. That is big news, and a solid investment in human capital.

WHEN the Crosby Street Hotel opens in downtown Manhattan on Tuesday, it will be the first property outside of London for Firmdale Hotels, the boutique chain dreamed up by Kit and Tim Kemp. While there was no conscious effort to reveal the hotel's English roots, there are hints, like a private garden, green roof and planted ''meadow.'' Kit and her team designed 40 different interiors for 86 rooms, from bright paisleys and florals to buttoned-up gray pinstripes. But old England it's not: the seats in the screening room are screaming orange leather. 79 Crosby Street. JEFFRIES BLACKERBY

After the buildup in early September to Derek Jeter's Yankees career hit record, we have probably all had our fill of hit milestones. But Jeter added another on Tuesday night, collecting his 200th hit of the season. At 35, he is the oldest regular shortstop to have a 200-hit season, according to the Elias Sports Bureau. His seven seasons of 200 hits are a record for a shortstop.

Suzanne had a true gift for enriching the lives of those around her, and we were all beneficiaries of that special gift. Patti Matson & Ed Gottesman Tinku and Ajit Jain and many other friends, all of whom miss her already

Tom Williams was about to send his Yale Bulldogs to face Cornell in their Ivy League opener at the Yale Bowl. But first he had to take the ceremonial handoff of his official proclamation. Gov. Jodi Rell of Connecticut had declared Saturday as Tom Williams Day in the state. ''It was special,'' said Williams, the first African-American head football coach in Yale history, Connecticut college history and New England Division I history. ''But my primary focus was on our football team and trying to figure out a way to win a football game.''

Mel Vader and Bob Henderson figured that martini hour on the terrace of their apartment in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, would grow only more interesting after Richard Meier built his 15-story glass tower across the way. From their sixth-floor perch, the couple have seen a toddler on the eighth floor ride her tricycle around her balcony, and watched a cleaning crew come in after 10 p.m. to sop up after a flood of water poured through six stories. They know which of their neighbors in the Meier building make their beds and which do not, and who wears what while brushing their teeth. On one particularly engaging afternoon, they sat, captivated, as a woman appeared in the living room of a gray-haired bachelor, leading Mr. Henderson to hope for an unfolding romance.

In the original ''Fame'' movie, which depicted four turbulent years in the lives of students aiming for stardom at New York's renowned High School of the Performing Arts, students from the actual school were recruited as extras, and actual teachers, including James Moody, who recently retired from the drama department, had speaking parts. Not so in the remake -- the producers call it a ''reinvention'' -- which opened Friday and stars Kelsey Grammer, Bebe Neuwirth and Debbie Allen, the lone holdover from the 1980 version, promoted to principal from her perch in the dance studio. But six seniors at the Upper West Side school, now known as the Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts, who attended a preview of the new film said the fledgling actors in the principal roles -- three are from New York or New Jersey -- reminded them very much of themselves. And they said the boot-camp speech that Ms. Allen delivers to freshmen in the new 'Fame' is right on target. ROBIN FINN

In general, I make it a habit not to come in contact with men's underwear. I guess I've heard too many frat-boy stories about what happens when guys put off doing a wash for a really long time. Since I'm single, this avoidance works out pretty well most of the time. On the off chance that I do encounter a guy's underpants, I expect that he's at least showered and worn clean ones for the occasion, and implore him to pick them up off the floor on his way out. So imagine my dismay at being confronted daily with the countless men who refuse to cover up their boxers or briefs. This mode of undress has been popular for years, and when it reached its all-time low -- buckling one's pants under the buttocks in the style of some hip-hop stars -- I thought it was finally on its way out. But no. Teenagers and 30-year-old men alike continue to stand in front of me on the subway, giving me an eyeful of their tighty-whities, which in many cases have ceased being both tight and white.

GURWIN--Joseph. With profound sadness the Board of Directors, Administration, Staff and Residents of the Gurwin Jewish Nursing & Rehabilitation Center mourn the loss of our esteemed founding President and benefactor, Joseph Gurwin. Joe was an inspiring, kind and generous gentleman, whose dedication to philanthropy brought lasting joy and an enhanced quality of life to countless people throughout the United States and around the globe. Because of his inability to bring his parents to the United States before they perished in the Holocaust, Joe and his late wife Rosalind took the opportunity to help create a Center that would care for the parents of others in a dignified and compassionate manner. His vision, dedication and leadership through the years have made the Gurwin name synonymous with excellence in caring for the elderly and those in need. He touched countless lives and will forever be remembered for helping to make his dream of "caring for those who cared for us" possible. Our Center will long stand as a legacy to our very special friend. We express heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Phyllis, his children Laura Flug, Eric and Karen Gurwin and his grandchildren Danielle, Jeffrey, Jason and Jaclyn, as well as the Pressman family. Lawrence Simon, Chairman Bert E. Brodsky, President Herbert H. Friedman, Exec VP

LAST week, my business partner, John Glenn, and I sat in my attic office, making last-second changes to how we placed arrows in a photograph of an archaeological discovery. Our book, ''If Stones Could Speak: Unlocking the Mysteries of Stonehenge,'' was bound to go to press the next day, and it was all because of a meeting in Memorial Park in Maplewood. About seven years ago, a few weeks after we moved to town, my wife, Marina Budhos, was pushing our then-2-year-old son in the swings at the park. Another mother, minding her own toddler, watched her intently.

THE NEWS Seeking to reclaim the health care debate, President Obama appeared on five morning TV talk shows on Sunday. BEHIND THE NEWS The interviews, taped the previous Friday, underscored Mr. Obama's decision to move forward on health care with -- or without -- Republicans. ''What I'm trying to do is explain the facts, which are if we don't do anything, a lot of Americans are going to be much worse off,'' he said. On Monday, he went on the ''Late Show'' with David Letterman, trading jokes but also discussing issues. He left with a heart-shaped potato, a gift from an audience member. ''This is remarkable,'' he said.

AS the automotive industry stimulus program known as cash for clunkers ramped up this past summer, enthusiasts worried that some much-loved cars would get caught in the clunkers net. Some fans of the Porsche 911 and Chevrolet Corvette feared that the program could mean the purging of their favorites. This week, a report in The Detroit Free Press uncovered some of the actual losses, and they're far more bizarre than even the nuttiest car nut had predicted. For one, according to data from the federal government, a 1997 Bentley Continental R, which sold new for around $250,000, was destroyed for the clunker credit of $3,500 or $4,500.

FORMAN--Irwin, of Tinton Falls, NJ, died September 23, 2009, one month after his 92nd birthday which he had celebrated with his wife, family members and friends and which he described as the "best birthday party since I was a kid." Irwin was the devoted and cherished husband of Lois Altman Forman for 52 years, and beloved father of Dr. Steven Forman of Pittsburgh and Craig Forman of Atlanta and San Francisco and adored grandfather of Lindsay, Gayle and Elliot Forman. Born in Lancaster, PA, Irwin served in the US Army during WWII in the Pacific and again in the Korean War and was a decorated Captain. After graduation from Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster, he worked with his father, Louis Forman, a civil engineer. He met his wife at McGraw-Hill where both were editors, and they lived in New York City, Monmouth County, NJ and West Palm Beach, FL. Irwin is survived by his wife, his sons, their wives Lynn and Cecile, and his two sisters Julia Welber of York, PA and Florence Bellack of Lancaster. A memorial service was held at Seabrook Village in Tinton Falls. Contributions in Irwin's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or to a charity of your choice.
SHAPIRO--Elsie. September 27, 1992 Remembered always with love.

Technology has transformed communications, increased the efficiency of retailing and helped elect a president. But because education is largely protected from incentives and consequences, it lags in embracing technology. That must and will change. At a New York City pilot program, School of One, for example, each student has a daily ''playlist'' tailored to their instructional level, interests and learning style. The school blends online learning, small group sessions and tutoring. It's a vivid picture of the shift from age cohorts slogging through a textbook to personalized digital learning.
The new rock album from the rapper Lil Wayne, ''Rebirth,'' is being released by Cash Money, not No Limit.

GURWIN--Joseph. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the passing of Joseph Gurwin of New York and Palm Beach, FL, a visionary in Jewish philanthropy and one of the giants of the American Jewish community. His exemplary character and devotion to the ATS and the Technion have been a source of inspiration and the basis of dramatic scientific achievement. One of the most generous ATS supporters, Mr. Gurwin was a member of our National and New York Metropolitan Region Boards. A Technion Guardian, he achieved the highest level of commitment. Mr. Gurwin's immense vision and readiness to invest in Israeli science enabled the Aerospace Engineering Faculty to become one of only 10 universities worldwide that build and launch their own satellites. He funded the Gurwin TechSat II, which remains in orbit after 10 years. Mr. Gurwin also provided support for the New York Metropolitan Region Nanomaterials Complex, an organic chemistry complex, and funds for several Palm Beach Chapter graduate fellowships and dormitories, among other Technion projects. Together with his family, he established the Phyllis and Joseph Gurwin Fund for Scientific Advancement that helps transform promising research into technologies that improve human life. Mr. Gurwin was honored by the Technion for his longtime support with an honorary fellowship and honorary doctorate. The ATS awarded him the Albert Einstein Award, the organization's highest honor. A revered New York humanitarian, Mr. Gurwin was named Long Island Philanthropist of the Year in 1991. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Phyllis; to Dr. Eric Gurwin and Laura Flug, his children with his late wife Rosalind; and the entire Gurwin family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen A. Laser, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Alan Forman, NY Metropolitan Region President Nancy Gad-Harf, NY Metropolitan Region Director
Theater Ben Brantley

Discredit the bachelor's degree as a job credential. It does not signify the acquisition of a liberal education. It does not even tell an employer that the graduate can put together a logical and syntactically correct argument. It serves as rough and unreliable evidence of a degree of intelligence and perseverance -- that's it. Yet across much of the job market, young people can't get their foot in the door without that magic piece of paper. As President Obama promotes community colleges, he could transform the national conversation about higher education if he acknowledges the B.A. has become meaningless. Then perhaps three reforms can begin: community colleges and their online counterparts will become places to teach and learn without any reference to the bachelor's degree; the status associated with the bachelor's degree will be lessened; and colleges will be forced to demonstrate just what their expensive four-year undergraduate programs do better, not in theory but in practice.

An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

It has been a forgettable season for Chipper Jones, the Braves' third baseman and potential Hall of Famer. Jones, a career .308 hitter, is certain to post a batting average below .300 for just the fifth time in 15 full seasons. It comes a year after he hit a career-high .364 that led the majors. Although Jones has had some lingering injury issues, he said last week that they were not the cause of what is a poor season for him: a .271 batting average with 17 home runs and 69 runs batted in.

HOVNANIAN--Kevork S.,founder and Chairman of the Board of one of the nation's largest homebuilders, died on September 24, at age 86. Mr. Hovnanian's story began when his Christian Armenian family fled the Middle East during a revolution which saw his successful road building company nationalized. Arriving unharmed but penniless in the United States, Mr. Hovnanian put his experience to work. With his three brothers, he founded the company that eventually became Hovnanian Enterprises. While his brothers eventually left to start their own successful businesses, Hovnanian Enterprises went on to become a NYSE, Fortune 500 Company. As he realized his American Dream, Mr. Hovnanian helped hundreds of thousands of families across the country realize their dream of home ownership. His accomplishments have led to an array of honors, including Harvard University's Dively Award for Leadership in Corporate Public Initiatives because of his company's successful inner-city community in Newark, The Rutgers University "25 top New Jersey Business leaders of the Century", top ranking performance on Forbes Platinum list and the Fortune 500 list, the National Quality Housing Award by the National Association of Homebuilders, and the Man of the Year by the New Jersey Council for Christians and Jews as well as by the Diocese of the Armenian Church of America in recognition for his assistance to earthquake victims in Armenia. For his contributions to the American society, Mr. Kevork Hovnanian was awarded with the Ellis Island Medal of Honor in 1993. Mr. Hovnanian's philanthropic efforts include establishing the K. Hovnanian Children's Hospital at Jersey Shore University Medical Center, the Emergency Care Center at Riverview Hospital and the new Cardiology Floor at the New York Presbyterian Hospital in New York City which is currently under construction. He also generously supported Armenian causes, including the construction of St. Stepanos Armenian Church in Elberon, NJ in memory of his mother. Furthermore, he built housing for earthquake victims in Armenia, and donated a townhouse for the Armenian Mission to the United Nations in New York City. He also rebuilt the famous Gevorgian Lyceum at the Holy See Etchmiadzin which remained closed during the Soviet era. He served as Co-Chair for the Fund for Armenian Relief for almost two decades and as Honorary Chair until his death. The complete list of his American and Armenian philanthropic endeavors is vast. Mr. Hovnanian is survived by his wife of over 60 years, Sirwart (Emily), five children and 13 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 3rd at Saint Vartan Armenian Cathedral at 630 Second Avenue New York, NY tentatively scheduled at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Fund for Armenian Relief 630 Second Avenue New York, NY 10016-4806 or Saint Stepanos Armenian Church Endowment Trust Fund 1184 Ocean Avenue Elberon, NJ 07740.

He was also a specialist on the NY Stock Exchange and a partner of Sprague & Nammack and later a partner of Murphy, Marcelles, Smith and Nammack. Jumbo was a member of the Westhampton country club, the Coral Beach and Tennis club of Paget Bermuda and a longtime member and past president of the Garden City golf club. Mass of Christian burial on Wednesday, September 30, at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City. Services handled by Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, Garden City, 516-746-0585.

STATES have taken the lead in adopting laws to protect consumers from some of the problem loans that helped trigger the home foreclosure crisis, but the federal government is now stepping up its efforts. On Oct. 1, new rules adopted by the Federal Reserve will go into effect, requiring greater diligence on the part of mortgage lenders and brokers who make so-called high cost loans for borrowers with weak credit. The interest rates on these loans are at least 1.5 percentage points higher than the average prime mortgage rate.

To appraise a one-bedroom one-bath co-op on the Upper East Side near Second Avenue, the appraisal firm Miller Samuel initially found 12 similar properties that had sold recently. They all were within about 10 blocks of the appraisal apartment; all were in postwar high-rise doorman buildings with similar views and similar building amenities. The features of each comparable apartment were reviewed, and adjustments were made for differences between the comparable and the apartment being appraised. For example, when a comparable had an amenity that the appraisal apartment lacked --say a renovated kitchen -- a dollar amount was subtracted from the comp's sale price, to make it more similar. And when the comparable didn't have something that the appraisal did -- say it was on a lower floor -- a dollar value was added to the comparable, again to make the two places more alike.

The latest approximate valuation of Twitter, the microblogging service that allows its users to transmit messages of up to 140 characters. Never mind that Twitter, with about 60 employees, has no discernible revenue. This is about the future. Now midway into its fourth year, Twitter is attracting an estimated 54 million visitors a month, and, along with Facebook, has remade the Web as a forum for sharing everything from street-level reports of revolt in Tehran to the most trivial tidbits of people's lives.

Lord Byron’s saucy letters to a clergyman, which include details of an affair with a servant girl and a reference to William Wordsworth as “Turdsworth” are set to be auctioned by Sotheby’s on Oct. 29 in London. The letters, to Byron’s close friend Francis Hodgson, are considered to be the most important series of the poet’s letters to come to market in more than 30 years. They include Byron’s comment that the Portuguese had “few vices except lies and sodomy,” and a swipe at his poet rivals Wordsworth and Robert Southey as “renegade rascals.” The letters, some of which are unpublished, were purchased in 1885 by a former prime minister, Archibald Primrose, the Earl of Rosebery, and have remained in his family. Gabriel Heaton, a Sotheby specialist in English literary and historical manuscripts, told the The Guardian of London: “Byron clearly enjoyed writing slightly outrageous things to a clergyman, but you also get a very strong sense of the depth of friendship they had. There’s real intimacy. “

An art exhibition with images of prominent African-Americans that was deemed offensive by many critics when it was presented in 1992 at the Leo Castelli gallery in New York, is being recreated as part of a major show opening Thursday at the Tate Modern in London. In 1992, the provocative “Red, Black, Green, Red, White and Blue,” by Rob Pruitt and Jack Early, consisted of store-bought posters of figures including the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Michael Jordan, Queen Latifah and others, accompanied by music in a room covered in gold foil and splattered with paint. Michael Kimmelman of The New York Times called the exhibition “at the least muddled and at the worst degrading.”

Has Darrell Hammond left NBC’s “Saturday Night Live”? Mr. Hammond’s status has not been officially disclosed, but this weekend, for the first time since the 1995 season, his name was not included in the opening credits. That might seem definitive, but Mr. Hammond has already appeared twice on this season’s special Thursday editions of “S.N.L.” And no sketches on Saturday involved any of the many impressions the show has relied on Mr. Hammond to provide, like Bill Clinton or John McCain. NBC executives and “S.N.L.” staff members declined to comment. One longtime staff member of “S.N.L.,” speaking on condition of anonymity because of the official no-comment position, said that Mr. Hammond’s absence meant he was no longer a regular but that he remained on good terms with the producers and would be available to perform characters as needed.

Austin ain't quite what it used to be, and in his story in our current fall travel issue, the novelist and Austin resident Jim Lewis considers what's been gained and lost. Lewis first encountered the Texas capital in the mid-1980s. For those of us who require cultural mile markers, that's between 1976 (the year in which Richard Linklater set "Dazed and Confused") and 1987 (when the South by Southwest music festival was inaugurated). We asked Lewis to come up with three addresses that still convey the feel of that old Austin, a place where, he writes, "fashion meant jeans, interior design meant the nearest Goodwill, transportation meant a $500 beater." This is what he rustled up.

A few seasons back, painting may have been all the rage, but suddenly drawing has never looked more fashionable -- at least drawing as seen through the eyes of the German artist Robert Knoke. Working from photographs, Knoke creates intense ink portraits using a combination of ballpoint pen and the fat markers favored by graffiti artists. There is something stern and almost sinister in his portrayals of everyone from Bret Easton Ellis and Patti Smith to Rick Owens and Lawrence Weiner who tend to stand resolutely on the edge of the page, staring suspiciously out of the corner of one eye. But according to Knoke, who grew up in Hanover but now shuttles between the art and fashion capitals of Paris, New York and Berlin, the portraits are really more about the artist than the subject. The Moment recently caught up with Knoke, who comes across as anything but sinister.

Updated (below) | 6:07 p.m. In the immediate aftermath of the devastation caused by Tropical Storm Ketsana, which hit the Philippines in force on Saturday, the country's government blamed victims for not heeding its warnings and suggested that its disaster relief efforts were not as bad as those of the American government during Hurricane Katrina. Yam Yam fuels Berlin's fashion community with fresh Korean comfort food in a canteen-style setting that was once a hub for Berlin fashion itself. During its five-year lifetime, the Best Shop lived up to its name, showcasing designers from Berlin and Scandinavia such as Wood Wood, Ann-Sofie Back and Henrik Vibskov. But after a season rocked by the recession, the proprietor, Sumi Ha, feared that fashion had become too fragile and decided to return to her first love: food.She scouted for locations to house a Korean restaurant, but nothing was right - until she realized the best location was under her nose, in her store on the fashionable Alte Schönhauser. Within a month, Yam Yam had become a lunch and meeting spot for her former shoppers, Berlin's designers, editors and art folk.

Formula One: Hamilton Wins in SingaporeStarting from pole, McLaren's Lewis Hamilton kept at bay a Singapore Grand Prix field rife with accidents and position changes. Hamilton saw few challenges in a lead that extended to 9.6 seconds over second-place finisher, Toyota's Timo Glock. Glock gave Toyota a repeat of its best Formula One finish. Finishing third, Renault's Fernando Alonso brought some good news to the scandal-dogged Renault team, as well as its first podium finish this season. (The New York Times)

It wasn't so long ago when, thanks to "Sex and the City," a quartet of over-accessorized Manhattanites stood metonymically for New York City. For those without premium cable, it was the sextet of "Friends" that transmitted Western (Village) aesthetics of upward mobility. Brooklyn then was nothing but a distant punch line, a borough relegated to "The Cosby Show" and Cosby sweaters. But if Jonathan Ames's new HBO series, drolly titled "Bored to Death," heralds a new era of New York in television and in the nation's imagination, it's now the era of downtown Brooklyn - or, at least, of Park Slope, Boerum Hill and Fort Greene. A quick update from the land of Apple: The company announced on Monday another set of remarkable numbers for the app store for the iPhone and iPod Touch. Customers have downloaded more than two billion apps in the last year and a half, up from a billion in April and a billion and a half in July. Apple says there are now 85,000 apps available for the phone, up from 65,000 in July.

At the London Design Festival, the writer and curator Max Fraser has organized three exhibitions to publicize his brand-new "London Design Guide." Each exhibition is thematically linked to one of what his book describes as the city's design tribes: the New Modernists are shown at Viaduct; the Escapists at the design store Mint; and the Revivalists at the Contemporary Applied Arts gallery. They're all interesting shows, but it's that last one that caught my eye, because everywhere you look this week, historical references abound, particularly among young designers.

Most people think of London fashion as crazy and conceptual - which is usually a fair assessment when it comes to women's wear. But let's not forget that London is also ground zero for classic men's tailoring. In the fall men's issue of T, we profiled Patrick Grant, who heads Norton & Sons and is the youngest "guv'nor" on Savile Row. Grant is also reviving E. Tautz, a more accessible yet long-forgotten English label; he got things going with a video presentation a few days ago during London fashion week. We think he's off to a great start - what do you think?

After his tweets kicked up a bit of a ruckus, according to The Post's ombudsman, Andrew Alexander, Mr. Narisetti shut down his Twitter account and The Washington Post issued new guidelines for its employees when they step into the social media fracas.
