A restaurant owner, squeezed by a slump in sales and growing debt to his landlord, discontinues his health insurance. A contractor decides not to replace a member of his small crew who quit. An industrial bicycle maker starts selling to universities, prisons and zoos. For a quintet of small businesses that The New York Times has been tracking for the past year, the persistent recession has hurt some more than others. As fall began, some cautious optimism about a recovery crept into recent interviews conducted by Patrick McGeehan, Erik Olsen and Gabriel Johnson. Georgette Blau

PARAMORE ''Brand New Eyes'' (Fueled by Ramen) Now that Hayley Williams is nearly 21, and her band, Paramore, has sold more than a million copies of its 2007 album, ''Riot!,'' romance isn't her main predicament. For Paramore's third studio album, ''Brand New Eyes,'' she and the guitarist Josh Farro also wrote songs about ambitions, wrecked friendships, the disillusionment of celebrity and the tensions that threatened to tear apart the band last year. In ''Looking Up,'' she sings ''I can't believe we almost hung it up.''

GURWIN--Joseph. To our dearest Dad/Papa Joe, we will never forget all the wonderful qualities you shared with us. We will miss your zest for life, the sparkle in your eye, your appreciation for all things beautiful, your wise counsel, your honesty and integrity, your strength and stoicism, your wonderfully expressive face. While so many in the world benefited from your generosity, we had the rare privilege of knowing and loving you as a person who played an indescribably important role in all of our lives. To say we will miss you misses the point, as you will always be with us in our hearts and souls. All our love, Laura, Danielle, Eric, Karen, Jeffrey, Jason and Jaclyn

MIRANDA LAMBERT ''Revolution'' (Columbia Nashville) Miranda Lambert has made her name in Nashville as a certain kind of hell-raiser: volatile, irrepressible, out for blood. On her first two albums, ''Kerosene'' and ''Crazy Ex-Girlfriend,'' she was always at her best summoning the wrath of a woman scorned. So the big news behind ''Revolution'' is the breadth of its emotional experience; it might have been more truthfully titled without the ''R.'' Ms. Lambert, still fearsome but no longer frenzied, sounds well beyond her 25 years and even further from her younger self.

William Safire, whose column appeared on this page for 33 years, often on Mondays, died on Sunday after a battle with pancreatic cancer. He was 79. What follows is one of the columns he wrote on his retirement from the Op-Ed page of The Times on Jan. 24, 2005.

Anita Renfroe is the comedian whose rapid-fire video chant of everything a mother says to her child in a day, sung to the ''William Tell Overture,'' made her an Internet sensation. Her latest book, ''Don't Say I Didn't Warn You,'' about middle age and motherhood, will be released on Tuesday. The book will be breaking into a category thick with cross-pollination, with ''I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell,'' which has been made into a movie, and two titles generated from existing humor Web sites: ''I Can Has Cheezburger?'' and ''The Truth About Chuck Norris.'' Crisscrossing the country, hundreds of thousands of long-haul truckers use computers in their cabs to get directions and stay in close contact with dispatchers, saving precious minutes that might otherwise be spent at the side of the road. The trucking industry says these devices can be used safely, posing less of a distraction than BlackBerrys, iPhones and similar gadgets, and therefore should be exempted from legislation that would ban texting while driving.

It also doesn't cause auto accidents, but they happen. DR. JAY C. BUTLER, of the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, on people's fears about being vaccinated. [A14]

TOPKIS--Gladys Susman, of New York City, died August 25, 2009, of heart failure. She was 81. Born in Brookline, MA, Ms. Topkis was granted a full scholarship to Radcliffe College, from which she graduated magna cum laude in 1948. After moving to New York, she soon began making a name for herself in the field of scholarly publishing, working in the editorial departments of houses such as Praeger Publishers, Free Press, and John Wiley & Sons. In 1978, she began teaching at the University of Denver's Publishing Institute, and continued to teach there, every summer and with enormous pleasure, for the next 30 years. In 1981 she became senior editor at Yale University Press, where she specialized in books on sociology, psychology, and psychoanalysis, many of which went on to win prestigious awards. When she left Yale, in 1998, her departure was marked with a festschrift featuring original papers written for the occasion by a number of internationally prominent psychoanalysts. Though technically retired, she continued to work on a freelance basis, and also acted as the Editorial Director of Felony & Mayhem Press, a small mystery-fiction imprint. She is survived by her daughter, Maggie Topkis, of New York City; by the more than 3,000 students whom she guided towards (or away from) careers in publishing; and by the hundreds of books she edited, all of which would have been much the poorer without her. In lieu of flowers, friends and colleagues are invited to make donations in her name to the Memorial Giving department of the Metropolitan Opera. A memorial service is planned for early November. For more details please email mst@felonyandmayhem.com.

Accounts Mars, McLean, Va., consolidated creative assignments for several brands so that the work for each would be handled globally by a single agency. BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, becomes the global creative agency for the Mars and Snickers brands. The changes include the shift of Snickers in the United States to BBDO from TBWA/Chiat/Day, New York, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom, and the shift of Mars in Australia to BBDO from Sapient Nitro, part of the Sapient Corporation. TBWA becomes the global creative agency for Whiskas; the changes include the shift of creative assignments in Latin America to TBWA from BBDO. And Sapient Nitro becomes the global creative agency for the Dove brand; the changes include the shift of some Dove assignments to Sapitent Nitro from TBWA.

MALONEY--Clifton H.W. The Board of Directors and staff of New York Foundation for Senior Citizens deeply mourn the passing of our outstanding Board Member and dear friend Clif Maloney and express our sympathy to his wife, Carolyn, daughters, Cristina and Virginia, his mother, Mrs. Paul Maloney and sister, Ginger. A wise and genuinely caring gentleman of exemplary integrity, Clif's invaluable expertise and support has helped the Foundation develop senior citizen housing and social service programs for three decades. He was a true friend to so many and will be greatly missed.

The day before he was arrested Thursday on charges of plotting to blow up the federal building in Springfield, Michael C. Finton was working as a fry cook at Seals Fish & Chicken in this old factory town deep in the Illinois cornfields. Tall and red-haired, Mr. Finton, 29, was known among co-workers as cheerful and polite, but unwavering when it came to religion and politics. He was especially critical of what he regarded as permissive society.

PITTARELLI--Ernest, Husband, Mentor, COO of Sailfish Capital Partners, and former head of UBS operations for the Americas, dies at 55 years of age. After a valiant eighteen-month battle with a rare form of leukemia, including two bone marrow transplants, Ernest "Ernie" Pittarelli of Fairfield, Connecticut died September 24, 2009 at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City after a two and half month stay surrounded by family and friends. He was born November 2, 1953, in Brooklyn, NY, the son of Rose Pittarelli and the late Carmine Pittarelli. He was the youngest of two siblings. He married Virginia (Ginny) D'Elia on February 21, 1981, who survives. In 2005, Ernie left retirement to join Sal Naro at Sailfish Capital Partners, as Chief Operating Officer. A recognized leader in hedge fund operations, he helped the firm grow to over $4.5b in assets. When the decision was made to wind down Sailfish, Ernie continued to direct operational matters and enabled the firm to exit the marketplace in a responsible manner, ultimately returning 98% of investor assets. Prior to Sailfish, he served in leadership at UBS for 21 years, most recently as Head of all U.S. Operations, including banking and securities related processing and settlement activities for the organization in North and South America. At UBS Ernie played a pivotal role in product development and several acquisitions and mergers, including the UBS/SBC and Paine Webber mergers. Ernie also committed a significant amount of time to the development of the financial markets, by working closely with the Securities Industry Association, Bond Market Association, The Federal Reserve and the New York Stock Exchange. Prior to UBS, Ernie spent nine years at AG Becker, where he held a number of management roles, including the support of its clearing businesses. Ernie was a member of the Fairfield University Advisory Board and an honorary member of the BETA GAMA SIGMA Honor Society. Ernie graduated from Pace University in 1977. "Ernie was my unwavering friend, mentor and partner for more than eleven years," said Sal Naro. "His loyalty, generosity of spirit and courage will forever be an inspiration to me and the many others he touched during his lifetime. I will miss him every day of my life." Calling hours will be held Tuesday, September 29, 2009 from 4pm to 9pm at Lesko & Polke Funeral Home, 1209 Post Road, in Fairfield Center. His Funeral Mass will take place on Wednesday, September 30th, at 11am directly in Assumption Church, 98 Riverside Avenue, Westport, Connecticut. Entombment will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations in memory of Ernest Pittarelli to: American Society of Hematology, 1900 M Street NW, Suite 200, Washington, DC 20036. Please make checks payable to: America Society of Hematology or Tisch Cancer Institute for Leukemia Research, 1 Gustav L Levy Place, P.O. Box 1049, New York, NY 10029. Please make checks payable to: Mount Sinai School of Medicine. For more information or to sign an online register, please visit www.LeskoPolkeFuneral- Home.com.

GURWIN--Joseph. With profound sadness the Board of Directors, Administration, Staff and Residents of the Gurwin Jewish Nursing & Rehabilitation Center mourn the loss of our esteemed founding President and benefactor, Joseph Gurwin. Joe was an inspiring, kind and generous gentleman, whose dedication to philanthropy brought lasting joy and an enhanced quality of life to countless people throughout the United States and around the globe. Because of his inability to bring his parents to the United States before they perished in the Holocaust, Joe and his late wife Rosalind took the opportunity to help create a Center that would care for the parents of others in a dignified and compassionate manner. His vision, dedication and leadership through the years have made the Gurwin name synonymous with excellence in caring for the elderly and those in need. He touched countless lives and will forever be remembered for helping to make his dream of "caring for those who cared for us" possible. Our Center will long stand as a legacy to our very special friend. We express heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Phyllis, his children Laura Flug, Eric and Karen Gurwin and his grandchildren Danielle, Jeffrey, Jason and Jaclyn, as well as the Pressman family. Lawrence Simon, Chairman Bert E. Brodsky, President Herbert H. Friedman, Exec VP

Democrats proposing an overhaul of the American health care system have gotten themselves locked in a box around the question of affordability. This is not the question of whether the proposed health care legislation is affordable for taxpayers and the federal government -- an issue that seemed to be answered when the Congressional Budget Office said the Senate Finance Committee's bill would eventually help reduce federal budget deficits.

If it seems unusual for the Jets and the Giants to be 3-0 in the same season, it's because it is. In the teams' 50-year history of coexistence, the Giants and the Jets have started 3-0 in the same season only one other time. That was in 2000, when Jim Fassel (Giants) and Al Groh (Jets) roamed the sidelines as the head coaches.

You've got to hand it to AT&T. They don't like Julius Genachowski's plan to apply network neutrality rules to wireless networks, and they aren't shy about saying so. Not so for Verizon and Sprint, which declined to answer a direct question about whether they think wireless systems should be covered by net neutrality rules.

The Kremlin has long responded to proposals for tougher sanctions against Iran with arms folded and a scowl. Last week, that attitude began softening, bringing the Obama administration closer to a diplomatic coup in its efforts to contain the Iranian nuclear program. But the relatively conciliatory statements by Russia's president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, present an opening to the administration that could turn out to yield little. Russia, a neighbor of Iran, is far more intertwined with it geopolitically than any other world power, and has more concerns about upsetting relations.

There are just some things in life that are better with a visual accompaniment, like business presentations, cooking classes and a film theory seminar. According to Rey Flemings, chief executive of Particle, status updates posted to Twitter and Facebook should be included on that list. His San Francisco company created a service called Robo.to that allows users to publish four-second videos that act as visual status updates.

David Ortiz was pulling on his socks at his locker when someone briefly turned off the row of lights above him in the Red Sox clubhouse. Distracted, Ortiz glanced up and made a mischievous face. ''Hey, Yankees,'' he said, ''pay the bills.''

And no matter how grimy her surroundings became -- Ol' Dirty Bastard, anyone? -- she remained inexorably Mariah, an impenetrable acrobat of technique.

The skirmish between Apple and Palm over whether owners of Palm devices can sync them up with their iTunes libraries has come to something of a resolution -- though maybe not the one Palm had hoped for. This summer, Palm filed a complaint with the USB Implementers Forum, an industry group that oversees standards for U.S.B. connections, claiming that Apple was restraining trade by allowing only Apple devices to have access to iTunes, its popular media management software.

It is every opera performer’s nightmare, and it happened to David Ott, a conductor, on Friday night: he fell into the pit. Mr. Ott had just finished leading a performance of a work he had composed, “The Widow’s Lantern,” with the Pensacola Opera at the University of West Florida. He went back on stage in the darkness to pick up his score, The Pensacola News Journal reported on its Web site, pnj.com. He said he stepped onto what he thought was the floor of the raised pit, which can move up and down, “and there was nothing there,” the site quoted him as saying. He fell 14 feet and broke nine vertebrae and dislocated his shoulder. “All I could think was that I was falling into hell,” he told the newspaper. “I was so glad when I hit because it finally stopped.” He was taken to the hospital but is hoping to conduct further performances Thursday and Friday, The News Journal said.

Conan O’Brien was joking sardonically on Monday night about the head injury he sustained during a Friday taping of “The Tonight Show,” but the footage of the incident is more frightening than laugh-out-loud funny.
Less than three months after resigning as governor of Alaska, Sarah Palin, the onetime vice presidential candidate, has completed her memoir.

A longstanding lawsuit involving royalties for the characters of Winnie the Pooh and his lovable, lucrative friends from the Hundred Acre Wood was dismissed by a United States district court in Los Angeles, Reuters reported. In a legal dispute that dates back to 1991, the estate of Stephen Slesinger, the producer who first acquired licensing rights to the Pooh works and characters from A. A. Milne in 1930, was suing for more than $700 million in royalties it says it was owed by the Walt Disney Company, which acquired the rights from Stephen Slesinger Inc. in 1961. When lower courts threw out that case following the misconduct of a private investigator, Slesinger’s heirs filed a copyright infringement suit against Disney. On Friday, Judge Florence-Marie Cooper ruled that Stephen Slesinger Inc. “transferred all of its rights in the Pooh works to Disney, and may not now claim infringement of any retained rights.” A Disney spokeswoman told Reuters that Stephen Slesinger Inc. still has a claim against Disney pending before U.S. patent regulators.

The troubled Skylight Opera Theater in Milwaukee has announced that it has a new managing director. She is Amy S. Jensen, who served as the finance director there from 1995 to 2001. Ms. Jensen comes from the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, where she has been a vice president and the chief financial officer. The theater’s financial woes led the previous managing director, Eric Dillner, to cut the staff, causing an uproar among many supporters, which eventually led to his resignation in August.

Facing a crop of freshly raised umbrellas from a stage in Bryant Park on Monday evening, Jeff Spurgeon, a WQXR-FM radio personality, praised the audience members for their tenacity. “In Chicago they’d have fled,” Mr. Spurgeon told what appeared to be several dozen hardy souls assembled for a performance by the St. Luke’s Chamber Ensemble. “In Milwaukee they’d be sitting there crying.” The occasion was the opening event of the Bryant Park Fall Festival, a series of free weeknight performances on the park’s upper terrace, meant to give institutions like the Metropolitan Opera, the Joyce Theater and Jazz at Lincoln Center a chance to showcase their coming attractions, rain or shine.

The New York medical examiner’s office ruled on Tuesday that the disc jockey Adam Goldstein, better known by his stage name, DJ AM, died from an accidental overdose of prescription drugs and cocaine, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Goldstein, a fixture of the Los Angeles club scene and the celebrity party circuit, was found dead in his Manhattan apartment on Aug. 28. At that time, police discovered him face-down in his bed wearing only sweatpants, with a crack pipe and prescription drugs nearby. The medical examiner’s toxicology report said that Mr. Goldstein had ingested OxyContin, Hydrocodone or Vicodin, Xanax, Ativan, Klonopin, Benadryl and Levamisole before his death, according to The A.P. Mr. Goldstein had said in interviews in recent years that he abused cocaine and crack in his 20s but had since cleaned up, and recently taped a reality series for MTV called “Gone Too Far,” in which he helped set up interventions for drug abusers. MTV has not yet said whether it will broadcast the series.
TLC is renaming “Jon & Kate Plus 8” and diminishing the father Jon Gosselin’s role on the rocky family reality show.

While the merry bells will keep ringing for the musical “Irving Berlin’s White Christmas,” the show will ring in a new cast when it returns to Broadway later this year. Press representatives for the musical, which is adapted from the 1954 “White Christmas” film with even more Berlin tunes, said on Tuesday that its principal cast would feature James Clow (of “Assassins” and “Wonderful Town”) in the Bing Crosby role; Melissa Errico (“Amour”) in the Rosemary Clooney role and Tony Yazbeck (“Gypsy”) in the Danny Kaye role. The Broadway cast will also include Mara Davi (“A Chorus Line”) in the Vera Ellen role, as well as Ruth Williamson, Peter Reardon, Remy Auberjonois, Cliff Bemis, Madeleine Yen and David Ogden Stiers. This latest Broadway run of “White Christmas,” which is directed by Walter Bobbie, will begin previews at the Marquis Theater on Nov. 13. Its limited run concludes after Jan. 3.

Update | 3:54 p.m. The conductor James Levine will undergo surgery for a herniated disk in the next few days, forcing him to cancel his performance with the Boston Symphony Orchestra on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall’s season-opening gala.

Fans of time travel and ravenous prehistoric creatures, rejoice: BBC America announced on Tuesday that “Primeval,” the popular but expensive British science-fiction television series that was canceled this summer after the end of its third season, has been saved from extinction. Reflecting the current economics of television production, the 13 new episodes, scheduled for release in 2011, will be a joint venture of ITV, the show’s British network; BBC Worldwide, which exports the show to other countries; and the production company Impossible Possible Limited, along with several other financial partners. The announcement also said that the show runner, Adrian Hodges, would return along with the cast members Hannah Spearritt, Andrew Lee Potts and Jason Flemyng, who replaced the original star, Douglas Henshall, during the third season. In the United States, “Primeval” has been one of BBC America’s top-rated dramas.

Stop us if you’ve heard this one before: a newly announced Broadway show will tell the story of shady businessmen who convinced investors to buy into an ultimately worthless product. No, it’s not a revival of “The Producers” — it’s “Enron,” the acclaimed British play about that notorious energy company and the 2001 financial scandal that engulfed it. The play, written by Lucy Prebble (creator of the television series “Secret Diary of a Call Girl”), will open on Broadway in April at a Shubert Theater to be determined, its press representatives said in a news release. The British production, which featured Samuel West as Jeffrey K. Skilling and Tim Pigott-Smith as Kenneth L. Lay, opened this summer at the Minerva Theater in Chichester and moved to the Royal Court Theater; it is slated to transfer to the Noel Coward Theater in the West End in January. The Broadway transfer will be directed by Rupert Goold (who directed Patrick Stewart in “Macbeth”), but no casting has yet been announced. “Enron” will be produced on Broadway by Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel, Matthew Byam Shaw, Act Productions, Caro Newling for Neal St. Productions and the Shubert Organization.

West 45th Street in Manhattan, the Broadway artery where “A Steady Rain” (which opens tonight) with Hugh Jackman and Daniel Craig is playing next to “God of Carnage” with James Gandolfini, Hope Davis, Jeff Daniels and Marcia Gay Harden, is a big draw for the starstruck these days. Cellphone cameras at the ready, crowds wait nightly for a glimpse of the actors leaving after the final curtain call.

It turns out that if you put two stars of some of Hollywood’s highest grossing movies in a Broadway play together, that production will also make a lot of money. On Tuesday, the producers of the play “A Steady Rain,” which stars Hugh Jackman and Daniel Craig, said that the show had broken the record for the highest weekly gross of a non-musical production on Broadway. In a news release, press representatives for “A Steady Rain” said that the play posted a weekly gross of $1,167,954 for the week ending Sept. 20. (This sum was also a house record at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater.) The record for non-musical productions on Broadway was previously held by the Billy Crystal show “700 Sundays,” which grossed $1,061,688 for the week ending May 22, 2005. “A Steady Rain,” which is written by Keith Huff and directed by John Crowley opens on Tuesday night and is slated to run through Dec. 6.

In a bid to save money and to reorganize, the Smithsonian Institution has offered all of its 6,000 workers a voluntary buyout plan, a spokeswoman for the Smithsonian confirmed on Tuesday. The details of the buyout offer, reported Tuesday in The Washington Post, went out Monday in an email, Linda St. Thomas, the spokeswoman, said. “Almost all federal agencies do it,” she said. “It’s quite common. You do it so people can voluntarily leave if they’re near retirement age.”

Having planted the first vegetable garden at the White House in over 60 years, Michelle Obama will take her green thumb to another familiar (if fictitious) address: Sesame Street. In November, Mrs. Obama will appear on the season premiere of “Sesame Street” to teach the puppet and human residents of that children’s show about the benefits of planting a garden and healthful eating, Sesame Workshop said Tuesday in a news release.

Mary Delany, the English aristocrat who could charm the birds from the trees, is the subject of an engaging new show - "Mary Delany and Her Circle" - at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven. During the course of her long, satisfying life (1700-88), this doyenne of the domestic befriended poets and philosophers (Edmund Burke called her "a woman of fashion for all ages"); excelled at gardening, painting and all manner of craft (from embroidery to japanning); wrote hundreds of letters detailing the mores of her class; and was a loyal and trusted friend of the royal family.

In the 1971 essay, "Overpopulation and the Potential for Ecocide," Dr. Holdren and his co-author, the ecologist Paul Ehrlich, warned of a coming ice age.

Re: "He Works for The Times, Too" (Sept. 5) You can write all the columns you like to justify obvious conflicts of interest, but they are still there and they won't go away. When I was a young reporter on the state staff of The Providence Journal, staff members were not permitted to have any interests outside the paper or to write for any other local publication. That was the 1950s. Today is another matter, on The Journal and now, apparently, on The Times as well. There is no justification for it, and to write one is a phony exercise. The results are all too plain.The newspaper industry is on its way out. Newspapers are at or near the bottom of institutions in which the public has confidence. No one believes what they read, and consequently, fewer and fewer people are buying them.David Pogue's "expertise" is too valuable to be missed? Nonsense. If the Times wants to run a critique of this or that electronic gadget, it ought to be The Times's own appraisal, not the opinion of an outsider.JAMES K. SUNSHINEProvidence, R.I., Sept. 6, 2009The writer is a retired deputy executive editor at The Providence Journal. ● Criticism of David Pogue is misdirected. It should be directed at The New York Times for its policy of not distinguishing between staffers and freelancers. As a former Times freelance writer and photographer, my byline appeared as Pogue's does without any indication I wasn't a staffer.For my photos, however, the credit line was different from the ones for staff photographers.Ethics is a personal thing that every journalist espouses, or should. This doesn't mean, however, that the rules a company promulgates among its employees apply automatically to freelance contributors. Conflict-of-interest rules are usually meant to protect a company from criticism, not to prevent ethical lapses. Journalists go along with them because they are a condition of employment, not because they are needed. Nobody asks a freelancer who paid for lunch, unless you ask for reimbursement.ROBERT J. SALGADONew Hope, Pa., Sept. 6, 2009

After a period of hibernation, corporate mergers and acquisitions are back on the agenda, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column. A bar and concert venue, El Alamein hosts performances by bands and ensembles from the Nouvelle Scene Française -- New French Scene -- on a small stage nestled inside the péniche.

Laura Michelle Kelly, the West End’s original Mary Poppins, has found her way to Broadway in the Disney production of “Mary Poppins” running at the New Amsterdam Theater, Disney has announced. Ms. Kelly, left, who won an Olivier Award for her performance as the original Mary Poppins in the 2004 West End premiere of the show, starts Oct. 12 along with Christian Borle (“Legally Blonde” on Broadway), who plays Bert. They will be joined by some other new cast members: Jeff Binder (“The Lion King”) as Mr. Banks; Jenny Galloway, reprising her West End role as Mrs. Brill; and Michael McCarty as Admiral Boom, a role he created on Broadway.
